'The only available text for Macbeth is the one printed in the first edition of Shakespeare''s collected works, usually called the First Folio (1623, seven years after the playwright''s death). The editors of the Folio divided the play''s acts in scenes but did not provide place names for where each scene takes place. Later editors added the place names usually found in most editions of the play. I.1 is conventionally set in "a desert place" or some other strange landscape.

text:
'The witches speak in rhymed tetrameter couplets. Most Shakespearean verse is blank verse (unrhymed) and in pentameters. The witches'' speech is meant to be eccentric and spell-like, and its place at the very onset of the play highlights the supernatural tone of the entire work.

Unlike most Shakespearean verse, the witches'' couplets are not iambic (a rising rhythm between syllables going from unstressed to stressed, as in "to BE or NOT to BE"). They are trochaic, that is, each pair of syllables (or "foot") descends from stressed to unstressed ("FAIR is FOUL and FOUL is FAIR"). The four feet in the witches'' tetrameter should have eight syllables, but the lines often end with a stressed word, dropping the last unstressed syllable. The effect of contrast with the usual iambic pentameter is one of incomplete inversion, and incompleteness and reversal of a "natural" order are indeed the characteristics of this witch-dominated play. Another famous instance of trochaic tetrameter in Shakespeare (aside from songs) is the speech of the fairies in A Midsummer Nightâ€™s Dream.
'

text:
'    In Renaissance dramas such as Shakespeare’s, the term Chorus refers not to a group of singers, but rather to  a single person who provides background information about the events of the play.  The Chorus is not a character in the play—rather, the role is similar to that of a narrator.

    You may notice that the Prologue spoken by the Chorus comprises fourteen lines, and that these lines rhyme.  In fact, this fourteen-line speech is a specific type of poem popular in the Renaissance, called the sonnet.  In most cases, Renaissance poets used the sonnet as a love-poem.  Here, Shakespeare uses it simply to “lay the scene” for the play: to provide the setting (the Italian city of Verona), the major players in the action, and even to sketch out the play’s plot.  If you read the sonnet carefully, there won’t be too many surprises left in the play.

    Although I have no wish to spoil the play for you (you probably already know what happens, in any case), I’m going to give you a careful reading of this opening sonnet.  Why?  Well, in the introduction (which I hope you read), I promised to show you how I read Shakespeare, and I’m going to make good on that promise.  Step 1: Paraphrase.  First, I try to figure out what Shakespeare’s words mean—that is, I paraphrase the meaning of Shakespeare in my own words.  Here''s a brief paraphrase of the sonnet:

(Lines 1-4): In Verona, where the play takes place, two families are involved in a long-standing feud that is about to erupt with new violence ("From ancient grudge break to new mutiny").  (Lines 5-8) These families have children ("From forth the fatal loins of these two foes") who, despite the fact that their families are at war, become lovers and subsequently commit suicide ("take their life")—which causes their parents to make peace between their families ("Whose misadventured piteous overthrows / Doth with their death bury their parents'' strife").  (Note: Shakespeare has just told us the entire plot of the play.)  (Lines 9-14) (Just in case you didn''t get it the first time, Shakespeare wants to tell you again:) The play you''re about to see will present the story of the lovers and their feuding parents.

    Okay; that''s a bare-bones summary of the sonnet.  You should read through Shakespeare''s version and try to understand every word; but what I''ve written is a basic map of its meaning.  At this point, a word of caution: you''ve probably seen those attractive editions of Shakespeare that give you a "translation" of Shakespeare alongside the real deal.  You''ve probably also encountered Cliff-Notes, or Spark-Notes.  Don''t  be fooled: while these resources can be used AFTER you''ve read the play, they cannot be substituted for the real thing.  And to tell the truth, part of the experience of reading Shakespeare is figuring out the meaning for yourself.  But just as important is step (2): moving beyond the literal meaning—that is, once you know what they mean, looking at Shakespeare''s words and asking why and how: why he chose the words he did, and how they have a greater meaning in the context of the whole play.

    After the prologue, these questions get much more interesting.  But even in the prologue, there''s much to think about.  For instance: isn''t it odd that Shakespeare begins by telling us that the two warring families are similar?  "Alike in dignity" means "having the same social standing" (they''re both rich, wealthy families); but beyond that, Shakespeare doesn''t bother to identify how the two families are different.  Like the warring families in The Godfather, they don''t actually seem to be very different at all.  But unlike the mobsters, who have a reason to fight, these families don''t even have a motive for hating one another.  As we begin to read the play, we should bear in mind that the families are fighting a battle that has no real cause.

    One more item of interest.  Think about how Shakespeare chooses to tell you the feuding families have children: "From forth the fatal loins..."  Loins! -- you know that word!  It refers to the genital region, and whenever it''s used, it conjures up the idea of sex.  Shakespeare chooses to say "the families had children" in a way that draws our attention to sex.  The adjective "fatal," which modifies "loins," has two meanings, which together introduce two important, conflicting, themes in the play.  The first meaning is "relating to fate," while the second is "deadly."  If we consider the first meaning, "fatal loins" introduces the idea that the lovers are controlled, from their very birth, by an impersonal higher power—i.e., Fate; but if we take "fatal" to mean "deadly," then "fatal loins" gives us an  oxymoron (a combination of two contradictory ideas), since it suggests that the sexual organs of Romeo''s and Juliet''s parents, which should create life by producing a baby, are deadly, that is, capable of killing.  How can this oxymoron make sense?  Shakespeare implies that since the two families are so concerned with killing and violence, even their act of reproduction—which should renew life—is infected by their viciousness, and instead leads to death.  In other words, Romeo and Juliet are born to and brought up by families poisoned by the hatred of the feud they maintain, a hatred that will make it impossible for their love to exist and leads to their deaths.  "Fatal loins" can thus indicate either that the children (Romeo and Juliet) have no control over their lives but are instead ruled by an impersonal fate; or, instead, that it is the fault of their families, and not of Fate, that their love is doomed, and that they die.

    No one expects you to spend this much time thinking about every passage in the play; but as you read, you''ll want to choose certain passages that stand out to you and attempt the same kind of analysis I''ve just performed for the sonnet.  First, determine exactly what''s happening; and next, choose words and thoughts that strike you as intriguing, or that remind you of other parts of the play.  As your guide, I''ll be pointing out crucial themes and images and ideas in the play.  I''ll occasionally also direct your attention to particularly enjoyable (or raunchy, or violent, or funny) images.  After all, this is a play about growing up during a violent feud; in other words, its main subjects are sex and violence.  Especially in terms of sex, it can be as explicit as Hollywood has ever been.

    So let''s read!

'

'The opening of the play proper doesn’t seem to be too interesting, but a careful reading reveals a vulgar sexual subtext to the conversation.  While the exchange between the servants Sampson and Gregory seems to be about the feud between the family they serve (the Capulets, Juliet’s family) and its rival (the Montagues, Romeo’s family), they use a series of sexual puns [for examples, see below].  At the very opening of a play famous for a portrayal of pure, ideal, young love, Shakespeare presents two dirty-mouthed men whose see male-female relationships as a smutty joke.  To them, “love” is no more than sex; and sex turns out to be no more than a brutal rape.  How does such an opening make you react?  Keep it in mind as you read the rest of the play.

Note: the opening 20 lines offer a series of puns; to follow them, just pick up any paperback version of the play, and the footnotes will clue you in.

'

text: 'The final vulgar pun in this series of sordid remarks.  “Tool” can refer either to a sword—or, in slang, to a penis.   (Sampson continues the dirty joke when he says, in the next line, “My naked weapon is out”.) Gregory and Sampson have made their discussion of the feud a discussion of sex and sexual prowess.  In the first scene of the play, Shakespeare has thus associated violence and sex—both in subject-matter (rape) and in language (the puns, like "tool," that refer simultaneously to violence and to sex).'

text:
'In the 19th century, London had a reputation for being foggy and full of smog--think of Dickens novels or movies about Jack the Ripper. Londoners of the 16th and 17th centuries, however, thought of their city as an oasis of luxury and civilization on an otherwise backward island. There was a prejudice against northern England and an outright fear and loathing of Scotland, the neighboring kingdom which had been completely independent until 1603. The play was probably written less than five years after King James of Scotland had inherited the English throne and had traveled to London, but even the Scottish James and his own noblemen preferred the southern capital and considered Scotland almost barbaric. The world of Macbeth is dark in many senses: it''s the dark ages, in a dark country, with characters driven by dark motives.
'

text:
'    The opening scene has been brilliantly orchestrated to catch the attention of a theatrical audience: at first only two people appear on stage; then two more—and a fight begins.  And rapidly the number of people on stage increases, even as the battle grows more intense.  From the silence and inactivity that comes before the play begins, Shakespeare rapidly whips up a storm of action involving dozens of people.

    But the theatrical spectacle of violent disorder, which as a reader you must imagine for yourself, actually masks a very orderly symmetry in the scene: first two servants of the Capulets appear; then two servants of the Montagues; then Benvolio, a Montague nobleman, comes on stage; then Tybalt, a Capulet nobleman, stalks on stage; then Capulet and his wife appear; and then Montague and his wife appear.  For every Capulet appears a Montague, and vice versa.  Moreover, with this symmetry, Shakespeare gives us a social model of each family: first the lowest social rank, the servants, appear, followed by the nobles of each family, Benvolio and Tybalt, followed at last by the highest-ranking members of each family, the lords and ladies.  Shakespeare thus illustrates the social hierarchy that makes up each household, and also demonstrates that the feud extends from the top of the social ladder to the bottom.

'

text: 'After the prince arrives, the brawl is suddenly halted.  In the silence after the commotion of battle, Shakespeare gives Prince Escalus the first extended speech, in poetry, of the play.  Just as the rapidly-escalating brawl seizes the audience’s attention, so, too, does the sudden silence, followed by a powerful speech.  Shakespeare shows himself a master of manipulating the audience—of drawing them deeply into the dramatic world that he’s creating on the stage.'

text: 'Here we get a suite of day/night imagery, and already Shakespeare has begun to adjust our normal sense of what constitutes day and night.  Romeo constructs an “artificial night” by closing his windows during the day.  We haven’t even met him, yet, but already we know much about Romeo: he must normally be a good son, close to his parents and sociable with them, for they''re worried about a change in his behavior—recently, he''s turned into an enigmatic, moody sort of teenager, a true loner; he’s also associated with darkness—not light, which he appears to dislike.  And Shakespeare begins to associate certain ideas with day/light and night/darkness: night becomes associated with solitude and moodiness, day with companionship and beauty.'

'Remember the oxymoron in the prologue?  Well, here’s a whole series of oxymorons—and though Romeo seems to be trying to describe the feud and the contradictory emotions it involves, as his list continues, it’s clear he’s simply ranting, giving vent to his private emotions.  Benvolio understands: “No, coz,” he says, “I rather weep”—he’s saddened to see that Romeo is so out of sorts, so distraught.

O loving hate!   /  O any thing, of nothing first create!   /  O heavy lightness! serious vanity!   /  Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!   /  Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,   /  sick health!   /  Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!   /  This love feel I, that feel no love in this.   /  Dost thou not laugh?

text: 'With this affected passage, which is once again rife with oxymorons, Romeo confirms our opinion of him as a good-hearted but self-obsessed youth.  In fact, Romeo seems to be a young man struggling to find his own identity.  The oxymoron had long been a stock poetic device intended to convey the intense, contradictory emotions involved in passionate love (e.g., feeling at once on fire and icy cold); and by speaking largely in oxymorons, and continually groaning about his sad state, Romeo reveals himself to be struggling to find his own, individual language in which to speak.  Here is the initial treatment of what will turn out to be a major theme: growing up and trying to find one’s own voice—one’s own identity.  For Romeo, at this juncture, the project of finding a unique voice involves trying out the fancy language of older lovers (oxymoron).'

'Duncan is the King of Scotland. Shakespeare based this character on the historical king Duncan I who reigned between 1034 and 1040, more than 500 years before the playwright''s time. (There''s more time between Shakespeare and the historical events on which he based Macbeth than between his own time and the 21st century.) The historical Duncan was probably 40 when he was killed, but Shakespeare chose to make his character an elderly king.

'Noblemen were rarely alone. They mantained a retinue of "attendants" who were always at their beck and call. This entourage served as their private assistants and bodyguards and often wore "livery," a kind of uniform that anounced who they worked for (or, as they said, "whose man they were"). Before 1603, Shakespeare and his fellow actors in his company were the Lord Chamberlain''s men. After 1603, they all became the King''s men.

'Benvolio, still trying to cure Romeo of his self-involved, affected love for a girl who doesn’t return his affection, once again suggests that Romeo attempt to fix his attentions elsewhere.  Note the language Benvolio uses to make his suggestion: he characterizes love as an “infection” of the “eye”—Romeo’s unrequited love is a “rank poison” that can only be cured by a new disease.  Two important points: first, Benvolio characterizes love in negative terms (as a disease); and second, love remains associated with sight—it is an infection of the eye, and not, for instance, the heart.

'Cutting off the head of a traitor and using it as a trophy and a warning to future rebels was part of the standard punishment for treason in Shakespeare''s time. London Bridge and other landmarks in London and  were decorated with the heads of famous traitors. Tourists at the time often commented on the ghoulish attractions in diaries and letters.


Traitor''s Gate in Old London Bridge, with the exhibited heads on poles, can be seen in this engraving by Claes Jansz Visscher, (c. 1616).'

'After the sergeant''s descriptions of Macdownald''s disembowelling and beheading and of Macbeth and Banquo bathed in blood and wounds, Ross, another Thane, arrives with the rest of the narrative. His crazed expression, says Lennox, is coherent with his "strange speech." Shakespeare continues using language to make the general ambiance of the play dark, bloody, and strange from the very first scenes. We should remark that he is deliberately doing this with words and not with actions--all the audience has seen until now is a bare stage, heard the noises of war, and witnessed a few characters making expository speeches about actions that happened offstage.

text:
'Early modern stagecraft made much use of visual and aural special effects. The sound of thunder was an efficient and easily understood way (then and now) to convey an eerie mood. Beating drums or rolling objects over a sheet of metal were probably thunder-making devices at the time. (According to anecdotal tradition, in the early 1700s--a century after Shakespeare--a playwright had devised a very good thunder-making machine, which he unveiled in one of his own plays. The play was an artistic and commercial flop, but everyone was impressed by the machine, and a rival company copied the design and used it to great success in its production of Macbeth. The hapless playwright kept complaining that the other company had "stolen his thunder," and his expression of disappointment became commonplace.)
'

text:
'Editors have agreed to amend the spelling of this word to "weird," though the First Folio uses "wayward." The 17th century pronunciation was probably "we-yird." It''s a peculiar word, almost onomatopoeic, in that it looks and sounds strange and it also means "strange," among other related meanings. Its use in Macbeth to refer to the witches is one of the most famous ones, but the word goes back to the earliest forms of English, almost a thousand years before Shakespeare, when "wyrd" meant "fate, destiny." It retained heavy supernatural overtones. (This passage is also the source of "The Weird Sisters," the musical group mentioned in the Harry Potter books and played in the Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire movie by members of English groups Pulp and Radiohead.)

text:
'Here we see Macbeth already influenced by his ambition (or by the prophecy). It\\''s the kernel of an idea and it\\''s mentioned in passing, but he is already fudging the moral implications of his becoming king. He says that to become king would be as unbelievable as to become Cawdor. In feudal terms this is incorrect: he couldn\\''t become king unless the entire royal family died (or was killed), but he could easily become Cawdor if the current Thane of Cawdor were to be executed for treason and his titles taken by the crown to be gifted to whomever the king wanted. Given that Cawdor\\''s rebellion has just failed and that Macbeth himself has defeated Cawdor in combat, the possibility of his becoming Cawdor is substantially less unbelievable than the possibility of his becoming king, at least while remaining a loyal subject.

text:
'This is a passage with many resonances in the Shakespearean canon. The image of someone dressed in borrowed clothes can stand for a number of issues that seem to recur in his work: impersonation, usurpation, unreasonable ambition, servants who want to become their masters, and general feelings of social inadequacy. As a working actor, Shakespeare would spend much of his time rehearsing and performing in "borrowed clothes," both figuratively (in character) and literally (stage costumes were often cast-offs from the wardrobes of the nobility).

text:
'Macbeth''s first monologue, done as an aside to the audience (a common theatrical convention at the time) while the other characters are having a quiet conversation onstage. Shakespeare''s soliloquies and monologues are among his most celebrated developments, providing a clear snapshot of a character''s inner dilemmas during various points in the evolution of a play''s conflict. This soliloquy explores Macbeth''s confusion and mixed emotions during the first manifestation of his desire to seize the crown.
'

I am thane of Cawdor:   /  If good, why do I yield to that suggestion   /  Whose horrid image doth unfix my hair   /  And make my seated heart knock at my ribs,   /  Against the use of nature? Present fears   /  Are less than horrible imaginings:   /  My thought, whose murder yet is but fantastical,   /  Shakes so my single state of man that function   /  Is smother''d in surmise, and nothing is   /  But

The statute against treason in Shakespeare''s time defined it not only as attempting to kill the monarch, but also as "imagining" such an attempt. The most common application of this was against those planning some kind of plot (thus performing it in their imagination), but it was also used against those who spoke out loud about having thoughts of killing the monarch.

'Banquo elaborates on Macbeth''s previous metaphor of the "borrowed clothes." He excuses Macbeth''s strange introspection about being proclaimed Thane of Cawdor by pointing out that he still has to get used to his new honor, like garments that only take the shape of new owners after a period of use. Again, this metaphor is particularly relevant to actors such as Shakespeare and his fellows, who often performed wearing clothes that had previously belonged to members of the nobility.

A bad life, according to certain theologians, can be completely redeemed by a pious and repentant death. At the end of the play, Cawdorâ€™s death will be contrasted by that of Macbeth, who sinks into godless nihilism and refuses to repent.'

text:
'Banquo has already used this word to refer to the truth in the witches’ prophecy. Trifles were generally contrasted with serious matters and, as in this particular case, deep spiritual matters. By obsessing over the crown, Macbeth proves dazzled by what every religious character knows to be a trifle, human glory. Compared to a virtuous man like Banquo or even a last-minute repentant rebel like Cawdor, Macbeth appears as a figure similar to the legendary Dr Faustus, who sold his soul to the devil and failed to accept God’s offer of repentance to the very last. When Macbeth was written and first performed, Dr. Faustus was well-known as the protagonist of a very famous and popular play written by Christopher Marlowe in the mid-1590s.

'
quote: 'trifle.

text:
'Duncan has become skeptical of the pseudo-science of physiognomy, which taught that a person’s character can be deciphered by “reading” his or her face. The implication of this statement is that he did believe in it and was thus surprised to learn that he had been fooled by Cawdor’s apparent loyalty. Duncan is presented as too trusting for his own good, marking him as an innocent and making Macbeth’s betrayal even more reprehensible. In his innocence, Duncan resembles the character of the saintly but ineffectual Henry VI in the three plays about his chaotic reign that Shakespeare had worked on at the beginning of his career. Like Duncan, he loses his crown and is killed by his enemies.


'
quote: 'There''s no art   /  To find the mind''s construction in the face:   /  He was a gentleman on whom I built   /  An absolute trust.

text: 'Macbeth’s entrance immediately following Duncan’s reflection about his own gullibility makes for effective stage business: the line “he was a gentleman on whom I built absolute trust” applies literally to Cawdor but also prefigures Macbeth’s betrayal of the innocent king.'

text: 'Duncan figuratively wishes Macbeth’s behavior in battle had been less stellar so that he would have enough to reward him. This entire speech is an example of the kind of hyperbolic praise that was typical in court circles in Shakespeare’s time. The exaggerated praise is used for dramatic effect to shadow Macbeth’s crime and make it seem even more brutal.'
quote: 'Would thou hadst less deserved,   /  That the proportion both of thanks and payment   /  Might have been mine!

text: 'Duncan unwittingly continues making his own deathbed and fueling Macbeth’s thoughts of usurpation.'
quote: 'More is thy due than more than all can pay.

text: 'An interesting phrase in the context of the years around 1606, when the play was probably written. In 1603, King James had brought to London his children, the royal princes and princesses, and England had had “state children” for the first time in most people’s lifetimes (the notoriously childless Elizabeth had reigned since 1558, and she had been preceded by her equally unfruitful siblings, Mary and Edward VI). The protection of “state children” had become a novel matter of national security and the resonance for audiences would have been much more immediate than before the death of Elizabeth. Shakespeare had famously explored royal infanticide in his earlier and very popular play about the reign of Richard III, where that villainous king is made directly responsible for the deaths of the “princes in the tower.”'

text: 'To safeguard. The main practical reason for the existence of the feudal system was to provide safety for all the members of the feudal community. Any breach of trust and safety threatened the entire system. This was why usurpations were considered the most atrocious of crimes: by attacking the monarch, head of the feudal pyramid, the rebels were failing in their personal duties as well as compromising their but their chances for success.  Once in power, they would remain tainted by their initial transgression. A usurping king, according to a widely held notion, could never be an effective king because he could never ensure his own safety or guarantee any bonds of trust. Shakespeare had explored these issues in the 1590s with his plays about the reigns of Richard II, Henry IV, and Henry V. Although Richard had not been a very good king and had created the circumstances for his own overthrow, his usurping successor had never been able to control the kingdom because his claim to the throne had been undermined by the usurpation. It was only his repentant death and his sonâ€™s conquest of France that had redeemed (though only partially) his original sin against the system. Still, England had not been â€œsafeâ€ until the triumph of Henry VII over Richard III had put an end to the civil wars caused by Henry IVâ€™s usurpation. Like Macbeth, the usurping kings Henry IV and Richard III could never reestablish safety, and this lack of safety was instrumental in the deterioration of their power.'

'Duncan is officially naming his son Malcolm as his heir. Much as it was customary to create the heir apparent to the English throne "Prince of Wales," since the middle ages the Scottish monarch gave his heir apparent the titles of Duke of Rothesay, Earl of Carrick, Lord of Renfrew, and Great Steward of Scotland. In Shakespeare''s time the titles were held by Prince Henry, the eldest son of King James (today the titles are held by Prince Charles, who is also Prince of Wales, and Queen Elizabeth''s oldest son and heir). "Prince of Cumberland" is Shakespeare''s take on this kind of title in his version of the dark ages.

text:
'Macbeth here is speaking (as an aside to the audience) like other Shakespearean traitors, like Richard III and Iago. At this point he has abandoned any thoughts of his "single self" or integrity and is fully in the grip of the duplicity or multiplicity characteristic of the witches. This doubling of the self is what allows for deceit and hypocrisy: what is done in the dark can be different that what is done under the light, and what the eye does not want to see can be done by the hand without showing it to the eye. By splitting himself between an eye (fearful) and a hand (resolute) and giving the hand permission to act in darkness, Macbeth shows how he has been corrupted by the prophecy and his own ambition away from the singular good.

Also, notice Macbeth''s use of "that" "which" and "it": they all refer to the murder of usurpation, but in his mind at this point they are acts with no name--what is seen can be named, but what is done in darkness cannot.
'

'    Despite her vulgarity, the Nurse does seem to display a genuine affection for Juliet.  Here’s one of Shakespeare’s trademarks: complexity of character.  In his best plays, Shakespeare never gives us a purely evil, or a purely vulgar, or a purely good, character—rather, he tempers virtues with vices, and vice versa.  This is the complexity of real human beings, and Shakespeare’s ability to create living, breathing characters relies on his understanding of the paradoxes inherent in human nature.

    That said, do all the characters in Romeo and Juliet demonstrate such complexity?  What of Tybalt and Mercutio (whom we haven''t yet met)?

'

text:
'    Lady Capulet begins a long and overly complex speech in which she uses the conceit, or extended metaphor, of the male lover as an unbound book.  To be bound is to be married, in this metaphoric language—and in Shakespeare’s plays, we must always be alert to double-meanings lurking beneath the surface of the language.  “To be bound” smacks of bondage—i.e., slavery.  Here, such a meaning is not explicit, but simply hovers, unexpressed, as an undertone.  Keep your eyes and ears open for other uses of the word “bound” (in any form: to bind, bondage, etc.), and see if Shakespeare develops the notion of being bound.

    Whatever the undertones of her speech, and whatever its metaphoric intricacies (her comment about fish in the sea strikes me as willfully obscure), Lady Capulet is very clear in her intent: unlike her husband, she very much wants Juliet to marry Paris.  Like her husband and Benvolio, however, she deems sight the important sense in the game of love—“This night shall you behold him at our feast.”  Her literary metaphor for the lover serves to develop with a great deal more subtlety than Capulet or Benvolio the notion of sight as a means of judging the prospective lover.  If Benvolio is simply saying to Romeo, “there’ll be a bunch of gorgeous girls at the feast,” then Lady Capulet is telling Juliet something altogether more complex—but ultimately, her meaning, despite the intricacy of her speech, doesn’t amount to much more than “look at him, and then decide to marry him.”

'

text:
'    Juliet’s reply to her mother is one of the most delicious moments of the play.  Read her first line out loud (indeed, you should be reading many of these lines aloud — Shakespeare meant them to be spoken!), and marvel at the pert alliteration and crisp consonance and charming assonance.  The sound of the language complements its sense: Juliet seems to be obeying her mother to the letter, saying she’ll consider Paris without being improperly affectionate, only going so far as to follow her mother’s advice in considering his offer of marriage.  But Juliet is actually hedging—she doesn’t in fact consent to marry Paris, but instead, by adopting the guise of an extraordinarily submissive daughter, manages to avoid committing to the marriage.  “I’ll look to like, if looking liking move,” which expresses a tripping delicacy in its sound, demonstrates the agility of Juliet''s mind in cleverly disobeying her mother by seeming to obey her.  How does she disobey?  In reponse to her mother''s question, "can you like of Paris'' love?", i.e., "can you accept his love?", she replies "I''ll look to like" (i.e. "I''ll attempt to like him") "if looking liking move," i.e., "if looking at him can make me like him."  Or that''s the meaning her mother probably accepts; but Juliet uses the word "look" (look/looking) twice in a single line—and "look" has two meanings.  The second part of her line can be read with either the literal meaning, "to gaze at"—or with the figurative meaning that it takes in the first part of her line, in which case Juliet''s meaning is "I''ll try to like him, if trying to like him will make me like him."  Equivocation, pure and simple, that she means her mother to misunderstand as obedience.  Later in the play, too, when the situation is more desperate, Juliet will speak in double-meanings to her mother so that Lady Capulet thinks her daughter obeys when in fact Juliet is rejecting her mother''s authority.  

    Unlike Romeo, who enters the play using the borrowed language of the oxymoron, which expresses the sentiments of a love (for Rosaline) that he probably doesn''t really feel, Juliet comes onstage in full command of a subtle language all her own that allows her, at thirteen years old, to function as a private and independent young woman.

    The contrasting portrayal of Romeo and Juliet, accomplished through the language they speak, reminds us of Shakespeare''s astonishing virtuosity as a writer—of why he''s considered the greatest poet in the English language.  If we read his lines too quickly, Shakespeare''s characterization will escape us: all of his language seems so beautiful, so impossibly eloquent.  But if you pay attention to the subtleties of his language—how and why each character speaks the way he or she does—you''ll realize that the beauty of Shakespeare''s words is never "beauty for beauty''s sake"; rather, the sheer splendor of his language is always enlisted in a carefully, rigorously organized dramatic plan—here, the contrasting characterization of the title-characters.

    Feel free to get caught up in the sheer beauty of the language—in fact, you''re missing a lot if you don''t.  Most of the time, when I read Shakespeare, I''m so overwhelmed by the poetry itself that I can''t concentrate on the subtleties of meaning; only on a second reading, or even a third, can I begin to escape the magnetic allure of the beautiful language.  So to reiterate: be seduced by Shakespeare''s words; but after you''ve wallowed in their beauty, think long and hard about them.  Once you''ve gained access to some of the deeper meanings governing the play, your admiration for Shakespeare''s language will only increase.

'

text: 'Imagery of day.  “We burn daylight”—Mercutio intends a  figurative meaning, that, as he says, they’re wasting time (“we waste our lights in vain”).  But Romeo, in his moodiness, chooses to take him literally—“no,” he says, “we’re not actually burning daylight.”  Romeo’s remark may seem the willful misunderstanding of a moody teenager, but he inadvertently causes us to consider a more profound meaning, one that is linked to the day/night imagery running throughout the play: with their torches, these men are creating an artificial daylight (so they can walk in the dark).  The torch is a means of creating artificial day, just as by closing his shutters Romeo generated an artificial night.  Shakespeare is playing with the notion of what constitutes day, what constitutes night.  We’ve already seen that day has been associated with light and sight and beauty and companionship; but here, at night, the torches create an artificial light and facilitate the companionship of Romeo and his friends.'

text: 'In his first real comment on Juliet, Romeo mixes the imagery of night and light, and involves Juliet in that imagery: Juliet becomes herself a source of light, outshining the torches within the darkness of night.  Romeo continues, developing the dark/light imagery by likening Juliet to a snowy (white) dove seen against black crows.  But, precisely heeding Benvolio’s advice, he admits that she “o’er her fellows shows”—that she appears, to his eyes, more beautiful than any other woman.  And just as Benvolio promised—and Romeo swore would never occur—Romeo forgets his former “love” (Rosaline) and consecrates himself to Juliet.  How does he vow that his former affection was utterly unimportant?  “Forswear it [that I loved before[, sight,” he cries.  For Romeo, even as he falls in love with Juliet, sight—and its ability to judge “true beauty”—remains the crucial tool in the game of love.'

'Although England was a Protestant country from the mid-1500s onward, the memory of Catholic ritual still affected the imaginations of writers and audiences. Images of eating were often associated with the ritual of the Eucharist, a representation of a king (Jesus) offering his own body as a sacrifice to be eaten (during the mass). Bodies being eaten by worms were also a common preoccupation of writers at the time. Thus, Duncan''s innocent reference to Macbeth''s hospitality is made ominous by the prophecies the audience has heard and by Macbeth''s own asides that illustrate his descent into corruption.

text:
'    Among the most famous lines in English literature.  Romeo and Juliet’s first exchange is actually another sonnet!  It’s a beautiful duet of a poem, full of shy flirtation ending in a passionate kiss.  Before they kiss with lips, Romeo and Juliet kiss in words—by exchanging the rhyming lines of a sonnet.  Read this sonnet very carefully, and note how Romeo chooses to flirt with Juliet by using the language of religion.  Juliet plays along.  As Romeo blasphemously co-opts the language of religion to facilitate a kiss, the flirtation somehow becomes invested with the special aura of the sacred—the kiss is at once physical and profane, but also the granting of a prayer.

    In this exchange, both Romeo and Juliet use original language in a highly charged, erotic flirtation.  And the language is utilitarian as well as beautiful: Romeo’s goal is to get a kiss, and he succeeds!

    Consider carefully how Shakespeare, whom we’ve already seen manipulate an audience with consummate skill, once again plays with the emotions of the audience: no sooner have Romeo and Juliet kissed than they must part.  In fact, we’ll see, Romeo and Juliet are always being forced to part, and it is this aspect of their relationship—passion always seen at the moment of parting—that endows it with such sweet urgency.

'

text:
'    Act 2 begins with another sonnet pronounced by the Chorus.  Act 1 has given us some of Shakespeare’s great lines, from Juliet’s pert and agile first words to Mercutio’s fantastic imaginings.  With the duo love-sonnet that constitutes Romeo and Juliet’s first interaction, Shakespeare ratchets up the intensity of the play’s lyricism, enlisting a formal lyric device—that is, the sonnet—to generate the erotic charge between the lovers.  And with the enforced parting that separates Romeo and Juliet as soon as they’ve begun passionately to kiss, Shakespeare manipulates the audience through frustration—just as the play rises to a new level in beauty of language, in emotional temperature, in excitement, the lovers are separated.  There’s nothing like frustrated desire to increase that desire.  Note Shakespeare’s genius as a dramatic playwright: this separation not only serves the play’s plot by increasing Romeo and Juliet’s mutual desire; it also increases our desire, as the audience, to see the lovers reunited.  Shakespeare is very much aware that he’s writing for an audience, and he takes great pains to make the experience of the audience as exciting as the experience of the characters within his play.

    All that said—with the temperature of the play rising, the lovers parted even as they kiss, the action pressing forward towards the famous balcony scene—Shakespeare then includes another expository sonnet that, quite frankly, is rather dull.  One early edition (Q1) of the play doesn’t include this sonnet; I wish it had never been included in any edition of the play, for it retards the play’s forward surge with tedious and, worse, superfluous exposition.

    What does it say?  Here’s a quick prose paraphrase:

    Romeo’s forgotten his old crush; when he saw Juliet, Rosaline no longer seemed beautiful.  In fact, Juliet loves Romeo, too [remember how Rosaline didn’t return Romeo’s affection?].  But there’s a problem: their families are enemies, so it’ll be difficult for them to meet the way most lovers can.  With the strength of their passion, however, they’ll find a way to see each other.

    All this information is quite obvious to the audience or the reader.  Beyond the literal meaning of the poetry, does the language of the sonnet encode some more profound meaning or thematic content?  In its imagery, the sonnet simply recycles what we’ve already seen and heard: “Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie, / And young affection gapes to be his heir” — Juliet has just cried, “If he [Romeo] is marrièd, / My grave is like to be my wedding bed.”  As for organization, the sonnet is constructed as a plot-summary—and, unlike most well-written sonnets, then, it isn’t united by an underlying theme.  It does, however, end with a strong sentiment, couched in language somewhat more powerful than the rather pedestrian writing of lines 1-12: "But passion lends them power, time means, to meet, / Temp''ring extremities with extreme sweet."  The immense dangers to which the lovers expose themselves will be tempered—that is, qualified, or made less—by immense pleasures (let your imagination conjure up what those pleasures might be).  The phrase "temp''ring extremities with extreme sweet" should catch your attention: first, it has a genuinely Shakespearean ring; second, it''s a somewhat clumsy oxymoron.  "Extremities" is not the precise opposite of "extreme sweet," but Shakespeare means the two to oppose one another.  The oxymoron has infected the language of the play since its opening; beyond its use in conveying Romeo''s aping of adult mannerisms and, later, Juliet''s extreme emotion, perhaps—we should begin to think—the oxymoron has some more profound significance in the play.

    Let''s reconsider the definition of the oxymoron.  The union of two opposites.  But what, ultimately, is a heterosexual relationship?  Just that: the union of opposites.  In many ways, Romeo and Juliet is a play about discovering sexuality—Juliet is thirteen and arriving at full sexual development; Romeo is in his mid-to-late teens, arriving (since men mature later than women) at the same relative stage.  Their falling in love is not merely an emotional, but also very much a sexual, awakening (we''ll be looking at this further in a few scenes); and their mutual sexual awakening also catalyzes and drives a rapid process of maturation.  But the bottom line, for now: their relationship—the mystery of attraction between heterosexual men and women, a mystery these lovers have just discovered and begun to marvel at—is a physical oxymoron, the male and female united.
 
    Even further: Romeo and Juliet stand as more than just a pair of opposites in their sex—they come from families at war.  Their relationship is thus also a social oxymoron—a union of two fatally opposed families.

    But what, you''re saying, does all this have to do with the sonnet at the beginning of act 2?  And why am I not, you ask, letting you continue reading?  Here''s the reason: I wanted to point out that this sonnet does, despite its seeming superfluousness (it tells us what we already know and what we''re about to see in the balcony scene) have a relation to the overarching thematic concerns of the play—its final lines provide a mixed oxymoron: the social (and physical) danger of their meeting combined with the extreme delights of that meeting.

    And I want to say that, despite that thematic connection, the sonnet still irks me.  Why?  In addition to its superfluousness in imparting to us the plot, the sonnet also makes itself far too obvious in spelling out the theme of oxymoron.  Here''s an old truism: show, don''t tell.  By telling us that the lovers'' passion will make up for the dangers they risk, Shakespeare condescends to us, babies and cossets us.  The following scene will show us more than this sonnet can possibly tell.

    So remember: Shakespeare may be a writer of genius, but even a genius can make a mistake.  This sonnet is an example.  What follows the sonnet will redeem Shakespeare, for it constitutes one of the great scenes in Western drama—and one of the greatest passages in Western literature.

    But I should practice what I preach; rather than my telling you, let''s read!

'When Lady Macbeth opens her mouth, the first thing the audience hears is the voice of her husband speaking through her while she reads his letter out loud. This act of stage ventriloquism is the first instance of a curious phenomenon in their relationship--the fact that between that point and the murder of Duncan they seem to merge into a single character. This combined Macbeth/Lady Macbeth is in line with the witches and their gender confusion (they seem women but have beards) and it''s an uncanny complement to Macbeth''s loss of his "single self" and his division into duplicitous parts (the eye, the hand).

'Like Macbeth (and unlike Banquo), Lady Macbeth considers the prophecies infallible and a source of knowledge that announces something that already has been decided (Macbeth has already been crowned because the witches said so). This conception of fate had classical and pagan roots, and had an important theological manifestation in some forms of Protestantism (like Calvinism) that insisted on divine predestination. Other Christian writers strongly objected to predestination and they particularly warned against prophecies that had their origin in agents of the devil (this is Banquo''s take on the witches).

text: 'In this soliloquy, Romeo demonstrates that he is indeed an adolescent male.  We’ve already seen his relative immaturity, his attempts to ape the courtship-language of older men; here, as his hormones really do begin to rage, he exhorts Juliet to cast off her “vestal livery”—that is, to cast off the costume of the virgin.  In other words, Romeo wants Juliet to reject her virginity—to accept sexuality just as he is doing.  But beyond this metaphoric meaning, Romeo is literally saying, “Take off your clothes!”  He’s hoping (not unreasonably, since it’s late in the evening and he’s looking through her bedroom window) that Juliet is about to get undressed.'

text:
'Note how Shakespeare captures Romeo’s uncertainty: Romeo talks to himself, asks himself a question, responds to the question, but then rejects his first response.  All of Romeo’s lines are poetry (the meter is iambic pentameter); but simply because they are poetry does not mean they read like a tightly organized lyric poem.  One of Shakespeare’s innovations as a dramatic writer lies in his ability to capture in words the patterns of human thought.  Most famous among his plays, in this respect, is Hamlet—in the "To be, or not to be" soliloquy, for instance, the audience can hear poetry at the service of psychology, as Shakespeare makes Hamlet''s words express the activity of the Prince''s mind.  The distinguished British literary critic Sir Frank Kermode has written a book, called Shakespeare''s Language, about the evolution of Shakespeare''s ability to portray consciousness in poetry.  According to Sir Frank, Shakespeare matured from a playwright who wrote beautiful but psychologically unrealistic lyric poetry into a dramatist who used words as a means to portray human psychology.  While he wrote Romeo and Juliet fairly early in his career, Shakespeare already demonstrates himself to be a fine student of the mind, tracking Romeo''s mental fits and starts.
'

'    Interrupting Juliet, Romeo converts her philosophical pondering into an erotic moment.   As Juliet rhetorically offers “all myself” to Romeo, he reveals his presence to her by crying “I take thee at thy word.”  In addition to the obvious meaning of taking someone at their word—i.e., trusting someone—Romeo unmistakably charges his words with an erotic current.  Note also how Shakespeare enacts Romeo’s impetuous decision to reveal himself: Juliet begins an iambic pentameter line, but Romeo, unable to restrain himself, completes that line for her.  Shakespeare presents a brilliant pun: as Juliet pronounces the word “myself” in the middle of her pentamer line, which she expects to complete, Romeo interrupts and finishes her line—thus, quite literally, performing the action of taking Juliet at (i.e., as she speaks) her word (“myself”).

    This kind of erotically charged wordplay characterizes Romeo’s initial discourse with Juliet.

'    And now we begin to see why night is important for the lovers: without a true light-source, it is impossible to see.  The sense of sight, which has thus far been the dominant sense operating in the game of love, can be replaced by hearing.  (Though she has only exchanged a few words with him, Juliet can distinguish Romeo by his voice alone.)

text:
'    With this comment, Juliet sums up the nature of the lovers’ relationship: they’re always at the point of parting—at the ball, throughout this scene—and their passion is defined by that status.  To part from someone you love is to be reminded how deeply you care for that person; so that as Romeo and Juliet are forced continually to part from each other, they grow ever more aware of their feelings for each other.

    And, as we have seen, the effect of these continual partings, surprisingly, is to calm Romeo’s concupiscence (i.e., horniness).  We begin to see that arriving at sexual maturity, for Shakespeare, entails an emotional maturation, as well.

text:
'    The Friar presents an oxymoron: the earth is at once a tomb and a womb—the place where dead bodies lie and new bodies are born.  The metaphor, continuing the language of oxymoron we’ve seen throughout the play, implies that death and life are closely related.  Remember the “fatal loins” of the first act’s prologue?  

    The Friar introduces his metaphor as he begins to discuss herbs (the children of the earth)—they can be used for good or ill, he says; an herb that, when smelled, is beneficial, can, when eaten, kill.  “Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied” the Friar says (a few lines below this citation).  As so often in his plays, Shakespeare presents philosophical arguments in separate pieces—it is up to us, the audience/readers, to draw together various ideas spoken by different characters.  Juliet has said that “a rose by any other word would smell as sweet”—presenting the notion that language (the names by which we call things) does not alter the identity of things.  Now, the Friar argues that nature is not intrinsic—that is, that a thing can be either good or evil—depending on how it is used.  Juliet and the Friar take opposite stances: for Juliet, something is either good or bad, regardless of how it is named; for the Friar, how we name something—i.e., how our usage determines its name (poison if used to kill, medicine if used to cure)—determines its nature.

'

text: 'Once again, don’t be too concerned with the rapid twists and turns of Mercutio’s speech in the following scene.  As his name indicates, he is mercurial—“having a lively, volatile, or restless nature; liable to sudden and unpredictable changes of mind or mood; quick-witted, imaginative” (Oxford English Dictionary).  Even Shakespeare’s audience—the patrons of the theaters of London—would not be able to follow Mercutio’s sudden twists and turns; that is, in fact, the point—we are not supposed to be able to keep up with Mercutio’s mercurial nature.  If Romeo (before he met Juliet) could not invent his own language, Mercutio has the opposite problem—he invents too much to say, and says it.  Similarly, if Romeo’s problem lay in his lack of individuality, Mercutio is too individual—he is eccentric, zany, idiosyncratic.  He is at once the life of the party and the crazy guy who gets on everyone’s nerves.'

text:
'    Like Mercutio, the Nurse doesn’t try to control herself when she speaks—she simply says anything that comes into her head.  While her language isn’t filled with puns, as Mercutio’s speech always is, the Nurse is just as vulgar as Mercutio.  In fact, one can compare Mercutio and the Nurse as foil characters—that is, as characters who are similar enough that it is rewarding to compare them, and who are different enough that a comparison allows us to distinguish characteristics of both that we would not otherwise recognize.  (The idea is that by setting two similar objects side by side, one can recognize not only the obvious—how they are alike—but also what makes each object unique.)

    Harold Goddard, a brilliant critic of Shakespeare, has written about the similarity of Mercutio and the Nurse in what I think must be the most exciting essay ever written about Shakespeare—it’s called, simply, “Romeo and Juliet,” and you can find it in the first volume of Goddard’s essays on all of Shakespeare’s plays, entitled The Meaning of Shakespeare (University of Chicago).

text: 'Just as in her opening line (“I’ll look to like if looking liking move”), Juliet uses repetition of words to telling effect.  Whereas in that earlier line she seemed to obey her mother’s authority but made clear to us that she was in fact subverting it, here she expresses her exasperation with the delaying Nurse by mocking the Nurse’s excuse for delay.  “I am out of breath,” the Nurse says; Juliet’s point is that if the Nurse can say she’s out of breath, she’s not really out of breath.  To make her point, Juliet over-uses the word breath in her question—she doesn’t ask, “How can you be out of breath if you’re talking?”  Rather, she says “How art thou out of breath when thou has breath / To say to me that thou art out of breath?”  The annoyed Juliet is insisting that the Nurse has a good deal of breath.  (Shakespeare also makes it very easy for an actor [here, actress] to infuse her lines with the proper emotion: each time Juliet repeats "breath," she can modulate her voice to sound more and more exasperated.)'

text:
'    No violence has occurred since the opening scene’s mayhem.  Tybalt threatened to unleash violence at Capulet’s ball, but Capulet restrained him.  Here, as we approach the middle of the play, tension is building: Tybalt has challenged Romeo to a duel; the weather is hot and “the mad blood stirring.”  Something must snap.

    As J.A. Bryant, Jr., has argued in his excellent introduction to the Signet Classic edition of Romeo and Juliet, while some critics have considered the following scene a transition from the mode of comedy into the mode of tragedy, the entire play is fraught with the sense of tragedy—from the deadly opening brawl to the continual talk of death and violence.  But rather than seeing Romeo and Juliet as merely a tragedy, or as a comedy that shifts gears to become a tragedy halfway through its dramatic arc, I wonder if we might think about the play as a competition between comedy and tragedy.

    English professors, among them Harvard University’s Gordon Teskey, sometimes discuss the distinction between comedy and tragedy as a distinction between narratives that end in marriage, and thus promote social unity, and narratives that end in death, and thus tear apart society.  In the previous scene, Romeo and Juliet were married—the event that usually concludes a comedy, establishing social unity and promoting general happiness; but no sooner does this marriage take place than, in the next scene—as we will see—a terrible, deadly violence breaks loose.

    Think about how you might define a “comedy” or a “tragedy.”  It’s hard to think about Romeo and Juliet as a comedy, since I suspect all of us know the ending isn’t a happy one; but, trying to think objectively, purposely “forgetting” your knowledge of the end of the play, in what ways might the play be considered comic?  In what ways tragic?

'

'    With his continually repeated line, Mercutio draws our attention to his status as an “outsider”—someone who belongs neither to the Capulets and Montagues.  Since it is he who initiated the quarrel with Tybalt, why does he—who has courted danger by choosing to duel—curse both the Montagues and the Capulets?

    This line is one of the play’s most famous, but also one of its most inscrutable.  Even the most famous critics of the play don’t really agree about its meaning.  So you have the opportunity to figure out something that, despite four hundred years of study, no one has yet really understood.

'

text:
'    If there is a decisive moment for Romeo, here it is: rather than mourning Mercutio’s imminent death, Romeo focuses on his own social standing—“my reputation stained / With Tyablt’s slander”—and recognizes that Juliet’s “beauty” has caused him to become too “effeminate.”  Juliet’s love has indeed, as we have seen, caused Romeo to mature into a fine young man, one who opposes violence and seeks to quell it; but Veronese society has a competing code of conduct—the ideology of the feud, and more broadly, of society in general—one that insists men requite violence with violence, that they behave like “men.”  Romeo has attained his own individuality by loving Juliet—against the code of the feud, which holds that Montagues and Capulets must ever hate one another.  And according to his individual ethical beliefs, violence is wrong.

    But the brutal, powerful ideology of the feud violently asserts itself as Tybalt stabs Mercutio, and in this speech we see Romeo rejecting the identity predicated on his love with Juliet in favor of his identity as a son of the House of Montague.  (Note how all Romeo can discuss is social hierarchy: “This gentleman, the Prince’s near ally…” and “my reputation,” etc.)  Romeo understands his previous behavior as unmanly, as “effeminate.”  It is clear that he has already decided to obey the dictates of the feud—to take up the role of the “man” and avenge Mercutio’s death.

    In modern society, we of course reject such notions that valor is masculine and pacifism feminine, that masculine means strong/courageous and feminine weak/helpless.  In Renaissance society these notions were very much current (see Stephen Greenblatt’s brilliant discussion of sexuality and gender in the Renaissance, “Fiction and Friction,” from Shakespearean Negotations [University of California]); but that does not mean that everyone agreed with them.  From the evidence presented by the play thus far, how do you think Shakespeare characterizes the “feminine” and the “masculine”?  Does he give a more positive connotation to “feminine” or “masculine” qualities?

    [For the use of the word “code” in this context, I am indebted to Professor Daniel Albright of Harvard University.  See the chapter on Romeo and Juliet in Professor Albright’s newly published book, Musicking Shakespeare (Rochester).]

'

text:
'    The Friar’s comment might almost be a comment on the play itself: as many critics and teachers have noted, Romeo and Juliet is a play of incredible haste—events don’t so much occur as trip over one another.  We’ve talked a lot about the nature of Romeo and Juliet’s love as passion at the moment of parting—a state that imbues their love both with an urgency, as one might expect, and also with a sense of maturity (which one might not as readily anticipate).  In fact, the entire play itself is characterized by a breathless hastiness—on which many characters (e.g., the Friar) comment—that, in addition to endowing the drama with urgency, serves also to magnify the import of emotions and events.  In Hollywood films, a fast pace helps to make many a blockbuster more exciting and involving than it actually is; here, a set of already-exciting situations becomes accelerated into a dizzying blur of action.  Indeed, the speed of the play is so remarkable partly because it is one of the few original elements of Shakespeare’s plot: that is, although he pilfered his plot and characters from already-existing sources, Shakespeare altered those sources by accelerating the time-frame of the story.  Beyond the expected increase in excitement, the acceleration also serves to heighten the impact of emotions and, further, to make a set of already-well-drawn characters particularly vivid, to etch them indelibly into our imagination.

    Why might accelerating events heighten the impact of characterization?  For one, because the dizzying pace of the action forces us to remember the youth of the protagonists—just as they barely taste maturity before untimely death, Romeo and Juliet barely give us a chance to know them before they’re hurried off the stage.  And that effect—the sense that we glimpse only for a few moments characters whom somehow we feel we already know well—isn’t true merely of the lovers, but also of, say, Mercutio—or, even, Benvolio, who, although he does not die, nonetheless disappears from the play around the same time Mercutio does.

    So by having the Friar and other characters comment on the pace of the action, Shakespeare may perhaps be slyly inserting a bit of commentary on his own play (below the Friar muses, in reference to the plans for imminent marriage, “I would I knew not why it should be slow’d”).

'

text:
'    In the following exchange, Paris tries continually to initiate the dialogue of love—the kind of back-and-forth, mutual exchange we hear at the end of the first balcony-scene, or throughout the second (the farewell scene).  But in response to Paris’ warmth, Juliet is resolutely cold, frustrating her prospective husband’s attempts to kindle an amorous conversation.  In fact, just as she pacified her mother with double-meanings that offered one understanding to her mother and allowed Juliet—and the audience—another, subversive understanding, here Juliet offers remarks that cannot be interpreted as improper or rude to the man who has been declared her fiancé—but that, nonetheless, encode her faith to Romeo.

    I’ve mentioned above Stephen Greenblatt’s brilliant essay on sexuality in the Renaissance (“Fiction and Friction,” from Shakespearean Negotiations, California).  On a stage that limited the representation of sex (in the Elizabethan Era, Shakespeare could scarcely ask an all-male cast to do much more than kiss), bantering conversation, Greenblatt argues, is Shakespeare’s primary means of generating erotic charge—via a sort of verbal “friction.”  Here, Juliet successfully frustrates Paris’ attempt to generate such friction.  Compare their dialogue, in which Juliet turns aside or subverts Paris’ meanings, to the love-sonnet with which Romeo and Juliet initiate their romance.

'

text:
'    Like Romeo, but in a less crazed manner, Juliet announces she is willing to die rather.  Her motives: she refuses to betray Romeo by marrying Paris and to betray God by committing bigamy.

    In the Renaissance (as by some people today), it is held a sin against God to commit suicide—to self-murder.  The sin of suicide is probably graver than the sin of bigamy; so Juliet is blasphemously elevating her love for Romeo above her devotion to God.  And she is making her argument—that she will commit suicide rather than commit bigamy—to a Friar, a representative of God.

    Taking into account Juliet’s resolve, and the Friar’s response to it—and recalling the role of the Friar throughout the play—what is the role of religion in this drama?  How does Shakespeare characterize Christianity?  

'

text:
'    How rational—or likely to succeed—do you consider the Friar’s plan?

    To modern audiences, it often seems a desperate and foolish scheme; but in her predicament, Juliet can scarcely be blamed for accepting it.  Despite her maturity, Juliet is, we must remember, only thirteen years old—and she looks to trusted figures for guidance and council.

    But perhaps the plan is less foolhardy than it may seem.  Juliet has expressed herself willing to commit suicide; whereas with the desperate, hysterical Romeo the Friar could avert a suicide-attempt by rebuking him for cowardice, with Juliet the Friar recognizes a firmer, more resolute character.  Romeo, in melodramatic fashion, desires to kill himself because, overwhelmed by emotion, he has lost the ability to reason; with his purely emotional motivation for self-murder, he can be dissuaded from the attempt, restored to reason, by the sheer force of the Friar’s personality.  But with Juliet the motive for suicide is not strictly emotional—rather, it is quite logical: she refuses to commit bigamy or to betray Romeo.  All the force of her emotion supports and bolsters this logic.  The Friar, a reasonably wise man pressed to the end of his wits, realizes that saving Juliet from self-murder is a task that will require a logic greater than her own—a convincing reason for not committing suicide.  But, beyond the threat of eternal damnation—which, interestingly, the Friar refuses to offer—such a compelling reason does not exist.  So what does the Friar do?  He co-opts Juliet’s resolve to die by allowing her to commit a false suicide.  Just as you turn your tires into a skid to regain control of a car, yielding to the danger in order to overcome it, the Friar encourages Juliet’s suicidal impulse in a way that nullifies it.

    Look again at the way in which the Friar couches his argument: “Then is it likely thou wilt undertake /A thing like death to chide away this shame, / That cop''st with death himself to scape from it” ....Recognizing Juliet has become nearly obsessed with death (look at her strange acceptance of the Friar’s plan—its increasingly explicit evocation of death), the Friar tries to take control of that obsession by allowing Juliet to evacuate it in a way that both saves her life and may, in fact, even lead to the greater happiness of a reunion of the two lovers.

    Considered in these terms, the Friar’s plan is not some lunatic scheme that the distraught Juliet too-readily accepts, but rather a brilliant and psychologically acute stratagem for saving Juliet’s life.

'

text:
'    This brief conversation is a type of exchange (or scene) one sees frequently in Shakespeare’s plays: it seems to have nothing to do with anything.  Or, rather, it seems so unimportant that you wonder why Shakespeare would have bothered to include it.  But the impression that this exchange—or any of the similar scenes Shakespeare includes in this and other plays—is unimportant or incongruous is utterly misleading.  Here, as elsewhere, we should remember that Shakespeare is a brilliant writer, and sometimes sets us puzzles that—like those of, say, James Joyce—can either be ignored or picked up and, if not solved, at least thought about.

    Whenever you encounter a seemingly trivial, unimportant moment in Shakespeare’s plays, you should be on your guard: more often than not, these incidents explain or comment on some of the play’s important themes.  In fact, Shakespeare—like Joyce, with whom he is often compared—seems to enjoy investing what seems trivial with deep significance.

    Back to the scene at hand: what, you’re probably wondering, could possibly be the significance of the Servingman’s retort to Capulet?

    Well, what is the Servingman saying?  In response to Capulet’s order to hire "cunning" (i.e., skillfull) cooks for Juliet''s wedding feast, the Servingman asserts that "You shall have none ill, sir"—i.e., "You won''t be hiring any bad cooks."  Why can the Servingman make this statement with such confidence?  "I''ll try if they can lick their fingers"—that is, he will test them ("try them," in Capulet''s words) by asking them to lick their own fingers.  And why, Capulet wants to know, should this test reveal a cook''s skill?  "Marry, sir," the Servingman replies, "''tis an ill cook that cannot lick his own fingers."  What the Servingman means is that only a bad or incompetent cook would refuse to sample his own cooking.

    What, then, is the significance of this brief conversation?  It is no accident that this little exchange occurs just after Friar Laurence offers his (lunatic/brilliant? you decide) plan to Juliet, a plan that, he says, will require great courage to execute.  What Shakespeare gives us, through the innocuous banter of the Servingman, is a formulation of that old cliché—"Practice what you preach."  The Friar has been very ready to dole out advice, to tell Romeo and Juliet what is right and wrong; but, like the cooks the Servingman wishes to test, if he refuses to "lick his own fingers"—to offer the same resolution and courage he has insisted Romeo and Juliet display—he will be an "ill mentor."  More specifically, the Friar must himself play a part in the scheme he has devised—he must eat the meal he has prepared.  Keep your eyes open for the Friar''s behavior later in the play, and see if, in both the general and specific senses, he licks his own fingers.

    Indeed, this theme—the role of the mentor, or giver of advice, vis-à-vis the pupil, or receiver of advice—undergirds the entire play: recall Benvolio''s friendly advice (and Mercutio''s hectoring advice) to Romeo, Capulet''s fatherly advice to Paris, the Nurse''s busybody but affectionate advice to Juliet, and so forth.  Do these "mentors" and plan-concocters heed their own advice, or participate in their own plans?  Mercutio certainly does both—to his death (and his cursing of the Capulets and Montagues, though neither house is ultimately responsible for his self-precipitated demise).  But more subtly, do these other mentors live up to the moral example they insist on for their "pupils"?  And, more broadly, then, who has the right to give advice?  Must one earn that right?  And what are the responsibilities of those who give advice?

    In a play about coming to maturity, Shakespeare suggests, to my mind, that one emblem of true maturity lies not in the ability to make all one''s own decisions without guidance, but rather in the ability to give advice in which one believes.  To steer another''s course requires sure knowledge of how to sail; or, put another way, before one cooks a dish for friend, one must first taste and enjoy the dish.

'

text: 'In this terrible moment, Juliet demonstrates the fine stuff she is made of.  Before our very eyes, we see Juliet attain the mantle of maturity.  The potential for this maturity existed from the moment we met Juliet; but her love for Romeo, and the trials she has already endured, have catalyzed a transformation in her character—from confidence to resolution; from reliance on others to a complete self-reliance.  As she poses fearful questions and then herself answers them, Juliet passes from the last lingering stages of adolescence into the sphere of adulthood.'

text:
'    As before, Shakespeare has cleverly interwoven two separate plots—the plot concerned with Romeo and Juliet, and the plot engineered by Capulet to have Juliet marry Paris.  The former plot has reached a climax with Juliet’s taking of the drug—and, with Juliet’s seeming death, that plot must impinge on the other, for Juliet is a character in both.  In other words, the two plots, which have been in increasing friction (the marriage-plot drives Juliet to the desperate measure of nearly committing suicide), are about to collide.

    Put simply: only the audience is completely aware of both plots—and we experience a sense of increasing tension, now, as Shakespeare draws out the moment when the two will collide—when Juliet will be discovered, “dead.”

    The technical term for this phenomenon—when the audience is aware of some circumstance of which the characters in the play remain unaware—is dramatic irony.  In most cases, this circumstance has a crucial—even life-or-death—significance for the character(s) who remains unaware of it.  Dramatic irony thus has a huge payoff: a heightened sense of involvement for the audience—we long to be able to participate in the play, to enter its reality by shouting a warning, by alerting the hero to an unknown danger (or reward).  (A bit later, we’ll see an excruciating example of dramatic irony....)

    While the term dramatic irony is most often applied to one specific scenario, we should note that, with his interwoven plots, Shakespeare makes it a guiding principle of Romeo and Juliet.

'

text:
'    We can believe more in the Nurse’s grief—for despite her betrayal of Juliet (by suggesting that she commit bigamy and betray Romeo by marrying Paris), she genuinely believed herself to be acting in Juliet’s best interests.

    Note, too, her manner of mourning: she curses the day—both in the sense of the specific date, and in the sense of day as daytime (as opposed to nighttime).  And, we recall, the precise time is dawn—sunrise.  With the rise of the sun, the dawn of the new day, is discovered Death.  Just as the imagery associated with day and night has been altered and sometimes inverted throughout the play, here, the Nurse says “Never was seen so black a day as this.”  Romeo created artificial night at the play’s opening; now does Juliet’s “death” cast the day into the seeming darkness of grief.

'

text:
'    We must at least consider the Friar’s moral responsibility for the grief—real or simulated—occasioned by Juliet’s “death.”  The Friar’s interest in saving Juliet from bigamy or death is not entirely selfless: with either outcome (bigamy or suicide), the Friar, too, would be at fault.  By playing his role in the complicated plot he concocted to save Juliet, he is also saving himself; and, moreover, he is knowingly causing parents the grief of seeing their child dead.

    Once again, then, does the Friar have the right to behave as he does?  And how does it affect our reading of his character to note how easily, once again, he breaks into his accustomed mode of lecturing (admonishing!) people who are overcome by strong emotion?

'

text:
'Capulet’s comment recalls the modulation (a musical word meaning alteration in pitch) of the play from comedy into tragedy.  For the audience, that modulation was definitive, but surprisingly, for Capulet—whose relative, Tybalt, had been killed—the shift didn’t really seem to occur.  Here Capulet expressly converts the would-be wedding trappings into funeral array.  Shakespeare is echoing the earlier shift from the comic to the tragic (at Mercutio’s death) and drawing our attention to the power of emotions: material things—here, the supplies for the wedding—do not change, but when our emotional condition changes, our perception of the material world is irrevocably altered.  In a way, Shakespeare is calling attention to the versatility of his stage—and the power of his dramaturgical craft: his art, Shakespeare seems to be insisting, does not rely on props to accomplish its powerful emotional effect.
'

'    Romeo’s response to Juliet’s “death” is telling: his speech is short and bereft of metaphor.  Rather than the long-winded, self-involved oxymorons he once spewed forth to tell of his sorrow, here he feels more deeply than he can possibly articulate.  After his brief howl, Romeo immediately subsides into what seem to be practical concerns.

    How should an actor interpret these lines?  Is Romeo really indifferent?  How strong is his emotion?

    With his typical genius, Shakespeare encodes his stage directions in spoken lines: Balthasar, Romeo’s servant, notes in response that “Your [Romeo’s] looks are pale and wild.”  The well-prepared actor will use the speech of other characters to determine how to play his own role.  In Shakespeare, this rule is often, as here, a vital tool in acting.

'

text:
'    Recall the Friar’s opening speech, in which the Friar staked out a position of relativism predicated on his knowledge of plants: a plant may be either poison or cure, depending on how it is used, the Friar insisted.  If a plant is used to promote life, it is virtuous—if death, full of vice.  From that position one can build the general proposition of relativism—that nothing is intrinsically good or evil, but rather becomes “good” or “evil” based on how it is used.  Here, by calling poison a “cordial,” Romeo extrapolates a more extreme version of that philosophical understanding”: for him, even a poison may be defined as virtuous if it reunites him with his true love, Juliet.

    Shakespeare implies that desperation has a powerful effect on human psychology—it can alter our entire system of moral valuation.  With suicide as his aim, Romeo—as we will soon see—begins to lose his sense of moral value, his understanding of what is “good” and what is “bad.”

'

text:
'    Perhaps the most perplexing feature of the end of the play is Shakespeare’s refusal to allow Romeo and Juliet a final reunion.  In his loud and ludicrous film, Baz Luhrmann allows the lovers a final meeting—both are already dying, but they are allowed to die with each other.  But this kind of emotional release is precisely what Shakespeare refuses to permit.

    Shakespeare does not intend for us to attain the catharsis of a tearful final reunion; rather, he wishes us to understand the senselessness, the futility, of the lovers’ deaths.

'

text:
'    The opening sonnet’s promised end: the children’s misadventures “Doth with their death bury their parents’ strife.”

    What waste there has been in this play—what a waste of two bright young adults who scarcely tasted the joys of a loving maturity.

    If so much of the play’s events occurred outside the sight and the operation of the law, here, at the close, the Prince—who in vain attempted to assert the city’s law to halt the feud—promises to make the rule of law pervasive.  The death of Romeo and Juliet—made inevitable not by Fate, but by the unreasoning hatred of their families—has at last mended the rift between the two families.  If love catalyzed the maturation of the two adolescents, accomplishing a miraculous modulation from puberty into adulthood, a surfeit of deaths catalyzes a maturation, all too late, in Capulet and Montague, as they at last lay down their swords, or crutches, to join together in grief.  If that bond proves ineffectual, there is always the rule of justice that the Prince has promised.  We must hope, however, that the legacy of the lovers lies in a willing, if uneasy, and not an enforced, peace.
