text:
'The 1623 Folio gives this stage direction and the first line of Hecate''s song. Around 1664, the Restoration playwright William Davenant (who fancied himself Shakespeare''s artistic heir) obtained the rights to "Macbeth" from the King''s Men and based his text on their script prepared for performance. Davenant''s version expands the "etc." of the Folio''s stage direction into a whole song by Hecate and the Spirits before the First Witch''s line leading to the exit. In 1778, Middleton''s "The Witch" was finally published (it had been unsuccessful and had remained only in manuscript since the 1610s) and scholars and editors began questioning the authorship of the Hecate scenes in Macbeth.

Davenant''s version of the end of III.5, included in many editions of "Macbeth," reads:

Hecate
...His hopes ''bove wisdom, grace, and fear;
And you all know security
Is mortals'' chiefest enemy.

Spirits (singing dispersedly within)
Come away, come away.
Hecate, Hecate, come away.

Hecate
Hark, I am called! My little spirit, see,
Sits in a foggy cloud and stays for me.

(The Song)

Spirits (within)
Come away, come away,
Hecate, Hecate, come away.

Hecate
I come, I come, I come, I come,
With all the speed I may,
With all the speed I may.
Where''s Stadlin?

Spirit (within)
Here.

Hecate
Where''s Puckle?

Another Spirit (within)
Here.

Other Spirits (within)
And Hoppo, too, and Hellwain, too,
We lack but you, we lack but you.
Come away, make up the count.

Hecate
I will but ''noint, and then I mount.

(Spirits appear above. A Spirit like a Cat descends)

Spirits (above)
There''s one comes down to fetch his dues,
A kiss, a coll, a sip of blood,
And why thou stay''st so long I muse, I muse,
Since the air''s so sweet and good.

Hecate
O, art thou come? What news, what news?

Spirit
All goes still to our delight.
Either come, or else refuse, refuse.

Hecate
Now I am furnished for the flight. (She ascends with the spirit and sings)
Now I go, now I fly,
Malkin my sweet spirit and I.

[Spirits (and Hecate?)]:
O what a dainty pleasure ''tis
To ride in the air
When the moon shines fair,
And sing, and dance, and toy, and kiss.
Over woods, high rocks and mountains,
Over seas and misty fountains,
Over steeples, towers and turrets,
We fly by night ''mongst troops of spirits.
No ring of bells to our ears sounds,
No howls of wolves, no yelps of hounds.
No, not the noise of waters-breach
Or cannons'' throat our height can reach.

Spirits (above)
No ring of bells to our ears sounds,
No howls of wolves, no yelps of hounds.
No, not the noise of waters-breach
Or cannons'' throat our height can reach.(Exeunt into the heavens the Spirit like a Cat and Hecate)

First Witch
Come, let''s make haste. She''ll soon be back again. (Exeunt)

'
quote: 'Music and a song within: ''Come away, come away,'' & c

text:
'The rhymed verse here is far more pedestrian than the mysterious riddles of the witches in previous scenes. This is one of the reasons this whole scene has been ascribed to Thomas Middleton or another hack reviser much inferior to Shakespeare as a poet. Also the tone of the scene, particularly in the Davenant version (see other notes for this scene), points much more to spectacles like "Midsummer Night''s Dream" or Jacobean masques and pageants, than the much more mysterious tone of dread and doom leading up to it.
'
quote: 'I, the mistress of your charms,   /  The close contriver of all harms,   /  Was never call''d to bear my part,   /  Or show the glory of our art?

text:
'This is the typically convoluted speech of court politics. The gist of Lennox''s introduction is that what he said coincides with what the other lord thinks and that they should both reach their own conclusions quietly. Courtiers were justifiably paranoid about making direct statements about political situations.
'
quote: 'My former speeches have but hit your thoughts,   /  Which can interpret further: only, I say,   /  Things have been strangely borne.

text:
'First mention of Macbeth''s official explanation for Banquo''s murder: Fleance, his own son, killed him. This is identical to his explanation for the murder of Duncan.
'
quote: 'Whom, you may say, if''t please you, Fleance kill''d,   /  For Fleance fled:

text:
'This is a subtle indication that Macbeth''s support among his thanes is eroding. Lennox''s words until then have been generally ambiguous about his position, but this line gives away his real opinion of Macbeth.
'
quote: 'As, an''t please heaven, he shall not--they

text:
'Noblemen in Shakespeare''s time were falling in and out of the king''s favor for all kinds of reasons. Being "in disgrace" could cause trouble for noblemen and make them easy targets for their enemies. "Broad words," things said without subtlety or ambiguity, often led to a fall from favor.
'
quote: 'from broad words and ''cause he fail''d   /  His presence at the tyrant''s feast, I hear   /  Macduff lives in disgrace:

text:
'"Tyrant" was an extremely loaded word at the time. Scripture and the vast majority of political writing made it very clear that all subjects were supposed to submit to the authority of the king. Rebelling against, or merely questioning, royal power was strongly discouraged, even if a king made mistakes or was weak or ineffectual or a "bad king." However, there was a crucial loophole that produced a lot of debate: if the king committed horrible crimes or his cruelty made his rule unbearable, he could degenerate into a "tyrant" and, some (though not all) political and religious thinkers argued, he could be be legitimately deposed by his subjects.

Lennox''s use of this word is unusually unsubtle and shows how much\r\nMacbeth''s position has deteriorated at this point in the play.
'
quote: 'tyrant''s

text:
'Lennox and the other lord are now openly discussing Macbeth as a tyrant (see previous note). By speaking to each other in these terms they can both be accused of the crime of "conspiracy" (literally, breathing together), one of the highest forms of treason.
'
quote: 'From whom this tyrant holds the due of birth

text:
'England is not only presented as more civilized than Scotland (a view widely shared by the London audience of the play) but as its religious mirror image: while the northern kingdom has degenerated into the unnatural rule of the tyrant Macbeth, where witches run rampant, England is ruled by a "holy" king.

The king of England at the time the historical Macbeth ruled Scotland was Edward, known as The Confessor. Edward was the last of the unchallenged Anglo-Saxon kings of England, and his childless death in 1066 precipitated a struggle for the throne between various contenders that led to the Norman invasion of England and the defeat of the Anglo-Saxon Harold II by William the Conqueror.

Edward was renowned for his piety (he founded Westminster Abbey and was buried there) and even the Norman rulers recognized him as a holy figure. He was made a saint in 1161 by the Catholic Church.



The shrine of Edward the Confessor in Westminster Abbey.
'
quote: 'Lives in the English court, and is received   /  Of the most pious Edward with such grace   /  That the malevolence of fortune nothing   /  Takes from his high respect: thither Macduff   /  Is gone to pray the holy king,

text:
'Until the 1603 accession of King James of Scotland to the English throne it had been usual for those disgruntled with Scottish rulers to travel south and ask for support from England. The English rulers preferred a weak Scotland and so tended to provide armies and money, often in secret, to stir up trouble in the northern kingdom. Many earls of Northurmberland (controlling the northeastern part of England) intervened in Scottish politics. Siward was the earl of Northumberland at the time of the historical Macbeth and Edward the Confessor.
'
quote: 'To wake Northumberland and warlike Siward:

text:
'Lennox is envisioning the English invasion and the depostition of Macbeth as a Holy Crusade, sanctified from heaven. The play here again parallels Shakespeare''s earlier "Richard III," where Richard''s deposition by Richmond (the future Henry VII) is seen as blessed by God.

The deposition of Macbeth is also seen as a restoration of harmony and natural order, turned upside down by the murder of Duncan and the exclusion of his heirs from the throne.
'
quote: 'That, by the help of these--with Him above   /  To ratify the work--we may again   /  Give to our tables meat, sleep to our nights,   /  Free from our feasts and banquets bloody knives,   /  Do faithful homage and receive free honours:   /  All which we pine for now:

text:
'"Angel" was related to the Greek word for "messenger." Here the messenger between the conspirators in Scotland and Macduff, preparing the invasion from his English exile, is metaphorically linked to an actual heavenly angel. This is contrasted with the previous envoy, Macbeth''s messenger to Macduff ordering him to return, who is described as "cloudy," or angry.
'
quote: 'Some holy angel   /  Fly to the court of England and unfold   /  His message ere he come, that a swift blessing   /  May soon return to this our suffering country   /  Under a hand accursed!

text:
'Later editors added the place names usually found in most editions of the play. IV.1 is conventionally set somewhere in a cavern, around a boiling cauldron.

This scene is notorious among scholars because it highlights the problems one encounters when trying to identify the "true" text of a Shakespearean play, or when trying to figure out "what Shakespeare actually wrote." Many years ago, it was noticed that the songs in the Hecate scenes (III.5 and IV.1) were identical to songs in "The Witch,"a play written by Thomas Middleton sometime between 1610 and 1615. Further analysis of the tone and meter of all of III.5 and parts of IV.1 has led scholars to believe that Shakespeare did not write those parts of the play.

The scholarly consensus is that Shakespeare wrote "Macbeth" around 1606, but sometime before 1623 (when the First Folio was published) Shakespeare''s company somehow had "Macbeth" revised for performance by someone else (possibly Middleton), who then grafted a couple of crowd-pleasing scenes and songs from "The Witch" onto it.
'
quote: 'SCENE I.

text: 'Later editors added the place names usually found in most editions of\r\nthe play. IV.2 is conventionally set in Macduff''s castle at Fife.'
quote: 'SCENE II.

text:
'Another copia, a rhetorical laundry list showing the writer''s knowledge of a subject and skill in enumeration and variation. This is a catalogue of disgusting ingredients traditionally associated with the dreaded witches'' brew.
'
quote: 'Scale of dragon, tooth of wolf,   /  Witches'' mummy, maw and gulf   /  Of the ravin''d salt-sea shark,   /  Root of hemlock digg''d i'' the dark,   /  Liver of blaspheming Jew,   /  Gall of goat, and slips of yew   /  Silver''d in the moon''s eclipse,   /  Nose of Turk and Tartar''s lips,   /  Finger of birth-strangled babe   /  Ditch-deliver''d by a drab,   /  Make the gruel thick and slab:   /  Add thereto a tiger''s chaudron,   /  For the ingredients of our cauldron.

text:
'The 1623 Folio gives this stage direction, Hecate''s first speech, and the first line of her song. Around 1664, the Restoration playwright William Davenant (who fancied himself Shakespeare''s artisitic heir) obtained the rights to "Macbeth" from the King''s Men and based his text on their script prepared for performance. Davenant''s version expands the "etc." of the Folio''s stage direction into a whole song by Hecate and the other witches before the Second Witch''s line about pricking "thumbs." In 1778, Middleton''s"The Witch" was finally published (it had been unsuccessful and had remained only in manuscript since the 1610s) and scholars and editors began questioning the authorship of the Hecate scenes in Macbeth.

\r\n

Davenant''s version of this section of IV.1, included in many editions of "Macbeth," reads:

\r\n

HECATE
O, well done! I commend your pains,
And every one shall share i’ th’ gains.
And now about the cauldron sing
Like elves and fairies in a ring,
Enchanting all that you put in.
Music and a song.
HECATE
Black spirits and white,
Red spirits and gray
Mingle, mingle, mingle,
You that mingle may.
FOURTH WITCH
Tiffin, Tiffin,
Keep it stiff in.
FIFTH WITCH
Firedrake Pucky,
Make it lucky.
HECATE
Liar, Robin,
You must bob in.
CHORUS
Around, around, around, about, about,
All ill come running in, all good keep out.
FOURTH WITCH
Here’s the blood of a bat.
HECATE
O put in that, put in that.
FIFTH WITCH
Here’s lizard’s brain.
HECATE
Put in a grain.
FOURTH WITCH
Here’s juice of a toad, here’s oil of adder,
That will make the charm grow madder.
FIFTH WITCH
Put in all these, ‘twill raise the stench.
HECATE
Nay, here’s three ounces of a red-haired wench.
CHORUS
Around, around, around, about, about,
All ill come running in, all good keep out.


'

I commend your pains;   /  And every one shall share i'' the gains;   /  And now about the cauldron sing,   /  Live elves and fairies in a ring,   /  Enchanting all that you put in.   /  Music and a song: ''Black spirits,'' & c HECATE retires

text:
'A very famous quotation from this play, used to announce some impending doom. "Something Wicked This Way Comes" was used by Ray Bradbury as a title for a horror/fantasy novel about a sinister carnival. The novel was adapted into a movie in 1983.
'
quote: 'By the pricking of my thumbs,   /  Something wicked this way comes.

text:
'The "deed with no name" of the witches echoes Macbeth''s inability throughout the play to spell out his treason and crime. Things done in darkness, outside of human and divine eye, things with no name abound in this play, adding to the general tone of supernatural unease.
'
quote: 'What is''t you do?   /  ALL A deed without a name.

text:
'From a theological point of view, Macbeth is now engaging in the dangerous practice of "conjuration," or invoking evil spirits for the express purpose of asking them questions, a practice expressly forbidden by orthodox religion. Although Macbeth might have been able to pass off his first encounter with the witches as accidental, now he has descended into their space and is engaging them of his own volition. "That which you profess" means their religion, and ultimately is an oblique reference to the devil, which is contrasted with increasing references to his enemies'' piety.
'
quote: 'I conjure you, by that which you profess,   /  Howe''er you come to know it, answer me:

text:
'A bombastic speech about Macbeth''s total lack of care for his kingdom in pursuit of his selfish obsession. This sounds suspiciously like the bragging of reckless tyrants in Marlowe''s plays (e.g., Tamburlaine)--most audience members, familiar with that playwright''s popular spectacles, would have recognized Macbeth''s descent into tyrannical madness.
'
quote: 'Though you untie the winds and let them fight   /  Against the churches; though the yesty waves   /  Confound and swallow navigation up;   /  Though bladed corn be lodged and trees blown down;   /  Though castles topple on their warders'' heads;   /  Though palaces and pyramids do slope   /  Their heads to their foundations; though the treasure   /  Of nature''s germens tumble all together,   /  Even till destruction sicken; answer me   /  To what I ask you.

text:
'Conjuration and witchcraft were described by early modern writers in terms similar to contemporary writings about addiction. The witches have gotten Macbeth hooked on unholy prophecy by giving him a free sample in Act I, and now that he''s actively looking for them, they offer him a more dangerous kick--direct contact with evil spirits or demons (though Shakespeare is purposefully ambiguous and stops short from bringing onstage the devil himself). The comparison between witchcraft and addiction to drugs in particular was recently explored on the 6th season of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" (2001-2), when Buffy''s friend Willow became "addicted" to magic.


'
quote: 'Say, if thou''dst rather hear it from our mouths,   /  Or from our masters?   /  MACBETH Call ''em; let me see ''em.

text:
'These eerie apparitions show Shakespeare taking advantage of the popular special effects available at the time to dazzle the crowds. In Shakespeare''s hands, these gimmicks are used to further the uncanny plot and not for mere spectacle.


Henry Fuseli, Macbeth Consulting the Vision of the Armed Head (1793-1794).
'
quote: 'Thunder. First Apparition: an armed Head

text:
'Once summoned, evil spirits had to be dismissed by the conjurer. The actor playing Macbeth should probably be made to perform some kind of mysterious gesture at this point.
'
quote: 'Dismiss me.

text:
'Stages in Shakespeare''s time had a standard trap door that was used for many purposes, one of which was to bring supernatural characters in and out of the stage mid-scene. Shakespeare was fond of this feature and would often incorporate it into his plots.
'
quote: 'Descends

text:
'Conjuring, even in jest as part of a play, was considered dangerous business at the time. Shakespeare is careful to explicitly maintain the ambiguity of the spirits and apparitions that result from Macbeth''s invocation.

It is no accident that Macbeth and Marlowe''s Dr. Faustus, both staging acts of unholy conjuration, have developed over the centuries a reputation for being "cursed." Superstitious actors to this day refuse to name the play or its lead character offstage, referring to it by the euphemism "the Scottish play."
'
quote: 'Whate''er thou art,

text:
'The bloody baby, fittingly, makes a prophecy related to childbirth. This emboldens Macbeth into believing he is invincible, but he doesn''t understand that it is in fact a riddle, and he will only receive the answer moments before being killed in combat later in the play.
'
quote: 'laugh to scorn   /  The power of man, for none of woman born   /  Shall harm Macbeth.

text:
'The crowned child''s prophecy also makes Macbeth sure of his invincibility, though, like the previous one, it is also in fact a riddle that won''t be understood or deciphered by the tyrant until it is too late for him. In a sense, by subverting the natural order with the murder of Duncan, Macbeth has created the circumstances of his own overthrow and any prophecy about unnatural marvels (like a wood going up a hill) should make him uneasy.
'
quote: 'Macbeth shall never vanquish''d be until   /  Great Birnam wood to high Dunsinane hill   /  Shall come against him.

text:
'The stage directions in Hamlet form a kind of shadow drama to the action of the play; they are one of the pleasures that Hamlet offers its readers and denies its live audiences.  The big fish in the stage direction pond is, of course, "Exit Ghost," about which more will be said.
'

text:
'Though the Second Quarto gave this line to Horatio, the Folio gives it to Marcellus.  Horatio - Hamlet''s skeptical friend - would not be the first one to mention the ghost among his friends.  In fact, in line 1.1.29, Horation dismisses Marcellus and Bernardo.  "Tush tush, ''twill not appear."  He''s wrong, but you have to admire him for trying to hang onto reality just one second more, before things really start to get weird. 
'

text:
'Here is an important moment of exposition.  We learn that Horatio is not a guard (he is a school friend of Hamlet''s) and that the "dreaded sight" has appeared twice.  In some ways, the audience too has been "entreated along."  How many eyes have to see something before it is real?
'
quote: 'entreated

text:
'It was believed in Elizabethan England that a ghost would speak only if spoken too.  It helped if the interlocutor knew Latin, the language of exorcism, so that in case of emergency the evil spirit could be banished (OC).  It sounds funny, but it is revealing of Horatio''s position in the politics of the play: not quite with the guards, or the ghost, or even Hamlet himself.
'
quote: 'speak

text:
'Another expositional tidbit that tells us about Horatio''s character.  Though the guards have tried on several occasions to make him believe their story about the ghost, Horatio has as many times refused to hear them.
'
quote: 'again

text:
'Here is a spectacular instance of action completing a thought.  If Bernardo had continued his speech, he would have said "the ghost entered."  Instead, we bring the action to the present and the play begins in earnest, with the dramatic present (enter ghost) taking over from the exposition ("last night of all"). 
'
quote: 'Enter

text:
'For readers who aren''t familiar with the story of Hamlet: Hamlet''s father, the king of Denmark, has died mysteriously before the play begins, and his brother Claudius has become king.  "The king that''s dead" identifies the ghost as Hamlet''s father, whereas "the king that''s living" would be Claudius.
'
quote: 'king that''s dead.

text:
'Let''s take the opportunity to mention here that Shakespeare was a really good playwright.  By having Horatio say, essentially, "I''m scared as hell," Shakespeare makes us scared.  Keep in mind that Horatio has been the calm, level-headed character up until this point.  To have the guy who says "everything''s under control" suddenly shriek and hide under a rock is very disconcerting indeed.
'
quote: 'like: it

text:
'"As thou art to thyself" is never so simple in Shakespeare.  We''ll see later on instance in which Hamlet seems very unlike himself - or can be one thing and its opposite at the same moment.  (Recall Lear''s line, "Who is he can tell me who I am?" etc.)
'
quote: 'thou art to thyself:

text:
'The problem of interpreting the supernatural recurs and recurs in Shakespeare.  Here, Horatio will have to figure out what it means that the ghost is appearing.  For other instances of augury look at Julius Caesar (in which a priest sacrifices a cat and finds its heart missing) and Lear, which is set during a long and brutal thunderstorm.  And don''t forget the witches in Macbeth...
'

text:
'Horatio gives the backstory to the play''s main military conflict.  Hamlet\\''s father, King Hamlet, killed Fortinbras of Norway in a battle.  Now Fortinbras''s son, Young Fortinbras, is out for his revenge: two sons at odds over the deeds of their fathers.  Could it be, asks Horatio, that the appearance of the ghost presages an explosion between Hamlet and young Fortinbras?
'

'

text:
'...and we''re back. Horatio knows that the ghost could "blast him" - affect him with its power - but he wants to know what it''s up to, and so decides that it''s worth his while to get in its way.  Part of the effect comes from the juxtaposition of abstract ghostly concerns - "stay illusion" - with practical concerns of the state - "do you, um, know anything that''s going to happen in Denmark in the next week or so?"
'

text:
'Marcellus knows where to find Hamlet because Claudius will today announce his marriage to Hamlet''s mother, Queen Gertrude, and the whole court will be in attendance.  Just as Claudius is doing his best to erase the memory of King Hamlet, Horatio will have to report to Prince Hamlet that his father refuses to be forgotten. 
'

text:
'Welcome to Hamlet - possibly the greatest play ever written and the source of every quote and book title you can think of. Get comfortable, because it''s also the longest of Shakespeare''s plays.
'
quote: 'SCENE

text:
'Here is the villain Claudius doing his villainous best to convince everyone that he feels bad about killing his brother and marrying his widow.  For someone whose heart is "in grief, " though, Claudius is suspiciously composed.  His sentences are complex, he references proverbs (see notes in any good edition - Arden, Oxford - for more), he deals systematically with matters personal and political.  It''s true Shakespeare''s verse is always beautiful, but for examples of characters experiencing true grief we have to look elsewhere.  To see just how flat Claudius''s "grief" is, look at Othello''s "smote him thus" speech, Hamlet''s Yorick speech, and others.
'
quote: 'KING CLAUDIUS

text:
'This stage direction has given Shakespeare scholars and theater directors much trouble. A "glass" here most likely means a mirror (a "looking glass"), and it is supposed to evoke the mysterious "scrying glasses" used by clairvoyants and other occultists in Shakespeare''s time. But in terms of stage practice it is unclear exactly what this glass is supposed to mirror. Macbeth''s next speech seems to imply that the mirror is pointed at the line of kings, therefore producing  the effect of an even longer line. But scholars have suggested that pehaps Macbeth was devised as a "royal play" and the mirror then pointed at the courtly audience, and at King James and his heirs in particular.
'
quote: 'A show of Eight Kings, the last with a glass in his hand; GHOST OF BANQUO following

text:
'Shakespeare would have known from his readings in Scottish history that Banquo was considered an ancestor of the house of Stuart, King James'' dynasty. The effect with the mirror and this line are very likely a courtly compliment telling the royal audience that Banquo''s line, through James, will extend forever. (The compliment, of course, sidesteps the thorny issue of the origin of the vision--most likely a demonic apparation!)
'
quote: 'will the line stretch out to the crack of doom?

text:
'This is taken to be an allusion to King James having become king of England as well as of Scotland.
'
quote: 'and some I see   /  That two-fold balls and treble scepters carry:

text:
'After Macbeth''s horror at the vision, this cheerful speech seems out of place.  Scholars consider it one of the non-Shakesperean revisions to this scene, adding another popular song-and-dance routine to the otherwise gloomy play.
'
quote: 'Ay, sir, all this is so: but why   /  Stands Macbeth thus amazedly?   /  Come, sisters, cheer we up his sprites,   /  And show the best of our delights:   /  I''ll charm the air to give a sound,   /  While you perform your antic round:   /  That this great king may kindly say,   /  Our duties did his welcome pay.   /  Music. The witches dance and then vanish, with HECATE

text:
'Macbeth is damning himself. After the bad news of the show of kings, this is the turning point for his character--he now knows he''s doomed and, though he''s overconfident that no mortal can defeat him (because of the first two apparitions), from this point onwards he conducts himself as a tyrant bent on self-destruction.
'
quote: 'And damn''d all those that trust them!

text:
'Convinced of his own doom, Macbeth has finally become resolute and decisive. This newfound impulsiveness makes him the kind of man that Lady Macbeth had been wishing for in the first acts of the play, but Macbeth''s rise to full manhood is paradoxically simultaneous with his wife''s descent into madness.
'
quote: 'from this moment   /  The very firstlings of my heart shall be   /  The firstlings of my hand. And even now,   /  To crown my thoughts with acts, be it thought and done:   /  The castle of Macduff I will surprise;   /  Seize upon Fife; give to the edge o'' the sword   /  His wife, his babes, and all unfortunate souls   /  That trace him in his line. No boasting like a fool;   /  This deed I''ll do before this purpose cool.

text:
'He lacks the natural feelings that would have prevented him from leaving. This is the flipside to Lady Macbeth''s accusation that Macbeth had too much of the milk of human kindness.
'
quote: 'wants the natural touch:

text:
'Ross'' description of political turmoil would have resonated with early modern audiences, particular those in London who dealt with court and government figures. A state of permanent tension among courtly factions was common and Ross'' expressions reveal the anxieties of citizens and courtiers.
'
quote: 'I dare not speak   /  much further;   /  But cruel are the times, when we are traitors   /  And do not know ourselves, when we hold rumour   /  From what we fear, yet know not what we fear,   /  But float upon a wild and violent sea   /  Each way and move.

text:
'The Gospel According to Matthew (21.6) had Jesus praise the piety and wisdom found in "the mouth of babes." This scene is uncharacteristically unsubtle for Shakespeare, using the trite strategy of creating sympathy with an innocent child to emphasize the enormity of Macbeth''s cruelty. (Children in general don''t come to good ends in Shakespeare''s plays. They are also annoyingly precocious and bratty--see the "princes in the tower" in "Richard III" or the insufferable Mamilius in "Winter''s Tale").
'
quote: 'And what will you do now? How will you live?   /  Son As birds do, mother.

text:
'This kind of quick back and forth dialogue leading to a punchline that elaborates on the language of the exchange was a device that Shakespeare had developed throughout his career, particularly in the comedies (see "Comedy of Errors" and "Taming of the Shrew"), and the scenes involving clowns and jesters (see "Merchant of Venice," "King Lear," and also the Porter section earlier in this play, II.3).
'
quote: 'Was my father a traitor, mother?   /  LADY MACDUFF Ay, that he was.   /  Son What is a traitor?   /  LADY MACDUFF Why, one that swears and lies.   /  Son And be all traitors that do so?   /  LADY MACDUFF Every one that does so is a traitor, and must be hanged.   /  Son And must they all be hanged that swear and lie?   /  LADY MACDUFF Every one.   /  Son Who must hang them?   /  LADY MACDUFF Why, the honest men.   /  Son Then the liars and swearers are fools,   /  for there are liars and swearers enow to beat   /  the honest men and hang up them.

text:
'In the Shakespearean universe, the child''s precocious banter pretty much guarantees an early grave for him.
'
quote: 'If he were dead, you''ld weep for   /  him: if you would not, it were a good sign   /  that I should quickly have a new father.   /  LADY MACDUFF Poor prattler, how thou talk''st!

text:
'This kind of half-baked social commentary was standard in the early modern period. The whole scene is sententious, perhaps to quickly sketch the characters of Lady Macduff and her son before disposing of them.
'
quote: 'I am in this earthly world; where to do harm   /  Is often laudable, to do good sometime   /  Accounted dangerous folly:

text:
'A "fry" was a young fish (thus the modern expression "small fry"). Shakespeare cut his tragic teeth on Senecan tragedies such as "Titus Andronicus," chockful of gore and onstage violence. This graphic infanticide would not have endeared the playwright to those obsessed with the "Classic" or "Aristotelian" tradition (the French tragedians of the second half of the 17th century, for example), who insisted that all instances of extreme violence occur offstage. (Though these Neoclassicists had no problem with describing those acts in gory detail through the device of a messenger.)
'
quote: 'What, you egg!   /  Stabbing him Young fry of treachery!

text:
'The irony, of course, is that Malcolm doesn''t know what the audience has just witnessed in the previous scene.
'
quote: 'He hath not touch''d you yet.

text:
'Malcolm is shown as wiser than his father, who believed that he could read people''s intentions and character in their faces.
'
quote: 'That which you are my thoughts cannot transpose:   /  Angels are bright still, though the brightest fell;   /  Though all things foul would wear the brows of grace,   /  Yet grace must still look so.

text:
'A play on the similarity of "afeered" (legitimate, confimed) and "afraid." "Title" here means the rightful title to the crown, which belongs to Malcolm "legitimately," though he is "afraid" to claim it by deposing Macbeth.
'
quote: 'The title is affeer''d!

text:
'Malcolm''s self-deprecation is a brilliant stage moment that invariably
fools the audience and aligns it with the confused Macduff, who then
becomes a stand-in for them. Up until this point Malcolm is a rough
sketch--this scene turns him into a Shakespearean hero, one that serves
an identical function as Richmond (the future Henry VII) in "Richard
III."'

text:
'Malcolm''s forecast of his bad kingship allows Shakespeare to insert some mild social commentary that might have resonated with the more politically-minded members of the audience. Still, his critique of "bad kings" is commonplace and vague and absolutely tame compared with the scurrilous topical barbs of fellow playwrights like Ben Jonson.

text:
'Malcolm''s revelation puts an end to the equivocation of the previous conversation. His speech explicitly contrasts him with the "devilish" Macbeth and establishes his virtuous credentials.

quote: 'Devilish Macbeth   /  By many of these trains hath sought to win me   /  Into his power, and modest wisdom plucks me   /  From over-credulous haste: but God above   /  Deal between thee and me! for even now   /  I put myself to thy direction, and   /  Unspeak mine own detraction, here abjure   /  The taints and blames I laid upon myself,   /  For strangers to my nature. I am yet   /  Unknown to woman, never was forsworn,   /  Scarcely have coveted what was mine own,   /  At no time broke my faith, would not betray   /  The devil to his fellow and delight   /  No less in truth than life: my first false speaking   /  Was this upon myself: what I am truly,   /  Is thine and my poor country''s to command:

text:
'The English king is Edward the Confessor, later canonized by the Catholic Church as a saint. The Doctor''s intervention is self-explanatory: sick people came to Edward to be cured by his touch--his holiness is added to Malcolm''s virtues, and the upcoming invasion of Scotland is then cast in terms of two clearly defined sides: good/heavenly/Edward & Malcolm vs evil/devilish/Macbeth.

Edward''s healing touch was a real historical reference: in the middle ages many people suffered of scrofula, a kind of tuberculosis that resulted in the inflamation of the lymph nodes. A superstition developed that the king of England could cure those suffering from scrofula (renamed "The King''s Evil") by touching them (there was similar supersition concerning the king of France). In England this cure was traditionally said to have started with Edward the Confessor.

This peculiar--and unsanitary--practice (imagine thousands of sick people, many of them very poor, crowding kings and queens as their only hope for health!) lasted until well into the 18th century. Dr. Samuel Johnson was one of the last people touched by Queen Anne for scrofula, when he was a child in 1712.
'
quote: 'Ay, sir; there are a crew of wretched souls   /  That stay his cure: their malady convinces   /  The great assay of art; but at his touch--   /  Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand--   /  They presently amend.   /  MALCOLM I thank you, doctor.   /  Exit Doctor MACDUFF What''s the disease he means?   /  MALCOLM ''Tis call''d the evil:   /  A most miraculous work in this good king;   /  Which often, since my here-remain in England,   /  I have seen him do. How he solicits heaven,   /  Himself best knows: but strangely-visited people,   /  All swoln and ulcerous, pitiful to the eye,   /  The mere despair of surgery, he cures,   /  Hanging a golden stamp about their necks,   /  Put on with holy prayers: and ''tis spoken,   /  To the succeeding royalty he leaves   /  The healing benediction. With this strange virtue,   /  He hath a heavenly gift of prophecy,   /  And sundry blessings hang about his throne,   /  That speak him full of grace.

text:
'One of many passages in this scene describing the corruption of Macbeth''s Scotland. Notice how the characters define mood and atmosphere by sheer language. Shakespeare''s plays are never too dependant on stage directions or lighting and sound cues: much of the development and change throughout the play is a clever effect produced by language alone.
'
quote: 'It cannot   /  Be call''d our mother, but our grave; where nothing,   /  But who knows nothing, is once seen to smile;   /  Where sighs and groans and shrieks that rend the air   /  Are made, not mark''d; where violent sorrow seems   /  A modern ecstasy; the dead man''s knell   /  Is there scarce ask''d for who; and good men''s lives   /  Expire before the flowers in their caps,   /  Dying or ere they sicken.

text:
'After all the debate between Macbeth and his wife earlier in the play, now Macduff in his grief is presented as the ultimate example of manhood.

His vengeful stoicism impressed the 19th-century poet and critic Samuel Coleridge. "How admirably Macduff''s grief is in harmony with the whole play!," he wrote in 1818.  "It rends, not dissolves, the heart. ''The tune of it goes manly.'' Thus is Shakspere always master of himself and of his subject, -- a genuine Proteus: -- we see all things in him, as images in a calm lake, most distinct, most accurate -- only more splendid, more glorified. This is correctness in the only philosophical sense. But he requires your sympathy and your submission, you must have that recipiency of moral impression without which the purposes and ends of the drama would be frustrated and the absence of which demonstrates an utter want of all imagination, a deadness to that necessary pleasure of being innocently -- shall I say, deluded? -- or rather drawn away from ourselves to the music of noblest thought in harmonious sounds. Happy he, who not only in the public theatre, but in the labours of a profession, and round the light of his own hearth, still carries a heart so pleasure-fraught!"'
quote: 'This tune goes manly.

'"Epicure" in the early modern period was a derogatory term meaning "decadent and soft" (often with effeminate overtones). The word derived from popular perceptions of the teaching of Epicurus, though, like "Machiavellian," its connotations had little to do with the actual teachings of the philosopher in question. According to popular prejudice, when compared to the rough Scots, the English were considered soft.

text:
'This is one of the most famous passages of Macbeth, often quoted by people without realizing that it is in fact a eulogy of sorts for Lady Macbeth. The passage illustrates Macbeth''s descent into a nihilistic acceptance of his fate and his vision of an amoral, random world resonates with the atmospheric universe of "King Lear." (This passage was popular with the Existentialists of the mid-20th century, and famously gave its title to one of Faulkner''s best-known novels).

Out, out, brief candle!   /  Life''s but a walking shadow, a poor player   /  That struts and frets his hour upon the stage   /  And then is heard no more: it is a tale   /  Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury,   /  Signifying nothing.

text:
'Macbeth is both trapped in his castle by the siege, and tied to his destiny by the prophecies. In his predicament, he''s much like the tormented bears used in Shakespeare''s time for popular entertainment. The bears were tied to a stake in a "Bear-baiting Pit" and dogs were thrown at them. This peculiar arena bloodsport (involving gambling) competed with the theater for the entertainment money of Londoners.


Picture of bearbaiting by a 16th-century Italian artist.

'It was considered dishonorable for gentlemen to engage mercenaries ("kerns") in battle. Macbeth uses them because he doesn''t have many loyal followers left. The failed rebellion against Duncan in Act I, defeated by Macbeth, employed these reviled kerns.

text:
'Roman generals and politicians who failed at something were famously supposed to commit suicide by "falling on their own swords," a fact that Shakespeare used in "Julius Caesar" and "Antony and Cleopatra." Macbeth, now completely out of control and released from any sense of conventional honor and morality, laughs at the practice.

text:
'This is a nice theatrical flourish that also serves to show a medieval instance of Anglo-Scottish influence and collaboration, something that King James, interested in uniting his two kingdoms would have appreciated.

Shakespeare was adapting the historical material for dramatic effect. Duncan was a young man when he died in 1040, and he left two children, Malcolm and Donalbain. The historical Duncan was killed in a skirmish by men loyal to Macbeth, who succeeded him. In 1054, the English launched a campaign to depose Macbeth and place another Malcolm (not Duncan''s son) on the throne, but that campaign failed. Three years later, Malcolm (Duncan''s son) managed to defeat and kill Macbeth and a few months later, he masterminded the assassination of Macbeth''s stepson and heir Lulach "The Weakling." Only then he became King Malcolm III of Scotland.
'
quote: 'My thanes and kinsmen,   /  Henceforth be earls, the first that ever Scotland   /  In such an honour named.

text:
'Claudius has already assumed the role of king, and presumes to speak for the entire kingdom.  His thought order is revealing, too:
1. Death of King Hamlet (ll. 1-7)
2. His marriage to Queen Gertrude (ll. 7-14)
3. Back to affairs of state: the demand of Young Fortinbras that Denmark surrender the lands usurped from his father, King Fortinbras (ll.14-)

This is a generational view of the kingdom, beginning with the deceased King, moving to the living King and Queen, and finally to the young rival of the kingdom (and, by inference, to the rival''s rival: Hamlet, our hero). 
'

text:
'Most editors do mark this speech as an aside, but not all.  The case against designating Hamlet''s first words in the play as an aside is clear: the conflict between Claudius and him will only escalate, and there is no reason that Hamlet would want to hide his dislike for Claudius at this early moment.  Claudius''s response - "oh, you''re still sad?" - makes more sense if he''s just heat Hamlet say something sulky and extremely clever.
'

text:
'This line is a play on a proverb - "the nearer in kin the less in kindness," and also a play on the word "kin," which meant "cousin."  "The more closely related to you I become," Hamlet is saying, "the more I hate your guts."  Keep in mind that Hamlet is saying this in front of his mother.

text:
'Hamlet introduces the theme of the inner and the outer, or what I will call from now on the "seeming/being" problem - how things in Hamlet can seem to be one way and really be another (this doesn''t sound deep just yet, but it is.  Stay tuned).  Hamlet is saying that his outward mourning garments are only "trappings" - what''s really going on is inside, hidden from view. 
'

'Hamlet wants to leave Denmark and return to Wittenberg, to university.  Claudius doesn''t want him to.  Why?  It would look bad for the kingdom, Gertrude needs support, Hamlet stands to inherit the throne.  Note that only after his mother entreats him to stay does Hamlet "bend" himself.

text:
'It''s nice to read Shakespeare with a two-volume clothbound OED and magnifying glass on your bedside table.  If you don''t have that, here''s the entry about the "too too" construction in this line:
1602 SHAKES. Ham. I. ii. 129 Oh that this too too solid Flesh would melt. Reduplicated for emphasis: too too (formerly occas. written as one word, toto, totoo, tootoo).    a. Qualifying an adj. or adv.; chiefly in sense 2c. (Very common c1540-1660.)

It may have been common but in the mouth of a good actor it''s unbelievably effecive.  Hamle is literally crawling out of his "too solid" skin.  Actors are often given the direction to differentiate between repeated words or phrases in their scripts.  One may imagine how to interpret the second "too" in a new way.\r\n

'
quote: 'O, that this too too solid flesh would melt   /  Thaw and resolve itself into a dew!

text:
'Hamlet wants to hold on to the memory and nearness of his father.

Cf. the Concordance to Shakespeare, which meticulously lists every instance of interesting words in the plays - how often is "everlasting" used, for example, and where.)

'within a month-- (my mother has married another man and forgotten my father).  It''s hard for Hamlet to finish that sentence, just as it is hard for him to come to terms with what is happening.  (For another such case in Shakespeare look at the "surcease success" line in Macbeth - a thing hard to say and harder still to do  [Greenblatt, lecture].)
'

text:
'This idea obsesses Shakespeare across his canon.  What happens when a character in the extremes of grief or emotion is unable to express what he feels?  Shakespeare didn''t make it up, of course, but he does take it to a new, complicated place, in which characters'' find their inner lives tip increasingly towards chaos as a result of having to keep their outer lives in perfect order.
'
quote: 'But break, my heart; for I must hold my tongue.

text:
'Hamlet is gentle with Horatio.  Keep in mind that Hamlet has just given in to his mother and Claudius and so will not be returning to Wittenberg with Horatio.  To paraphrase 1.2.175: "I may not be able to teach you anything scholarly here, but I will teach you how to drink like a fish," i.e. "we''ll have a good time," OR, "Elsinore is so depressing that we''ll have to drink to stay sane."
'
quote: 'I would not hear your enemy say so,   /  Nor shall you do mine ear that violence,   /  To make it truster of your own report   /  Against yourself: I know you are no truant.   /  But what is your affair in Elsinore?   /  We''ll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.

text:
'Hamlet feels comfortable quibbling on the funeral with Horatio, who offers a sincere apology for the swift turnaround Hamlet has suffered from father''s funeral to mother''s remarriage.  "No," says Hamlet, "it''s not bad - it''s simply economics.  This way we just took the food from the funeral and fed it to our wedding guests."  It''s not true, of course, but it certainly seems that way to Hamlet, and it has metaphorical truth as well.
'
quote: 'I pray thee, do not mock me, fellow-student;   /  I think it was to see my mother''s wedding.   /  HORATIO Indeed, my lord, it follow''d hard upon.   /  HAMLET Thrift, thrift, Horatio! the funeral baked meats   /  Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.

text:
'Hamlet''s father is still part of his waking consciousness, just on the edge of his earthly perceptions.
'
quote: 'Where, my lord?   /  HAMLET In my mind''s eye, Horatio.

text:
'A great Shakespearean reversal:
Hamlet: I''ll never see my father again
Horatio: Not so: he''s back.
'
quote: 'shall not look upon his like again.   /  HORATIO My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.

\r\n    1. The action of wondering or marvelling; wonder, astonishment, surprise. arch.

In a modern movie version we may have a close-op on Hamlet''s face here.

quote: 'Two nights together had these gentlemen,   /  Marcellus and Bernardo, on their watch,   /  In the dead vast and middle of the night,   /  Been thus encounter''d. A figure like your father,   /  Armed at point exactly, cap-a-pe,   /  Appears before them, and with solemn march   /  Goes slow and stately by them: thrice he walk''d   /  By their oppress''d and fear-surprised eyes,   /  Within his truncheon''s length; whilst they, distilled   /  Almost to jelly with the act of fear,   /  Stand dumb and speak not to him. This to me   /  In dreadful secrecy impart they did;   /  And I with them the third night kept the watch;   /  Where, as they had deliver''d, both in time,   /  Form of the thing, each word made true and good,   /  The apparition comes: I knew your father;   /  These hands are not more like.

Hamlet to Horatio, inquiring about his father (paraphrase):

text:
'From OC: "Hell-mouth was a stage property well known to the Elizabethan playgoer...Hamlet is facing the possibility that the Ghost may, in accordance with Protestant thinking of the time, be a devil which has assumed (i.e. appropriated) the body of the dead king."

That''s all very well, but let''s consider something else.  If the ghost indeed were a "usurper," then he would remind us very much of Claudius, who has, in many ways, appropriated the dead king''s identity like a demon.  Shakespeare doesn''t need any of this other-wordly chicanery because he''s already got it in real life, through Claudius.
'

text:
'Laertes doesn''t want his sister to respond to Hamlet''s romantic advances.  The reasons for this would make an interesting paper.  Is Laertes sexually jealous?  Competitive and threatened?  Genuinely concerned for his sister''s emotional well-being?  All of the above? None?
'
quote: 'For Hamlet and the trifling of his favour,   /  Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood,   /  A violet in the youth of primy nature,   /  Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting,   /  The perfume and suppliance of a minute; No more.

text:
'"Hamlet isn''t free to love you unless the state of Denmark condones it - he is prisoner to his political position."

quote: 'Think it no more;   /  For nature, crescent, does not grow alone   /  In thews and bulk, but, as this temple waxes,   /  The inward service of the mind and soul   /  Grows wide withal. Perhaps he loves you now,   /  And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch   /  The virtue of his will: but you must fear,   /  His greatness weigh''d, his will is not his own;   /  For he himself is subject to his birth:   /  He may not, as unvalued persons do,   /  Carve for himself; for on his choice depends   /  The safety and health of this whole state;   /  And therefore must his choice be circumscribed   /  Unto the voice and yielding of that body   /  Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he loves you,   /  It fits your wisdom so far to believe it   /  As he in his particular act and place   /  May give his saying deed; which is no further   /  Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal.

"Little sis, please don''t let Hamlet have access to your virgin vagina." 

Sounds funny, but it''s absolutely true.

text:
'This is quite a funny little exchange.  Laertes lecturse Ophelia on chastity, telling her that it''s safest always to be a little afraid of men.  Ophelia counters by saying that Laertes better practice what he preaches, to which Laerte''s responds "fear me not" - a word-for-word reversal of his advice not ten lines ago!
'
quote: 'safety lies in fear:   /  Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.   /  OPHELIA I shall the effect of this good lesson keep,   /  As watchman to my heart. But, good my brother,   /  Do not, as some ungracious pastors do,   /  Show me the steep and thorny way to heaven;   /  Whiles, like a puff''d and reckless libertine,   /  Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads,   /  And recks not his own rede.   /  LAERTES O, fear me not.

text:
'Polonius, one of the funniest characters in Shakespeare, will remind readers of restoration comedy of Mrs. Malaprop-esque characters, those sympathetic men and women who are often well-meaning but who simply can''t get put together a perfect sentence or even use a complicated word correctly.  In the (much-underappreciated!) Michael Almereyda movie of Hamlet, Bill Murray played Polonius.  Not bad casting choice, all things considered.
'
quote: 'LORD POLONIUS

text:
'Okay, so we just gave Polonius kind of a bad rap.  This sincere and beautiful send-off speech to a son going a broad is loving and lovely.  While there is something funny about a father distilling a lifetime of knowledge (and the kind of knowledge best conveyed by example) in a 20-line speech to his son, by the time he gets to the central point - the ubiquitous line "to thine own self be true" -we''re on Polonius''s side.  This is no accident.  We have to like him for a key moment in the play to be effective, as will be seen.
'
quote: 'Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar.   /  Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried,   /  Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel;   /  But do not dull thy palm with entertainment   /  Of each new-hatch''d, unfledged comrade. Beware   /  Of entrance to a quarrel, but being in,   /  Bear''t that the opposed may beware of thee.   /  Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice;   /  Take each man''s censure, but reserve thy judgment.   /  Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy,   /  But not express''d in fancy; rich, not gaudy;   /  For the apparel oft proclaims the man,   /  And they in France of the best rank and station   /  Are of a most select and generous chief in that.   /  Neither a borrower nor a lender be;   /  For loan oft loses both itself and friend,   /  And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.   /  This above all: to thine ownself be true,   /  And it must follow, as the night the day,   /  Thou canst not then be false to any man.   /  Farewell: my blessing season this in thee!

1602 SHAKES. Ham. I. iii. 100 O. He hath my Lord of late made many tenders Of his affection to me. P... Doe you beleeue his tenders, as you call them?

text:
'And out comes hilarious Polonius, delivering lines that every parent delivers to every child at some point, albeit in different forms.
'
quote: 'I do not know, my lord, what I should think.   /  LORD POLONIUS Marry, I''ll teach you:

text:
'Polonius delivering his treatise on young male lovers.  Essentially, "men will say anything when they want to sleep with you."  The verb "lend" is funny here, too, because it suggests that payback time must come eventually, and the tongue must make good on its debt to the soul by providing love or at the very least love-making.
'
quote: 'Ay, springes to catch woodcocks. I do know,   /  When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul   /  Lends the tongue vows:

'Another instance of the seeming/being question.
'
quote: 'Giving more light than heat, extinct in both,   /  Even in their promise, as it is a-making,   /  You must not take for fire.

text:
'Polonius is described as a member of the Danish Privy Council, but the presence of business words in his lexicon reveals that he has one eye towards commerce and has been financialy successful.
'
