text: 'In England, Danes and other Scandinavians were reputed to be notorious carousers.'
quote: 'though I am native here   /  And to the manner born, it is a custom   /  More honour''d in the breach than the observance.   /  This heavy-headed revel east and west   /  Makes us traduced and tax''d of other nations:   /  They clepe us drunkards, and with swinish phrase   /  Soil our addition; and indeed it takes   /  From our achievements, though perform''d at height,   /  The pith and marrow of our attribute.

text:
'Here Hamlet and his friends are venturing out of the safety of the castle to glimpse the ghost.  Symbolically, this is the stage of tragedy that Goerthe would call the "departing" - the act of leaving your more desirable situation for a more dangerous one, in which you are implicated forcefully and against your will.
'
quote: 'Enter HAMLET, HORATIO, and MARCELLUS

text:
'This confusion as to the exact time of night ("is it 12 yet?") helps to establish the kind of "supra-temporal" space in which we will be for the rest of the scene: the kind of space in which the living and the dead can be alive together is surely outside of normal time.
'
quote: 'I think it lacks of twelve.   /  HAMLET No, it is struck.   /  HORATIO Indeed? I heard it not:

text:
'The kind of excess that probably wouldn''t have been permitted under King Hamlet, who was a serious man and a military leader.  The contrast between the two men - Claudius as a party animal and King Hamlet as more disciplined - will surface again when the ghost enters (he''s not exactly wearing a party hat) and later on in the bedroom scene between Hamlet and Gertrude.
'
quote: 'The king doth wake to-night and takes his rouse,   /  Keeps wassail, and the swaggering up-spring reels;   /  And, as he drains his draughts of Rhenish down,   /  The kettle-drum and trumpet thus bray out   /  The triumph of his pledge.

text:
'To drink the whole shot (or whatever) in a single cup (OC).
'
quote: 'his pledge.

text:
'These digressive lines appear only in Q2 - they vanish in the Folio text.  Because the Q2 text was published based on performance, it''s conceivable that this speech was added because a costume change or other stage business was necessary during this time, and Shakespeare had to fill a few extra seconds (Greenblatt introduces this possibility, though does not necessarily buy it).  At any rate, here we get a pretty stock satire of the heavy-drinking Danes that interrupts the flow of action just when things are heating up. 

Close readers may want to keep their eyes on the word "mole," to which we will return.
'
quote: 'This heavy-headed revel east and west   /  Makes us traduced and tax''d of other nations:   /  They clepe us drunkards, and with swinish phrase   /  Soil our addition; and indeed it takes   /  From our achievements, though perform''d at height,   /  The pith and marrow of our attribute.   /  So, oft it chances in particular men,   /  That for some vicious mole of nature in them,   /  As, in their birth--wherein they are not guilty,   /  Since nature cannot choose his origin--   /  By the o''ergrowth of some complexion,   /  Oft breaking down the pales and forts of reason,   /  Or by some habit that too much o''er-leavens   /  The form of plausive manners, that these men,   /  Carrying, I say, the stamp of one defect,   /  Being nature''s livery, or fortune''s star,--   /  Their virtues else--be they as pure as grace,   /  As infinite as man may undergo--   /  Shall in the general censure take corruption   /  From that particular fault: the dram of eale   /  Doth all the noble substance of a doubt   /  To his own scandal.

text:
'"Burst" is an interesting verb to use.  Hamlet is obsessed with questions of the physical powers of ignorance and knowledge: can knowledge or its absence do something to your body?  "Let me not burst in ignorance" suggests that ignorance is forcing itself out of Hamlet, pulling him apart just as his father''s dead bones must have pulled apart his "cerements" (a made-up Shakespearean word for grave clothes - OC).
'
quote: 'Let me not burst in ignorance; but tell   /  Why thy canonized bones, hearsed in death,   /  Have burst their cerements;

text:
'Full armor.
'
quote: 'complete steel

text:
'One of the first moments to hint at Hamlet''s suicidal tendencies.  "I do not set my life in a pin''s fee" isn''t outright self-annihilating, of course, but it does suggest Hamlet''s feeling that his life is somehow secondary to a number of other concerns - or perhaps it''s that the corrupt world makes life itself irrelevant and desperate by nature.
'
quote: 'Why, what should be the fear?   /  I do not set my life in a pin''s fee;   /  And for my soul, what can it do to that,   /  Being a thing immortal as itself?   /  It waves me forth again: I''ll follow it.

text:
'People were afraid of suicide and sudden death in the 16th century.  Suicide would land you in hell straight away, while sudden death would prohibit you from entering heaven without detouring through purgatory (OC).  Horatio''s concerns are legitimate - if the ghost is a devil he may tempt Hamlet to kill himself (by jumping off a cliff, etc.) and therefore be damned to hell. 
'
quote: 'What if it tempt you toward the flood, my lord,   /  Or to the dreadful summit of the cliff   /  That beetles o''er his base into the sea,   /  And there assume some other horrible form,   /  Which might deprive your sovereignty of reason   /  And draw you into madness? think of it:   /  The very place puts toys of desperation,   /  Without more motive, into every brain   /  That looks so many fathoms to the sea   /  And hears it roar beneath.

text:
'Clever.  "If you stop me from going to see this ghost, then I will kill you and you will become a ghost yourself."
'
quote: 'I''ll make a ghost of him that lets me!

text:
'Much can be made of this line.  At the time the play was written, Elizabeth''s monarchy was in decline and there was a feeling in England that something was indeed "rotten" at the very top of society.  Strict definitions of revenge also require some kind of "rotten-ness" to function, because the mechanisms by which revenge can legally be obtained - i.e. by appeal to the government - must somehow cease to function.  Hamlet doesn''t have the option of going through the state to get his revenge because the state itself is the source of the problem (Greenblatt).
'
quote: 'Something is rotten in the state of Denmark.

text:
'The ghost responds to Hamlet''s command with another command.  Who is really in charge here?
'
quote: 'I''ll go no further.   /  Ghost Mark me.

text:
'The first hint that the ghost is in purgatory.  England under the Anglican Church repudiated the Catholic notion of purgatory, and so the ghost (which is to say, Shakespeare) can''t say outright where he is (Greenblatt).
'
quote: 'My hour is almost come,   /  When I to sulphurous and tormenting flames   /  Must render up myself.

text:
'There are pages to be written about this speech.  We''re back in a discussion of purgatory, and back in taboo territory - "I am forbid to tell the secrets of my prison-house."  Shakespeare finds a way to make purgatory even scarier by omitting detail, by having the ghost suggest how scary his tale would be if he could tell it. 

Why is Shakespeare so obsessed with the specific stages of the afterlife?  One hint is that his father, John Shakespeare, that most famous of glovemakers, died not long before the play was written.  A letter has been found from John asking William to pray for his salvation after his death.  The theme of the demanding dead - those persons who still want something from you after they''ve expired - is very alive (no pun intented) for Shakespeare at this moment (around 1600).  Shakespeare''s 11-year-old son Hamnet had also died not long before the writing of the play (Greenblatt).
'
quote: 'I am thy father''s spirit,   /  Doom''d for a certain term to walk the night,   /  And for the day confined to fast in fires,   /  Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature   /  Are burnt and purged away. But that I am forbid   /  To tell the secrets of my prison-house,   /  I could a tale unfold whose lightest word   /  Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood,   /  Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres,   /  Thy knotted and combined locks to part   /  And each particular hair to stand on end,   /  Like quills upon the fretful porpentine:   /  But this eternal blazon must not be   /  To ears of flesh and blood. List, list, O, list!   /  If thou didst ever thy dear father love--

text:
'The ghost is really creeping Hamlet out here.  Murder is always foul, but this one is "strange and unnatural."  What makes it unnatural is the family betrayal, the sex (Gertrude remarried), and the method. 
'
quote: 'strange and unnatural.

text:
'The ghost isn''t without his sense of humor.  "I find thee smart," he says, "but then again you''d have to be a real idiot to misunderstand this."
'
quote: 'And duller shouldst thou be than the fat weed   /  That roots itself in ease on Lethe wharf,   /  Wouldst thou not stir in this.

text:
'"O my prophetic soul" is a strange line.  Does Hamlet mean that he knew all along of Claudius''s fratricide?  The editors of the Oxford say no, that he is only referring to his intuitive dislike of Claudius.  Very likely, but it is nevertheless revealing of Hamlet the character that his first reaction, upon hearing of his father''s murder, is not "I''ll avenge you" or even "How nauseating," but rather, "I have a particularly keen intuition."
'
quote: '''Tis given out that, sleeping in my orchard,   /  A serpent stung me; so the whole ear of Denmark   /  Is by a forged process of my death   /  Rankly abused: but know, thou noble youth,   /  The serpent that did sting thy father''s life   /  Now wears his crown.   /  HAMLET O my prophetic soul! My uncle!

text: 'Here is a theme of great interest to Shaksepeare: the ease with which gifts (wit, talent, intellect) can be used for immoral purposes just as they can be used for moral ones.  Claudius is clever - he''s got "wit and gifts" - but he puts that cleverness to work in conniving ways.  Click on the link to Lear 1.2 for Edmund''s (the bastard son of Gloucester''s) wonderful monologue about bastardy, jealousy, and the possibilities of talent.'
quote: 'Ay, that incestuous, that adulterate beast,   /  With witchcraft of his wit, with traitorous gifts,--   /  O wicked wit and gifts, that have the power   /  So to seduce!--won

text:
'"Gifts" is literally "presents," but when put alongside "wit" it takes on its quibble meaning: "talent."
'
quote: 'gifts,--

text:
'Part of the specific cruelty of King Hamlet''s murder is that he is killed in his sleep, and so is unable to undergo the last rites that would have speeded his passage to heaven.  We''ll see later on, when Hamlet has a chance to "dispatch" Claudius while he''s praying, the importance of the dying man''s state at the moment of death to the state of the soul in the afterlife.
'
quote: 'Sleeping within my orchard,   /  My custom always of the afternoon,   /  Upon my secure hour thy uncle stole,   /  With juice of cursed hebenon in a vial,   /  And in the porches of my ears did pour   /  The leperous distilment; whose effect   /  Holds such an enmity with blood of man   /  That swift as quicksilver it courses through   /  The natural gates and alleys of the body,   /  And with a sudden vigour doth posset   /  And curd, like eager droppings into milk,   /  The thin and wholesome blood: so did it mine;   /  And a most instant tetter bark''d about,   /  Most lazar-like, with vile and loathsome crust,   /  All my smooth body.   /  Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother''s hand   /  Of life, of crown, of queen, at once dispatch''d:   /  Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,   /  Unhousel''d, disappointed, unanel''d,   /  No reckoning made, but sent to my account   /  With all my imperfections on my head:   /  O, horrible! O, horrible! most horrible!

text:
'Hamlet and King Hamlet both are obsessed by the royal bed and its occupants.  Incest and the fantasy of Gertrude making love to Claudius is an image that will drive much of the psychological action of the play.  Note that the line "if thou hast nature in thee" precedes the image of the unnatural marriage bed.  "Nature" here means "normal human emotion," but also implies Nature, capital "N," meaning the natural order of marital, reproductive sex, that Claudius and Gertrude are subverting by sleeping with one another.
'
quote: 'royal bed

text:
'In his "Hamlet in Purgatory," Greenblatt locates the move from traditional revenge tragedy to Shakespearen revenge tragedy in those these two words: "Remember me."  Whereas a normal revenge plot, like the play on which Hamlet is based (a 12th century Icelandic saga - available at your favorite bookstore!), the plot spirals outward, as the hero exacts his vengeance on more and more implicated people.  In this play, the plot moves inward, as the action moves to Hamlet''s process of remembering his father rather than, say, whittling little wood spikes to secure a giant net over the court of Iceland, as he does in the 12th century epic mentioned above.
'
quote: 'Adieu, adieu! Hamlet, remember me.

text:
'Keep in mind the name of Shakespeare''s London theater, The Globe, and its notoriously rowdy audiences.  "This distracted globe" could also mean, then, "Shut up in the back, there!  We''re doing a play."  If we buy that (as the Norton Shakespeare does), then Hamlet could be saying "as long as there is theater - as long as Hamlet is performed - you, the character King Hamlet, will be remembered."
'
quote: 'globe.

text:
'"That one may smile and smile and be a villain."  Here is Hamlet standing amazed at the seeming/being question, which is more and more perplexing the more you think about.  Note how Hamlet''s verse gets more and more broken ("My tables / My tables") as he tries to organize his thoughts, and then as he writes them on his tablets to record them on his "tables" - in his notebook (tablets). 
'
quote: 'That one may smile, and smile, and be a villain;   /  At least I''m sure it may be so in Denmark:   /  Writing So, uncle, there you are. Now to my word;   /  It is ''Adieu, adieu! remember me.''   /  I have sworn ''t.

text:
'A quibble, if we take it as such: "errant knight/arrant knave," meaning, "wandering knight/downright knave."
'
quote: 'arrant knave.

text:
'The ghost is literally underneath the stage, but aiding Hamlet nonetheless.
'
quote: '[Beneath] Swear.

text:
'Recall that the ghost is at work under the stage.  From OED:

Mole, n.
II. Extended uses.\r\n    3. a. A person who works underground; a person who works in darkness or in secrecy.

(this line of Hamlet''s is given as a textual example.)
'
quote: 'mole!

text:
'"Your" is a Q2 divergence from F''s "our," which turns the sense of the speech.  "Our" means that Hamlet, a student and rationalist, joins Horatio in trying to reconcile this supernatural occurence with his natural philosophy.  "Your" loses the sense of joint struggle.  Most editors now (including Norton''s) use "our" rather than "your."
'
quote: 'your philosophy.

text:
'Hamlet hatches his plot: to pretend to be mad (to put on an "antic disposition").  For his plan to work, these two must keep quiet.  The ghost chimes in again from his sub-stage lair.
'
quote: 'But come;   /  Here, as before, never, so help you mercy,   /  How strange or odd soe''er I bear myself,   /  As I perchance hereafter shall think meet   /  To put an antic disposition on,   /  That you, at such times seeing me, never shall,   /  With arms encumber''d thus, or this headshake,   /  Or by pronouncing of some doubtful phrase,   /  As ''Well, well, we know,'' or ''We could, an if we would,''   /  Or ''If we list to speak,'' or ''There be, an if they might,''   /  Or such ambiguous giving out, to note   /  That you know aught of me: this not to do,   /  So grace and mercy at your most need help you, Swear.

text:
'Polonius, missing Laertes (his son) and wanting news of him, prepares his man Reynaldo to travel to France and see what he''s up to.
'
quote: 'Enter POLONIUS and REYNALDO LORD POLONIUS Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo.   /  REYNALDO I will, my lord.   /  LORD POLONIUS You shall do marvellous wisely, good Reynaldo,   /  Before you visit him, to make inquire   /  Of his behavior.

text:
'Polonius likes to spy.  We''ll see him use the same tactical processes when he arranges to spy on Hamlet.
'
quote: 'Inquire me first what Danskers are in Paris;   /  And how, and who, what means, and where they keep,   /  What company, at what expense; and finding   /  By this encompassment and drift of question   /  That they do know my son, come you more nearer   /  Than your particular demands will touch it:   /  Take you, as ''twere, some distant knowledge of him;   /  As thus, ''I know his father and his friends,   /  And in part him: '' do you mark this, Reynaldo?

text:
'In other words, "slander Laertes to strangers and then gauge, by their reactions, whether or not Laertes is guilty of the charges you have invented against him."
'
quote: 'Marry, sir, here''s my drift;   /  And I believe, it is a fetch of wit:   /  You laying these slight sullies on my son,   /  As ''twere a thing a little soil''d i'' the working, Mark you,   /  Your party in converse, him you would sound,   /  Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes   /  The youth you breathe of guilty, be assured   /  He closes with you in this consequence;   /  ''Good sir,'' or so, or ''friend,'' or ''gentleman,''   /  According to the phrase or the addition   /  Of man and country.

text:
'One of Polonius''s funniest lines.  There may be an interesting essay in the comparison between Polonius''s methods to catch a "carp of truth" with a "bait of falsehood" and Hamlet''s staging of the play for Claudius and his court.  Hamlet and Polonius both lay on a "carp" (they invent a story that bears some relation to reality and present it in public), and see whether or not anyone takes the "bait" (they watch people''s reactions to see whether or not their suspicions are founded).  One can''t take this comparious too far, of course, because Hamlet is certain that he''s right and Polonius is more of a speculator.  Be that as it may, though, the two have eerily similar minds for observation and subterfuge.
'
quote: 'Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth:

text:
'Ophelia enters obviously distraught.  As we''ll see in a moment, she''s been disconcertingly mishandled by the mad-seeming Hamlet.
'
quote: 'Enter OPHELIA

text:
'Polonius, not Ophelia, is the first to suggest this thesis ("he''s just lovesick") as an explanation for Hamlet''s behavior.  He will stick to it for a long time.
'
quote: 'Mad for thy love?   /  OPHELIA My lord, I do not know;   /  But truly, I do fear it.

text:
'Hamlet is a great scrutinizer of faces.  Click the link to read the line (and its setting) from the bedroom scene in which he asks Gertrude to look at her own face.
'
quote: 'He falls to such perusal of my face   /  As he would draw it.

text:
'"Sight was thought to result from both sending light out and taking it in through the eyes" (Norton).  Hamlet leaves Ophelia, throwing light and scrutiny back onto her, walking into darkness.  A metaphoric reading might go something like: Hamlet walks into a dark future blindly, looking with penetrating light (sight) onto a complicated past. 
(If such a reading satisfies you, you are probably reading too simply, but such a metaphor could well be included in a more subtle interpretation.)'
quote: 'And, with his head over his shoulder turn''d,   /  He seem''d to find his way without his eyes;   /  For out o'' doors he went without their helps,   /  And, to the last, bended their light on me.

text:
'Polonius is on to something here, even though he''s sniffing the wrong trail like the hunting dog in his metaphor (who "goes beyond" himself, i.e. loses the scent by moving too fast).  Hamlet does indeed face ruin by a corrosive, bound-up inner force, but that force is not, as Polonius believes, his love for Ophelia. 
'
quote: 'This must be known; which, being kept close, might   /  move   /  More grief to hide than hate to utter love.

text:
'Claudius is summoning Rosencrantz and Guildernstern into Denmark to figure out what''s wrong with Hamlet.  They aren''t as loyal as Horatio, and will work in Claudius''s service against their friend.  The betrayal of Hamlet by Rosencrantz and Guildentern is another instance of Hamlet losing figures he once trusted (father, mother, and now friends).
'
quote: 'Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern!   /  Moreover that we much did long to see you,   /  The need we have to use you did provoke   /  Our hasty sending. Something have you heard   /  Of Hamlet''s transformation; so call it,   /  Sith nor the exterior nor the inward man   /  Resembles that it was.

text:
'"Why are you asking us?  You could just order us." 
'
quote: 'Both your majesties   /  Might, by the sovereign power you have of us,   /  Put your dread pleasures more into command   /  Than to entreaty.

text:
'A revealing chiasmus.  These two are interchangeable as far as Claudius and Gertrude are concerned.
'
quote: 'Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.   /  QUEEN GERTRUDE Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz:

text:
'Another allusion to hunting.  Polonius likes to fantasize that he is tough and clever as a hound on the trail.  He is relentlessly optimistic, as he is here, that things will be simpler than they are.
'
quote: 'Have I, my lord? I assure my good liege,   /  I hold my duty, as I hold my soul,   /  Both to my God and to my gracious king:   /  And I do think, or else this brain of mine   /  Hunts not the trail of policy so sure   /  As it hath used to do, that I have found   /  The very cause of Hamlet''s lunacy.

text:
'The first instance of Gertrude doubting the quickness of her marriage to Claudius.  Is she regretful?  Or does she simply understand that such a marriage could be unsettling for a son like Hamlet?  Note the tendency of King Hamlet (as ghost) and Gertrude to refer to people in the play''s universe as they relate to Hamlet.  Not "my brother" but "your uncle," in the ghost scene.  Not "King Hamlet" or even "my husband" but "his father," as we see here.
'
quote: 'our o''erhasty marriage.

text:
'Good news: Fortinbras has been persuaded to "arrest" his preparations againt Denmark, and Valtemand has brought a document to assure this arrangement.
'
quote: 'Most fair return of greetings and desires.   /  Upon our first, he sent out to suppress   /  His nephew''s levies; which to him appear''d   /  To be a preparation ''gainst the Polack;   /  But, better look''d into, he truly found   /  It was against your highness: whereat grieved,   /  That so his sickness, age and impotence   /  Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests   /  On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys;   /  Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine   /  Makes vow before his uncle never more   /  To give the assay of arms against your majesty.   /  Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,   /  Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee,   /  And his commission to employ those soldiers,   /  So levied as before, against the Polack:   /  With an entreaty, herein further shown,   /  Giving a paper That it might please you to give quiet pass   /  Through your dominions for this enterprise,   /  On such regards of safety and allowance   /  As therein are set down.

text:
'Polonius is always promising to do one thing and, in the act of so promising, doing the exact opposite.  Here he gives a spectacularly long-winded ode to brevity.
'
quote: 'This business is well ended.   /  My liege, and madam, to expostulate   /  What majesty should be, what duty is,   /  Why day is day, night night, and time is time,   /  Were nothing but to waste night, day and time.   /  Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,   /  And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,   /  I will be brief: your noble son is mad:

text:
'Perpend belongs on its own line, so that we can see the space Polonius leaves to make sure he has an attentive audience.  "Perpend" sounds silly to us now (it means "1. a. trans. To ponder, consider; to examine, investigate." OED), and it is indeed silly.  Shakespeare used it only five times in total (Concordance).
'
quote: 'Perpend.

text:
'Lots to talk about here.  All the references to "illness" or lines like "I have not art" are doubly significant, meaning both "I am ill with love for you" and also "I am not good at writing poetry (especially when distracted by my love for you."  This trifling little letter, then, touches on some of the major problems for Hamlet.  Namely, the problem of ordering an increasingly disordered world ("my tables, my tables") and the problem of seeing the truth when the institutions of order are in disarray.  Doubting truth to be a liar (suspecting truth to be a liar, that is), is not out of the question in Hamlet''s Denmark, of course.
'
quote: '''To the celestial and my soul''s idol, the most   /  beautified Ophelia,''--   /  That''s an ill phrase, a vile phrase; ''beautified'' is   /  a vile phrase: but you shall hear. Thus:   /  Reads ''In her excellent white bosom, these, & c.''   /  QUEEN GERTRUDE Came this from Hamlet to her?   /  LORD POLONIUS Good madam, stay awhile; I will be faithful.   /  Reads ''Doubt thou the stars are fire;   /  Doubt that the sun doth move;   /  Doubt truth to be a liar;   /  But never doubt I love.   /  ''O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers;   /  I have not art to reckon my groans: but that   /  I love thee best, O most best, believe it. Adieu.   /  ''Thine evermore most dear lady, whilst   /  this machine is to him, HAMLET.''

text:
'Again: too late for brevity when you''re 12 lines into your story.
'
quote: 'short tale to make--

text:
'In other words, "if I''m wrong, then cut off my head."  Polonius is very confident, but Claudius wants more evidence.  Here we see the beginning of the parallel rush for verification by Claudius and Hamlet: Hamlet to verify and act on the prophesy of the ghost, Claudius to verify whether Hamlet is mad or not. 
'
quote: '[Pointing to his head and shoulder]   /  Take this from this, if this be otherwise:

text:
'Another instance of Polonius''s over-confidence.  "If I''m wrong, then I should be pushing a peasant''s wagon, not working in the palace."  Actually, that''s not such a bad idea...
'
quote: 'if he love her not   /  And be not from his reason fall''n thereon,   /  Let me be no assistant for a state,   /  But keep a farm and carters.

text:
'Some directors may give Hamlet staggered entrances.  The first one to an outer room or recess of the stage from which he could hear Polonius lay out his plan, and then a second into the inner room where the three finally see him (Norton).
'
quote: 'But, look, where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.

text:
'Recall Polonius''s stated project a few moments earlier: to catch a "carp."
'
quote: 'fishmonger.

text:
'Hamlet quibbles on "sun"/son.  ("Don''t expose Ophelia to the son [i.e. me].")
'
quote: 'For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a   /  god kissing carrion,--Have you a daughter?   /  LORD POLONIUS I have, my lord.   /  HAMLET Let her not walk i'' the sun:

text:
'This line is famous, famous, famous.  Hamlet breaks the word "words" into a repetitive, meaningless figure of speech, just as characters in the play (and people in the world) may use words to convolute and disguise meaning rather than to illuminate it.  Even underneath the most obfuscating words, though - like those that Hamlet speaks in his "madness" - there is some correspondence to reality.
'
quote: 'Words, words, words.

text:
'We are reminded of Lear''s fool, and then of Lear''s own oracular madness.  For the archetypical example of madness-as-perception, we look to Lear''s speech upon Cordelia''s death:
  Lear. And my poor fool is hang''d! No, no, no life!
     Why should a dog, a horse, a rat, have life,
     And thou no breath at all? Thou''lt come no more,
     Never, never, never, never, never!
     Pray you undo this button. Thank you, sir.
     Do you see this? Look on her! look! her lips!
     Look there, look there! He dies.
Click the link to read the context of this monologue, as well as other selections from Lear.
'
quote: '[Aside] Though this be madness, yet there is method   /  in ''t. Will you walk out of the air, my lord?   /  HAMLET Into my grave.   /  LORD POLONIUS Indeed, that is out o'' the air.   /  Aside How pregnant sometimes his replies are! a happiness   /  that often madness hits on, which reason and sanity   /  could not so prosperously be delivered of.

text:
'This spectacular triplet - "except my life, except my life, except my life" - has been driving scholars crazy for some time now.  The reason is that it appears only in Q2 but was eliminated in F, condensed as "except my life, my life, my life."  Editors generally agree that this formulation packs less punch, but why in the world would Shakespeare eliminate the other two "excepts" in his official edition - the Folio text?  To make matters worse, the Folio text eliminates the word "not" that appears in Q2 as follows: "you cannot, sir, take from me anothing that I will NOT more willingly part withal."  As John Jones notes in his "Shakespeare at Work," the "not" reverses the sense of the negations that follow.  In our text here, we''ve got the best of both worlds - the marvelous "except, except, except" of Q2 without the pesky "not" of the Folio.

These kinds of matters can be drab, but they do make you realize that we''re dealing with actual manuscripts here, not just abstract "Plays," and the dream of the definitive Shakespearean text is a complicated one to realize.  What you''re reading is a text that is still up for debate.
'
quote: 'You cannot, sir, take from me any thing that I will   /  more willingly part withal: except my life, except   /  my life, except my life.

text:
'Norton notes the triple pun: G & R are "private" persons (civilians, not officials), the are "private" relations of Hamlet (his friends), and they hang around Fortune''s waist (her "privates").
'
quote: 'privates

text:
'Hamlet understands the creative quality of thought.  For him, Denmark is a prison, but for one who thinks of Denmark as a normal place, then that''s what it is for him.
'
quote: 'We think not so, my lord.   /  HAMLET Why, then, ''tis none to you; for there is nothing   /  either good or bad, but thinking makes it so: to me   /  it is a prison.

text:
'The word of "remember me," the word of the mind, is the confined/infinite world of the play.
'
quote: 'O God, I could be bounded in a nut shell and count   /  myself a king of infinite space, were it not that I   /  have bad dreams.

text:
'Recall also Mercutio''s Queen Mab speech (click the link to read it), and the general Elizabethan scientific obsession with the atom: the small, invisible elements of the world that exert great influence on it.

Mercutio: Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut...'
quote: 'nut shell

text:
'R & G''s first instict is to lie, an instinct which betrays their sense of loyalty to the King and, more generally, to authority.  One sympathizes with them, though, because they are not royalty like Hamlet and so cannot make a habit, as he does, of infuriating the powerful.
'
quote: 'But, in the   /  beaten way of friendship, what make you at Elsinore?   /  ROSENCRANTZ To visit you, my lord; no other occasion.   /  HAMLET Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks; but I   /  thank you: and sure, dear friends, my thanks are   /  too dear a halfpenny. Were you not sent for? Is it   /  your own inclining? Is it a free visitation? Come,   /  deal justly with me: come, come; nay, speak.   /  GUILDENSTERN What should we say, my lord?   /  HAMLET Why, any thing, but to the purpose. You were sent   /  for; and there is a kind of confession in your looks   /  which your modesties have not craft enough to colour:   /  I know the good king and queen have sent for you.   /  ROSENCRANTZ To what end, my lord?   /  HAMLET That you must teach me. But let me conjure you, by   /  the rights of our fellowship, by the consonancy of   /  our youth, by the obligation of our ever-preserved   /  love, and by what more dear a better proposer could   /  charge you withal, be even and direct with me,   /  whether you were sent for, or no?   /  ROSENCRANTZ [Aside to GUILDENSTERN] What say you?   /  HAMLET [Aside] Nay, then, I have an eye of you.--If you   /  love me, hold not off.   /  GUILDENSTERN My lord, we were sent for.

text:
'Hamlet is cautious with R & G.  He doesn''t tell them outright that his madness is performance, but neither does he speak to them as he speaks to Polonius. 
'
quote: 'What a piece of work is a man! how noble in reason!   /  how infinite in faculty! in form and moving how   /  express and admirable! in action how like an angel!   /  in apprehension how like a god! the beauty of the   /  world! the paragon of animals! And yet, to me,   /  what is this quintessence of dust? man delights not   /  me: no, nor woman neither, though by your smiling   /  you seem to say so.   /  ROSENCRANTZ My lord, there was no such stuff in my thoughts.   /  HAMLET Why did you laugh then, when I said ''man delights not me''?   /  ROSENCRANTZ To think, my lord, if you delight not in man, what   /  lenten entertainment the players shall receive from   /  you: we coted them on the way; and hither are they   /  coming, to offer you service.

text:
'Norton notes that such a rival company of Shakespeare''s existed in the early 1600s.
'
quote: 'Nay, their endeavour keeps in the wonted pace: but   /  there is, sir, an aery of children, little eyases,   /  that cry out on the top of question, and are most   /  tyrannically clapped for''t: these are now the   /  fashion, and so berattle the common stages--so they   /  call them--that many wearing rapiers are afraid of   /  goose-quills and dare scarce come thither.

text:
'In other words, people are suckers for those on top.  Men who would sneer openly at Claudius while King Hamlet live are now sycophants to him (they even pay money for little pictures of him).
'
quote: 'It is not very strange; for mine uncle is king of   /  Denmark, and those that would make mows at him while   /  my father lived, give twenty, forty, fifty, an   /  hundred ducats a-piece for his picture in little.   /  ''Sblood, there is something in this more than   /  natural, if philosophy could find it out.

text:
'A case of egregious "double casting," as would have been common in Shakespeare''s Globe.
'
quote: 'uncle-father and aunt-mother

text:
'"I''m only the slightest degree off from sanity" (as north-north-west is only a tiny needle''s jump from true north).
'
quote: 'north-north-west:

text:
'A parody of dramatic genre theory.
'
quote: 'tragedy,   /  comedy, history, pastoral, pastoral-comical,   /  historical-pastoral, tragical-historical, tragical-   /  comical-historical-pastoral, scene individable, or   /  poem unlimited:

text:
'Jepthah''s daughter was sacrificed, according to the story.
'
quote: '''One fair daughter and no more,   /  The which he loved passing well.''

text:
'A quibble on "beard" ("defy") reveals something of this line.  Actors are always dressing up, and though Hamlet has never seen these players before, one is always seeing an actor with his face "valenced," or made younger, or painted, or any number of other alterations.
'
quote: 'O, my old   /  friend! thy face is valenced since I saw thee last:   /  comest thou to beard me in Denmark?

text:
'Hamlet''s lines are not in verse here, and the disorder of his meter (his lack of meter, that is) is made more vivid by the snippets of Virgil that he quotes and misquotes. 
'
quote: 'I heard thee speak me a speech once, but it was   /  never acted; or, if it was, not above once; for the   /  play, I remember, pleased not the million; ''twas   /  caviare to the general: but it was--as I received   /  it, and others, whose judgments in such matters   /  cried in the top of mine--an excellent play, well   /  digested in the scenes, set down with as much   /  modesty as cunning. I remember, one said there   /  were no sallets in the lines to make the matter   /  savoury, nor no matter in the phrase that might   /  indict the author of affectation; but called it an   /  honest method, as wholesome as sweet, and by very   /  much more handsome than fine. One speech in it I   /  chiefly loved: ''twas Aeneas'' tale to Dido; and   /  thereabout of it especially, where he speaks of   /  Priam''s slaughter: if it live in your memory, begin   /  at this line: let me see, let me see--   /  ''The rugged Pyrrhus, like the Hyrcanian beast,''--   /  it is not so:--it begins with Pyrrhus:--   /  ''The rugged Pyrrhus, he whose sable arms,   /  Black as his purpose, did the night resemble   /  When he lay couched in the ominous horse,   /  Hath now this dread and black complexion smear''d   /  With heraldry more dismal; head to foot   /  Now is he total gules; horridly trick''d   /  With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons,   /  Baked and impasted with the parching streets,   /  That lend a tyrannous and damned light   /  To their lord''s murder: roasted in wrath and fire,   /  And thus o''er-sized with coagulate gore,   /  With eyes like carbuncles, the hellish Pyrrhus   /  Old grandsire Priam seeks.''   /  So, proceed you.

text:
'Hamlet and Polonius provide a running commentary on the performance of the players.  It could be that Hamlet is feeling them out to see if they''ll be suitable for his devices.
'
quote: 'This is too long.   /  HAMLET It shall to the barber''s, with your beard. Prithee,   /  say on: he''s for a jig or a tale of bawdry, or he   /  sleeps: say on: come to Hecuba.   /  First Player ''But who, O, who had seen the mobled queen--''   /  HAMLET ''The mobled queen?''   /  LORD POLONIUS That''s good; ''mobled queen'' is good.

Mobled

\r\n  In later examples often with allusion to Shakespeare.

(A rarity in Shakespeare.  This is the only occurance.  [Concordance])

quote: 'mobled

text:
'Polonius is asking a more profound question than he realizes: "Can saying something make you feel it?"
'
quote: 'Look, whether he has not turned his colour and has   /  tears in''s eyes. Pray you, no more.

text:
'"Now I am alone" completes the line "God b''wi''ye," which makes the idea of alone-ness a little ironic.  If God implies "all things supernatural," then Hamlet''s being alone is complicated by the presence of his father.
'
quote: 'Ay, so, God be wi'' ye;   /  Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN Now I am alone.

text:
'Hamlet picks up Polonius''s idea (see note on "Look whe''er...") of the actor becoming his words.  Actors are symbolic of the seeming/being problem in that they seem to have the ability to transform their very souls in the service of a fiction.

For a much cooler take on this idea, watch Godard''s "Le Petit Soldat," (1963), in which Michel Subor and Anna Karina talk about the actor as prostitute.

http://youtube.com/watch?v=KQp_V3KtjyY

'
quote: 'O, what a rogue and peasant slave am I!   /  Is it not monstrous that this player here,   /  But in a fiction, in a dream of passion,   /  Could force his soul so to his own conceit   /  That from her working all his visage wann''d,   /  Tears in his eyes, distraction in''s aspect,   /  A broken voice, and his whole function suiting   /  With forms to his conceit? and all for nothing!

text:
'"If that guy can work himself up like that for nothing, then imagine what he could do if he had my inner life."

(a bit like the Elizabethan "I think Brad Pitt would play me in a biopic.")
'
quote: 'What would he do,   /  Had he the motive and the cue for passion   /  That I have?

text:
'Hamlet''s fantasy of a vicious object for his revenge is just that: a dream.  No one pulls his beard, or spits on him, or anything at all like that.  He is pricked by something both more and less provocative than these petty (imagined) offenses.
'
quote: 'Am I a coward?   /  Who calls me villain? breaks my pate across?   /  Plucks off my beard, and blows it in my face?   /  Tweaks me by the nose? gives me the lie i'' the throat,   /  As deep as to the lungs? who does me this?   /  Ha!   /  ''Swounds, I should take it:

text:
'Hamlet is testing out the ability of "words words words" to rouse a man to action, seeing if he, like the actors, can stimulate real passion with empty rhetoric.
'
quote: 'bloody, bawdy villain!   /  Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!   /  O, vengeance!

text:
'"But enough talk!  I am going to take action!  I''m going to...I''ll...put on a play and make him watch it."

Hamlet is banking on the special power of drama to make people identify with the action on the stage.  If Claudius is in fact guilty, he cannot help but evince his guilt when his crime is presented (albeit obliquely) by the players.  This notion of the guilty betraying themselves is fairly common (recall Poe''s "The Tell-Tale Heart," for instance).
'
quote: 'About, my brain! I have heard   /  That guilty creatures sitting at a play   /  Have by the very cunning of the scene   /  Been struck so to the soul that presently   /  They have proclaim''d their malefactions;   /  For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak   /  With most miraculous organ. I''ll have these players   /  Play something like the murder of my father   /  Before mine uncle: I''ll observe his looks;   /  I''ll tent him to the quick: if he but blench,   /  I know my course.

text:
'Hamlet loves his father, but he isn''t about to ruin his life because of faulty evidence: he wants proof (recall the "parallel" plot of verification).

There''s much to be written about the maddening circularity of Hamlet''s awareness of his own "weakness and melancholy."  Hamlet acknowledges that he may have tricked himself into believing the ghost because he is in a fragile state.  But was it not the seeing of the ghost that threw him into that state to begin with?  Or was the melancholy of his father''s death enough to derail him to actual madness, of which the feigned madness is only a symptom (highly unlikely, to be sure)?  If not, though, is Hamlet behaving like an actor and creating madness by performing madness? 
And so on...
'
quote: 'The spirit that I have seen   /  May be the devil: and the devil hath power   /  To assume a pleasing shape; yea, and perhaps   /  Out of my weakness and my melancholy,   /  As he is very potent with such spirits,   /  Abuses me to damn me: I''ll have grounds   /  More relative than this:

text:
'Nice exposition, William Shakespeare. 
'
quote: 'And can you, by no drift of circumstance,   /  Get from him why he puts on this confusion,   /  Grating so harshly all his days of quiet   /  With turbulent and dangerous lunacy?

text:
'Why does Gertrude agree to surrender Hamlet to Claudius, as it were?   No clear answer is offered, but one may speculate.
'
quote: 'I shall obey you.

text:
'Claudius is beginning to buckle under the pressure of his double life.  This is important dramatically, because it will help explain his vulnerability to Hamlet''s device (that is, the play).
'
quote: 'Read on this book;   /  That show of such an exercise may colour   /  Your loneliness. We are oft to blame in this,--   /  ''Tis too much proved--that with devotion''s visage   /  And pious action we do sugar o''er   /  The devil himself.   /  KING CLAUDIUS [Aside] O, ''tis too true!   /  How smart a lash that speech doth give my conscience!   /  The harlot''s cheek, beautied with plastering art,   /  Is not more ugly to the thing that helps it   /  Than is my deed to my most painted word:   /  O heavy burthen!

text:
'Hamlet (and the play as a whole) is haunted by suicide.  Greenblatt reads this as Hamlet''s knowledge that the "melancholy" from which he suffers is as much internal as external, and that it may take his own death, rather than Claudius''s or anyone else''s, to ease him.
'
quote: 'To be, or not to be: that is the question:   /  Whether ''tis nobler in the mind to suffer   /  The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,   /  Or to take arms against a sea of troubles,   /  And by opposing end them?

text:
'It only takes a dagger to end it all.  Hamlet returns to the fragility of the human machine ("what a piece of work") as contrasted to the complexities and mysteries of the human soul.  As always, the spectre of the afterlife shows up again.  What keeps us from suicide, Hamlet suggests, is the fear of messing things up in our life after death.  Suicides, of course, wind up in hell, and Hamlet has good evidence of the suffering that''s in store for us when we die (he''s had dispatches from his father''s "prison house," after all). 

But it''s not just the threat of hell that keeps Hamlet alive.  In fact, that probably has little to do with it.  What prevents men from action of any kind is thought itself, is "conscience" (here "consciousness" as well).  Resolution is covered with the "pale cast" of thought, and our desire for anything - revenge, our own death - is lost in the space between thought and action. 

For those with an interest in this theme, 2.1 of Julius Caesar has a marvelous speech by Brutus about the disconnect between conception/desire and action.  It reads, in part:
Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,
I have not slept.
Between the acting of a dreadful thing
And the first motion, all the interim is
Like a phantasma, or a hideous dream:.

Click the link for the full scene.
'
quote: 'To die, to sleep;   /  To sleep: perchance to dream: ay, there''s the rub;   /  For in that sleep of death what dreams may come   /  When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,   /  Must give us pause: there''s the respect   /  That makes calamity of so long life;   /  For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,   /  The oppressor''s wrong, the proud man''s contumely,   /  The pangs of despised love, the law''s delay,   /  The insolence of office and the spurns   /  That patient merit of the unworthy takes,   /  When he himself might his quietus make   /  With a bare bodkin?

text:
'Claudius is in a tight spot.  He has to convince everyone that Hamlet''s hiding something that would be disastrous if revealed.  But he can''t say what, lest he incriminate himself.  Luckily for Claudius, Polonius is still credulous of his own theory - that Hamlet is lovesick - and so doesn''t interfere with the King''s suggestion that Hamlet be sent abroad. 
'
quote: 'Love! his affections do not that way tend;   /  Nor what he spake, though it lack''d form a little,   /  Was not like madness. There''s something in his soul,   /  O''er which his melancholy sits on brood;   /  And I do doubt the hatch and the disclose   /  Will be some danger: which for to prevent,   /  I have in quick determination   /  Thus set it down: he shall with speed to England,   /  For the demand of our neglected tribute   /  Haply the seas and countries different   /  With variable objects shall expel   /  This something-settled matter in his heart,   /  Whereon his brains still beating puts him thus   /  From fashion of himself. What think you on''t?

text:
'"If Gertrude can''t figure it out, then we''ll send him off."  Claudius has found his footing and suggests a plausible explanation for Hamlet''s exile: it wouldn''t do for the whole of Denmark to see that the late King''s son is a lunatic.

quote: 'Let his queen mother all alone entreat him   /  To show his grief: let her be round with him;   /  And I''ll be placed, so please you, in the ear   /  Of all their conference. If she find him not,   /  To England send him, or confine him where   /  Your wisdom best shall think.   /  KING CLAUDIUS It shall be so:   /  Madness in great ones must not unwatch''d go.

text:
'Most editors read this speech as a dramatic excess, unnecessary to the plot and included only because "acting" is a concern of the play (for a typical example, see Oxford).  But we have been trained by Polonius to read invectives against something as examples of the very thing against which they''re intended.  Take, for instance, Polonius''s drawn-out "brevity is the soul of wit" speech.

Here, Hamlet is doing something similar.  (Disclaimer: this is not a reading generally taken by editors.)  We''ve just come off the most actorly, histrionic moment in the whole play: the "to be or not to be" monologue.  Then, our brilliant, self-obsessed, dramatically inclined hero delivers a hortatory monologue about the dangers of overacting!  Viewed in this way, Hamlet''s advice to the players is as much a dialogue with himself as it is a seminar in Acting 101.
'
quote: 'Speak the speech, I pray you, as I pronounced it to   /  you, trippingly on the tongue: but if you mouth it,   /  as many of your players do, I had as lief the   /  town-crier spoke my lines. Nor do not saw the air   /  too much with your hand, thus, but use all gently;   /  for in the very torrent, tempest, and, as I may say,   /  the whirlwind of passion, you must acquire and beget   /  a temperance that may give it smoothness. O, it   /  offends me to the soul to hear a robustious   /  periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters, to   /  very rags, to split the ears of the groundlings, who   /  for the most part are capable of nothing but   /  inexplicable dumbshows and noise: I would have such   /  a fellow whipped for o''erdoing Termagant; it   /  out-herods Herod: pray you, avoid it.

text:
'Hamlet returns to the mirror, and to the idea of self-reflection generally.  Recall the way he looked into Ophelia''s face in the mad scene with her - we''ll see mirrors again in the bedroom scene with Gertrude.

What''s so cool about this monologue is that it makes the case for the theater as a more-real reality than reality itself, because it doesn''t just perform virtue (or vice), but shows virtue to itself.  Theater, that is, can tell us what we are.  This is precisely the object of Hamlet''s plot to snare Claudius - to show vice to itself in the mirror of the theater.    
'
quote: 'for any thing so overdone is   /  from the purpose of playing, whose end, both at the   /  first and now, was and is, to hold, as ''twere, the   /  mirror up to nature; to show virtue her own feature,   /  scorn her own image, and the very age and body of   /  the time his form and pressure.

There is a lot of power in the play from multiple observers, as Polonius and Claudius know when they spy on Hamlet and Ophelia.

Give him heedful note;   /  For I mine eyes will rivet to his face,   /  And after we will both our judgments join   /  In censure of his seeming.

'OED:
Chameleon, n.
  1. A saurian reptile of the genus Chamæleo, family Chamæleonidæ, small lizard-like creatures, distinguished by a prehensile tail, long tongue, eyes moving independently, and covered each with a single circular eyelid, but esp. by their power of changing the colour of the skin, ‘varying through different shades of yellow, red, gray, brown, and dull inky blue’ (Carpenter Zoology 1847). From their inanimate appearance, and power of existing for long periods without food, they were formerly supposed to live on air. These attributes made the name famous and familiar to many who knew nothing else of the animal.

'"Metal," Oxford notes, is traditional Elizabethan love language (the beloved as magnet).  But metal often puns in Shakespeare with mettle, as in "undaunted mettle" from Macbeth.  Mettle is the stuff you''re made of, and that stuff can be wrought like metal, melted down, changed.  "Metal more attractive" is both "a hot young girl" and "someone who hasn''t betrayed me."

text:
'Dumb shows were a slightly outdated allegorical prelude to dramas by the time Shakespeare was writing, but not so outlandish as to be out of place with a tragedy like this one (that is, "The Murder of Gonzago").

Keep in mind also that though we, as audience, know how the dumb show relates to Claudius''s murder of King Hamlet, Claudius isn''t expecting anything out of the ordinary.  The prologue would get his attention but not blow Hamlet''s cover just yet - especially because the familial connection between the murder and the murdered isn''t made obvious in the dumb show.

bank of flowers: she, seeing him asleep, leaves him. Anon comes in a
fellow, takes off his crown, kisses it, and pours poison in the King''s
ears, and exit. The Queen returns; finds the King dead, and makes
passionate action. The Poisoner, with some two or three Mutes, comes in
again, seeming to lament with her. The dead body is carried away. The
Poisoner wooes the Queen with gifts: she seems loath and unwilling
awhile, but in the end accepts his love Exeunt

text:
'In the grand tradition of Shakespearean clowns and fools, Hamlet is finishing the thought of a serious character by giving it a funny, new sense. 

Take, for instance, this exchange from Twelfth Night:

Fool: Sir, I live by the church.
Viola: Art thou a churchman?
Fool: No such matter, sir.  I do live by the church; for I do live at my house, and my house doth stand by the church.

or, from Love''s Labour''s Lost:

Costard: Let me not be pent up, sir: I will fast, being loose.
Moth: No, sir; that were fast and loose: thou shalt to prison.

quote: 'Full thirty times hath Phoebus'' cart gone round   /  Neptune''s salt wash and Tellus'' orbed ground,   /  And thirty dozen moons with borrow''d sheen   /  About the world have times twelve thirties been,   /  Since love our hearts and Hymen did our hands   /  Unite commutual in most sacred bands.

text:
'In other words, "only a woman who killed her first husband should take a second."  Hamlet replies "wormwood, wormwood," which means, essentially, "nonsense," because in the case of Denmark a woman wed the second husband without herself killing the first.  Hamlet is saying "that particular situation isn''t the case in Denmark."

You might say that the difference between murder and remarriage isn''t as big as the proverb ("In second husband...") makes it out to be.  In the case of purgatory, forgetting is equivalent to damnation - and death - because the living must remember the dead to allow their ascent to heaven.  If remarriage means forgetting, then, the remarriage means a kind of murder of the soul.

Another way to read the "wormwood" line now follows.  Instead of "nonsense," what about this other definition from teh OED:

  2. fig. An emblem or \r\ntype of what is bitter and grievous to the soul.

"Grievous to the soul" could be taken to mean both "offensive to Nature" and also "grievous to the soul of the dead husband, who requires that we remember him."
'
quote: 'In second husband let me be accurst!   /  None wed the second but who kill''d the first.

text:
'This is one of the strangest parts of the play.  Just when we expect a brother of the king to show himself and commit the murder, a nephew to the king appears and does the job.  It''s hard not to read the nephew as Hamlet himself.  For those who want to ready the play with an Oedipal twist, things just keep getting better.

After the boy poisons his father, Hamlet tells us, he "gets the love of Gonzago''s wife."  In other words, if we follow the allegory of the play, Hamlet would kill his father and marry his mother.  Though Hamlet finds "un-Natural" sexuality repulsive, here he is watching a play that has weird sexuality at its center.  Do we believe that this is the alteration that Hamlet promised to the players in the scene before this one?
'

His   /  name''s Gonzago: the story is extant, and writ in   /  choice Italian: you shall see anon how the murderer   /  gets the love of Gonzago''s wife.

'A great line.  Disease is a problem of the body, wit is a structure in the mind.  Taken together, there is a connection between the sickness of the soul and the physical body, which obsesses Hamlet (and Shakespeare) here.  Note the recurring idea in the play that speaking is necessary to prevent thought from decaying the body from inside.

text:
'Hamlet asks Guildenstern to do something simple - to play on the recorder.  When he can''t do that, Hamlet poses a follow-up question: "If you can''t even master this little instrument, how on earth can you understand something as complicated as me?"

quote: 'Why, look you now, how unworthy a thing you make of   /  me! You would play upon me; you would seem to know   /  my stops; you would pluck out the heart of my   /  mystery; you would sound me from my lowest note to   /  the top of my compass: and there is much music,   /  excellent voice, in this little organ; yet cannot   /  you make it speak. ''Sblood, do you think I am   /  easier to be played on than a pipe? Call me what   /  instrument you will, though you can fret me, yet you   /  cannot play upon me.

text:
'Oxford makes the somewhat dubious observation that Hamlet, having asked Guildenstern to play upon the pipe, now "plays" upon the "windbag" Polonius.  I believe it''s a hard case to make that Shakespeare intended to make that particular pun, but the image of Polonius whistling and tooting like a recorder as Hamlet throws him for loop after loop is a pretty funny one.

quote: 'My lord, the queen would speak with you, and   /  presently.   /  HAMLET Do you see yonder cloud that''s almost in shape of a camel?   /  LORD POLONIUS By the mass, and ''tis like a camel, indeed.   /  HAMLET Methinks it is like a weasel.   /  LORD POLONIUS It is backed like a weasel.

text:
'Lots going on here.  Let''s use the presence of Nero as a starting point.

Nero (37-68 CE) is here because of his "unnatural" relations with his mother.  Not only did he commit incest with her, he cut open her body to look into her womb.  Hamlet is aware that he has impulses that might pull him in the "unnatural" direction in regards to Gertrude.  We don''t really believe that he would ever kill her and dissect her, but the prospect of incest isn''t out of the question at this point.  Certainly incestuous desire is very much in the air.

Nero is introduced after Hamlet''s spectacular line, "O heart, lose not thy nature."  This is one of the early instances of Hamlet''s awareness of his own tendency to lose control of the revenge plot, and of his own feelings.  I will call this phenomenon "the struggle and the thrill of losing control," because I believe that Hamlet tries to keep his cool at many moments in the play (especially in the knock-out bedroom scene we''re about to see) even as he is thrilled to be losing it. 
'
quote: 'Tis now the very witching time of night,   /  When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out   /  Contagion to this world: now could I drink hot blood,   /  And do such bitter business as the day   /  Would quake to look on. Soft! now to my mother.   /  O heart, lose not thy nature; let not ever   /  The soul of Nero enter this firm bosom:   /  Let me be cruel, not unnatural:   /  I will speak daggers to her, but use none;   /  My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites;   /  How in my words soever she be shent,   /  To give them seals never, my soul, consent!

text:
'A question of obligation to the single body (to Hamlet as a son) or to the body politic (to Denmark as a people).  These three are proceding on the assumption that Hamlet is a danger to the "many many bodies" that depend upon a stable state.  "Many many" is a clever rhetorical play by Guildenstern, because it further reduces the importance of the individual. 
'
quote: 'Most holy and religious fear it is   /  To keep those many many bodies safe   /  That live and feed upon your majesty.

text:
'Readers of Richard II will recall his monologue from the prison in Act V, which includes the line:
"Thus play I in one person many people."

Shakespeare''s kings are often aware of the contradictions of being a monarch.  For one thing, your single, living body inhabits an office (i.e. wears the crown) on which many, many bodies depend.  What''s more, when you die, the office itself lives on.  For more on this theme, click the link to read Richard, who is a much more interesting thinker than Rosencrantz, considering it deeply.

http://shakespeare.mit.edu/richardii/richardii.5.5.html
'
quote: 'The single and peculiar life is bound,   /  With all the strength and armour of the mind,   /  To keep itself from noyance; but much more   /  That spirit upon whose weal depend and rest   /  The lives of many. The cease of majesty   /  Dies not alone; but, like a gulf, doth draw   /  What''s near it with it: it is a massy wheel,   /  Fix''d on the summit of the highest mount,   /  To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things   /  Are mortised and adjoin''d; which, when it falls,   /  Each small annexment, petty consequence,   /  Attends the boisterous ruin. Never alone   /  Did the king sigh, but with a general groan.

\r\nI had most need of blessing, and ''Amen''
\r\nStuck in my throat.

text:
'There is the possibility that Claudius is so far gone as a sinner that all of the mercy in heaven won''t save him. 

Repenting is made especially difficult by Claudius''s particular situation.  Rather than repent, as a reformed sinner can, that his offence is behind him, Claudius must ask pardon for what is very much a work-in-progress: he''s still got the "effects" (wife, crown) that he won by sinning.   And while sinners on earth may win out over the righteous, in heaven ("above") they''ll have no such luck.
'
quote: 'What if this cursed hand   /  Were thicker than itself with brother''s blood,   /  Is there not rain enough in the sweet heavens   /  To wash it white as snow? Whereto serves mercy   /  But to confront the visage of offence?   /  And what''s in prayer but this two-fold force,   /  To be forestalled ere we come to fall,   /  Or pardon''d being down? Then I''ll look up;   /  My fault is past. But, O, what form of prayer   /  Can serve my turn? ''Forgive me my foul murder''?   /  That cannot be; since I am still possess''d   /  Of those effects for which I did the murder,   /  My crown, mine own ambition and my queen.   /  May one be pardon''d and retain the offence?   /  In the corrupted currents of this world   /  Offence''s gilded hand may shove by justice,   /  And oft ''tis seen the wicked prize itself   /  Buys out the law: but ''tis not so above;

text:
'What exactly does Claudius want?  Is he prepared to pray sincerely, and to act on it?

quote: 'All may be well.   /  Retires and kneels

text:
'Another instance of the stage directions implying the direction of the drama.  All will not be well, and the agent of the unrest enters into the scene at the moment when the hope for a favorable turn of events is at its highest.
'
quote: 'All may be well.   /  Retires and kneels Enter HAMLET

text:
'According to the theology of the time, dying while praying was a one-way ticket to heaven.  But Hamlet wants to put Claudius on a highway to hell.  So he needs to give the situation careful consideration (needs to "scan" it).  If he kills Claudius now, it would be as if he were paying him his "wages" - that is, eternal life - for a job he''d done (killing King Hamlet).

There''s another problem with killing Claudius now: Claudius wouldn''t know why he''s dying.  An important part of the revenge tragedy is the moment when you pull out your sword and tell your enemy "this is why I am about to kill you."  If Hamlet kills Claudius without a moment of explanation, his revenge plot would somehow malfunction.  For the definition of archetypical revenge, see Tamora''s speech from Titus Andronicus:

I am Revenge: sent from the infernal kingdom,
To ease the gnawing vulture of thy mind,
By working wreakful vengeance on thy foes.
Come down, and welcome me to this world''s light;
Confer with me of murder and of death:
There''s not a hollow cave or lurking-place,
No vast obscurity or misty vale,
Where bloody murder or detested rape
Can couch for fear, but I will find them out;
And in their ears tell them my dreadful name,
Revenge, which makes the foul offender quake.
'
quote: 'Now might I do it pat, now he is praying;   /  And now I''ll do''t. And so he goes to heaven;   /  And so am I revenged. That would be scann''d:   /  A villain kills my father; and for that,   /  I, his sole son, do this same villain send   /  To heaven.   /  O, this is hire and salary, not revenge.

text:
'Words are an engine that require a battery - thought.  Is this the difference between words with meaning and "words, words, words"?
'
quote: 'Words without thoughts never to heaven go.

'[["Enter Gertrude and Polonius"]]  (Who on earth is Queen Margaret?!)

quote: 'QUEEN MARGARET

text:
'Here it is, the one you''ve been waiting for, the Bedoom Scene.  Pages and pages of critical ink have been spilled trying to figure out what''s going on here, and film adaptations (not to mention stage productions) will all put their stamp on it.

It makes sense to begin with a line of Hamlet''s, 3.4.15: "What''s the matter now."  Hamlet may as well be asking himself this question, because figuring out just what the matter is proves increasingly difficult in this scene.  In a nutshell, Hamlet''s rage seems to be out of proportion to its object.  What about Gertrude is making him so angry?  If we reject T.S. Eliot''s theory, that Shakespeare himself has lost track of the "matter" in the play at large (a theory that, as I will suggest, fails to explain the entrance of the ghost into this scene), then we have our work cut out for us.

Let''s begin with a note on staging.  Although setting the scene with a bed is now typical, Oxford''s editors take pains to point out that "a closet is not a bedroom," and that the bed made its debut in the 1930s in a famous New York production.  Nevertheless, the bed is as much a spectre as a physical presence, and as readers of Hamlet we may imagine what we will (within reason, of course).  Now, on to the text.

In 3.4 Hamlet is obsessed by his newly sexualized mother.  This woman who was once mother and, to a lesser degree, wife, is now irrefutably a lover, and the bed at the center of her chamber has been the site of (gasp!) love-making with Claudius.  That is the simplest theory, anyway.

Another reading might suggest that Hamlet has finally found power over his mother, and that there is a thrill in its exercise.  Recall that Gertrude has thus far deferred to Claudius in making decisions about Hamlet.  Now, the two are alone, and she must confront him one on one. 

Greenblatt and others suggest that Hamlet''s obsession with Claudius and Gertrude as a couple exists alongside an obsession with Gertrude''s sexuality as such.  In this reading, Hamlet''s deeply imagined fantasy of Gertrude''s sexuality ("enseamed bed," e.g.) begin to make us uneasy.  Just what does Hamlet want from his mother?

Finally, click the link to read Eliot''s essay on Hamlet, which includes a brief treatment of Gertrude as an objective correlative.   Eliot writes of Gertrude: "It is just because her character is so negative and insignificant that she arouses in Hamlet the feeling which she is incapable of representing."

Perhaps the best way to read 3.4 is to keep all of these readings in mind but let none of them fully take over.

'
quote: 'SCENE IV. The Queen''s closet.

quote: 'Hamlet, thou hast thy father much offended.   /  HAMLET Mother, you have my father much offended.   /  QUEEN GERTRUDE Come, come, you answer with an idle tongue.   /  HAMLET Go, go, you question with a wicked tongue.

text:
'Images are a preoccupation of Hamlet''s in this scene.  Here is the first instance of reflection (unless one counts Hamlet''s near-identical repetitions of Gertrude''s lines as "reflections" of her sentences) in 3.4, but Hamlet will also make much of his father''s miniature portrait.

Nothing symbolizes the seeming/being problem so much as reflections and images.  With reflections, one has two images - one real and one 2-dimensional - of the same person existing simultaneously.  How can this be?  Just as Gertrude is multiple things to Hamlet (mother, sexual being, etc.), so too does she have multiple images.  It''s hard to know exactly what Hamlet hopes to achieve by making her look at herself.  It could be that he wants her to confront her face (her self) honestly and deeply, as if that alone could somehow make her see herself as he sees her.  Complicating this idea is the reflected image, which is by necessity a "false" picture of the self.
'
quote: 'Come, come, and sit you down; you shall not budge;   /  You go not till I set you up a glass   /  Where you may see the inmost part of you.

text:
'The contradiction of the "inmost" part being revealed by a mirror, which only shows the "outmost" part, should not be lost.
'

'Gertrude will exaggerate this scene slightly when she recalls it to Claudius in 4.1:

"In his lawless fit,
Behind the arras hearing something stir,
He whips his rapier out, and cries ''A rat, a rat.''"

In fact, Hamlet seems remarkably collected as he slays Polonius, even going so far as to "wager" that his blow was fatal ("for a ducat, dead").

'Hamlet himself acts like a mirror here, using his language to reflect back accusations onto those around him.  Notice how "rash" is used first by Gertrude, and then applied by Hamlet first to her and later to Polonius.  The adjective appears only one more time in the entire play.

text:
'Shakespeare uses rhapsody in an obsolete sense:

3. A miscellaneous collection; a medley or confused mass (of things); a ‘string’ (of words, sentences, tales, etc.). Obs. (OED)

Hamlet, then, is invoking two sacred contracts.  The first is the marriage contract ("body of contraction") and the second is the bible ("sweet religion").  It''s no surprise that the character so interested in "words words words," and in what happens when words become meaningless or empty, focuses on these two things.  Hamlet is imagining the implications for the world if two of civilization''s most sacrosanct documents were reduced to a "confused mass."  In such a world, on what can he depend?

'
quote: 'sweet religion makes   /  A rhapsody of words:

text:
'Hamlet shows two pictures (maybe from Gertrude''s locket, from the wall, from engravings...).  There is an essay in Hamlet''s relationship to images.  Earlier he railed against women''s "painting," because of the false image it creates.  Now he treats images as reliable indicators of character. 
'
quote: 'Look here, upon this picture, and on this,   /  The counterfeit presentment of two brothers.   /  See, what a grace was seated on this brow;   /  Hyperion''s curls; the front of Jove himself;   /  An eye like Mars, to threaten and command;   /  A station like the herald Mercury   /  New-lighted on a heaven-kissing hill;   /  A combination and a form indeed,   /  Where every god did seem to set his seal,   /  To give the world assurance of a man:   /  This was your husband. Look you now, what follows:   /  Here is your husband; like a mildew''d ear,   /  Blasting his wholesome brother. Have you eyes?   /  Could you on this fair mountain leave to feed,   /  And batten on this moor? Ha! have you eyes?

text:
'"This to this?" - in other words, "Why in the world, considering that sex is slave to reason at your age, would you choose this guy (Claudius) after having been with this guy (pointing to the portrait of King Hamlet)?"

Here Hamlet excludes one of the explanations for Gertrude''s change of husband that might have satisfied him: sex.

quote: 'You cannot call it love; for at your age   /  The hey-day in the blood is tame, it''s humble,   /  And waits upon the judgment: and what judgment   /  Would step from this to this?

text:
'Lear, in 4.5, compares the vagina to hell: "There''s hell, there''s darkness, there''s the sulphurous pit."  Hamlet''s metaphor is sexual also.

Though the idea of sexual desire overpowering the will is nothing new, Hamlet sees it as symptomatic of an entire universe thrown out of whack. 
'
quote: 'O shame! where is thy blush? Rebellious hell,   /  If thou canst mutine in a matron''s bones,   /  To flaming youth let virtue be as wax,   /  And melt in her own fire: proclaim no shame   /  When the compulsive ardour gives the charge,   /  Since frost itself as actively doth burn   /  And reason panders will.

text:
'The poet Andrew Marvell, writing a few years after Shakespeare''s death,  treated this theme in his "Gallery," of which the last two stanzas are relevant:
These Pictures and a thousand more,  
Of Thee, my Gallery does store;  
In all the Forms thou can''st invent,  
Either to please me, or torment:  
For thou alone to people me,   45
Art grown a num''rous Colony;  
And a Collection choicer far  
Then or White-hall''s, or Mantua''s were.  
  
But, of these Pictures and the rest,  
That at the Entrance likes me best:   50
Where the same Posture, and the Look  
Remains, with which I first was took.  
A tender Shepherdess, whose Hair  
Hangs loosely playing in the Air,  
Transplanting Flow''rs from the green Hill,   55
To crown her Head, and Bosome fill.  
 
Marvell is treating his lover as a gallery of varying images, just as Hamlet treats his mother and father as changelings - capable of looking (and being) one way or another at the drop of a hat.

To read Marvell''s poem in its entirety, click the link:
http://www.bartleby.com/105/63.html
'
quote: 'Look here, upon this picture, and on this,   /  The counterfeit presentment of two brothers.

text:
'"Tinct" is "color," and so Gertrude is describing a black spot in her soul that cannot be removed.  This is yet another instance of the "mole" - the intractable physical symptom of moral decay - in Hamlet.  Recall both:

So, oft it chances in particular men,
That for some vicious mole of nature in them,
As, in their birth--wherein they are not guilty,
Since nature cannot choose his origin--
By the o''ergrowth of some complexion,
Oft breaking down the pales and forts of reason,
Or by some habit that too much o''er-leavens
The form of plausive manners, that these men,
Carrying, I say, the stamp of one defect,
Being nature''s livery, or fortune''s star,--
Their virtues else--be they as pure as grace,
As infinite as man may undergo--
Shall in the general censure take corruption
From that particular fault: the dram of eale
Doth all the noble substance of a doubt
To his own scandal.
(1.4)

and (in a line in which "mole" has a slightly different sense, but must include the other sense also):

Well said, old mole! canst work i'' the earth so fast?
A worthy pioner! Once more remove, good friends.
(1.5)
'
quote: 'And there I see such black and grained spots   /  As will not leave their tinct.

text:
'"Enseamed" is "greasy," or "fatty."  To enseam an animal was to strip it of fat.  Here, Hamlet uses it to mean "dirty" or "sweaty."  He pulls no punches in confronting Gertrude with the physical images of the sex act.  Oxford glosses "Honeying" as "using words like honey - sweet-talking," which would be another instance of Hamlet obsessing over language that doesn''t mean exactly what it says.
'
quote: 'In the rank sweat of an enseamed bed,   /  Stew''d in corruption, honeying and making love

text:
'This may contradict Eliot''s argument, a portion of which follows:

The "madness" of Hamlet lay to Shakespeare''s hand; in the earlier play a simple ruse, and to the end, we may presume, understood as a ruse by the audience. For Shakespeare it is less than madness and more than feigned. The levity of Hamlet, his repetition of phrase, his puns, are not part of a deliberate plan of dissimulation, but a form of emotional relief. In the character Hamlet it is the buffoonery of an emotion which can find no outlet in action; in the dramatist it is the buffoonery of an emotion which he cannot express in art. The intense feeling, ecstatic or terrible, without an object or exceeding its object, is something which every person of sensibility has known; it is doubtless a study to pathologists. It often occurs in adolescence: the ordinary person puts these feelings to sleep, or trims down his feeling to fit the business world; the artist keeps it alive by his ability to intensify the world to his emotions. The Hamlet of Laforgue is an adolescent; the Hamlet of Shakespeare is not, he has not that explanation and excuse. We must simply admit that here Shakespeare tackled a problem which proved too much for him.

If, as Eliot suggests, Shakespeare somehow "lost control" of his play and his character, then why would he introduce the ghost at this moment to get Hamlet back on track?  Essentially, the ghost tells Hamlet "you''re getting distracted!  Your mother''s not the problem here, it''s your uncle you should be worried about."  In Eliot''s language, the ghost would say, "Can''t you see that your mother is an inadequate objective correlative for your emotions!?"

The ghost instead urges Hamlet to "step between her and her fighting soul."  The question raised by the line is what the meaning of "her" is, if "her fighting soul" is somehow divorced from it.  We may read this as "step between her reason and her soul," or "between her conscience and her sou," but no matter what reading we give it we get the general thrust of the line.  The ghost is worried that Hamlet is losing the plot of the play (that is, the plot of the revenge tragedy), and he emerges at this point to refocus the energies of his fraying son.
'
quote: 'Do not forget: this visitation   /  Is but to whet thy almost blunted purpose.   /  But, look, amazement on thy mother sits:   /  O, step between her and her fighting soul:   /  Conceit in weakest bodies strongest works:   /  Speak to her, Hamlet.

text:
'A very funny line.  Imagine someone holding you at gunpoint, then talking to themselves for a moment, then lowering the gun and asking "so, how was your day?"
'
quote: 'How is it with you, lady?

text:
'Gertrude can''t see the ghost.
'
quote: 'That you do bend your eye on vacancy   /  And with the incorporal air do hold discourse?

text:
'A beautiful moment of doubt from Hamlet.  He recognizes that the ghost is right in at least one respect: his mother may not be the appropriate (or practical) target for his anger.  Reading lines 120-3, we assume that Hamlet is talking to Gertrude, because he has been talking to her in lines 118-119.  But Gertrude''s response - "To whom do you speak this?" - tell has that Hamlet''s lines 120-3 were intended for the ghost.

Either way, this is a moment of uncharacteristic vulnerability.  He must part ways with parental love as such if he is to continue with his revenge plot, if he wants to keep up his "true colour" (with pun on "choler").
'
quote: 'On him, on him! Look you, how pale he glares!   /  His form and cause conjoin''d, preaching to stones,   /  Would make them capable. Do not look upon me;   /  Lest with this piteous action you convert   /  My stern effects: then what I have to do   /  Will want true colour; tears perchance for blood.

'Shakespeare used ecstasy in both OED senses:
1. The state of being ‘beside oneself’, thrown into a frenzy or a stupor, with anxiety, astonishment, fear, or passion.
and
    2. Pathol.   

a. By early writers applied vaguely, or with conflicting attempts at precise definition, to all morbid states characterized by unconsciousness, as swoon, trance, catalepsy, etc.


Hamlet''s revulsion to the word ("Ecstasy!") leads us to the second definition more than the first.
