'Note Hamlet''s change of technique: moments ago Gertrude''s blood was malfunctioning ("the hey-day in the blood...").  Now, when Hamlet wants to prove himself sane, he compares his blood to Gertrude''s "temperate pulse."  Is this a change wrought by the entrance of the ghost?

text:
'Unction here used as "soothing ointment," but also with the connotation of last rites, as in "extreme unction," a sense which would have been very much alive in 16th-century England.  A "flattering unction" would then be something to sooth the soul in life and also prepare it for death.

Moving on, Hamlet is now making a slick (and risky) rhetorical move.  "Don''t confuse your bad behavior with my ''madness,''" or, "Don''t think I''m mad just because you feel guilty."  The confusing thing is that Hamlet''s "madness," whatever it is, stems from Gertrude''s "tresspass," and so the two are difficult to distinguish.

text:
'This is a typical feature of the revenge tragedy: the virtuous engines through which redress might normally be sought are in the hands of the vicious, forcing virtue to be a beggar at vice''s door (i.e.  forcing the moral universe off-kilter and installing a vicious king in the office once held by a virtuous one, etc.).

And the Lord God formed\r\n a man from the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath\r\n of life, and the man became a living soul.

'Both "let''s drag you away" and "let''s get to the point."  "Draw toward an end" meant "conclude what you''re saying."  Hamlet delivers an appropriately rhetorical eulogy for this deflated windbag (whom we loved nevertheless).

text:
'Hamlet tells his mother "good night" on four separate occasions in this scene, and each time he lauches back into his diatribe.  Only now, at last, does he let her be. 

As you prepare to read 4.1, keep in mind the breath of life, because Claudius will try to decipher Gertrude''s "sighs" and "profound heaves," as though the answers he''s loooking for could be found in the breath itself.
'
quote: 'Exeunt severally; HAMLET dragging in POLONIUS

text:
'

Claudius is trying to decipher the meaning of Hamlet''s sighs.  This introduction to the second half of the play is a nice reminder to us that the action of Hamlet takes place largely on the inside of the characters - especially Hamlet himself - and that the outward shows of emotion, like the "profound heaves" that so frustrate Claudius, are only indicators of the "real" drama taking place beneath. 


Coleridge (1772-1834) called this phenomenon "ad et apud intra" tragedy, that is, tragedy "from inside the action."  This is contrasted with a tragedy like Macbeth, in which the action is more external ("ad extra," to Coleridge).  Claudius reminds us that the great mystery of this play isn''t what Hamlet''s doing but what he''s feeling and thinking.  We will return to Coleridge frequently (as well as other 19th century critics) as we begin to make sense of the end of the play.

'
quote: 'There''s matter in these sighs, these profound heaves:   /  You must translate: ''tis fit we understand them.   /  Where is your son?

text:
'We have to keep our eyes on the death of Polonius, because it will provide the impetus for Ophelia''s final unraveling in her spectacular mad scene, which is still to come.  \r\n

\r\n
Gertrude also hits on the divided quality of Hamlet''s "madness" - he does not seem to be directly seeking one particular object (why does Polonius have to die at all?) but rather to be lashing out in one way and then retreating and lashing out in another.  We know by this time that Hamlet is unsure of how to carry out his revenge, and of whether he wants to carry it out at all.
'
quote: 'in his lawless fit,   /  Behind the arras hearing something stir,   /  Whips out his rapier, cries, ''A rat, a rat!''   /  And, in this brainish apprehension, kills   /  The unseen good old man.

text: 'Interesting that Shakespeare does not bring this moment onstage, and have Hamlet weep over the body in front of the audience.  Knowing that he does express remorse over the slaying of Polonius allows the audience to experience two contradictory reactions: feeling sympathy and trust for Hamlet because his sanity is showing through his madness, while still feeling scared at how volatile he seems to have become.'
quote: 'he weeps for what is done.

text:
'This is not bad advice for these two sycophants: Claudius will indeed dispose of them ("squeeze them dry") when he''s done.\r\n

\r\n
Coleridge observes that Hamlet''s madness here "consists in the free utterance of all the thoughts that had passed through his mind before."  In other words, Hamlet is telling the truth to R&G in the most biting, honest way he can.  Hamlet is lucky, because the more vituperative he is in his encounters, the more he is taken for mad (which is to say, the more his interlocuters want to believe he''s mad).
'
quote: 'Besides, to be demanded of a sponge! what   /  replication should be made by the son of a king?   /  ROSENCRANTZ Take you me for a sponge, my lord?   /  HAMLET Ay, sir, that soaks up the king''s countenance, his   /  rewards, his authorities. But such officers do the   /  king best service in the end: he keeps them, like   /  an ape, in the corner of his jaw; first mouthed, to   /  be last swallowed: when he needs what you have   /  gleaned, it is but squeezing you, and, sponge, you   /  shall be dry again.

text:
'Oxford Classics declares this chiasmus ("The body...the body") to be "a riddle" that is incomprehensible to audiences.  Even if it is resistant to a simple, perfect meaning, consider a number of features of the sentence:

There is a pun on body, which we recognize from Richard II and elsewhere - body politic/physical body.  That the body is with the king may simply mean that the people are the king''s subjects.  Conversely, that the king is not with the body may mean that the king is not on the side of his people, that he is corrupt and deceitful (which he is).

Or, the second part of the phrase may use body only in the physical sense.  In this reading, "the king is not with the body," may mean, "King Hamlet is not with his physical body - he is a ghost."  

The dislocation of the king from his body, or from his subjects, could further allude to the usurping of Hamlet''s rightful throne by Claudius.  Had Gertrude not married him, Hamlet would now be the king of Denmark.  In that sense, the rightful king is not with his rightful body.

Finally, the last line of this scene - "The King is a thing - of nothing" - returns us to the theme of nothingness, which haunts Hamlet throughout the play (recall the threat of suicide, e.g.).  As Goethe observed in his reading of the play, "the feeling of nothingness will not leave Hamlet."

Hamlet sees nothingness in everything, so to speak.
'

text:
'As Hamlet''s "madness" hits full bloom, these flights of associative fancy become more and more frequent.  In understanding their structure and composition, Coleridge''s assessment is useful.

Coleridge calls Hamlet''s technique "the science of method."  What appears to be a kind of pseudo-lunatic free-association, Coleridge says, is in fact a different way of viewing facts and events.  Characters with less natural genius than Hamlet tend to view the world in a more limited, literal way.  These "uneducated" characters are defined by "a habitual submission of the understanding to mere events and images as such, and independent of any power in the mind to classify or appropriate them."  It doesn''t take much to see that Hamlet does just the opposite.  He views the world as a network of relationships between things - not simply the isolated things themselves.  

Because of this relational method of perception, Hamlet is able to uncover chains of meaning and resonances which are lost on other characters.  Hamlet is therefore a scientist of method.

In this speech Hamlet moves fluidly from the initial image provoked by the word "Polonius" - the dead body - to the fate of that body in the ground, then to the fate of all of our bodies after death, and finally to the ultimate indifference of death (and the "convocation of worms") to our station and physical stature in life.  

(We will return to the science of method later on, when Hamlet describes to Horatio how he "sealed" R&G''s fate.)
'
quote: 'Not where he eats, but where he is eaten: a certain   /  convocation of politic worms are e''en at him. Your   /  worm is your only emperor for diet: we fat all   /  creatures else to fat us, and we fat ourselves for   /  maggots: your fat king and your lean beggar is but   /  variable service, two dishes, but to one table:   /  that''s the end.

text: 'An allusion to the royal "progress," or vernal trip by Elizabeth and James I through England.  Hamlet is imagining the royalty feeding on the decomposed and recycled remains of a beggar when they stop along the way - a continuation of the "worm" theme of the previous speech.  Note that Hamlet''s relational thinking often extends beyond the confines of a single monologue, so that the logic of his speech remains obvious to him alone.  '

text:
'This line carries overtones of the bedroom scene, and Hamlet''s fury at the sexual confusion of his mother''s marriage to Claudius.  

Shakespearean characters in the throes of madness, real or feigned, often confuse the identities of those they are close to.  In 4.6 of Lear, Lear confuses Gloucester with his traitorous daughter Goneril:

Lear: Ha!  Goneril with a white beard!

In both cases, a male character is mistaken (or, in Hamlet''s case, provocatively taken) for a female character who has betrayed the protagonist.

To read this scene in full, click the link below.

'This verb will echo later on in the play, and is well worth noting.  As will soon be clear, Hamlet''s fate has been sealed by Claudius is more than the figurative sense: the royal signet ring has impressed his seal into the letter that instructs the recipient to kill the bearer (i.e. Hamlet).  Later on, Hamlet will re-seal the letter to seal the fates of R&G.\r\n

\r\n
More on this theme - and on the implications for the science of method reading - when we reach the relevant scene.

text:
'An excellent final couplet of Shakespeare''s.  Rhyming "done" and "begun" - two opposites that are close nonetheless - is appropriate for Claudius at this moment.  Recall that Claudius has been divided within himself since the murder of King Hamlet.  Here, his speech itself becomes divided, with the beginning ("begun") coming after the end ("done") of the action he wants to put into play (the death of Hamlet).

We are reminded of Macbeth''s monologue in 1.7, when he is considering Lady''s proposition to murder Duncan:

Macbeth: If it were done when ''tis done, then ''twere well
It were done quickly: if the assassination
Could trammel up the consequence, and catch
With his surcease success; that but this blow
Might be the be-all and the end-all here...

Like Claudius, the impossibility of getting it "done" is built in to the language itself.  Where the unintended ramifications of Claudius''s plot are implied by that menacing "begun," as if when Claudius thinks it''s done it''s really only starting, the ramifications of Macbeth''s are implied in the phrase "surcease success," which Greenblatt notes is as hard a thing to say as it is to do.

All of this adds up to a foreboding technique of Shakespeare''s: to include, in the very language expressing some new scheme or device, the possibility that that scheme will soon get out of the hands of its executor.

'
quote: 'done,   /  Howe''er my haps, my joys were ne''er begun.

text: 'Claudius is saying "alas, alas" because Hamlet appears to have lost it.  But this is not without it''s irony, because the "alas, alas" could be read in isolation as an expression of human helplessness in the face of death, which is what Hamlet has in fact been talking about.'

'Done/Begun must also bring up Bob Dylan''s "Stuck Inside of Mobile With the Memphis Blues Again," which contains the following rhyme:

Oh, Mama, can this really be the end?
To be stuck inside of Mobile with the Memphis blues again.

The British critic Christopher Ricks, of Oxford, calls this one of the best rhymes in the whole Dylan catalogue, and it doesn''t take much to see the connection between end/again and done/begun.  (For an excellent discussion of the nature of such rhymes as these, check out "Dylan''s Visions of Sin," with attention to the introduction.)

To listen to the song: http://youtube.com/watch?v=kqe7YOlkvfo

text:
'Fortinbras sends his captain to confirm with Claudius that he has license to pass onto Danish soil. 

The Fortinbras plot, which will become increasingly important in act five, is worth discussing briefly.  In his "Wilhelm Meister''s Apprenticeship" (1796), Goethe''s young protagonist considers the ethics of cutting ("mutilating") Hamlet to make it more amenable to performance by his acting company.  To figure out which scenes and characters would lend themselves to cutting, he divides the play into two "classes of objects," into the second of which - "external relations" - he places the Fortinbras plot. 

By "external relations" Wilhelm means the practical machinery of the play, by which the characters move from place to place and are "combined" with one another in a variety of ways.  The Norway subplot is one such "combiner" of persons, and viewing it this way can help us understand the mechanisms of these acts (four and five).  Although Fortinbras himself is not of the first class of objects, he is an important instrument with which Shakespeare can force his characters into the crucial configuration that will allow him the climactic final scenes.

We''ll return to Goethe again later on.  (For more, check out the novel "Wilhelm Meister''s Apprenticeship," which was translated into English for the first time in 1824.)
'

I humbly thank you, sir.

text:
'By now we''re accustomed to these speeches of Hamlet''s, in which he outlines the circumstances that should occasion his revenge but does not exact it.

Coleridge read these lines as follows:
"Hamlet is a man living in meditation, called upon to act by every motive human and devine, but the great object of his life is defeated by continually resolving to do, yet doing nothing but resolve."

Hamlet mistakes resolution for action once again in these lines.  Or does he?
'

text:
'The critics of the 19th century (Coleridge, Goethe, Hazlitt, etc.) seized on lines like these to paint a picture of Hamlet as desperately "wanting resolution" (Hazlitt).  Because the world in his own mind is so much more vivid and active than the dull world around him, his desires for revenge are lost in translation, so to speak, from conception to execution.

We may imagine the following dialogue between Hamlet and William Hazlitt (1778-1830), the British critic:

Hamlet: I do not know why yet I live to say ''This thing''s to do.''

Hazlitt: It''s certainly strange.  You seem "incapable of deliberate action," even as your circumstances certainly make revenge desirable and necessary.

Hamlet: Yes.  What''s more, I had the chance to kill Claudius.  I didn''t, though, because he was praying.

Hazlitt: You are only using Claudius''s praying as an excuse for your inaction.  Coleridge - my buddy - agrees with me on this one.

Hamlet: You''re probably right.  But I want my revenge to be perfect.

Hazlitt: Indeed you do.  But you may not get it perfectly.  You are a man who, because "he cannot have his revenge perfect, according to the most refined idea his wish can form, declines to have it altogether."

Hamlet: Well.  We''ll see about that.
'
quote: 'I do not know   /  Why yet I live to say ''This thing''s to do;''

text:
'A perfect example of Hamlet''s mistaking the diagnosis of his problem for the resolution of it.  Hamlet, as we have seen many times before, seems unable to distinguish the accurate observation of his desperate situation for the action that would be required to right it.

quote: 'Rightly to be great   /  Is not to stir without great argument,   /  But greatly to find quarrel in a straw   /  When honour''s at the stake.

text:
'Hamlet notes that greatness isn''t about talking all the time (which he does), but about acting (which Fortinbras does). 

He observes that Fortinbras has less cause than Hamlet to go to war, but that he has the true quality of a warrior, which is to drum up any conflict he can find when his honor is at stake, simply so that he will have cause to fight and defend himself.  This is the meaning of "find[ing] quarrel in a straw" - finding the reason to fight in a seemingly meaningless offense.


'

text:
'This is precisely what we will do in a moment - "collect" (make sense of) Ophelia''s mad speech.  "Nothing" is an important word here, because Shakespeare could have written "nonsense."  Nothing implies that Ophelia''s speech is somehow empty, not simply irrational.  Indeed, the meaning behind her words in this scene has been speculated on, and the observation here that it "moves" its hearers alludes to a certain powerful quality of it that transcends normal, average, nonsense speech.
'

text:
'Ophelia is thinking about Polonius, her father, and imagining the way in which he was buried.  As we know, this does not come close to describing Polonius''s dishonorable end - he''s still in the castle somewhere, rotting! - and for this reason the imagery of traditional and respectful burial are especially poingnant.

Both F and Q2 add the word "not" in the third line of the song, as in: "Which bewept to the grave did not go."  The "not" breaks the rhythm, of course, which leads editors to read it as a last-minute addition by Ophelia when she realizes that what she''s describing is the opposite of what happened to her father.

The "sweet flowers" will recur in many different guises throughout this scene.
'

text:
'An allusion to the folk tale in which Christ visits a baker, asks for food, receives it, and turns the baker''s daughter - who has reprimanded her mother for being overly generous - into an owl (OC).

In moments like this, Anna Jamesons''s theory that Ophelia is repeating and reworking certain fairy tales and rhymes that her nurses would have sung to her as a child, seems particularly attractive.  (For a brief description of Anna Jameson see the first note to this section.)

This type of gloss can be performed relatively easily on many of these speeches.

This is a poignant song, because it alludes to exactly what has happened to Ophelia.  We don''t know for sure whether or not Hamlet and she had sex before the play began, but certainly the one-two punch of Hamlet''s abandonment and her father''s death would be enough to destabilize her, and it''s no wonder that themes of love and rejection find their way into these songs.

text:
'Claudius is only half-right.  Polonius''s death has indeed hit Ophelia hard.  But we can''t deny the effect of Hamlet''s cruelty towards her ("get thee to a nunnery," etc.) on her emotional stability.  Without a consideration of Hamlet, any assessment of Ophelia''s madness is grossly lacking.

We must therefore say to Claudius what Titinius says to the dead Cassius in 5.3 of Julius Caesar: "thou hast misconstrued everything."
'

'OED gives:

[This is the commonest of a group of reduplicated words of parallel forms and nearly synonymous meaning, including hudder-mudder, Sc. hudge-mudge, and obs. hody-moke. Nothing definite appears as to their derivation or origin, and it is not unlikely that they came from different sources, and influenced each other. An early form, more usual in 16th c., was hucker-mucker (hoker-moker), the second element of which may have been the ME. vb. mukre, mokere-n to hoard up, conceal, whence mukrere, mokerere hoarder, miser (cf. sense 1b). Whether hucker had an independent existence (cf. the prec. words), or was merely a riming variation, cannot at present be determined. The change to hugger-mugger was phonetically easy and natural, but may have been helped by the influence of hudder-mudder, which was app. of different origin.] 

    A. n.

    1. Concealment, secrecy; esp. in phr. in hugger-mugger: in secret, secretly, clandestinely. Formerly in ordinary literary use, now archaic or vulgar.

text:
'Laertes may not be the most likeable character, but his grief over his sister''s madness is geniune.  What seems like rhetorical hot air is in fact the best he can do to express how distressed he is to see Ophelia like this.

Thus the tendency of Laertes to use inflated language, to be a braggart, to be all the things that Hazlitt described as "rodomontade," is made sympathetic when brought up against Ophelia''s madness and subsequent death.

(Tieck also notes that Shakespeare seems to have given Laertes a chance to become more sympathetic to audiences in these Ophelia scenes, and especially at her funeral.)
'
quote: 'O heat, dry up my brains! tears seven times salt,   /  Burn out the sense and virtue of mine eye!   /  By heaven, thy madness shall be paid by weight,   /  Till our scale turn the beam. O rose of May!   /  Dear maid, kind sister, sweet Ophelia!   /  O heavens! is''t possible, a young maid''s wits   /  Should be as moral as an old man''s life?   /  Nature is fine in love, and where ''tis fine,   /  It sends some precious instance of itself   /  After the thing it loves.

text:
'These songs are full of striking contrasts: the lyrical, childish, spring-like "hey nonny nonny" with the grave-side imagery, for instance.
'
quote: 'They bore him barefaced on the bier;   /  Hey non nonny, nonny, hey nonny;   /  And in his grave rain''d many a tear:--   /  Fare you well, my dove!

text:
'Laertes sees that there''s much to be deciphered in these songs and fragments.  Recall Horatio at 4.5.7:

Her speech is nothing:
Yet the unshaped use of it doth move
The hearers to collection...

text:
'Most editions include a gloss of the meanings of these various herbs. 

Tieck, however, delves into it more deeply.  Click on the specific herb or flower for Tieck''s (and, sometimes, Oxford''s) historical and figurative interpretations of Ophelia''s images.
'
quote: 'There''s rosemary, that''s for remembrance; pray,   /  love, remember: and there is pansies. that''s for thoughts.   /  LAERTES A document in madness, thoughts and remembrance fitted.   /  OPHELIA There''s fennel for you, and columbines: there''s rue   /  for you; and here''s some for me: we may call it   /  herb-grace o'' Sundays: O you must wear your rue with   /  a difference. There''s a daisy: I would give you   /  some violets, but they withered all when my father   /  died: they say he made a good end,--

text:
'Tieck: German rosemary was often strewn at weddings in England.  "It is because of her father, now dead, that she gives Laertes rosemary" to recall the union of the mother and father.
'
quote: 'rosemary,

text:
'Tieck: Pansies come from the French pensée, as noted in OED:

[< Middle French pensée (1460-6; French pensée; 1874 or earlier in sense ‘pansy-coloured’), transferred use of pensée thought.

These flowers are fore reminiscences, thoughts, and memories.  Tieck suggests a progression from rosemary (the wedding, the parents when alive) to pansies (pensées), the thoughts and memories of the parents after their deaths.
'
quote: 'pansies.

text:
'Tieck: Fennel is for flattery but proverbially for sex, desire, etc.
'
quote: 'fennel

text:
'Tieck: Columbine is for "faithlessness" and "crass sensuality." 

Faithlessness evokes Hamlet, of course, with "crass sensuality" invoking the perversion of their true love by Hamlet''s hyper-sexualized rejection of her.
'
quote: 'columbines:

text:
'Shakespeare''s use of "rue" here is unbelievably cool.

Tieck: In English, the meanings of "rue" and "ruth" overlap.  OED gives "contrition and regret" for both, and so the "herb of grace" suggests both the repentance which is necesasry to prepare the heart for devotion (this is the "rue" sense) as well as the forgiveness that may follow such a preparation (this is the "ruth" sense). 

Tieck suggests that Ophelia offers rue to Gertrude because of her "illicit marriage," but Ophelia herself should by all rights be wearing willow, which was the flower of the "abandoned lover."  (Significantly, Ophelia will kill herself near a willow tree.)

(For more of Tieck''s excellent discussion of this speech and others, see "Observations on some Characters in Hamlet," from 1823 (translated 1903).)

text:
'Claudius is deliberate here in his efforts to be taken seriously as a mourner. 

He is always in the uncomfortable position of a murderer at a funeral.
'
quote: 'I must commune with your grief,   /  Or you deny me right.

text:
'We have already discussed Anna Jamesons''s theory - that these songs are taken from ones that Ophelia''s nurse would have sang to her as a child.

But we must also introduce Goethe''s (better) theory, because Ophelia is about to make her exit and we''re running out of time.  Goethe suggests the following explanation for Ophelia''s constant singing in this scene.  The structure of these remarks is in dialogue, because Wilhelm (the protagonist of Wilhelm Meister - see introductory note to 4.5) is talking to a woman named Aurelia:

Aurelia: Should not the poet have furnished the insane maiden with another sort of songs?  Could one not select some fragments out of melancholy ballads for this purpose?

Wilhelm: Silently she lived within herself, yet she scarce concealed her wishes, her longing; the tones of desire were in secret ringing through her soul; and how often may she have attempted, like an unskillful nurse, to lull her senses to repose with songs which only kept them more awake.

We now see that Jameson was drawing on Goethe when making her own hypothesis about Ophelia.  Readers of Hamlet may make their own judgements, of course, about the place of the songs in this scene, asking themselves Why songs? and Why these songs?
'
quote: 'For bonny sweet Robin is all my joy.   /  LAERTES Thought and affliction, passion, hell itself,   /  She turns to favour and to prettiness.   /  OPHELIA [Sings]   /  And will he not come again?   /  And will he not come again?   /  No, no, he is dead:   /  Go to thy death-bed:   /  He never will come again.

'Hamlet has escaped from the Danish ship bound for England by jumping aboard the pirate ship just as it was breaking free.  R&G are now left alone on the Danish ship, still headed for England, while Hamlet is returning to Denmark.

text:
'Laertes asks why Claudius didn''t pursue legal action against Hamlet (OC).
'
quote: 'Why you proceeded not against these feats,   /  So crimeful and so capital in nature,   /  As by your safety, wisdom, all things else,   /  You mainly were stirr''d up.

text:
'Claudius gives two reasons to Laertes, which we can choose to believe or suspect.  First, he says, "I love my wife too much to take action against her son - she would be heartbroken."  Second, Hamlet is well-loved by the people of Denmark, and Claudius couldn''t risk losing popularity by going after him.

As we know, though, Claudius''s concern isn''t so much in taking action against Hamlet but in concealing the action he does take.
'
quote: 'O, for two special reasons;   /  Which may to you, perhaps, seem much unsinew''d,   /  But yet to me they are strong. The queen his mother   /  Lives almost by his looks; and for myself--   /  My virtue or my plague, be it either which--   /  She''s so conjunctive to my life and soul,   /  That, as the star moves not but in his sphere,   /  I could not but by her. The other motive,   /  Why to a public count I might not go,   /  Is the great love the general gender bear him;   /  Who, dipping all his faults in their affection,   /  Would, like the spring that turneth wood to stone,   /  Convert his gyves to graces; so that my arrows,   /  Too slightly timber''d for so loud a wind,   /  Would have reverted to my bow again,   /  And not where I had aim''d them.

text:
'Claudius puts himself in the same camp as Laertes.  "Both of us," he says, "have suffered wrongs at the hands of Hamlet.  But we are men who will respond to these challenges." 
'
quote: 'Break not your sleeps for that: you must not think   /  That we are made of stuff so flat and dull   /  That we can let our beard be shook with danger   /  And think it pastime.

text:
'Hamlet is trying to frame his return as unthreatening so that he can gain audience with Claudius.  For this reason, he uses the words "naked" and "alone" - a trick that will pique Claudius''s interest a few lines later.
'
quote: '''High and mighty, You shall know I am set naked on   /  your kingdom. To-morrow shall I beg leave to see   /  your kingly eyes: when I shall, first asking your   /  pardon thereunto, recount the occasion of my sudden   /  and more strange return. ''HAMLET.''

text:
'Claudius is trying to take stock of the scope of this change of plans.  Has the whole ship been diverted back to Denmark, or has Hamlet somehow escaped the fate (death) that was meant for him?
'
quote: 'Are all the rest come back?

text:
'This is the fantasy of a classic revenge, in which the avenger gets to tell the offender, "This is what you did, and this is why I am going to kill you."

For an outline of the classic revenge methodology, see Titus Andronicus 5.2, which includes the following speech of Tamora''s:

I am Revenge: sent from the infernal kingdom,
To ease the gnawing vulture of thy mind,
By working wreakful vengeance on thy foes.
Come down, and welcome me to this world''s light;
Confer with me of murder and of death:
There''s not a hollow cave or lurking-place,
No vast obscurity or misty vale,
Where bloody murder or detested rape
Can couch for fear, but I will find them out;
And in their ears tell them my dreadful name,
Revenge, which makes the foul offender quake.
'
quote: 'It warms the very sickness in my heart,   /  That I shall live and tell him to his teeth,   /  ''Thus didest thou.''

text:
'Claudius is concocting the grounds for the duel between Hamlet and Laertes.  Lamort, so the story goes, was so enamored of Laertes''s abilities with a sword that Hamlet was jealous and wanted to prove his abilities against Laertes.
'

text:
'Claudius is very skillful at manipulating Laertes.  Here, he riles him up by equating the love of his father with the desire to kill Hamlet.
'
quote: 'Not that I think you did not love your father;   /  But that I know love is begun by time;   /  And that I see, in passages of proof,   /  Time qualifies the spark and fire of it.   /  There lives within the very flame of love   /  A kind of wick or snuff that will abate it;   /  And nothing is at a like goodness still;   /  For goodness, growing to a plurisy,   /  Dies in his own too much: that we would do   /  We should do when we would; for this ''would'' changes   /  And hath abatements and delays as many   /  As there are tongues, are hands, are accidents;   /  And then this ''should'' is like a spendthrift sigh,   /  That hurts by easing. But, to the quick o'' the ulcer:--   /  Hamlet comes back: what would you undertake,   /  To show yourself your father''s son in deed   /  More than in words?

text:
'These lines appear only in Q2.  They were cut from the Folio probably because they distracted the audience from the unveiling of Claudius''s plan.  Claudius himself, Oxford notes, seems to realize that he''s gone on too long and regains his momentum with the line, "To the quick o''the ulcer."
'

But, to the quick o'' the ulcer:--

text:
'This is opposite of the logic that excused Hamlet from cutting Claudius''s throat while he was praying.

quote: 'No place, indeed, should murder sanctuarize;   /  Revenge should have no bounds.

text:
'The plan is to make Hamlet so jealous of Laertes''s fame as a duler that he will have no choice but to fight him.  It will thus appear to Gertrude and Denmark that Hamlet is the agent of his own death (when, as Claudius anticipates, he dies in the duel).
'
quote: 'Hamlet return''d shall know you are come home:   /  We''ll put on those shall praise your excellence   /  And set a double varnish on the fame   /  The Frenchman gave you, bring you in fine together   /  And wager on your heads:

text:
'Claudius tells Laertes that one of the sworts will be blunted, so that Laertes will be safe from Hamlet. In the original story of Hamlet (see earlier notes), the theme of switching swords is also important.  Hamlet''s sword has been riveted to its sheath by the fearful king, and Hamlet switches it with the king''s normal swort at the last minute.  Then, when he draws and goes at the king, the king finds his sword riveted tragically to its sheath and so is unable to defend himself.  A perfect revenge. 
'
quote: 'he, being remiss,   /  Most generous and free from all contriving,   /  Will not peruse the foils; so that, with ease,   /  Or with a little shuffling, you may choose   /  A sword unbated,

quote: 'And, for that purpose, I''ll anoint my sword.   /  I bought an unction of a mountebank,   /  So mortal that, but dip a knife in it,   /  Where it draws blood no cataplasm so rare,   /  Collected from all simples that have virtue   /  Under the moon, can save the thing from death   /  That is but scratch''d withal:

text:
'A mountebank is a traveling herbist or chemist.  Spectacular etymology from OED:

[< Italian montambanco, montimbanco (late 17th cent.), contracted form of monta in banco (1598 in Florio), lit. ‘mount on bench’ (< monta imperative of montare

MOUNT v. + in on + banco bench: see BANK n.2), with reference to the raised platform used by itinerant salesmen. Cf. Middle French montenbancque (15th cent.). Cf. SALTIMBANCO n.
  Florio (1598) glosses montar'' in banco (lit. ‘to mount on a bench’) as ‘to plaie the mountibanke’.] 

    1. a. An itinerant charlatan who sold supposed medicines and remedies, freq. using various entertainments to attract a crowd of potential customers. Later also (more generally): an itinerant entertainer. Now chiefly hist.
'

'

text:
'These two lines scan together iambically, which suggests that Claudius is mid-thought when Gertrude enters.
'
quote: 'Our purpose may hold there.   /  Enter QUEEN GERTRUDE How now, sweet queen!

text:
'Coleride gets carried away by the emotion of Ophelia''s death:

"That Laertes might be excused for not cooling, the Act concludes with the affecting death of Ophelia, - who in the beginning lay like a little projection of land into a lake or stream, covered with spray-flowers quietly reflected in the quiet waters, but at length is undermined or loosesned, and becomes a fairy isle, and after a brief vagrancy sinks almost without an eddy!"

Coleridge happens upon the "liquid" quality of Ophelia''s motion through the play, a stream diverted by outside action but able to do little to affect her own course.
'
quote: 'Drown''d! O, where?

text:
'(The willow was mentioned already in the notes to Ophelia''s flower speech.)

Willows do in fact have white under-sides to their leaves, making them a lovely metaphor here for Shakespeare.  Though they appear living when seen from above on land, they reveal their white underbellies when water reflects them.  And white, as has been seen, is associated by Ophelia and others with age and death.  Tragically, Ophelia''s death has nothing to do with age.
'
quote: 'There is a willow grows aslant a brook,   /  That shows his hoar leaves in the glassy stream;

text:
'

Feminist readings of the play often cite this passage as a defense by Gertrude of the fragile Ophelia.  By declining to say outright that Ophelia killed herself, Gertrude is protecting not only her honor but also Laertes''s feelings.  She is softening the blow.

\r\n

There are also practical reasons for framing Ophelia''s death as something other than suicide.  In early modern England suicide was a serious crime, and suicides were denied Christian burial rites in all but cases of extreme insanity.  In fact, there were court cases in the early 17th century that dealt with just such questions: How insane was the defendant at the moment of suicide?  Could it have been helped?  etc.

\r\n

(For more, see "Ophelia''s Maimed Rites," an article by Michael MacDonald in the Fall 1986 Shakespeare Quarterly.)

'
quote: 'There, on the pendent boughs her coronet weeds   /  Clambering to hang, an envious sliver broke;   /  When down her weedy trophies and herself   /  Fell in the weeping brook.

text:
'A beautiful elegy for his dead sister.  (Laertes''s words at his sister''s graveside will be more ornate that these, part of what Tieck calls a "challenge" to Hamlet to meet him in the extravagancy of his mourning.)

For now, though, we glimpse a private, destitute Laertes, and we cannot help but feel for him.  This is an astonishing feat of Shakespeare''s, because only a few moments ago Laertes was plotting the ignominious death of Hamlet by poison, and we were not so sympathetic.
'
quote: 'Too much of water hast thou, poor Ophelia,   /  And therefore I forbid my tears: but yet   /  It is our trick; nature her custom holds,   /  Let shame say what it will:

text:
'This more emotionally "tragic" response to death is the appropriate backdrop for the following scene, in which the play''s attitude towards death will be transformed by the gravediggers.
'
quote: 'Alas, then, she is drown''d?   /  QUEEN GERTRUDE Drown''d, drown''d.

text:
'

This interlude between Ophelia''s death and her burial allows for a scene in which, critics generally concede, Shakespeare looks at death from a very different angle.  More traditional critics often note the "positivist" (Harold Bloom''s word) attitude of the gravediggers as contrasted with the more emotional and religious attitude of Laertes and Gertrude in the previous scene.

Bloom also notes the gravedigger''s "chilling pride" in his labor, of which more will be seen. 

(For more of this kind of criticism, check out Harold Bloom''s "Hamlet: Poem Unlimited.")

'
quote: 'SCENE I. A churchyard. Enter two Clowns, with spades, & c

text:
'The clowns are discussing the ethical problems of burying a suicide in a Christian cemetery.  Can it be done?  Should it be?  The Book of Common Prayer prohibited burying suicides with full Christian ceremony, and the issue poses significant challenges to these characters (OC).
What''s important to remember is that Ophelia is, in Greenblatt''s word, only "suspected" of suicide by these characters.  It''s therefore not a foregone conclusion that she will be granted or denied any type of burial. 
(For more, see Stephen Greenblatt, "Hamlet in Purgatory," pp. 245-6.)
'
quote: 'Is she to be buried in Christian burial that   /  wilfully seeks her own salvation?

text:
'A quibble: straight as in "straightaway" and also as in "correctly shaped."
'
quote: 'straight:

text:
'Perversion of Latin "ergo" (therefore) (OC).
'

text:
'The actor would gesture to set the scene: "Imagine that the water''s right where that tree is..."
'
quote: 'Here lies the water; good: here   /  stands the man; good;

text:
'This is the potivist tendency noted by Bloom.  The gravediggers (of whom the First Clown is chief - he''s the one with the shovel) are trying rationally to figure out Ophelia''s death.  Contrast this deliberate reconstruction of the moment of her drowning with Gertrude''s "Drown''d, drown''d" only a few moments earlier.
'
quote: 'if the man go to this water,   /  and drown himself, it is, will he, nill he, he   /  goes,--mark you that; but if the water come to him   /  and drown him, he drowns not himself: argal, he   /  that is not guilty of his own death shortens not his own life.

text:
'The second clown is a skeptic, and he''s probably right.  If Ophelia hadn''t had powerful family connections, she might not have wound up in a Christian cemetery.
'
quote: 'crowner''s quest law.   /  Second Clown Will you ha'' the truth on''t? If this had not been   /  a gentlewoman, she should have been buried out o''   /  Christian burial.

text:
'"Great folk" like Ophelia have a privilege that average people don''t have: to kill themselves and avoid the consequences in the afterlife. 
'
quote: 'the more pity that   /  great folk should have countenance in this world to   /  drown or hang themselves,

text:
'The first clown, in the tradition of other Shakespearean fool-savants (Macbeth''s Porter, the asp-salesman who sells Cleopatra the snake), sees the contradictions of his profession.  By saying that the gallows outlives the church, the second clown commits heresy, and so may wind up on the gallows himself - whereby he will prove the very maxim that brought him to the gallows in the first place!
'
quote: 'What, art a heathen? How dost thou understand the   /  Scripture? The Scripture says ''Adam digged:''   /  could he dig without arms? I''ll put another   /  question to thee: if thou answerest me not to the   /  purpose, confess thyself--   /  Second Clown Go to.   /  First Clown What is he that builds stronger than either the   /  mason, the shipwright, or the carpenter?   /  Second Clown The gallows-maker; for that frame outlives a   /  thousand tenants.   /  First Clown I like thy wit well, in good faith: the gallows   /  does well; but how does it well? it does well to   /  those that do in: now thou dost ill to say the   /  gallows is built stronger than the church: argal,   /  the gallows may do well to thee.

text:
'Bloom assumes that the great Shakespearean fool Robert Armin played the gravedigger, and so the songs Shakespeare gave him would no doubt have been exploited to their fullest entertaining potential.
'
quote: 'In youth, when I did love, did love,   /  Methought it was very sweet,   /  To contract, O, the time, for, ah, my behove,   /  O, methought, there was nothing meet.

text:
'Hamlet articulates the contradiction that the gravedigger poses to the play as a whole.  How is it that a man whose business is death can whistle as he works, as it were?
'
quote: 'Has this fellow no feeling of his business, that he   /  sings at grave-making?

text:
'Those with less experience of death are more affected by it than those, like Hamlet and Laerets, who are newly acquainted with it.
'
quote: '''Tis e''en so: the hand of little employment hath   /  the daintier sense.

text:
'OED gives the following for "jowl" as a verb:
2. To bump; to strike, knock, or push; esp., to dash (the head, etc.) \r\nagainst something.

Keep in mind that "jowl" is also the jaw.

quote: 'jowls

text:
'This kind of thinking about the body after death would have been very alive for Shakespeare in 1601, the (likely) year of Hamlet''s composition.

Not only had his son Hamnet (a variation of Hamlet) died young in 1596, but his father John died in 1601.  By introducing the irreconciliable transformation of a living person into a decaying body, Shakespeare brings to light the contradictions behind the burial ritual itself.  Burial, and indeed all rituals for "managing grief," is meant to ease the suffering of the living (Greenblatt).  But it must by nature rub up against the source of the grief itself, and come face to face with the physical evidence of the dead body. 

(For more, see "Hamlet in Purgatory," pp. 246-7.)
'
quote: 'That skull had a tongue in it, and could sing once:   /  how the knave jowls it to the ground, as if it were   /  Cain''s jaw-bone, that did the first murder! It   /  might be the pate of a politician, which this ass   /  now o''er-reaches; one that would circumvent God,   /  might it not?   /  HORATIO It might, my lord.   /  HAMLET Or of a courtier; which could say ''Good morrow,   /  sweet lord! How dost thou, good lord?'' This might   /  be my lord such-a-one, that praised my lord   /  such-a-one''s horse, when he meant to beg it; might it not?   /  HORATIO Ay, my lord.   /  HAMLET Why, e''en so: and now my Lady Worm''s; chapless, and   /  knocked about the mazzard with a sexton''s spade:   /  here''s fine revolution, an we had the trick to   /  see''t. Did these bones cost no more the breeding,   /  but to play at loggats with ''em? mine ache to think on''t.   /  First Clown [Sings]   /  A pick-axe, and a spade, a spade,   /  For and a shrouding sheet:   /  O, a pit of clay for to be made   /  For such a guest is meet.   /  Throws up another skull HAMLET There''s another: why may not that be the skull of a   /  lawyer? Where be his quiddities now, his quillets,   /  his cases, his tenures, and his tricks? why does he   /  suffer this rude knave now to knock him about the   /  sconce with a dirty shovel, and will not tell him of   /  his action of battery? Hum! This fellow might be   /  in''s time a great buyer of land, with his statutes,   /  his recognizances, his fines, his double vouchers,   /  his recoveries: is this the fine of his fines, and   /  the recovery of his recoveries, to have his fine   /  pate full of fine dirt? will his vouchers vouch him   /  no more of his purchases, and double ones too, than   /  the length and breadth of a pair of indentures? The   /  very conveyances of his lands will hardly lie in   /  this box; and must the inheritor himself have no more, ha?

text:
'Hamlet is considering the possibility of the body "living on" after death in a different form.  For sheep and calves, this kind of perpetuity comes with the practical use of their skins: to make paper.  Hamlet toys with the idea but immediately dismisses it, having decided that it offers little consolation. 
"Sheep and calves" here means "idiots."
'
quote: 'Is not parchment made of sheepskins?   /  HORATIO Ay, my lord, and of calf-skins too.   /  HAMLET They are sheep and calves which seek out assurance   /  in that.

text:
'A spectacular pun.  Dead bodies do indeed "lie" in their graves, but the gravedigger is still alive.  Therefore, he "lies" (doesn''t tell the truth) in his grave, which proves simultaneously that the grave is his and is not his.
'

text:
'"Quick" means "living."  This word will come back, of course, in Laertes''s moving speech at Ophelia''s graveside.

text:
'Unlike Hamlet, the gravedigger sees death as a loss of all earthly identity.
'
quote: 'Who is to be buried in''t?   /  First Clown One that was a woman, sir; but, rest her soul, she''s dead.

text:
'Hamlet isn''t only refering to the gravedigger''s positivism and rationality here.  Recall that Hamlet has seen direct evidence that the distinction between the "quick and the dead" is not at all absolute.  He has see, in other words, his father''s ghost.

Following Greenblatt''s lead, let''s draw the following contrast.  For Hamlet, the dead can still appear and even make demands.  Shakespeare begins 5.1 with the gravedigger''s rational consideration of Ophelia''s suicide, believing as they do that a single and correct answer exists for this question: Where should Ophelia wind up?

Hamlet knows that the station of the soul after death is not set in stone.  Hamlet''s father is in Purgatory at present, but with the prayers of the living he may ascend to heaven.  Death is not a question with an "absolute" answer, in this formulation.  But the gravedigger scene suggests that death is final and entirely physical and earthly. 

Where does Shakespeare stand?
'
quote: 'How absolute the knave is!

text:
'This is a poignant reminder of the state of affairs in the Denmark of Hamlet''s youth.

Goethe devotes considerable space in "Wilhelm Meister" to an imaginary exercise that is relevant to this line.  Wilhelm, trying to figure out how best to play Hamlet, tries to envision what his life would have been like before the death of his father.  Wilhelm finds that this helps him understand what critics call the "inconsistencies" in Hamlet''s character (see Coleridge, Hazlitt, etc.).  What Wilhelm discovers is that Hamlet as a boy was probably handsome, well cared-for, and all set to become king.  That his father defeated Norway on the very day on which his son was born makes the parallel threat of Norway at this moment in the play seem symbolic of the decline of the kingdom of Denmark and the loss of Hamlet''s secure and hopeful youth.
'
quote: 'Cannot you tell that? every fool can tell that: it   /  was the very day that young Hamlet was born; he that   /  is mad, and sent into England.

text:
'This is the knockout example that Coleridge uses when describing his "science of method."  He writes:
"When the habit of method is present and effective, things the most remote in diverse time, place, and outward circumstance, are brought into mental contiguity and succession, the more striking as the less expected."

The engine of Hamlet''s mind, when driven by the battery of some passion or dire circumstance ("connecting energy," to Coleridge), is capable of feats of assembly and compression that are truly astonishing.  It is abilities like this that lead critics to call Hamlet Shakespeare''s "genius" character.

(If you missed my description of the "science of method," see the note to Hamlet 4.3 on the line "Not where he eats...")'
quote: 'Why may   /  not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander,   /  till he find it stopping a bung-hole?   /  HORATIO ''Twere to consider too curiously, to consider so.   /  HAMLET No, faith, not a jot; but to follow him thither with   /  modesty enough, and likelihood to lead it: as   /  thus: Alexander died, Alexander was buried,   /  Alexander returneth into dust; the dust is earth; of   /  earth we make loam; and why of that loam, whereto he   /  was converted, might they not stop a beer-barrel?   /  Imperious Caesar, dead and turn''d to clay,   /  Might stop a hole to keep the wind away:   /  O, that that earth, which kept the world in awe,   /  Should patch a wall to expel the winter flaw!

text:
'This is the first instance of Laertes asking the Priest if any more ceremony can attend his sister''s funeral.  Greenblatt sees these requests as symptomatic of a larger problem in Hamlet: the breakdown of the systems and rituals which normally help us deal with grief and death (Greenblatt, "Hamlet in Purgatory.") 
Laertes doesn''t want his sister to be dishonored in death, to be sure, but he also wants some kind of ritual to hold onto as his grief consumes him.
'
quote: 'What ceremony else?   /  HAMLET That is Laertes,   /  A very noble youth: mark.   /  LAERTES What ceremony else?   /  First Priest Her obsequies have been as far enlarged   /  As we have warrantise: her death was doubtful;   /  And, but that great command o''ersways the order,   /  She should in ground unsanctified have lodged   /  Till the last trumpet: for charitable prayers,   /  Shards, flints and pebbles should be thrown on her;   /  Yet here she is allow''d her virgin crants,   /  Her maiden strewments and the bringing home   /  Of bell and burial.

    2. ministering angel n. (a) \r\nan angel who ministers to God (in quot. 1592: Lucifer); (b) \r\na kind-hearted person, esp. a woman, who nurses, aids, or comforts others.

Laertes is saying that his sister will be in heaven when the priest is "howling" in hell.

text:
'Hamlet''s grief over Ophelia seems at first to contradict his cruelty towards her in previous scenese.  Hazlitt offers a way to reconcile these two Hamlets:
"He could neither marry Ophelia, nor wound her mind by explaining the cause of his alienation, which he durst hardly trust himsefl to think of.  It would have taken him years to come to a direct explanation on the point...His conduct does not contradict what he says when he sees her funeral."

Knowing this, we are prepared to believe that Hamlet is sincerely grief-stricken (as of course we know him to be) at this moment.  With such a reading in mind we turn to Tieck''s reading of the competitive grieving that we see between Hamlet and Laertes.  Tieck reads this and the following monologues of Laertes, which are indeed extravagant, as an invitation (challenge) to Hamlet to come and meet him in the outward display of his love and grief for Ophelia.
'
quote: 'Now pile your dust upon the quick and dead,   /  Till of this flat a mountain you have made,   /  To o''ertop old Pelion, or the skyish head   /  Of blue Olympus.   /  HAMLET [Advancing] What is he whose grief   /  Bears such an emphasis? whose phrase of sorrow   /  Conjures the wandering stars, and makes them stand   /  Like wonder-wounded hearers? This is I,   /  Hamlet the Dane.   /  Leaps into the grave LAERTES The devil take thy soul!   /  Grappling with him HAMLET Thou pray''st not well.   /  I prithee, take thy fingers from my throat;   /  For, though I am not splenitive and rash,   /  Yet have I something in me dangerous,   /  Which let thy wiseness fear: hold off thy hand.

text:
'Hamlet''s theatrical vocabulary here ("prologue," "play") suggests that he thinks of his re-writing of the commission as a creative act, whereby he will rechart the course of the action that follows, which is, of course, the action of the play itself.

text:
'Hamlet is performing aloud the contents of his letter.  This is Hamlet playing Hamlet, so to speak - the real Hamlet dramatizing the actions of the written, strategic Hamlet.
'
quote: 'As England was his faithful tributary,   /  As love between them like the palm might flourish,   /  As peace should stiff her wheaten garland wear   /  And stand a comma ''tween their amities,   /  And many such-like ''As''es of great charge,   /  That, on the view and knowing of these contents,   /  Without debatement further, more or less,   /  He should the bearers put to sudden death,   /  Not shriving-time allow''d.

text:
'"Shriving time" means time for confession and penitence.  Hamlet knows firsthand the importance of last rites, of confession at the moment of death, because his father is suffering in Purgatory partly as a result of his being denied shriving time. 

The punishment that he has concocted for R&G is thus made more "perfect" by the inclusion of this final line.  (Whether or not the phrase "shriving time" was included exactly in that way in the actual text of Hamlet''s forged commission is not entirely clear, and it doesn''t much matter: the point her is the glimpse we get of Hamlet''s conception of his revenge, not necessarily the details of the revenge itself.)
'
quote: 'shriving-time

text:
'We return to the seal that seals fates, as discussed earlier.  Coleridge notes that Hamlet''s gift for compression of narrative means that he sometimes eliminates important details, like the manner in which the letter was sealed, and so Horatio must keep him on track to assemble the complete picture.

But, in the   /  verity of extolment, I take him to be a soul of   /  great article; and his infusion of such dearth and   /  rareness, as, to make true diction of him, his   /  semblable is his mirror; and who else would trace   /  him, his umbrage, nothing more.   /  OSRIC Your lordship speaks most infallibly of him.   /  HAMLET The concernancy, sir? why do we wrap the gentleman   /  in our more rawer breath?   /  OSRIC Sir?   /  HORATIO Is''t not possible to understand in another tongue?   /  You will do''t, sir, really.   /  HAMLET What imports the nomination of this gentleman?   /  OSRIC Of Laertes?   /  HORATIO His purse is empty already; all''s golden words are spent.   /  HAMLET Of him, sir.   /  OSRIC I know you are not ignorant--   /  HAMLET I would you did, sir; yet, in faith, if you did,   /  it would not much approve me. Well, sir?   /  OSRIC You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is--   /  HAMLET I dare not confess that, lest I should compare with   /  him in excellence; but, to know a man well, were to   /  know himself.   /  OSRIC I mean, sir, for his weapon; but in the imputation   /  laid on him by them, in his meed he''s unfellowed.

text:
'Greenblatt notes the strangeness of referring to King Hamlet not as "my father" but as "My King."  Up until this point, the memory of the ghost has been personal, as when Hamlet told Horatio he had seen his "father" way back when the ghost first appeared.

Now, in a line that is almost the last invocation of King Hamlet, the ghost has really died.  There is no longer a "father" alive for Hamlet, and instead - here, again Greenblatt - there is only a dead father who marks time since his death.  Recall that the gravedigger used the death of King Hamlet as a time-marker in answer to Hamlet''s question, and notice that Hamlet''s "signet ring" is the thing that brings up his father for the last time. 

Does the "death" of King Hamlet, coming at last in 5.2, invite the marvelous speech in 5.2.172-190?

For more, see Greenblatt, "Hamlet in Purgatory," pp. 226-27.
'
quote: 'Does it not, think''st thee, stand me now upon--   /  He that hath kill''d my king and whored my mother,

text:
'The last mention by Hamlet of his father.  As noted previously, Greenblatt reads this as a significant acceptance or acknowledgement of the reality of the death of King Hamlet.

Whereas before he had been an influential specter (with a pun, of course, on specter), he is now decidedly a memory - a stamp in wax that indicates he was there but is no longer.
'
quote: 'I had my father''s signet in my purse,

text:
'A spectacular speech that invites lots of critical speculation.  Hamlet here separates himself from his madness - "Who does it then?  His madness" - in a way that suggests many questions and provides few answers.

If Hamlet is aware of his madness, as he seems, then does that mean he was in control of it the entire play, even as his revenge plot seemed to veer constantly off course?  And does Hamlet''s naming of his "madness" suggest that he believes it - that it wasn''t all a means to an end but something other that took him over? 

Bloom sees in this speech an "aura of transcendance," which marks a shift from this world to the world of dying and death, as though Hamlet were somehow preparing to leave everything behind.  Reading with this in mind, a line like "Hamlet from himself be ta''en away" rings sadder and more poignantly true.

For more, see Bloom, "Hamlet: Poem Unlimited," pp. 99-103.
'
quote: 'Give me your pardon, sir: I''ve done you wrong;   /  But pardon''t, as you are a gentleman.   /  This presence knows,   /  And you must needs have heard, how I am punish''d   /  With sore distraction. What I have done,   /  That might your nature, honour and exception   /  Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madness.   /  Was''t Hamlet wrong''d Laertes? Never Hamlet:   /  If Hamlet from himself be ta''en away,   /  And when he''s not himself does wrong Laertes,   /  Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it.   /  Who does it, then? His madness: if''t be so,   /  Hamlet is of the faction that is wrong''d;   /  His madness is poor Hamlet''s enemy.   /  Sir, in this audience,   /  Let my disclaiming from a purposed evil   /  Free me so far in your most generous thoughts,   /  That I have shot mine arrow o''er the house,   /  And hurt my brother.

text:
'Greenblatt notes the tragic irony of this moment: Laertes dies completely ignorant of Claudius''s crime against King Hamlet.  What he thinks he''s talking about is the poisoning of Gertrude.  Those lines, "The king''s to blame" are therefore truer than he himself can imagine.

That Laertes never learns the true reason for his death - the first murder that sets all the rest in motion - tells us something about the nature of Hamlet''s messy revenge here.
'

text:
'Much can be made of Hamlet''s last words.  Many critics note the ominous drums of Fortinbras''s army offering a noisy answer to Hamlet''s death, and the hint of division and political turmoil in Denmark that colors Hamlet''s death.

Importantly, the Folio text reads: "The rest is silence.  O, O, O, O!"
Many editors eliminate this howl and instead put in something tame like "He gievs a long sigh," as in Oxford.  But "O, O, O, O!" may be making a comeback - it''s quoted in Greenblatt and elsewhere - that it well deserves.

If Hamlet''s "silence" is immediately shattered by whatever pain he is enduring, then the moment takes on new meaning - the physical body asserting itself one last time, etc. 

"The rest is silence" is beautiful, to be sure, but it doesn''t offer us any consolation that the cause of Hamlet''s actions in these last five acts will ever be explained fairly to the assembled court.  "The rest is silence" seems to shut the door on further remembrance. 

Or maybe it''s just the opposite.  Maybe this is simply Hamlet giving up, crushed by what Goethe called "a burden that [he] can neither support nor cast off" - the burden of remembering his father and "setting right" the moral universe of Denmark.

However we read Hamlet''s final line, we should do as it says and be silent for a moment before we batter it with critical theories and interpretations, to let it hit us with its full force.
'

text:
'It''s hard not to feel for R&G - collateral damage in a tangle of plots and counterplots. 

This moment must recall for us the end of Lear, in which Edmund''s order on the lives of Lear and Cordelia is recalled too late:

Edmund: Quickly send,
Be brief in it, to the castle; for my writ
Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia:
Nay, send in time.

Characters in Shakespeare are constantly being caught up in plots that are much bigger than themselves.  The clown in "Titus Andronicus" is an archetypical example.  He delivers a letter to the evil Tamora - whose contents is never revealed -  that results in the following scene:

SATURNINUS
Go, take him away, and hang him presently.
Clown
How much money must I have?
TAMORA
Come, sirrah, you must be hanged.
Clown Hanged! by''r lady, then I have brought up a neck to
a fair end.

R&G meet a similar end.  They aren''t altogether sympathetic, but do they deserve to die?  "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead" is a chilling line, because it extends the scope of the tragedy far beyond Hamlet, far beyond the castle, to distant shores and unrelated innocents.

quote: 'But since, so jump upon this bloody question,   /  You from the Polack wars, and you from England,   /  Are here arrived give order that these bodies   /  High on a stage be placed to the view;   /  And let me speak to the yet unknowing world   /  How these things came about: so shall you hear   /  Of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,   /  Of accidental judgments, casual slaughters,   /  Of deaths put on by cunning and forced cause,   /  And, in this upshot, purposes mistook   /  Fall''n on the inventors'' reads: all this can I   /  Truly deliver.

text:
'Hamlet''s "silence" is broken by his own funerary rites. 

Ophelia was denied an honorable burial.
Polonius''s body was much abused after his death.

But these last bodies will be given proper burial - the dead are going to be remembered (or will they?) and Hamlet''s eulogy in the mouth of Fortinbras is strangely moving and appropriate.  "He was likely...to have proved most royally" is especially sad, because the change to be "proved most royally" - to act as king - is exactly what has been denied Hamlet.

"The rest is silence," says Hamlet, but the last thing the audience hears, before the curtain falls on this greatest of Shakespeare''s tragedies, is noise.
'

quote: 'Shakespeare uses in passing the unusual word "auger-hole” (a hole made by carpenters with a tool called an auger) and this mention has suggested to some scholars that the playwright was very familiar with Scot''s “Discoverie.” Scot''s book was extremely controversial at the time because it insisted that what was thought by the majority to be witchcraft was really a combination of folk medicine and stage magic, and the witch-hunters were mostly prosecuting mentally ill or ignorant poor old women. Scot''s book was banned in England and many copies were burnt after 1603 because king James though it went against his own views on the matter.  /    /  The connection with Macbeth is fairly tenuous: Scot mentions among the supposed abilities of witches that they were able to go "in and out of awger-holes." Since the word is quite rare, those who want to believe that Shakespeare read Scot insist that he must have gotten that word from The Discoverie. This theory owes much to wishful thinking: some modern scholars would really like Shakespeare to share their skepticism and empathy for the victims of witchhunts, rather than the official view at the time.  /

But Makduffe quickly avoiding from his horse, ere he came at him, answered (with his naked sword in his hand) saying: "It is true Makbeth, and now shall thine insatiable cruelty have an end, for I am even he that thy wizards have told thee of, who was never born of my mother, but ripped out of her womb"

text:
'"In Macbeth at the Globe, 1610, the 20 of April, Saturday, there was to be observed, first, how Macbeth and Banquo, two noble men of Scotland, riding through a wood, there stood before them three women fairies or nymphs, and saluted Macbeth, saying three times unto him, "Hail, Macbeth, King of Codon; for thou shall be a King, but shall beget no kings," etc. Then said Banquo, "what all to Macbeth, and nothing to me?" "Yes", said the nymphs, "hail to thee, Banquo, thou shall beget kings, yet be no king"; and so they departed and came to the country of Scotland to Duncan, King of Scots and it was in the days of Edward the Confessor.

And Duncan had them both kindly welcome, and made Macbeth forthwith Prince of Northumberland, and sent him home to his own castle, and appointed Macbeth to provide for him, for he would sup with him the next day at night, and did so.

And Macbeth contrived to kill Duncan and through the persuasion of his wife did that night murder the King in his own castle, being his guest; and there were many prodigies seen that night and the day before. And when Macbeth had murdered the king, the blood on his hands could not be washed off by any means, nor from his wives hands, which handed the bloody daggers in hiding them, which by means they became both much amazed and affronted.

The murder being known, Duncan''s two sons fled, the one to England, the other to Wales, to save themselves. They being fled, they were supposed guilty of the murder of their father, which was nothing so.

Then was Macbeth crowned king; and then he, for fear of Banquo, his old companion, that he should beget kings but be no king himself, he contrived the death of Banquo, and caused him to be murdered on his way as he rode. The next night, being at supper with his noble men whom he had to bid to a feast, to the which also Banquo should have come, he began to speak of noble Banquo, and to wish that he were there. And as he did thus, standing up to drink a carouse to him, the ghost of Banquo came and sat down in his chair behind him. And he, turning about to sit down again, saw the ghost of Banquo, which fronted him so, that he fell into a great passion of fear and fury, uttering many words about his murder, by which, when they heard that Banquo was murdered, they suspected Macbeth.

Then MackDove fled to England to the king''s son, and soon they raised an army and cam to Scotland, and at Dunstonanse overthrew Macbeth. In the meantime, while MacDove was in England, Macbeth slew MackDove''s wife and children, and after in the battle MackDove slew Macbeth. Observe also how Macbeth''s queen did rise in the night in her sleep, and walked and talked and confessed all, and the doctor noted her words."

quote: 'According to the “Chronicles,” Duncane, unable to deal with Makdowald’s threat by his own dwindling authority, called a meeting of his noblemen. Makbeth, “speaking much against the kings softness, and overmuch slackness in punishing offenders” promised to defeat the rebels if he and his friend Banquho, another thane who had faced revolts against Duncane before, were given the authority to do so. They were, and Makbeth defeated the rebels, and drove Makdowald’s back to his castle, where the desperate outlaw killed his family before killing himself. “Thus was justice and law restored again to the old accustomed course,” says the chronicle, “by the diligent means of Makbeth.”  /

The second of them said; ‘Hail Makbeth thane of Cawder.’ But the third said; ‘All hail Makbeth that hereafter shall be king of Scotland.’”  /

The same night after, at supper, Banquho jested with him and said: ‘Now Mackbeth thou hast obtained those things which the two former sisters prophesied, there remaineth only for thee to purchase that which the third said should come to pass.’ Whereupon Mackbeth revolving the thing in his mind, began even then to devise how he might attain to the kingdom: but yet he thought with himself that he must tarry a time, which should advance him thereto (by the divine providence) as it had come to passe in his former preferment.”  /

The words of the three weird sisters also [...] greatly encouraged him hereunto, but especially his wife lay sore upon him to attempt the thing, as she that was very ambitious, burning in unquenchable desire to bear the name of a queen.”  /

text:
'Shakespeare''s depiction of Duncan''s murder and Macbeth''s accession to the Scottish throne differs from the account in "Holinshed''s Chronicle." The play omits any mention of Banquo''s complicity both for political (Banquo was King James'' ancestor) and dramatic reasons (his innocence makes his death and Macbeth''s crime more horrible).

For the prick of conscience (as it chanceth ever in tyrants, and such as attain to any estate by unrighteous means) caused him ever to fear, least he should be served of the same cup, as he had ministered to his predecessor. The words also of the three weird sisters, would not out of his mind, which as they promised him the kingdom, so likewise did they promise it at the same time unto the posterity of Banquho.”  /

text: 'Compare this with Shakespeare''s "Macbeth."'
quote: 'But Fleance “by the benefit of the dark night” and “by the help of almighty God reserving him to better fortune, escaped that danger: and afterwards having some inkling (by the admonition of some friends which he had in the court) how his life was sought no less than his father’s, who was slain not by ‘chance meddlie’ [accidental manslaughter] (as by the handling of the matter Makbeth would have had it to appear) but even upon a prepensed [premeditated] devise:* whereupon to avoid further peril he fled into Wales.”

text: 'See Shakespeare''s Macbeth.'
quote: 'After the murder of Banquho “nothing prospered with [...] Makbeth: for in manner every man began to doubt his own life, and durst unneth [scarcely] appear in the king’s presence; and even as there were many that stood in fear of him, so likewise stood he in fear of many.”

text: 'Compare with Shakespeare''s "Macbeth."'
quote: 'To protect himself even further and “so that he might the more cruelly oppress his subjects with all tyrantlike wrongs,” Mackbeth built “a strong castle on the top of an high hill called Dunsinane, situate in Gowrie, ten miles from Perth, on such a proud height, that standing there aloft, a man might behold well near all the countries of Angus, Fife, Stermond, and Ernedale, as it were lying underneath him. This castle then being founded on the top of that high hill, put the realm to great charges before it was finished, for all the stuff necessary to the building, could not be brought up without much toil and business.”  /

text: 'Compare this with Shakespeare''s "Macbeth."'
quote: 'Mackbeth, according to the chronicle, would have had Makduffe killed immediately, but he felt he didn’t have to because “a certain witch, whom he had in great trust, had told that he should never be slain with man born of any woman, nor vanquished till the wood of Bernane came to the castle of Dunsinane. By this prophesy Makbeth put all fear out of his heart, supposing he might do what he would, without any fear to be punished for the same, for by the one prophesy he believed it was unpossible for any man to vanquish him, and by the other unpossible to slay him. This vain hope caused him to do many outrageous things, to the grievous oppression of his subjects.”  /

text: 'Compare this with Shakespeare''s "Macbeth."'
quote: 'Saved by Mackbeth’s overconfidence, “Makduffe, to avoid peril of life, purposed with himself to passe into England, to procure Malcolme Cammore to claim the crown of Scotland.

text: 'Compare this with Shakespeare''s "Macbeth."'
quote: 'But this was not so secretly devised by Makduffe, but that Makbeth had knowledge given him thereof: for kings (as is said) have sharp sight like unto Lynx, and long ears like unto Midas. For Makbeth had in every nobleman’s house, one sly fellow or other in fee with him, to reveal all that was said or done within the same, by which slight he oppressed the most part of the nobles of his realm.

text: 'Compare this with Shakespeare''s "Macbeth."'
quote: 'he came hastily with a great power into Fife, and forthwith besieged the castle where Makduffe dwelled, trusting to have found him therein. They that kept the house, without any resistance opened the gates, and suffered him to enter, mistrusting none evil. But nevertheless Makbeth most cruelly caused the wife and children of Makduffe, with all other whom he found in that castle, to be slain. Also he confiscated the goods of Makduffe, proclaimed him traitor, and confined him out of all parts of his realm.”  /

text: 'Compare this with Shakespeare''s "Macbeth."'
quote: 'Makduffe, however, had already “escaped out of danger, and gotten into England unto Malcolme Cammore, to try what purchase he might make by means of his support, to revenge the slaughter so cruelly executed on his wife, his children, and other friends. At his coming unto Malcolme, he declared into what great misery the estate of Scotland was brought, by the detestable cruelties exercised by the tyrant Makbeth, having committed many horrible slaughters and murders, both as well of the nobles as commons, for the which he was hated right mortally of all his liege people, desiring nothing more than to be delivered of that intolerable and most heavy yoke of thralldom, which they sustained at such a caitif’s [villain’s] hands.  /    /  Makduffe’s words filled Malcolme with sorrow, but he was not sure that Makduffe had been wronged but the tyrant or whether he had been “sent from Makbeth to betray him.” Malcolme put the thane to a test and  “dissembling his mind at the first, he answered as followeth: ‘I am truly very sorry for the misery chanced to my country of Scotland, but though I have never so great affection to relive the same, yet by reason of certain incurable vices, which reign in me, I am nothing meet thereto. First, such immoderate lust and voluptuous sensuality (the abominable fountain of all vices) followeth me, that if I were made king of Scots, I should seek to deflower maids and matrons, in such wise that mine intemperance should be more importable unto you, than the bloodie tyranny of Makbeth now is." Hereunto Makduffe answered: "This surely is a very evil fault, for many noble princes and kings have lost both lives and kingdoms for the same; nevertheless there are women enough in Scotland, and therefore follow my counsel. Make thy self king, and I shall convey the matter so wisely that thou shalt be so satisfied at thy pleasure in such secret wise, that no man shall be aware thereof.’  /    /  “Then said Malcolme, ‘I am also the most avaricious creature on the earth, so that if I were king, I should seek so many ways to get lands and goods, that I would slay the most part of all the nobles of Scotland by surmised accusations, to the end I might enioy their lands, goods, and possessions; and therefore to show you what mischief may ensue on you through mine unsatiable covetousness, I will rehearse unto you a fable. There was a fox having a sore place on him overset with a swarm of flies, that continually sucked out her blood: and when one that came by and saw this manner, demanded whether she would have the flies driven beside her, she answered no: for if these flies that are already full, and by reason thereof suck not very eagerly, should be chased away, other that are empty and ‘fellie an hungred’ [fierce by hunger] should light in their places, and suck out the residue of my blood far more to my grievance than these, which now being satisfied do not much annoy me. Therefore saith Malcolme, suffer me to remain where I am, least if I attain to the regiment of your realm, mine unquenchable avarice may prove such; that ye would think the displeasures which now grieve you, should seem easy in respect of the unmeasurable outrage, which might ensue through my coming amongst you."  /    /  “Makduffe to this made answer, ‘how it was a far worse fault than the other: for avarice is the root of all mischief, and for that crime the most part of our kings have been slaine and brought to their final end. Yet notwithstanding follow my counsel, and take upon thee the crown. There is gold and riches enough in Scotland to satisfy thy greedy desire.’ Then Malcolme again, ‘I am furthermore inclined to dissimulation, telling of ‘leasings’ [lies], and all other kinds of deceit, so that I naturally rejoyce in nothing so much, as to betray & deceive such as put any trust or confidence in my words. Then since there is nothing that more becometh a prince than constancy, verity, truth, and justice, with the other laudable fellowship of those faire and noble virtues which are comprehended only in soothfastness, and that lying utterly overthroweth the same; you see how unable I am to governe any province or region: and therefore since you have remedies to cloak and hide all the rest of my other vices, I pray you find shift to cloak this vice amongst the residue.’"  /    /  “Then said Makduffe: ‘This yet is the worst of all, and there I leave thee, and therefore say; Oh ye unhappy and miserable Scottishmen, which are thus scourged with so many and sundry calamities, each one above other! Ye have one cursed and wicked tyrant that now reigneth over you, without any right or title, oppressing you with his most bloody cruelty. This other that hath the right to the crown, is so replete with the inconstant behavior and manifest vices of Englishmen, that he is nothing worthy to enjoy it: for by his own confession he is not only avaricious, and given to unsatiable lust, but so false a traitor withal, that no trust is to be had unto any word he speaketh. Adieu Scotland, for now I account my self a banished man for ever, without comfort or consolation,’ and with those words the brackish tears trickled down his cheeks very abundantly.”  /    /  “At the last, when he was ready to depart, Malcolme took him by the sleeve, and said: ‘Be of good comfort Makduffe, for I have none of these vices before remembered, but have jested with thee in this manner, onely to prove thy mind: for diverse times heretofore hath Makbeth sought by this manner of means to bring me into his hands, but the more slow I have showed my self to condescend to thy motion and request, the more diligence shall I use in accomplishing the same.’ Incontinently hereupon they embraced each other, and promising to be faithful the one to the other, they fell in consultation how they might best provide for all their business, to bring the same to good effect.”  /

text: 'Here! A hint at the central plot, finally! This is not the seed that is planted in Othello, his doubt has yet to arise. This seed is for us. And, I think, for Iago. Knowing his calculating and mercenary character within the first scene, how could he resist capitalizing on such an ominous suggestion? When reading Shax I have to constantly remind myself that it is being performed, ideally for the first time; try always to imagine that I do not know the plot, and note the order of revelation.'
