text: 'Oh, right - Iago is here. Pay attention to how often he is standing in the background throughout the play. He knows virtually everything we know at this point. Keep in mind which characters have a knowledge of action closest to that of the audience, and how that is (or is not) proportional to the amount of power they hold. What any given character knows (and what is being withheld from them) is crucial in Shax.'

text: 'This is the longest speech we have heard from Othello thus far, and it is anything but rude. His previous lines have been nothing but polite and professional, with a declaration of love as our introduction to his character. Count the adjectives here! Also how often he lists virtues and reinforces his own honesty. He is given a romantic turn of speech, a poet''s tongue. How readily we can believe that Desdemona would love him for it.'

text: 'This kills me. The Duke of Venice (and the whole war council) shifts from ''the Ottomites will attack, post-haste dispatch, send out our best'' to ''let''s listen to massive speeches about a domestic complaint''. text:
'We open on a scene of ill-inspired collusion, and in the first 20 lines we have Iago''s motivation. The object of his hate is not revealed explicitly, however, and is a nameless, faceless war hero who has slighted Iago. Note how we must put Othello''s character together for ourselves; he is first a man, then a captain (or some high level of military), then ''his Moorship'', then ''the Moor'', then a master, then ''the thicklips'', then a thief, a ''black ram'', a ''Barbary horse'', ''an extravagant and wheeling stranger''...and in this entire first scene we do not learn Othello''s name. This is possible because there is only one Moor, The Moor, and so we are immediately prompted to define Othello in terms of his own otherness.
Power of the exotic
inherent untrustworthiness of the other

Not so O can return safely to fight another day, as we might expect, but so he can return and consummate his marriage - for the good of Cyprus! For the peace of mind of the good citizen''s of Cyprus, O really needs to have a fully faceted union. Calling to Jove changes it from an idea of renewal to a mythic idea of renewal. Effect?

text:
'Because the textual history of King Lear is anything but straightforward, the first-time reader (and even the returning one) must ask herself: "What in the world am I reading?" The answer is that you are about to read a conflation of the First Quarto text of 1608 (the so-called "Pied Bull" quarto) and the Folio of 1623, which is 200 lines shorter than Q1 and contains a number of significant differences, textual and otherwise (Goneril is meaner in Q1, for instance) (Halio).

Most modern editions, like Muir''s Arden Shakespeare (which is recommended), conflate the two versions to keep the meaning intact while retaining some of the greatest hit lines that vary between the texts. (F has the famous "Never never never never," whereas Q1 gives only "Never never never," e.g.).

For those interested in the different manuscripts, Jay Halio''s "King Lear: A Guide to the Play" is a good place to start, and Dorothy Nameri''s "Three Versions of the Story of King Lear" a good place to continue.'

'Kent and Gloucester are discussing the pending division of Lear''s kingdom. This plot detail comes straight from Shakespeare''s sources (Holinshed, e.g.), and appears elsewhere in the English canon, such as in this selection from Spenser''s Faerie Queene:

king Leyr in happie peace long raind,
But had no issue male him to succeed,
But three faire daughters, which were well vptraind,
In all that seemed fit for kingly seed:
Mongst whom his realme he equally decreed
To have diuided.

text: 'There are two things going on in this scene.  The first is the division of the kingdom, and the second is the final stage of competition for Cordelia''s hand in marriage.  Cordelia is the youngest daughter, and her older sisters have already been married.  As France and Burgundy have both been competing for her hand (and, by extension, for a piece of the Kingdom of England), what better time than now - when Lear is abdicating - to seal the marriage prospects of Cordelia?'

text:
'Nature and merit are very important to Lear.  Nature refers to filial bonds, and merit to either a) natural abilities or b) - if nature is taken as "paternal affection, then filial bonds.

Importantly, nature and merit introduce the question of the "natural" obligations of the parent and child (specifically the child to the parent) and the "natural" abilities of the child as an individual (the theme that will drive Edmund''s fantastic "Thou nature art my goddess" speech a bit later on).
'

text:
'Nothing is a word that will reverberate throughout the entire play.  In his essay "Shakespeare and the Exorcists," Greenblatt describes Lear as a play that has been "emptied out" - a play in which the meaning has been evacuated from ancient ritual, in which filial bonds become meaningless, and so on. 

Nothingness, therefore, is a fear that is central to Lear''s psychology.  What infuriates Lear about Cordelia''s response - which is, admittedly, somewhat infuriating in its own right - is that it reveals what is underneath the concealing arts of her sisters: nothing.  By refusing to dress up her love of her father in fancy language, Cordelia is, perhaps, offering a vision of love that is too powerful for Lear to accept.  Or is he?

One of the great questions of this play is: Why does this first scene have to turn out like this?  Why does Lear think this division of his kingdom by "love" will be such a good idea?  Why can''t he see through Regan and Goneril?  Why can''t he see Cordelia''s love for what it is? 

I would like to introduce an interpretation of this scene that is in some ways at odds with the critical tradition, but which I think is illuminating for that very reason.  This is Stanley Cavell''s interpretation from his excellent 1976 essay "The Avoidance of  Love."  Cavell reads this scene as an effort by Lear to experience the kind of love that doesn''t require "recognition."  Whereas real love asks something in return (love, recognition, and so on), the artifice of love is much safer in that it demands nothing of its object.  Cavell sees Lear as precisely the kind of man who fears recognition, and by extension fears all feminine love.  He writes: "He wards it off for the reason for which people do ward off being loved, because it presents itself to them as a demand."

Whether or not you agree with Cavell, his is a good reading to keep in mind as this terrible scene sets in motion a number of even more terrible disasters - Cavell helps us keep the question in our minds as the play proceeds: "Why did this have to happen?"
'
quote: 'CORDELIA  /    /      Nothing, my lord.  /    /  KING LEAR  /    /      Nothing!  /    /  CORDELIA  /    /      Nothing.  /    /  KING LEAR  /    /      Nothing will come of nothing: speak again.  /

text: 'It''s ironic that a man as obsessed with filial obligation as Lear is doesn''t accept this declaration as the most honest kind of love.  Yet compared with Goneril and Regan''s over-the-top performances Cordelia''s response does indeed seem small.'
quote: 'According to my bond;

text:
'In Othello, Desdemona''s father suffers from the same anxiety, not believing that his daughter can love him as much when she has a lover. 

By challenging her sisters'' claims of filial love by conflating it somehow with erotic love, Cordelia becomes part of a larger dialogue that continues throughout the play - about the love of daughters compared to the love of mothers and lovers.  About this much more will be said.  Cordelia''s declaration of love comes with boundaries and time limits.  Given the performances we''ve just seen from her sisters, is it at all surprising that Cordelia frustrates her father with these lines?  Until now the problem seems clear: Cordelia messes up by professing her love in too practical, too earthly a way.

But is that really all?  I would like to introduce Cavell''s reading of this scene once more and relate it to these lines, because it will illuminate for us the undercurrent of Lear''s ambivalence about his daughter''s love.  If what Cordelia is offering is love that can be realized (as opposed to fantastical, "boundless" love), then Lear would indeed seem to be choosing artifice and safety over sincerity and complication in the lines that follow.'

text:
'Characters in Lear tend to appeal to the "operation of the orbs" - that is, to the supernatural - when confronting crisis.  Gloucester will do the same thing.  We will keep our eye on the tenuous relationship between the things that happen to our characters and the things that happen in nature.

Greenblatt resists any supernatural readings of Shakespeare, finding it much more productive to read lines like these as expressive of Lear''s longing for meaning in external events than as the actual expressions themselves (which, again, probably don''t exist).
'

That Lear retains the knights gives Shakespeare room to play with the question of property when it falls into the hands of the incompetent.  In doing so he no doubt had in mind the intriguing story of Brian Annesley, to whom we will return, but about whom you can now read by clicking the link.

text: 'The idea that a thing set in motion cannot be stopped (once the bow is drawn the only thing to do is get the hell out of the way) is a resonant one in the play.  What Greenblatt calls the "force of evil" in Lear is released in this first scene, and the metaphor of the bow is an apt one, although Lear himself doesn''t know, perhaps, how dangerous the arrow is that he has just notched.'

text:
'Kent doesn''t say ''swounds or any other Christian epithet because this play - shockingly - is not set in Jacobean England (even though it is). 

As Kent''s invocation of a pagan god here reminds us that Shakespeare intended Lear to be set in the "past," although exactly what year is not made specific.  The fool will joke paradoxically later on that he is born "before the time of Merlin," which gives us a good idea of the play''s relationship to history - it is both contemporary and distant, as Greenblatt formulates it.

Partly because the issue of a divided kingdom was sensitive under James I, who wanted to unite England and Scotland, Shakespeare did not make the play unequivocally contemporary.'

text:
'It''s worth comparing the banishment of Bolingbroke from Richard II to the banishment of Kent in these lines.  Note that Richard hands down the same sentence that Lear does, but he does so in a way that acknowledges the heaviness of the punishment he inflicts.  Lear does indeed seem mad, rash, and cruel by comparison.


KING RICHARD II
You, cousin Hereford, upon pain of life,
    Till twice five summers have enrich''d our fields
    Shall not regreet our fair dominions,
    But tread the stranger paths of banishment.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE

    Your will be done: this must my comfort be,
    Sun that warms you here shall shine on me;
    And those his golden beams to you here lent
    Shall point on me and gild my banishment.

KING RICHARD II

    Norfolk, for thee remains a heavier doom,
    Which I with some unwillingness pronounce:
    The sly slow hours shall not determinate
    The dateless limit of thy dear exile;
    The hopeless word of ''never to return''
    Breathe I against thee, upon pain of life. You, cousin Hereford, upon pain of life,

Let me not to the marriage of true minds
Admit impediments. Love is not love

text:
'Much can be made of these lines, the first hint of the kind of conniving spirit that made Goneril and Regan so hated by the early 19th century critics Coleridge, Hazlitt, and others.

Goneril and Regan are nobody''s fool and they recognize that what Lear''s just done is something close to madness (giving them all the land after some silly contest?!).  They are setting in motion, in their own minds, the line of thinking that will lead them to think of themselves as the rightful guardians or executors of Lear''s land, his knights, and all the rest.  In this sense they do mirror the daughters of Brian Annesley, mentioned previously,

Sir Annesley had a daughter named Grace Wildgoose (no doubt one of the two or three best names in history) who, in 1603, tried to have her father certified incompetent.  Brian''s youngest daughter - Cordell (!) - opposed the action.  When Sir B died he left Cordell everything - an ending which weirdly agrees with the sources of Shakespeare''s for this play but not with the ending of Shakespeare''s version.

(For more, see Halio.)'
quote: 'GONERIL  /    /      Sister, it is not a little I have to say of what  /      most nearly appertains to us both. I think our  /      father will hence to-night.  /    /  REGAN  /    /      That''s most certain, and with you; next month with us.  /    /  GONERIL  /    /      You see how full of changes his age is; the  /      observation we have made of it hath not been  /      little: he always loved our sister most; and  /      with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off  /      appears too grossly.  /    /  REGAN  /    /      ''Tis the infirmity of his age: yet he hath ever  /      but slenderly known himself.  /

text:
'"He''s always been bad, but now that he''s old, he''ll really be bad!"

What Spenser called Lear''s "feeble age" is widely regarded as a corrosive force that has to be managed and contained.  In this play there are no mothers - only daughters, sons, and old men - and much of the drama comes from the younger generation figuring out how to deal with the old, as here.
'
quote: 'The best and soundest of his time hath been but  /      rash;

text:
'This is a common fear in Shakespeare: that the traitor who is on your side may well shift allegiances and betray you next.  Lear, in other words, has betrayed his friend Kent - and in Regan and Goneril''s favor - but the type of man who would do something so rash and thoughtless may well turn the same type of arbitrary anger on his daughters, and so must be watched.

At the end of Richard II, Northumberland, who helped Richard take power in the first place, finds himself under similar scrutiny:

KING RICHARD II

    Must I do so? and must I ravel out
    My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,
    If thy offences were upon record,
    Would it not shame thee in so fair a troop
    To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst,
    There shouldst thou find one heinous article,
    Containing the deposing of a king
    And cracking the strong warrant of an oath,
    Mark''d with a blot, damn''d in the book of heaven:
    Nay, all of you that stand and look upon,
    Whilst that my wretchedness doth bait myself,
    Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands
    Showing an outward pity; yet you Pilates
    Have here deliver''d me to my sour cross,
    And water cannot wash away your sin.

NORTHUMBERLAND

    My lord, dispatch; read o''er these articles.

KING RICHARD II

    Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see:
    And yet salt water blinds them not so much
    But they can see a sort of traitors here.
    Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself,
    I find myself a traitor with the rest;
    For I have given here my soul''s consent
    To undeck the pompous body of a king;
    Made glory base and sovereignty a slave,
    Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.

NORTHUMBERLAND

    My lord,--

KING RICHARD II

    No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man,
    Nor no man''s lord; I have no name, no title,
    No, not that name was given me at the font,
    But ''tis usurp''d: alack the heavy day,
    That I have worn so many winters out,
    And know not now what name to call myself!
    O that I were a mockery king of snow,
    Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke,
    To melt myself away in water-drops!
    Good king, great king, and yet not greatly good,
    An if my word be sterling yet in England,
    Let it command a mirror hither straight,
    That it may show me what a face I have,
    Since it is bankrupt of his majesty.

'

text:
'This is a famous speech of Edmund''s, in which he lays out a naturalistic philosophy of the world that is at odds with both his father, Gloucester''s, and with Lear''s.  Edmund doesn''t believe that there is any connection between the natural world and the events of human life, and similarly rejects the social stigma of bastardy - if his body and mind are as perfect as Edgar''s, why should something as arbitrary as the date of his conception have anything to do with his status in the world in which he lives?

Whether or not you like Edmund, it''s hard to ignore the power of his arguments here.
'

text: 'The obsession with the meaning of words (and whether or not they mean anything at all) is underneath much of this play.  When Lear says, much later, "then there''s life in ''t," in reference to the title of "king," he is in many ways exploring the same avenue that Edmund is exploring here.'

I begin to find an idle and fond bondage  /      in the oppression of aged tyranny; who sways, not  /      as it hath power, but as it is suffered. Come to  /      me, that of this I may speak more. If our father  /      would sleep till I waked him, you should half his  /      revenue for ever, and live the beloved of your  /      brother, EDGAR.''  /

text:
'This is central to the play - whether or not outward shows indicate anything about the internal state of a character.

This will become increasingly important when the theme of the exorcism is introduced, but we may introduce that topic here because it relates to the letter in an important way. 

Later on, when he finds the need to disguise himself, Edgar will assume the manner of someone who is possessed by the devil and in need of exorcism.  In 1603, a few years before the composition of Lear, a theologian named Samuel Harsnett published a pamphlet called "A Declaration of Egregious Popish Impostures" in which he attempted to expose as frauds certain possessed men and exorcists.  (As Greenblatt notes in "Shakespeare and the Exorcists," exorcisms in Jacobean England were theatrical events attended by hundreds.)  Harsnett was concerned, in other words, with people whose outward disposition might not reveal honestly what''s going on internally - exactly the problem that Edmund pretends to care about now!  If this all seems like a hall of mirrors, that''s because it is.  But it''s worth keeping our eye on moments in the play that have the Harsnett quality of inside/outside mismatching, because that will become increasingly important to us as we come to the Edgar scenes later on.
'

text:
'Here is the antithesis to Edmund''s monologue at the beginning of this scene.  Whereas Edmund sees no connected between natural events and human ones, Gloucester sees meaning in the "late eclipses," seeing the discord in the kingdom as "sequent effects" of some kind of natural disruption. 

Gloucester then returns to Kent''s banishment at the end of the speech, which is indeed strange (and does indeed portend all kinds of bad "sequent effects") but which does not, crucially, have anything to do with the stars or the moon.  Like Lear, Kent looks for meaning in things that are meaningless.  Greenblatt formulates his misunderstanding by saying: "I have no wish to live in a culture where men believe in devils; I fully grasp that the torturers of this world are all too human."  Although this is a moment of almost silly self-seriousness from Greenblatt, he''s onto something - if only Gloucester understood that the problem was in the practical world of men, perhaps he would be better equipped to navigate the world of the play. 

When we see what happens to him later on, we will find it hard to disagree.'
quote: 'These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend  /      no good to us: though the wisdom of nature can  /      reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself  /      scourged by the sequent effects: love cools,  /      friendship falls off, brothers divide: in  /      cities, mutinies; in countries, discord; in  /      palaces, treason; and the bond cracked ''twixt son  /      and father. This villain of mine comes under the  /      prediction; there''s son against father: the king  /      falls from bias of nature; there''s father against  /      child. We have seen the best of our time:  /      machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all  /      ruinous disorders, follow us disquietly to our  /      graves. Find out this villain, Edmund; it shall  /      lose thee nothing; do it carefully. And the  /      noble and true-hearted Kent banished! his  /      offence, honesty! ''Tis strange.  /

text: 'And here is the elegant refutation of Gloucester''s submission to the pathetic fallacy.  '
quote: 'This is the excellent foppery of the world, that,  /      when we are sick in fortune,--often the surfeit  /      of our own behavior,--we make guilty of our  /      disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars: as  /      if we were villains by necessity; fools by  /      heavenly compulsion; knaves, thieves, and  /      treachers, by spherical predominance; drunkards,  /      liars, and adulterers, by an enforced obedience of  /      planetary influence; and all that we are evil in,  /      by a divine thrusting on: an admirable evasion  /      of whoremaster man, to lay his goatish  /      disposition to the charge of a star! My  /      father compounded with my mother under the  /      dragon''s tail; and my nativity was under Ursa  /      major; so that it follows, I am rough and  /      lecherous. Tut, I should have been that I am,  /      had the maidenliest star in the firmament  /      twinkled on my bastardizing.

text:
'All kinds of challenging questions are raised by Edmund''s trickery.  A few to consider might be:

What kind of wit (intelligence) gives one the right to land?

Does Edmund - much abused in scene 1.1 and before, as Coleridge reminds us - have the right to these lands?

Does Edgar''s credulity make him complicit?  Does he deserve it?

And so on...
'

text:
'The notion of the king as infant is a recurring fascination of Shakespeare''s (Richard II is a royal infant in many ways, for instance).

Goneril doesn''t know how prophetic this line is, though, because Lear will become more and more infantile as the storm picks up in the second half of the play and he begins commanding the elements ("Blow, winds!").  Greenblatt notes the tendency of young children to believe they have control of the natural world around them, and connects this with the inability of kings to come to grips with checks on their own power.
'

text:
'Kent knows how to flatter.  Shakespearean kings often love to be flattered, but good flatterers know how to do their work without making the artifice obvious.  They are like sleight of hand magicians. 

Kent, of course, is not flattering here in the strictest sense, because he does want to serve Lear.  But he knows how to appeal to the king''s narcissism (indeed, it is because of his narcissism and short-sightedness that Kent felt the need to return in the first place!). 

Perhaps the cleverest take on flattery in Shakespeare comes from Decius Brutus, who tells his friends of Julius Caesar:

DECIUS BRUTUS

    Never fear that: if he be so resolved,
    I can o''ersway him; for he loves to hear
    That unicorns may be betray''d with trees,
    And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,
    Lions with toils and men with flatterers;
    But when I tell him he hates flatterers,
    He says he does, being then most flattered.

'

'This is precisely the kind of behavior that Goneril will use to justify her increasing cruelty towards Lear. 

But one may ask why Lear is so angered by Oswald''s line.  We could say something like "he''s going crazy and so he''s doing crazy things," but it will be much more rewarding (and productive) for us as readers if we assume that Lear''s madness cloaks truth.  Certainly here we could imagine Lear''s identification as a father to be upsetting when perhaps he would have preferred Oswald to say, "You are the king."'

text:
'This song is a string of aphorisms that relate by varying degrees to Lear''s situation.  "Set less than thou throwest," like many of these lines, essentially means "hedge your bets - always keep something hidden or something in reserve."  But these commonplaces are couched in the song, and hidden in silly lines like "leave thy drink and thy whore."

Lear is therefore right to dismiss the fool''s song as "nothing," but as we know by now nothingness is never so simple as it seems in this play.  In this scene, Lear''s mention of nothing will set off a chain reaction of puns and insightful verbal acrobatics on the fool''s part all aimed at showing Lear the essential emptiness of his present position.
'
quote: 'Mark it, nuncle:  /      Have more than thou showest,  /      Speak less than thou knowest,  /      Lend less than thou owest,  /      Ride more than thou goest,  /      Learn more than thou trowest,  /      Set less than thou throwest;  /      Leave thy drink and thy whore,  /      And keep in-a-door,  /      And thou shalt have more  /      Than two tens to a score.  /    /  KENT  /    /      This is nothing, fool.  /

text: 'In addition to being wise, Lear''s fool is also very, very funny.  Here he tells the king (who has given up the title of king), that there''s really no title left for him but "fool."  The line also suggests that being a fool is something of a natural state to which everyone tends when all other trappings are stripped away.  '
quote: 'All thy other titles thou hast given away; that  /      thou wast born with.  /

text: 'The fool quibbles on "altogether."  Whereas Kent intended it to mean "this is not entirely foolish," the fool pretends to take it as "this does not represent the sum total of all the foolishness in the world," and so replies to Kent and Lear that even he, a fool by trade, cannot pretend to a monopoly on global idiocy - people do stupid things all the time and won''t leave foolishness to the professionals.'

text: 'The split egg is a visual metaphor for Lear''s division of the kingdom.  It also suggests the loss of sexual virility, which will come to haunt Lear more and more.  The Fool will tell him later on that "thou art a sheal''d peascod," which is to say, a penis with no testicles.  The empty egg is in the same symbolic universe: fragile, soft, empty, vulnerable.'

When thou  /      clovest thy crown i'' the middle, and gavest away  /      both parts, thou borest thy ass on thy back o''er  /      the dirt: thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown,  /      when thou gavest thy golden one away. If I speak  /      like myself in this, let him be whipped that first  /      finds it so.  /

text:
'Here the fool taps in to the ultimate male confusion in Shakespeare - the blurring of the boundaries between sexual love and familiar love (especially the love of the daughter, and the sexualization of the daughter). 

Cavell would tie this theme up with the general (Freudian) male problem of separation from the initial love object, the mother.  Certainly that tension is at play here.  The image, then, of a disciplining mother taking the rod to her son''s buttocks is a provocative one for many reasons - not only are the roles reversed, but they are undeniably eroticized in a confusing way.'

text: 'It''s true that Lear has been "transformed" lately, but we must remember that Goneril explained to Oswald at the beginning of this scene that she would instruct her household staff to provoke Lear to force him to confrontation (1.3.25, e.g.).  Goneril is similar to Edmund in these lines - clever and conniving behind a sympathetic, solicitous front.'

text:
'Lear, having lost the title and powers of the kingship, finds himself unrecognizable.  That he asks, "Where are his eyes?" (and not, say, "Where are his hands?" or "Where is his body?") tells us that the problem of the loss of self, for Lear, has as much to do with the loss of outside recognition as it does with self-knowledge.  "Where are his eyes?" asks those around to look at him, to recognize him, even as he finds himself unable to know himself in this transformed state.

"Who is it that can tell me who I am" is a line that gels nicely with Cavell''s notion of recognition and the problem of love.  Lear is a man who is furiously independent and finds himself in need of outside confirmation that he is still king, still a man - this is his tragedy at this particular moment of the play.  It is in some ways not unique among Shakespearean monarchs.

This is similar to a scene from the end of Richard II, when Bolingbroke observes Richard looking into a mirror.  Richard speaks first:

Re-enter Attendant, with a glass
    Give me the glass, and therein will I read.
    No deeper wrinkles yet? hath sorrow struck
    So many blows upon this face of mine,
    And made no deeper wounds? O flattering glass,
    Like to my followers in prosperity,
    Thou dost beguile me! Was this face the face
    That every day under his household roof
    Did keep ten thousand men? was this the face
    That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?
    Was this the face that faced so many follies,
    And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?
    A brittle glory shineth in this face:
    As brittle as the glory is the face;

    Dashes the glass against the ground
    For there it is, crack''d in a hundred shivers.
    Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport,
    How soon my sorrow hath destroy''d my face.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE

    The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy''d
    The shadow or your face.

KING RICHARD II

    Say that again.
    The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let''s see:
    ''Tis very true, my grief lies all within;
    And these external manners of laments
    Are merely shadows to the unseen grief
    That swells with silence in the tortured soul;
    There lies the substance: and I thank thee, king,
    For thy great bounty, that not only givest
    Me cause to wail but teachest me the way
    How to lament the cause. I''ll beg one boon,
    And then be gone and trouble you no more.
    Shall I obtain it?
'
quote: 'KING LEAR  /    /      Doth any here know me? This is not Lear:  /      Doth Lear walk thus? speak thus? Where are his eyes?  /      Either his notion weakens, his discernings  /      Are lethargied--Ha! waking? ''tis not so.  /      Who is it that can tell me who I am?  /

text: 'Goneril''s complaint that Lear''s rabble is causing chaos in her household is received by Lear as a breaking of the bond between father and daughter.  "Yet have I left a daughter" refers to Regan, to whose castle he''ll go next, and implies the loss of Cordelia and Goneril - those two are now subsumed, in Lear''s mind, in the same "bastard" category to which Edmund belongs.'

text:
'Lear is frightened and revolted by the sexuality of his daughter.  But why is it that he delivers these lines at this moment?  What has provoked him?

Before we can answer that, let''s consider Hazlitt''s diagnosis that Lear''s "rash haste, his violent impetuosity, his blindness to every thing but the dictates of his passions or affections, produces all his misfortunes," and see whether we can read these lines as an example of this rashness.  It certainly seems accurate that Lear is unable to check himself, even at this relatively early stage of his madness, when a powerful emotion (disgust, nausea, anger) overtakes him. 

So Lear has been provoked by a passion that we can''t fully explain.  But he is also - Cavell again - impotent at the hands of a younger woman, and so seems to conflate his daughter''s fertility with youth generally, and youth with power over age, and age with himself.  It doesn''t help that Albany, the evidence of his daughter''s sexuality as such, is present in this scene, and it is Albany who asks the question - "what hath moved you?" - that provokes these lines.'
quote: 'Suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend  /      To make this creature fruitful!  /      Into her womb convey sterility!  /      Dry up in her the organs of increase;  /      And from her derogate body never spring  /      A babe to honour her! If she must teem,  /      Create her child of spleen; that it may live,  /      And be a thwart disnatured torment to her!  /      Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth;  /      With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks;  /      Turn all her mother''s pains and benefits  /      To laughter and contempt; that she may feel  /      How sharper than a serpent''s tooth it is  /      To have a thankless child! Away, away!  /

text:
'"Attask''d" may be glossed as "accused," perhaps to "counterbalance priased," as Arden would have it. 

Goneril is being a sexual terrorist here on the order of Lady Macbeth.  To see how stuff like this works, let''s look at a selection from Macbeth, when Lady Macbeth is trying to rouse her husband to kill Duncan:

Lady Macbeth:
yet do I fear thy nature;
It is too full o'' the milk of human kindness
To catch the nearest way: thou wouldst be great;
Art not without ambition, but without
The illness should attend it: what thou wouldst highly,
That wouldst thou holily; wouldst not play false,
And yet wouldst wrongly win: thou''ldst have, great Glamis,
That which cries ''Thus thou must do, if thou have it;
And that which rather thou dost fear to do
Than wishest should be undone.'' Hie thee hither,
That I may pour my spirits in thine ear;
And chastise with the valour of my tongue
All that impedes thee from the golden round,
Which fate and metaphysical aid doth seem
To have thee crown''d withal.

I have bolded the phrase "milk of human kindness" because it evokes femininity, female milk, and so on - not things that a tough man (and one who doubts his own masculinity, as Macbeth and Albany do) wants to hear.  "Milky gentleness" shows an awareness of certain essential male fears, and a knowledge of how best to exploit them.

'In other words, "even a snail knows what to do with his house (kingdom): stay in it!  Don''t give it away!"

By bringing up horns, the traditional symbol of the cuckold, the fool does not mean to imply that Lear''s wife had affairs.  In his way of seeing the word, married men are all cuckolds simply by virtue of being married.

text:
'Now, with all of this "conjuring the moon" stuff attributed by Edmund to Edgar for the benefit of the superstitious Gloucester, things really get interesting.  Edmund knows how to manipulate his father and knows how frightening it is for Gloucester to imagine that some kind of "conjuring" could be going on right under his roof.  In the first sense, then, this is a clever tactical move.

But Edmund''s decision to bring the moon (and, by extension, the entire supernatural universe) into his designs against his brother also lead us back to Harsnett (who, you will recall, authored "A declaration of egregious popish impostures" in 1603 to debunk face exorcisms).  Edmund is implying, subtly, that his brother is in league with evil forces (maybe even that he is possessed).  This will take on a more ironic connotation later when Edgar himself puts on the disposition of Tom O''Bedlam and assumes the persona of a possessed man for purposes of protection.  Importantly, none of the "possessed" characters in the play are actually possessed - they are using the superstitions of their time for their own benefit.  Greenblatt takes this as evidence of Shakespeare''s own rejection of devils and the supernatural, and indeed it is compelling.'
quote: 'conjuring the moon  /      To stand auspicious mistress,--  /

text: 'Edmund is really laying it on thick here.  It''s astonishing that Gloucester doesn''t realize that the very child whom he so disparaged at the beginning of the play would be unlikely to come down so strongly on the side of father-son obligation at this stage of the game (remember how much we sympathized with Coleridge''s reading of the first scene, in which Edmund is indeed humiliated by his father''s insensitivity).  And yet, so it is. That Gloucester does buy it is a testament to Edmund''s unbelievable cunning in appealing to the weaknesses and values of the characters around him.'

text:
'It doesn''t take much to see that Gloucester is making a Lear-esque error here.  In fact, he is doing exactly as Lear did in scene 1.1: damning the loyal child and trusting the betraying one. 

The Gloucester parallel plot doesn''t appear in most of Shakespeare''s sources (the histories, Leir, Spenser), but Philip Sidney included it in a play from 1590.

text:
'One thing to think about as all of this goes on is why.  Why does Kent put himself through it?

To be sure, he remains loyal to Lear throughout, and does seem to be genuinely angered by Oswald, but does it help Lear (or Kent himself) to introduce all of this discord?

There isn''t a clear answer to this question. It''s worth remembering that Kent has the first line of the play - "I thought the King had more affected..." - and that he is clearly sensitive to the changes that are happening to Lear as a character and a king.

text:
'Kent is playing the roll of a fool here.  He responds wittily and efficiently to all attacks and questions, and he performs the fool trick of deflection, in which the meaning of his speeches is delivered sidelong to his interlocutors:

Cornwall: What is his fault?  (What''s wrong with him?)
Kent: His countenance likes me not.  (He''s ugly!)

text: 'Kent sees that Cornwall thinks poorly of his way of speaking (that is, his affected way of speaking - Kent is a noble of Gloucester''s status), and so he plays a game with him by ratcheting up his tone to a higher, more literary one.'

text:
'This is the overarching theme of much of Kent''s dialogue - the discernment of a flatterer from an honest man.

This is a microcosmic version of a problem that haunts the whole play, that of discernment of madness/sanity and spirits/reality.  I won''t rehash Greenblatt''s entire argument in "Shakespeare and the Exorcists," we can say at least that Kent''s obsession with flattery is a smaller version of these larger concerns.  If Lear, as Greenblatt suggests, is a play in which ancient meaningful rituals have been "emptied out" (inheritance, e.g.), then flattery is language that has similarly been emptied.  Kent''s position as character is perhaps closer to Edmund''s in his naturalism than to Gloucester''s in his superstition, but Kent is that rare naturalist who will side with the superstitious when he sees that they are in trouble.
'

text: 'A quibble in response to Cornwall, but also a resonant line given the way that age works in this play.  Recall that there are really two generations in Lear - old and young - and that Kent falls somewhere in the middle (he''s in his late forties).  In this line, then, Kent, knowingly or not, aligns himself with the older generation before his younger persecutors (Cornwall, Regan).'

 2. The Hospital of St. Mary of Bethlehem, used as an asylum for the reception and cure of mentally deranged persons; originally situated in Bishopsgate, in 1676 rebuilt near London Wall, and in 1815 transferred to Lambeth. Jack or Tom o'' Bedlam: a madman.

As Edmund has done so successfully with Gloucester by accusing Edgar of referencing the planets menancingly and portentiously, Edgar is here playing upon some of the fears and superstitions of his time.  Along with the implication that he is a lunatic, as will be seen, Edgar will suggest that he is possessed by the devil - adopting the typical characteristics of an impostor victim of possession as described by Samuel Harsnett (see previous notes).

text: 'As defined in Edward Jordan''s "Brief discourse of a disease called the suffocation of the mother" (1605), the mother (probably short for smother) was an "affect of the womb" that led to choking and other discomforts.  It''s not really important exactly what the medical definition of the thing is.  It is important that Lear connects emotional weakness - like the "climbing sorrow" - as essentially feminine, and fears its intrusion into his mind and body ("thy element''s below" - stay back!).'

text:
'The jump is short in Lear''s mind from petty offence to universe-shattering criminal act.  In Coleridge''s words: "The inveterate habits of sovereignty convert the wish into claim and positive right, and the incompliance with it into crime and treason."  What makes Lear so sympathetic at this moment, despite his "conversion" of wish to claim, is that he is indeed being wronged by his daughters in factual ways that have nothing to do with perception (they have, in some way, tricked him, and are now taking full advantage of his weakness).

text:
'One of the most terrible things about Lear''s position here is that he is dependent on the very people who are abusing him.  Even as he appeals to Regan for help he is revolted by his need to make such an appeal.  This type of situation lends itself nicely to Freudian readings such as Cavell''s, which would go something like this: "Men do not just naturally not love, they learn not to.  And our lives begin by having to accept under the name of love whatever closeness is offered, and then by having to forgo its object" (Adelman 86).

"Its object" is, of course, the infant''s mother.  Contributing to Lear''s confusion of female categories (mother/daughter/lover) is his return, in old age and madness, to a kind of infantalized state of rejection of women and dependency on them.
'
quote: 'O Regan, she hath tied  /      Sharp-tooth''d unkindness, like a vulture, here:  /    /      Points to his heart  /      I can scarce speak to thee; thou''lt not believe  /      With how depraved a quality--O Regan!  /

text:
'This is straight from the Grace Wildgoose case.  To review: Regan is articulating a position that was a hot topic in England at the time of the play''s composition because the aging Brian Annesly refused to have control of his estate wrested from him by his daughter, Grace Wildgoose. 

So - what is this argument''s nature and what are its merits?  Essentially it says that "discretion" is necessary in managing the affairs of the old (especially when there''s lots of money around), and discretion is exactly what old people lack.  By implication, though, Regan makes another argument - that she knows Lear better than he knows himself.  She does this by saying that Lear should submit to someone who knows "your state better than you yourself."  This resonates considerably for us because it is an answer to Lear''s question, "Who is he can tell me who I am."
'
quote: 'O, sir, you are old.  /      Nature in you stands on the very verge  /      Of her confine: you should be ruled and led  /      By some discretion, that discerns your state  /      Better than you yourself. Therefore, I pray you,  /      That to our sister you do make return;  /      Say you have wrong''d her, sir.  /

text:
'This is irony that tends precariously towards accuracy - a sure sign that the thing you most fear is exactly what''s coming right at you. 

Keep in mind when reading this line that "age" doesn''t mean the opposite of youth but rather "old people," as in, "That is no country for old men."

Inerchangeable targets for these curses signifies that Lear''s problem is somehow bigger than the specific people around him.  We are reminded of what Eliot wrote of Hamlet, that he is a man with an "inadequate objective correlative" for his emotions.

text: 'Greenblatt observes that Lear desires meaning from the inherently meaningless world around him.  A corrollary to this is that Lear desires direct assistance from the "meaningful" world in which he believes.  One thing to think about is: do we believe Lear actually hopes for a bolt of lightning to strike Goneril at this moment?  For what, precisely, is he praying.  Keep in mind that we are in a pagan (non-Christian, ahistorical), so this will not be prayer in any kind of early-modern England Christian sense (unless we decide that it is).'

text: 'Lear has become suddenly tender apologetic.  This line is very  reflective of Lear''s concerns in this scene as a whole.  He wants to maintain a parental stance towards Regan ("I will not trouble thee, my child") even as he finds himself in need of help, and recognizes that Regan wields considerable power over him ("I prithee...").  '

text: 'Regan is, of course, colluding with Goneril.  Lear doesn''t know this yet, and assumes that if he goes to Goneril and explains the abuses he''s suffered at the hands of her sister (Kent in the stocks, etc.), she will be sympathetic to him.  Regan knows this isn''t the case.  But she presents the argument to her father that anyone with reason can see through his mad anger ("passion") and won''t be taken in.  '

text:
'When you''re reading these lines and you become frustrated with Lear ("why can''t he just agree to the damn 25 knights!?"), recall that this has nothing to do with the 25 knights.

What''s at stake here is nothing less that Lear''s conception of himself as a man and a king.  Regan and Cornwall, by pulling a Wildgoose, are conspiring to strip him of his independence and his dignity.  The knights are only symbolic, to Lear, of the obligation of youth to defer to age rather than to become "guardians" of it. '

What should you need of more?  /      Yea, or so many, sith that both charge and danger  /      Speak ''gainst so great a number? How, in one house,  /      Should many people, under two commands,  /      Hold amity? ''Tis hard; almost impossible.  /    /  GONERIL  /    /      Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance  /      From those that she calls servants or from mine?  /    /  REGAN  /    /      Why not, my lord? If you will come to me,--  /      For now I spy a danger,--I entreat you  /      To bring but five and twenty: to no more  /      Will I give place or notice.  /    /  KING LEAR  /    /      I gave you all--  /    /  REGAN  /    /      And in good time you gave it.  /    /  KING LEAR  /    /      Made you my guardians, my depositaries;  /      But kept a reservation to be follow''d  /      With such a number. text:
'Lear is suggesting that everyone - even the "basest beggar" - is not truly leaving on exactly what he needs.  Everyone has something extra, no one is pure "unaccommodated man," to borrow a phrase from act three.

Given that, the distinction between 25 knights and 50 knights is not one of need but of propriety and dignity. '
quote: 'O, reason not the need: our basest beggars  /      Are in the poorest thing superfluous:  /      Allow not nature more than nature needs,  /      Man''s life''s as cheap as beast''s:

text:
'"If need were the only thing that guided man were need, then you, my daughter, wouldn''t be wearing that skimpy outfit, because you would be wearing something ugly but much more practical."

The dress that Regan is wearing, like Lear''s train of knights, are the outward shows that men gather to themselves.  The notion that man''s life is "cheap as a beast''s" without all of the material things with which we surround ourselves echoes a little of Hobbes, and indeed Greenblatt sees Shakespeare as responding to Hobbes''s philosophy obliquely in this play.  Where Hobbes would no doubt agree that the natural state of man matches Lear''s description, he would suggest that such a state is the starting point and we are moving away from it as civilization advances.  Shakespeare would say that we are moving toward it.
'

text:
'Act III is where this play really starts to take off, and the storm is the centerpiece of the action.  What you make of the storm will largely determine your reading of the play, and so I want to introduce a few questions and ideas about it before we begin looking at this act close-up.

The critic Charles Lamb, in his 1812 book "On the tragedies of Shakespeare, considered with reference to their fitness for stage representation," wrote of this play: "Lear is essentially impossible to be represented on a stage" (Muir 6).  Lamb was speaking both of the limited abilities of human actors to represent this most complex of Shakespeare''s kings, but also of the limits of theatrical artifice and of the stage itself.  How can we believe there is a storm when we know that a boy backstage is hitting a drum, and another is spilling water? 

The storm has been problematic for critics ever since.  Some, like Greenblatt, see it as a kind of cruel trick that Shakespeare plays on Lear.  The bard gives his leading man something out of which he tries to make meaning, only to reveal to him at the end of the play (by the death of Cordelia) that his suffering has been for nothing.  In that reading, the storm is not at all supernatural.  Greenblatt might say something like, "when enough water condenses in the clouds, it rains, as it does in act three of King Lear" (this is exaggerated, of course, but I want to draw a clear distinction between what I see as two diverging approaches to the storm).

The other reading of the storm might go something like this.  Lear is cast out and mad, and the symbolical theatrical representation of that is to have the natural world reflect his interior state.  Stormy man; stormy heavens.  This is the way that theater works: by expressionistically displaying the interior life of a character through the use of theatrical artifice.

Lamb probably tended more towards that second reading, and he read all of Lear''s trials (of which the storm is only one) as contributing to a "living martyrdom" of the king.  By the end of the play, Lamb (and the audience) is waiting for Cordelia to live and to take control of England along with the much-abused Lear, for this is exactly what happened in Shakespeare''s sources.  If Cordelia survives and Lear takes back his throne, the suffering he endured during the storm and afterwards would retroactively take on the significance of expiatory punishment. 

Yet Shakespeare denies us such a reading by killing Cordelia and Lear.  Given that neither of these two readings seems completely appropriate, what do we make of the storm?  Rather than offer a simplistic way to resolve this conflict, let us think of ourselves as joining the great critical debate about these scenes.  In thinking about them, one way to gauge where you stand is to ask yourself this question:

"If the play began three days later, would the storm take place during act two?" 


'

'This is the expositional point of this scene, to release the information that France is invading England.

It''s common for foreign invasion to follow civil war.  In fact, it''s almost a rule of British history.  In Shakespeare''s world domestic unrest will almost always lead to invasion (Fortinbras in Denmark, e.g.).

'Muir, in Arden, complement''s Greenblatt''s reading of Harsnett and Laer by providing a number of excerpts from Harsnett that echo throughout scene III.ii.  Harsnett wrote that a man feigning possession by demons will often be "so violent, boystrous, and bigge, as that he will ruffle, rage, and hurle in the ayre...and blow down steeples, trees, maypoles" (Harsnett 18).

text:
'The fool recognizes that the storm - that is, Nature - does not differentiate between classes of men.  The broader implication of this is that nature fails to correspond at all to the organization of human society.

Even among men, though, these distinctions are becoming blurry.  Even as Lear seems, in the speech that follows, to concede the indifference of the universe - "You owe me no subscription" - he insists that the storm is somehow in league with Goneril and Regan.  For Lear, these categories are not distinct, and this problem will become increasingly relevant as his madness reaches a full-blown stage.'
quote: 'here''s a night pities neither wise man nor fool.  /

text: 'Lear sees the evidence that the storm isn''t paying any attention to him, and yet he can''t get the idea out of his head: This rain and those daughters are part of the same category of elements, because both are doing something unnatural and cruel by "engendering battles" against an old man.  (Or so Lear thinks.)'
quote: 'here I stand, your slave,  /      A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man:  /      But yet I call you servile ministers,  /      That have with two pernicious daughters join''d  /      Your high engender''d battles ''gainst a head  /      So old and white as this.

text:
'The fool is alluding to the habit some women have of practicing pretty faces in front of the mirror.  (Some men have this habit too - let''s not kid ourselves.)  The image of the mirror has particular significance for us.

As we''ve already seen from Cavell, a mirror is the perfect symbol of self recognition in that it forces us to see ourselves and "be seen" by ourselves.  The image of a woman before a mirror is also a prefiguration of the final scene, in which Lear will place a mirror before Cordelia''s lips to see whether her breath will fog it (i.e. to see whether she is still alive).  It doesn''t.
'
quote: 'For there was never yet fair woman but she made  /      mouths in a glass.  /

text:
'Lear wishes curses on Regan and Goneril.  By in invoking Justice he again expresses his belief that certain ordering principles of the universe will eventually be brought to bear on the perpetrators of unnatural acts.  In fact, Regan and Goneril are safe inside their castle at this moment, and will not be so much as inconvenienced by the storm.  Importantly, the reason for this has nothing to do with divine providence.  It is not, as Lear probably believes, some kind of sick cosmic joke.

No.  The reason that Regan and Goneril are safe is a purely practical one; they have found shelter, unlike Lear, and they were able to do so because of their strong political position.  This is the way the world works, the play seems to suggest - not by wringing meaning out of the storm but by recognizing that certain human responses to it will guarantee our safety from it.'

text:
'As the old Irish song says, "Oh, the French are on the sea / They''ll be here without delay."  Indeed, France''s army has landed on English soil and plans to take advantage of the domestic divisions from which the kingdom is now suffering, such as the worsening conflict between Albany and Cornwall.

Gloucester has sided with the French and in support of Lear, which makes him undesirable in the extreme to Goneril and Regan.  Foolishly, he has hidden a letter from the French in his closet - a letter which confirms his traitorous sympathies.  Edmund, seeing his chance to ruin his father once and for all, decides immediately to reveal the letter.'
quote: 'I have  /      received a letter this night; ''tis dangerous to be  /      spoken; I have locked the letter in my closet:  /      these injuries the king now bears will be revenged  /      home; there''s part of a power already footed: we  /      must incline to the king.

text:
'Gloucester plans to go out into the storm and look for Lear.  He asks Edmund to run a diversion by telling Regan and Goneril that he''s gone to bed. 

Gloucester, and the older generation generally, still have the sense of loyalty and obligation that is lacking in the younger characters.  "The king my old master must be relieved," he says.  "Must be relieved," because he is old and was Gloucester''s superior.  This is simply the way the world works for Gloucester, but it is a fatal error to assume that everyone else shares these same attitudes about the world. 
'

text: 'Edmund has already been written into Gloucester''s will, and yet he remains unsatisfied.  His idea of a fair deserving is a complete inheritance of all of Gloucester''s goods: his money and his title.  Edmund has a conflicting subconscious desire to kill his father and to become him.  '

text:
'This sense that the natural processes of the world are being played out here is both accurate and warped.  While it''s true that the old fall and the young rise - Kent''s wheel must turn - Edmund is unnaturally interfering in this cycle.

As Greenblatt reminds us, though, age is an irrefutable fact in this play - not something that can be overlooked.  One of the things that happens to us is that we age, and when we do, we will be abused or taken advantage of unless we have protected ourselves with money and titles.  Youth can survive in this play unaccommodated, but age cannot.
'
quote: 'The younger rises when the old doth fall.  /

text:
'Perhaps one of the most beautiful lines of the play.  If he remains outside in the storm, Lear doesn''t have to think.  The thunder is too loud to allow for reflection, and so he is spared the agony of regret, anger, and fear - he is spared Dr. Johnson''s "a perpetual tumult of indignation, pity, and hope." 

But if he steps inside into the quieter, drier shelter, he will have nothing to protect him from reflection.  This is the great irony of the storm.  Even as it seems to amplify the chaos that Lear himself experiences it prevents him in a practical sense from reflecting on it.  This holds true whether or not we believe that the storm is in any way connected to Lear''s experience (that is, whether or not we believe that it is metaphysical).
'

text:
'In "Timon of Athens," probably the worst of Shakespeare''s plays (it is sometimes read as a draft or fragment), Timon spends the first two acts throwing feasts for his friends and giving them gifts.  He is always quick to loan money.

Soon enough, of course, Timon''s luck runs out and he needs loans himself.  Not surprisingly, all of his old "friends" refuse his servants when they coming asking for money.  This is how Timon reacts to his servant when he hears of the first such refusal:

TIMON

    What, are my doors opposed against my passage?
    Have I been ever free, and must my house
    Be my retentive enemy, my gaol?
    The place which I have feasted, does it now,
    Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?
    Lucilius'' Servant Put in now, Titus.

In this line Lear sounds not unlike Timon.  He is a man who is shocked to discover that people don''t treat him as generously as he believes he has treated them.  Timon proceeds to go mad (or almost mad) with fury and humiliation, inviting his friends over and serving them a soup made of stones.  Lear seems to sense that this particular line of thinking is a hop, skip, and a jump away from madness.
'

text: 'Lear initially decides to stay outside.  He has asked himself that frightening question, "Wil''t break my heart?" and answered yes.  At this point, though, he is so cold and exhausted that the needs of the body take over and he goes in.'

text:
'This is an interesting moment.  Lear begins to realize that when he was king there were men living under his rule that may not have had shelter during previous storms like this one.  "I have ta''en too little care [of the poor]," he says. 

Lear is experiencing what it is to be man in the natural state.  I wrote earlier that Greenblatt sees Shakespeare as kind of inverted Hobbsian who sees the state of nature as the destination of man rather than his origin.  In these lines Lear is rubbing up against the Hobbsian fact of existence from which his title and wealth have previously shielded him.
'

O, I have ta''en  /      Too little care of this!

text:
'Lear can imagine sympathetically what the poor experience, but he is ultimately an English monarch.  What he advocates as a solution to the problem is essentially trickle-down economics, allowing more of the surplus money in the kingdom (the superflux) to reach those who need it most.

text:
'Hazlitt wrote of these scenes, ""nothing can be more complete than the distinction between Lear''s real and Edgar''s assumed madness." 

In a certain sense that''s true - Edgar''s madness is a calculated play for survival whereas Lear''s madness is, well, madness.  But Edgar''s "madness" will affect him obliquely in ways that suggest Hazlitt may have  missed something.  When, later on, Edgar delays in telling his father who he really is, we see the shame that undergirds much of his actions, and his fear at seeing his father weakened.

Cavell further suggest that Gloucester''s personality becomes conflated with Lear''s as we move towards act four.  If this is true (and there is much textual evidence that it is - again, read "Avoidance of Love"), then it is not out of the question that Edgar sees something of his own weak, old father in Lear.  The relationship between roles and reality, madness and sanity is perhaps not as clear as Hazlitt would have it.
'

text:
'"Is man no more than this?" is in some ways the question of every fallen Shakespearean monarch.  Certainly Richard II wrestles with it, and even steely warriors like Coriolanus must confront it. 

As to this question of being better off dead, Lear is confronting what Greenblatt would call "the intolerable" - the threshold for suffering beyond which life becomes unlivable.  It is worth keeping this notion in mind as we continue to read the scene.
'
quote: 'Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer  /      with thy uncovered body this extremity of the skies.  /      Is man no more than this?

text:
'Montaigne, who is often a nice complement to Shakespeare, wrote that "miserable man...can neither go, nor speak, nor shift, nor feed himself unless it be to whine and weep, except he be taught" (AS).

By comparing the weak body of man to different animal bodies, Lear finds that we are not well-suited to brave the elements.  A bear has a hide, for instance, that protects it from extreme cold.  We don''t have bear skin, we only have bare skin (forgive me). 

Psychologically this line of thinking is precariously close to Lear''s rejection of the mother, because the weakness of our body must of course remind us of our origins and our birth (in passage from which I selected the above quote, Montaigne moves swiftly from bear hides to newborn babies). 
'

text:
'Again, most of this comes from Harsnett. 

Greenblatt has interesting things to say about all of this, of course.  Consider for now the purpose of an exorcism in England at this time.  Someone is possessed by the devil, he goes to an exorcist, the spirit is removed from him in front of a large crowd of people, all of whom are edified by the experience.  Harsnett didn''t believe that it was really happening, as we know, because he accused the "popish impostors" of performing possession as a show.  Nevertheless, the exorcism was a ritual performed in public that served no purpose beyond its own.  That is, it was relevant only to itself.  It was a means to its own end.

In this play, rituals like the exorcism take on a new meaning.  Because Edgar is pretending to be possessed for a very specific reason, he changes the stakes, making them both more human and much more terrifying.  There is no comfort of ritual here, only a modest tactic by a clever agent in an evil world.  Greenblatt writes:

"Edgar''s possession is a theatrical performance exactly in Harsnett''s terms, but there is no saving institution, purged of theater, against which it may be set, nor is there a demonic institution that the performance may be shown to serve.  On the contrary, Edgar mimes in response to a free-floating, contagious evil more terrible than anything Harsnett would allow...in King Lear, neither individuals nor institutions can adequately contain the released and enacted wickedness" (Halio 114).
'

Withold footed thrice the old;  /      He met the night-mare, and her nine-fold;  /      Bid her alight,  /      And her troth plight,  /      And, aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!  /    /  KENT  /    /      How fares your grace?  /    /  KING LEAR  /    /      What''s he?  /    /  KENT  /    /      Who''s there? 'Ding!  Here''s the first one.  Cornwall and Regan are very cruel, but they have what Cavell would call evil''s fear of showing itself.  It''s not that they want to protect Edmund from witnessing his father''s suffering - people who blind people don''t care about people''s children.  Instead, it''s that they have some kind of shame about the unreal suffering they are inflicting on another person.

Or do they?

text:
'This is sort of an Elizabethan situation gone wrong.  Torture happened, of course, in early 17th century England, but it was supposed to be done to elicit information from people, and to do it officially you needed an order from the queen''s privy council. 

Shakespeare has taken the barbarous underbelly of "civility" and brought it into the open, unaccommodated, without the disguise or pretense of justice to cloak the acts themselves.
'

text:
'Gloucester suffers from the same illusions Lear does - that the world will somehow right itself and take the side of the just over the side of the unjust.  In fact, the plucked beard hairs are just that, dead hairs, and will not have any power over Regan. 

The image of the violated body crying for its own revenge is common in Shakespeare, and perhaps the most spectacular instance is in Julius Caesar, when Mark Antony compares the dead Caesar''s wounds to "mouths" that will cry to be avenged.

Here, of course, is another reference to the torture that will soon be inflicted on Gloucester.  Shakespeare is building the suspense and baiting us with these lines, making us wonder, will this really happen?  Can this really be happening?

Cavell writes of this scene: "The physical cruelty symbolizes the psychic cruelty which pervades the play; but what this particular act of cruelty means is that cruelty cannot bear to be seen.  It literalizes evil''s ancient love of darkness" (Adelman 72).

text:
'This is an inversion of the classical revenge tragedy moment in which the good character informs the evil character "I am having my revenge on you because _________."  Here, though, it is the evil character telling an innocent "You have suffered for no reason because _____." 

In this universe, suffering is divorced from the structures which we use to give it meaning.'

text:
'Gloucester is reduced to a dog.

Cavell has an interesting take on the second line here, asking how it is that Regan knows Gloucester is going to Dover?  Why does she assume that?  Why does she say this?

Cavell writes: "The essential fact is that the name is primarily caught to the image of her father.  In her mind, the man she is sending on his way to Dover is the man she knows is sent on his way to Dover; in her paroxysms of cruelty, she imagines that she has just participated in blinding her father" (Adelman 77).

text: 'Edgar observes that were it not for suffering, no man would ever die.  What he means by this is that Hamlet''s "thousand natural shocks" are what prepare use for death - they make life so hard that we come to hate it, and therefore to be ready to leave it.  Edgar doesn''t yet know how accurate his remark is; soon enough his father will ask Edgar (in disguise) to help him end his life.'
quote: 'But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,  /      Lie would not yield to age.  /

text:
'This old man is a rarity in Lear in that he takes obligation seriously.  Not only that, but his sense of duty goes back at least one generation: "and your father''s tenant."  The story of Lear depends largely on the expected obligations of parents and children breaking down, and Shakespeare uses the old man as a sympathetic comparison case.

The old man is part of a category of characters in Shakespeare that includes, among others, the stable boy ("Groom") who visits Richard II in his prison cell in 5.5:

Groom

    Hail, royal prince!

KING RICHARD II

    Thanks, noble peer;
    The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.
    What art thou? and how comest thou hither,
    Where no man never comes but that sad dog
    That brings me food to make misfortune live?

Groom

    I was a poor groom of thy stable, king,
    When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York,
    With much ado at length have gotten leave
    To look upon my sometimes royal master''s face.

Like the old man, the Groom maintains a sense of loyalty amid a world that has thrown loyalty aside. 

Click Here to read Richard II 5.5.'
quote: 'O, my good lord, I have been your tenant, and  /      your father''s tenant, these fourscore years.  /

text:
'Perhaps one of the most devastating lines in all of Shakespeare.  Recall that Gloucester has only just delivered his speech about Edgar, at the end of 3.7:

O my follies!  Then Edgar was abus''d.
Kind Gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!

Carvell saw Gloucester''s shame of Edmund (for being a bastard) in the first half of the play as "misdirected."  He was ashamed of having conceived a son out of wedlock - not of having failed to treat that son as a human being.  Here we see Gloucester''s shame refocused on himself.  He did not say, in those lines from 3.7, "O my folly."  Gloucester sees almost every action he has taken as a cause for shame, regret, and repentance. 

His tragedy is that just as he comes to "see," he is blinded, and just as he is blinded, he sees that his sight was useless to him when he had it.  This is perfect tragedy.'
quote: 'you cannot see your way.  /    /  GLOUCESTER  /    /      I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;  /      I stumbled when I saw:

text:
'Edgar will reprise the theme of this speech later in the scene, in lines 25-6.  The idea that the worst is always yet to come is strong for Edgar, and with it the fear of Fortune''s wheel turning and bringing him lower and lower.  At the same time, there is a strange allure to "the worst."  Why?

Because, as Edgar says, "The lowest and most dejected thing of Fortune / Stands still in esperance."  In other words, the man whose life is at rock bottom can legitimately hope for improvement.  The trick, of course, is this: how can you know when your life is as bad as it is ever going to be?  Edgar will try to answer this question later in the scene.
'
quote: 'To be worst,  /      The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,  /      Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:  /      The lamentable change is from the best;  /      The worst returns to laughter. Welcome, then,  /      Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!  /      The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst  /      Owes nothing to thy blasts.

text: 'Edgar is the "food" which has fed Gloucester''s wrath.  '
quote: 'O dear son Edgar,  /      The food of thy abused father''s wrath!  /

text:
'One may well wonder at Gloucester''s choice of adjective.  "Abused" reminds us a little of Lear''s famous line in 3.2:

I am a man
More sinn''d against than sinning.

That Gloucester is abused is beyond doubt.  But why, in a confession to an unseen son - in an expiatory speech - does he need to remind the old man (and the audience) that bad things have happened to him?  If we were to be very hard on Gloucester, perhaps unduly hard, we would say that he has set in motion the very instrument of his own abuse - by being cruel to Edmund.  Nevertheless, such a reading makes us uncomfortable because it seems to mitigate the cruelty of Cornwall in the blinding scene.  How to read this line, then?


'
quote: 'abused

text:
'Edgar has formulated an answer to his question in the scene''s opening monologue.  If a man can say "I am at the worst," then he must not, in fact, be at the worst.  As long as he can reflect, and can assess his situation, then he must not be without some kind of hope (or at least some kind of distance between him and the abuse he suffers). 

Shakespeare is fond of this kind of paradox.  For instance, take this interaction between Juliet and her nurse from Romeo and Juliet 2.5:

Nurse

    Jesu, what haste? can you not stay awhile?
    Do you not see that I am out of breath?

JULIET

    How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath
    To say to me that thou art out of breath?

'
quote: 'O gods! Who is''t can say ''I am at  /      the worst''?  /      I am worse than e''er I was.  /

text: 'See previous note: this is the aphoristic formulation of Edgar''s idea of "the worst."'
quote: '[Aside] And worse I may be yet: the worst is not  /      So long as we can say ''This is the worst.''  /

text:
'A number of such correspondences in the play, in which one character evokes another in an eerily accurate way.  Another example would be the fool pretending to mistake a joint-stool for Goneril in 3.6.  Greenblatt notes that the comparison is a good one, because Goneril is indeed cold, unyielding, and unfeeling.  Here, Tom has evoked Edgar for Gloucester - a much more reasonable "error." 


'
quote: 'I'' the last night''s storm I such a fellow saw;  /      Which made me think a man a worm: my son  /      Came then into my mind;

text:
'Gloucester began the play by observing a connection between certain astral events and their "sequent effects" in the human world:

These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend
no good to us: though the wisdom of nature can
reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself
scourged by the sequent effects: love cools,
friendship falls off, brothers divide: in
cities, mutinies; in countries, discord; in
palaces, treason; and the bond cracked ''twixt son
and father.

Now, the bond between the heavenly world and the earthly one has been broken.  Gloucester can no longer find any meaning in the behaviors of men, nor any relation between those behaviors and any kind of divine cause: it seems that humans are used cruelly by distant Gods with no intention in mind but to enjoy the "sport" of toying with human lives.

We may note the following analogy in Gloucester''s reasoning:
GODS : MEN  ::  MEN: MEN
In Lear, men use one another in increasingly cruel and meaningless ways.  Gloucester learned of this firsthand when he was blinded. 

Those familiar with Hobbes''s "Leviathan" will recall that book''s uplifting aphorism: "Every man is enemy to every man."  If Gods are enemies of men (or - worse? - their indifferent antagonizers), then surely the men in this play do not seem all that different from Gods in their cruel treatment of one another.

(As for the idea of man being a game in the hand of God, or a small part in an impossible big system from which it is impossible to escape, Schopenhauer is a useful point of comparison.  "The World as Will and Representation" is of course the place to go for those interested.)

To read chapter 8 of "The Leviathan," click here.

text: 'Gloucester is taking "Tom" as his guide because he reminds him of his son, Edgar, who, of course, Tom is.  The irony of Gloucester''s wish to see his son being granted immediately after his "kill us for sport" line is indeed profound.'

text:
'Daub, OED:
  1. trans. In building, etc.: To coat or cover (a wall or building) with a layer of plaster, mortar, clay, or the like; to cover (laths or wattle) with a composition of clay or mud, and straw or hay, so as to form walls. (Cf.

DAB v. 8.)


The word was only a few hundred years old when Shakespeare used it here.  Edgar is using plastering as a metaphor for lying - literally for "covering up."  The word is used elsewhere in Lear, in 2.2, where Kent is fighting with Oswald:

OSWALD

    This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spared
    at suit of his gray beard,--

KENT

    Thou whoreson zed! thou unnecessary letter! My
    lord, if you will give me leave, I will tread this
    unbolted villain into mortar, and daub the wall of
    a jakes with him. Spare my gray beard, you wagtail?

("Jakes" means privy.)

text: 'Arden''s editors suggest that Gloucester has his own adultery in mind when he alludes to the "lust-dieted man," that is, the man who feeds only on lust.'

text:
'This is a very complicated speech grammatically, and so we''ll have to parse it carefully.

Gloucester begins by comparing his situation to Edgar''s.  Although both men have been brought low by fortune, Gloucester is undoubtedly the worse off of the two, and that means that Edgar is, by comparison, more fortunate.  Therefore, "that I am wretched makes thee happier."

Next, he describes himself as the "superfluous and lust-dieted man, / that slaves to your ordinance, that will not see / because he does not feel."  Lust-dieted is glossed in its own note.  "Slaves to your ordinance" is up for debate.  It could mean that instead of paying homage to Edgar, Gloucester is making demands of him (ordering that he accompany Gloucester to the Dover cliffs).  Or, if we read "slaves" in either of its two other senses (as given in OED) - to "tear away from" or "to make a slave" - then the line could mean that Gloucester is forcing Edgar to put aside what fate has in store for him (his ordinance) in order to serve Gloucester. 

Then, with the line "so distribution should undo excess," Gloucester closes out the speech by framing the whole thing as a redistribution of the thing called fortune - specifically good fortune - so that each man gets an equal share.

That he ends the speech by asking Edgar whether he "know[s] Dover" tells us that Dover has been on his mind throughout.  He is thinking of his suicide as he speaks these lines.
'
quote: 'that I am wretched  /      Makes thee the happier: heavens, deal so still!  /      Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,  /      That slaves your ordinance, that will not see  /      Because he doth not feel, feel your power quickly;  /      So distribution should undo excess,  /      And each man have enough.

text: 'After his blinding, Gloucester''s lines become more and more heartbreaking with every passing moment.  "From that place / I shall no leading need" is a surrendering of himself to death and fate, but Gloucester cannot know at this moment how ironic these lines must become - Edgar will indeed lead him from the place from which he "shall no leading need."'
quote: 'from that place  /      I shall no leading need.  /

text:
'"He won''t acknowledge insults which, if he paid attention to them, would demand that he got angry in response."  Goneril considers Albany a coward. 

The last time we saw him was in 1.4, when he witnessed Goneril''s dismissal of Lear''s knights and servants and warned her:

How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell:
Striving to better, oft we mar what''s well.

Then, in 3.1, we heard from Kent of the division between Albany and Cornwall:

There is division,
Although as yet the face of it be cover''d
With mutual cunning, ''twixt Albany and Cornwall...

Now, with the introduction of the erotic attraction between Goneril and Edmund, Albany coming to be viewed by Goneril much as Macbeth is seen by Lady Macbeth before the murder of Duncan.  Edmund, by contrast, is a powerful and conniving actor, and so is attractive to Goneril.
'

text: 'There are a number of sexual innuendos in this line and in the following line of Edmund''s.  "Conceive," obviously, is meant in the sense of "understand" and also "have intercourse (resulting in conception)."  "Stretch thy spirits up into the air" may intend "spirits" in the sense of "vital fluids" rather than "disposition."  '
quote: 'this kiss, if it durst speak,  /      Would stretch thy spirits up into the air:  /      Conceive, and fare thee well.  /

text:
'A pun: "death" means both "death on the battlefield" and "orgasm."  Shakespeare makes the same pun frequently, as in these lines from Antony and Cleopatra, which Enobarbus speaks to Antony:

Under a compelling occasion, let women die; it were
pity to cast them away for nothing; though, between
them and a great cause, they should be esteemed
nothing. Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of
this, dies instantly; I have seen her die twenty
times upon far poorer moment: I do think there is
mettle in death, which commits some loving act upon
her, she hath such a celerity in dying.

'
