Twelfth Night begins with a tempest, which scrambles the characters and separates the identical twins Viola and Sebastian.

Shakespeare didn''t lean particularly heavily on source material when writing Twelfth Night, but he did read Barnabe Rich''s "Apolonius and Silla," a prose story from 1581 which begins with a storm that leaves Silla and Apolonius moored on the island of Cyprus.

'

'This is a commonplace in Shakespeare: the incongruence between the outward appearance and the inward state.  It''s especially relevant to Shakespeare''s comedies of disguise and mistaken identity, of course, because the outward shows adopted by Viola will be intentionally misleading.

2.  A malarial fever, marked by successive fits or paroxysms, consisting of a cold, hot, and sweating stage. The name ague was apparently at first given to the burning or feverish stage, but afterwards more usually to the cold or shivering stage, as being the most striking external character of the disease.

text: 'The stage at the Globe theater was fairly empty. One or two big pieces of scenery (a bed, like in this play, or a tree) might be used, and many small props were used to set the stage or locate the action. There was no roof over the stage, and, of course, no lighting (the Blackfriars theater was lit by candles)--plays took place during the day, in full sunlight. Othello''s candle, then, serves not only to highlight the brevity and fragility of Desdemona''s life, but to locate the scene for the audience: it is at night.'

text:
'

Sir Andrew is a fool.  The wordplay here isn''t complicated, really, as long as you remember that Maria always gets the better of Andrew.  First, Andrew mistakes Toby''s orders - "accost" - for a last name, and so we get "Mistress Mary Accost."  Then Mary responds to his question, "do you think you have fools in hand?" in the negative, her reason being that Andrew''s hand isn''t in hers.  Andrew stupidly offers her his hand, proving that he is a fool, and later on declares himself to be "not such an ass but I can keep my hand dry."  He unwittingly proves himself to be just such an ass in these lines, which evoke the proverb "Fools have wit enough to keep themselves out of the rain."

'

text:
'

The world of Sir Toby, all revels, drunkenness, quibbles, and dances, is about as far from Olivia, Orsino, and Viola''s world as it''s possible to be.  While Orsino suffers, Olivia mourns, and Viola wanders, Toby thinks only of fun.  It''s sometimes said of Twelfth Night that the play moves from elegy to comedy, that it has changed modes by the time the final act arrives.  This may be so, but it seems more accurate to say that Twelfth Night is a play in which characters exist in different modes alongside each other, and always simultaneously.

'

text: 'J.R. Brown writes that Toby can be played as a plain old boor, or as "young and spry with a sense of style."  Brown cites Patrick Wymark''s Toby, from a 1958 production at Stratford, as an example of the latter version of Toby.  There have been productions of all types, though, including those that blend Brown''s versions into one: an old, buffoonish Sir Toby who is nonetheless spry and, at times, almost stylish, having an appreciation for nice wines, and so on.'

text:
'

It''s not clear whether Toby refers to Taurus, the bull, seriously or ironically.  Generally speaking, those who take astrology seriously in Shakespeare are either characters in plays set in ancient times (Gloucester, Octavius, etc.) or they are light-hearted Renaissance characters like Malvolio. 

In "The Oxford Companion to Shakespeare," it''s speculated that Shakespeare''s view of astrology, which was a hot science in Elizabethan England - the queen herself patronized the astrologer John Dee - and was often vigorously debated, conforms to that expressed in Sonnet 14:

Not from the stars do I my judgement pluck;
And yet methinks I have astronomy,
But not to tell of good or evil luck,
Of plagues, of dearths, or seasons'' quality;
Nor can I fortune to brief minutes tell,
Pointing to each his thunder, rain and wind,
Or say with princes if it shall go well
By oft predict that I in heaven find:
But from thine eyes my knowledge I derive,
And constant stars in them I read such art
As ''Truth and beauty shall together thrive,
If from thyself, to store thou wouldst convert'';
    Or else of thee this I prognosticate:
    ''Thy end is truth''s and beauty''s doom and date.''

Greenblatt would reject outright that Shakespeare could have believed in astrology, and it''s hard to refute him.  So we read Toby''s "taurus" line as a sign of both the lighthearted climate of the play generally and of Toby''s intellectual register more specifically.

'

text:
'Much of the critical dialogue surrounding this speech is motivated by the textual history of this one word (Richard Levin''s article "The Indian/Iudean Crux in Othello," in Shakespeare Quarterly, offers the best analysis of this issue). Here, briefly, is the controversy: the First Quarto text (1622) prints Indian, but the First Folio (1623) prints Iudean (you can imagine that, in a period of greater typographical flexibility, the two words would look very similar). Bibliographical evidence is complicated and indeterminate on both sides (a typesetter either mistaking Indian for Iudean or vice-versa is equally possible).

The contextual arguments go as follows: Indian makes sense because the wealth of India (especially in gemstones) was notable in Renaissance England, and the ignorance of Indians who were unaware of the value of these gems was commented upon by Renaissance writers (hence "base"). On the other hand, Iudean makes sense because Desdemona was betrayed treacherously, and (in the Geneva bible), in betraying Christ Judas threw away "a pearl of great price" (Matthew 13:46). The matter remains open, but Levin''s conclusion makes sense to me: that it is appropriate for Othello to compare himself to the Indian, whose base action results from ignorance, and "very inappropriate for him to compare himself to Judas, whose action was regarded as a conscious choice of evil."
'

text:
'This line recalls Act 3 Scene 3, where Iago questions what kind of "ocular proof" Othello really wants: the handkerchief, presented in a false context, is the object that poisons Othello''s sight.

There is a more interesting context for this line, however, and it is the antitheatrical discourse that surrounded the English Reformation. Iconoclastic reformers thought that images in general, and the theater in particular, were dangerous because they drew attention away from the word--language, in the theology of radical Protestantism, was the way in which God chose to communicate, so images (and especially religious images) were inherently troubling. Early English theater was largely composed of religious plays, so reformers had their work cut out for them. Even after the public theaters opened and plays became mostly secular, the theater was seen as a place of licentiousness and ribaldry, not a place where good Christians should be on a Sunday afternoon. This controversy was in the public zeitgeist from the late fifteenth century through the middle of the seventeenth century, and would flare up periodically during changes in political or religious leadership.

Shakespeare''s placement of what is essentially an iconoclastic pronouncement ("the object poisons sight") at the end of a play is, as you can imagine, a matter of much interest for Shakespeare scholars. There''s quite a lot of work that deals with this issue in general, but one excellent, balanced, and readable book on this subject is Huston Diehl''s Staging Reform, Reforming the Stage: Protestantism and Popular Theater in Early Modern England.
'

text: 'Iago later cites his suspicion that Othello has slept with Emilia, his wife, as his motive for destroying him, but there is absolutely no evidence for this idea, and this never quite seems to be what''s really motivating Iago. Some people (Othello himself, later, as well as Emilia and Lodovico) think that Iago might be an incarnation of the devil, motivated by pure evil, but I think this line gives us some clue to his motivation. Iago just doesn''t like to have a master--or rather, to have a master that he cannot himself master in return.'
quote: 'I follow him to serve my turn upon him:   /  We cannot all be masters, nor all masters   /  Cannot be truly follow''d.

text: 'Iago''s basic rhetorical strategy works as follows: he says (or hints at) the thing that he wants his listener to believe (often the exact opposite of the truth), and then the listener''s imagination reiterates, reformulates, and thus strengthens Iago''s lies. Here he claims honesty and goodness, and is then granted the epithet "Honest Iago." His half-disclaimed suggestions of Desdemona''s infidelity worm their way into Othello''s mind like weeds, where they multiply and soon take over.'

text: 'It seems here like Iago is actually trying to convince Cassio to seduce Desdemona. This would be evidence for critics like Stephen Greenblatt, who believes that Iago is the ultimate improviser: he doesn''t know the details of his own plan in advance, but tries things out and sees what works. He may initially think that getting Cassio to actually make a pass at Desdemona would be a good idea, but later realizes that he doesn''t even need to do this--he can just lie about it.'

text:
'

The passage of time is difficult to gauge in Twelfth Night.  Here, Valentine implies that only a few days have past since Viola washed up on the shores of Illyria in 1.1; she left that scene intending to serve Olivia, and winds up serving Orsino.  So we could reasonably assume that no more than a week has passed between 1.1 and 1.4.

But later,in 5.1, Antonio will tell Orsino that he has been in Illyria "for three months" (5.1.92).  How is this possible, if Antonio was shipwrecked at the same time as Viola?  J.R. Brown calls this a double time scheme, in which the action of the whole play takes three months while the scenes take only a few days.

Arden calls this line "inconsistent" with 5.1.92, and notes that some critics suggest Antonio''s "three months" are exaggerated for dramatic effect, in order to make his relationship to Sebastian seem closer (Arden).

'

text:
'The critic Bertrand Evans, in his book "The Fruits of the Sport," calls Viola the closest character to the audience.  What he means is that Viola''s udnerstanding of the dramatic irony of scenes like this is the most sophisticated.  Like the audience, she is able to recognize that the Duke''s lines are close enough to "strike sparks from the truth," in Evans''s phrase.

There''s another irony here, which comes from the Duke''s assumption that Cesario is too young a boy to have a man''s voice and appearance.  In fact, the actor playing Viola would probably have fit that description.'

text:
'Feste is certainly one of Shakespeare''s most interesting fools.  A.C. Bradley loved him the best of all of them.

Part of Feste''s power is that he isn''t very funny.  He''s witty, sure, but his wit is attuned more to accurate commentary on the action than to the amusement of the characters.  Here, he sets up a clever reversal of Olivia''s reasons for mourning.
'

text:
'Sir Toby belches loudly in the middle of this line, which explains why he curses pickle-herring for inflating him, so to speak.

Interestingly, pickle-herring was also a kind of stage name for clowns and fools in 17th century German and Dutch (as pekelharing), perhaps because pickle-herring was an accompaniment to heavy drinking and so would have been eaten while watching fools, or behaving foolishly.

That pickle-herring connects so closely with drunkenness and foolishness is appropriate for Sir Toby, who is forever arriving on the scene fresh from another bender.
'

text:
'Viola (as Cesario) was obviously very insistent at Olivia''s gate.  Still, Olivia capitulates pretty quickly to another entreaty from Orsino, in whom she''s already decided she has no interest (or has she?).  This kind of line gives us reason to support the second of J.R. Brown''s interpretations of Olivia - as a girl (or even a woman) who is indulging in the "fantasy" of mourning rather than engaging in the real thing.

By giving Olivia so many lines expressing reluctance ("he shall not") before he has her admit Cesario, Shakespeare also set himself up for a virtuosic 100-line performance in which Olivia''s feelings about Cesario will change "from scorn to love" (in Bertrand Evans''s words).
'

text:
'Viola departs from her assigned speech and asks Olivia to lift her mourning veil and show her face.

Olivia treats her face as though it were a portrait to be presented ("such a one as I"), and Viola continues that metaphor with a biting twist in her line, "If God did all."  What she means is, "If you''re not using makeup."  Shakespeare often uses painting (that is, applying cosmetics) as a way to express both the practical side of physical beauty, as when Iras tells Charmian "You shall paint when you are old," in Antony and Cleopatra, and also as a kind of metaphoric lens through which male characters can understand their own doubleness, and their own deceptions - take Claudius''s line in Hamlet 3.1: "The harlot''s cheek, beautied with plastering art, Is not more ugly to the thing that helps it Than is my deed to my most painted word" (3.1.53ff).

At any rate, it''s very bold of Viola to bring up the possibility that Olivia has made herself up.
'

text:
'This is precisely the argument of Sonnet 1:

From fairest creatures we desire increase,
That thereby beauty''s rose might never die,
But as the riper should by time decease,
His tender heir might bear his memory:
But thou, contracted to thine own bright eyes,
Feed''st thy light''st flame with self-substantial fuel,
Making a famine where abundance lies,
Thyself thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel.
Thou that art now the world''s fresh ornament
And only herald to the gaudy spring,
Within thine own bud buriest thy content
And, tender churl, makest waste in niggarding.
Pity the world, or else this glutton be,
To eat the world''s due, by the grave and thee.

Men and women who are physically beautiful have the obligation to reproduce, so that their beauty can be preserved after their death.
'

text:
'And, in a little over 100 lines, Olivia has fallen in love with Cesario.  A classic Shakespearean wooing scene.

Note that Olivia refers to love as "the plague," something both contagious and, to put it mildly, undesirable.  Why is it that these characters, whose lives are rule by love or the avoidance of love, spend so much time disparaging it?
'

text:
'Plague wasn''t uncommon in Elizabethan England.  Transmitted by rat fleas, the disease was wrongly assumed by doctors to be an airborne contagion.  That explains why an outbreak of plague could lead to the closing of public buildings, like playhouses, where people gathered together and so breathed the same air. 

So, plague wasn''t a joke or a metaphor for Shakespeare and his contemporaries.  Shakespeare''s characters were granted immunity to the plague by their author, so they use it lightly and metaphorically, as Olivia does here (or as Orsino does in line 1.1.19).  (See "The Oxford Companion to Shakespeare" - "plague.")'

text:
'We''re back on the seacoast - again, probably the eastern Adriatic ("Illyria" in Classical Antiquity). There''s a division between the civilized, interior world of Orsino and Olivia, and the uncivilized, natural world of Sebastian and Viola (at least in 1.1).

This is a familiar device in Shakespeare, giving us the forest and the city in Midsummer Night''s Dream, for instance. The wildness of the outdoors and the civilization of the city are categories that aren''t absolute, of course, but from the storm we get the energy that scrambles the characters before throwing them back into the palaces and inner chambers of Illyria.

(Some editors think this scene takes place on the street rather than on the coast.)
'

text:
'This is not an uncommon idea in Shakespeare.  When strong male characters begin to cry, or to behave in a way that is considered womanly, they often describe themselves being overwhelmed by the spirit of their mothers - that is, by womanliness in general. 

One interesting reversal of this is in Julius Caesar, when Cassius blames his "rashness" - rather than a more traditionally feminine quality - on his mother.  Brutus replies:

When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,
He''ll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

 
'

text:
'Shakespeare''s characters often lose control of their speech when they''re in love, sometimes with hilarious results.  There''s also a sense that the mouth can be hijacked, so to speak, by other, more sensual, parts of the body: the eyes, the penis, and so on.  In Hamlet, Polonius warns Ophelia about Hamlet''s sweet talk:

When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul
\r\nLends the tongue vows...

In other words, lust - hot blood - will make a person say anything.  Polonius suspects Hamlet of eloquence, but here lust has the opposite effect on Olivia, making her speech "distracted." 



'

text:
'Viola compares a woman''s heart to soft wax, on which a man can imprint his seal; it''s very easy for a woman to fall in love, she reasons.  Viola''s logic here is that action and behavior is modeled on appearance.  Women are soft (like wax) and they are also physically weaker than men and prone to fickle changes of emotion.  Kate, at he end of Taming of the Shrew, says:

Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth,
Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions and our hearts
Should well agree with our external parts?

And Hamlet, revolted at Gertrude''s over-hasty marriage to Claudius, says:

Frailty, thy name is woman!

But it isn''t so simple, of course.  If anything, Viola should know that the exterior condition doesn''t agree at all with the interior; she is in disguise!

text: 'A fantastic Shakespearean word, though not a coinage.  Shakespeare uses fadge in two senses.  The first, "to turn out, end up," is how it''s intended in this line.  The second sense is "to succeed, turn out well," as in Love''s Labour''s Lost when the Spanish buffoon Armado declares, "We will have, if this fadge not, an antic" ("Shakespeare''s Words," Crystal and Crystal).'

text:
'In Hippocrates'' "On the Nature of a Human Being," health is said to consist of a balance between the "four humors" of the body: blood, phlegm, yellow bile, and black bile.  These were thought to correspond to the elements of nature - water, fire, earth, air - and to promote good health when balanced well (For more, see "Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece" - "health.")

Toby''s lines don''t really make logical sense, but they do set Andrew up for a very funny response.

text:
'This beautiful song was probably written by Shaksepeare, and it''s a beautiful mix of melancholy longing ("where are you roaming?") and sensual desire ("come kiss me, sweet and twenty.")

Yet, as with so much of Twelfth Night, Festes'' song is both a pean to youth and love and an elegy to them.  It recognizes that love is a passing pleasure while refusing to cheapen or darken the vision of young love as it is presented.  In fact, it''s the passage of time that makes love so important, and so pleasurable. "In delay there lies no plenty," sings Feste; let''s get all we can right now, because (and despite that) tomorrow isn''t certain.


'

''T is not hereafter;  /  Present mirth hath present laughter;  /  What''s to come is still unsure.  /  In delay there lies no plenty,  /  Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty,  /  Youth''s a stuff will not endure.  /

text:
'These three lines are reminiscent of Andrew Marvell''s "To His Coy Mistress," written in the middle of the 17th century, in which a young man tries to convince a woman to sleep with him.  What''s his strategy?  "We''re running out of time," he tells her - youth''s a stuff will not endure.


"To His Coy Mistress"

Had we but world enough, and time,
This coyness, lady, were no crime.
We would sit down and think which way
To walk, and pass our long love''s day;
Thou by the Indian Ganges'' side
Shouldst rubies find; I by the tide
Of Humber would complain. I would
Love you ten years before the Flood;
And you should, if you please, refuse
Till the conversion of the Jews.
My vegetable love should grow
Vaster than empires, and more slow.
An hundred years should go to praise
Thine eyes, and on thy forehead gaze;
Two hundred to adore each breast,
But thirty thousand to the rest;
An age at least to every part,
And the last age should show your heart.
For, lady, you deserve this state,
Nor would I love at lower rate.

        But at my back I always hear
Time''s winged chariot hurrying near;
And yonder all before us lie
Deserts of vast eternity.
Thy beauty shall no more be found,
Nor, in thy marble vault, shall sound
My echoing song; then worms shall try
That long preserv''d virginity,
And your quaint honour turn to dust,
And into ashes all my lust.
The grave''s a fine and private place,
But none I think do there embrace.

        Now therefore, while the youthful hue
Sits on thy skin like morning dew,
And while thy willing soul transpires
At every pore with instant fires,
Now let us sport us while we may;
And now, like am''rous birds of prey,
Rather at once our time devour,
Than languish in his slow-chapp''d power.
Let us roll all our strength, and all
Our sweetness, up into one ball;
And tear our pleasures with rough strife
Thorough the iron gates of life.
Thus, though we cannot make our sun
Stand still, yet we will make him run.
'

text:
'Malvolio''s puritanical character seems to come from a deep-rooted sense of decency, and morality.  Here he appeals to large concepts, like respect for time, for place, and for others, rather than simply disparage Toby and Andrew for making noise.  Malvolio''s question is always, "Have you no decency?"

For this reason, Charles Lamb described Malvolio as being "not essentially ludicrous.  He becomes comic but by accident.  He is cold, austere, repelling, but dignified, consistent, and, for what appears, rather of an over-stretch morality."  "Over-stretched" is a good adjective for Malvolio.  He is stretched thin by the obligation he feels to prevent the immorality of others, or at least to check it and correct it.
'

text:
'This is a famous line because it is often taken to represent the irrepressible character of the Twelfth Night spirit as against the puritanical, starchy morality of Malvolio. 

Keep in mind that Twelfth Night was probably written for the twelfth, and final, night of the Christmas festivities in England.  The festivities included drinking, dancing, and even cross-dressing.  Diarists from the early 17th century note all kinds of mischief that went on around twelfth night.  The spirit of festivity, and, by extension, of comedy as a dramatic mode, is somehow more powerful than its natural adversary, restraint. 

The festive beats the somber; comedy beats elegy.
'

text:
'The plan is to forge a love letter from Olivia to Malvolio and then let him find it.

Bertrand Evans, in his "Fruits of the Sport," called Twelfth Night a play of "practisers," by which he means a play in which everyone is out to play a trick on everyone else.  We''ve already seen Viola trick Orsino and Olivia; now Maria, Toby, and Andrew will trick Malvolio - purely for the fun of it. 
'

text:
'A strange, heartbreaking line from Sir Andrew. Just when we''re laughing hardest at him for all his foolishness in this scene (like the line, "I have''t in my nose too") Shakespeare gives him a poignant and sorrowful memory of lost love. 

When Virginia Woolf saw Twelfth Night at the Old Vic in 1933, she was struck by this line.  She wrote that when Andrew speaks it, "we feel that we hold him in the hollow of our hands; a novelist would have taken three volumes to bring us to that pitch of intimacy" (Wells 80).
'

text:
'This is interesting, given that we''ve just heard Viola speak on the subject of women''s fickleness.  Viola comapared a woman''s heart to soft wax in which a man may plant his seal, a metaphor that makes men out to be hard and constant and women out to be inconstant.

Orsino''s suggestion that Cesario marry a younger woman implies the opposite, that young men are "giddy and unfirm" and so need to wait longer than women do to figure out what they want.  It''s better to marry a woman who will "wear to you," that is, adapt to you, than to marry one who is already sure of herself.
'

text:
'Orsino used this same metaphor in his speech at 1.1.8ff, in his opening monologue:

O spirit of love, how quick and fresh art thow,
That notwithstanding thy capacity
Receiveth as the sea...

It''s this side of Orsino, the inflated, blowhard side, that leads people to accuse him of being a "lover of love" rather than a lover of Olivia.

This speech is also weirdly similar to Feste''s song, in that both the speaker of the song and Orsino claim to own a special portion of an indefinable quantity: love or death.  In the song, Feste sings, "My part of death no one so true did share it," which means, "I am the truest man who ever died for love."  Now we hear Orsino making similar claims, such as "No woman''s heart / So big, to hold so much," meaning "I am more passionate a lover than any woman can be."'

text:
'You may be wondering what bear-baiting is, and why Malvolio disapproves of it.  The Arden editors note dryly that bear-baiting is something "of which Puritans disapproved," leaving us to ask, What is it?  Is it giving a bear a fishing rod and letting him catch trout?  Is it luring him to you with a jar of honey?

It is not.  Bear-baiting is an old "sport" in which a bear is chained to a stake and torn apart by dogs.  If you want to see it (and you may not want to), you can by clicking here.

It''s worth noting that Thomas Macaulay''s "History of England" includes this line about bear-baiting: The Puritan hated bearbaiting, not because it gave pain to the bear, but because it gave pleasure to the spectators.  This fits in with what we know about Malvolio.'

text:
'Here Malvolio is fantasizing about marrying Olivia, whom he suspects of harboring a secret affection for him, and so becoming "Count Malvolio!"  By having Malvolio enter proclaiming self-deluded nonsense about Olivia''s favoritism of him, Shakespeare shows us that Maria''s device is a supremely clever one.  The best pranks are those which work by appealing to the narcissism of their targets. 

Salvador Dali famously told Smithsonian Magazine, "Every morning when I wake up, I experience an exquisite joy â€” the joy of being Salvador DalÃ­ â€” and I ask myself in rapture: What wonderful things is this Salvador DalÃ­ going to accomplish today?"

Malvolio, though not a genius, does have something of the Dali about him, which we''ll see more of once he discovers the letter.'

text:
'Malvolio is really indulging himself now.  In performance it''s up to the actor to convey the full-blown delusion that''s giving Malvolio such undeniable pleasure here, and successful renditions of Malvolio capture the sincerity and self-importance with which he considers the possibility of becoming a Count.  There is nothing fantastical or childlike about Malvolio here, nothing whistful, only the practical, day-to-day details, duly considered, of what his life would be like if he were husband to Olivia. 

Charles Lamb wrote of the Malvolio he saw in 1793, "With what ineffable carelessness would he twirl his gold chain!"  "Ineffable carelessness" as an expression of deluded self-importance is the name of Malvolio''s game.
'

text:
'Poor Malvolio; the joke is really on him in these lines.

"C U T" spells "cut," which was slang for vagina, OED citing a sense in which it means a "strait" for water.  Continuing in that vein Malvolio admires Olivia''s "great P''s," which of course are her "great pisses," the connection with CUT and P''s now becoming clear to everyone but him. 

Careful readers will notice the the sentence Malvolio reads, "To the unknown beloved..." doesn''t have a C or a P in it, so Andrew''s question - "Why that?" - has no good answer except this: "Because it''s a good joke, and it makes Malvolio look like a fool" (Arden).'

text:
'This is the first of two references to the Sophy in Twelfth Night, so it''s worth looking into who he was and why he''s here.

The Sophy, or Shah of Persia, was very much on the Elizabethan mind in 1601, the approximate date of Twelfth Night''s composition. That''s because an explorer named Anthony Sherley paid him a visit between 1598 and 1601, then traveled for a while in his kingdom while the Shah his brother hostage. This little piece of trivia has even helped us date the play after 1600 (Arden).'

text:
'Here''s one take on Gertrude''s lines: she''s standing up for her son, dissembling on his behalf. It''s hard to forget, after all, that in the last scene, Hamlet explained to her that "I essentially am not in madness, / But mad in craft" and that "My pulse as yours doth temperately keep time, / And makes as healthful music." How straightforward -- Hamlet feigns madness, clues his mother in to that deception, and enlists her in his effort to keep the true nature of this "insanity" from Claudius. Case closed.

Or not. It''s also hard to forget that Hamlet''s "madness" goes through a dizzying array of modulations and redefinitions. Polonius and Ophelia believe it; Claudius suspects it but searches for its "source" nonetheless; Gertrude, as we can see here, is easily swayed. Even more importantly, Hamlet himself has no idea what''s going on in his head -- and maybe Shakespeare doesn''t have any idea, either (that''s what T.S. Eliot argued in "Hamlet and His Problems," his famous essay on Shakespeare''s failure to provide an "objective correlative" for Hamlet''s behavior). Hamlet is convinced he''s not truly mad, but he''s not convinced that he''s completely fine, either. Rather, he insists on a certain psychic impenetrability, proscribing any genuine encounter with the true nature of his anxiety. Paradoxically, Gertrude''s statement that Hamlet is as "Mad as the sea and the wind," seemingly certain, just serves to remind us of the insoluble and inconclusive nature of Hamlet''s "madness."

A bit more on Hamlet''s self-knowledge (or lack thereof): Hamlet may not be plagued by madness, but any candid account of the depression from which he is suffering eludes him â€“ and the relationship between his melancholy and his mock lunacy is even more obscure. When Rosencrantz and Guildenstern first interrogate him as to his condition in Act II, Scene II, he gives an assessment whose vagary seems at first calculated to mislead his interrogators until it becomes clear that his confusion is genuine. â€œI will tell you why [you were sent for],â€ Hamlet begins, making a show of sparing Rosencrantz and Guildenstern the need to explain themselves: "I have of late, but / wherefore I know not, lost all my mirth, forgone all / custom of exercises and, indeed, it goes so heavily with / my disposition that this goodly frame the earth seems / to me a sterile promontory." Manifestly, Hamlet says nothing that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern â€“ and Claudius and Polonius â€“ do not already know: he is melancholy (having â€œlost all his mirthâ€) and he is behaving rather erratically (having â€œforgone all / custom of exercisesâ€). He leaves Rosencrantz and Guildenstern disappointed in their efforts to discover, as Claudius had asked them, why â€œnor thâ€™exterior nor the inward man / Resembles that it was."

Were they more perceptive listeners, though, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern might have noticed that Hamletâ€™s rather extended self-assessment gradually loses its caricatural element. Not only is the â€œearth [â€¦] sterile,â€ the heavens â€“ â€œthis brave oâ€™erhanging firmamentâ€ â€“ â€œappeareth nothing to me but a foul and pestilent / congregation of vapors.â€ Though Hamlet is able abstractly to recognize â€œWhat piece of work is a man â€“ how noble in reason; [â€¦] the beauty of the world; the paragon of animalsâ€ â€“ man is nothing more to him, at base, than the â€œquintessence of dust.â€ Hamlet concludes with desolate finality: â€œMan delights not / me." In an effort to preempt and deflect any questioning from Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, Hamlet inadvertently probes the depths of his psychic pain.
'

text:
'Claudius is saying that it was his love -- "our love," the royal love -- that kept Hamlet safe despite the clear threat he posed to the public safety. Flash forward to IV.vii and it''s clear that other factors are at work. When Laertes asks Claudius in that scene why he hasn''t punished Hamlet for killing Polonius, Claudius says nothing about his own love for Hamlet; rather, it''s the fact that "The Queen his mother / Lives almost by his looks" and that "the general gender bear him" a "great love" that bar him from pursuing justice.

We talk a lot about Hamlet''s inaction and indecision in this play, but what about Claudius''s? Here Claudius (implicitly) brings up three possible explanations -- his love, Gertrude''s love, the people''s love -- but they don''t seem totally plausible. Clearly, the latter two are more in keeping with our idea of Claudius as an unscrupulous character than the first, but none of them could be determinative. Claudius murdered his brother; why not his brother''s son?
'

text:
'To whom is Hamlet''s liberty a threat? Claudius tries to extend it to everyone -- "to you yourself, to us, to every one" -- but this is a clear instance in which our predisposition to doubting Claudius''s candor is operative. He knows by this point that Hamlet has a bone to pick, and he''s looking after his own interests. Yet Claudius is more honest than he appears; that is, Hamlet is a threat to Gertrude (the bedroom interview, anyone?) and to the state (can you imagine Hamlet at the helm of Denmark?). Shakespeare is a pretty good playwright, and here he provides ample evidence of that by having the text speak to us on three levels: a basic level (Claudius speaks and we listen); a psychological level (Claudius is clearly a lying, good-for-nothing throne-stealer and his motives are transparent); and a meta-level that transcends character (Claudius may be deceiving Gertrude and himself, but he''s also saying something intelligible and instructive that the reader is made to consider).
'
quote: 'liberty is full of threats to all;

text:
'Notice that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern have been completely reduced to puppets at this point -- they enter and exit without saying a word. They are nothing more than extensions of Claudius, of the investigative apparatus he employs to looks into "the Hamlet problem." Not only are they the same as Claudius, however; they are the same as each other. They move about the stage as one entity and they are rendered voiceless together.

This is, of course, something we''ve seen for a long time. When Gertrude and Claudius address Rosencrantz and Guildenstern for the first time in II.ii, they demonstrate that the characters with the most distinctive names in the play are in fact interchangeable. â€œThanks, Rosencrantz, and gentle Guildenstern,â€ proclaims Claudius, only to have his words garbled by his wife: â€œThanks, Guildenstern, and gentle Rosencrantz." This seemingly marginal exchange is instantly brought to bear on Hamlet; Gertrude bids the pair â€œvisit / My too much changed sonâ€ and instructs the other courtiers to â€œbring these gentlemen where Hamlet is." In the same breath as the one in which she asserts that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are indistinguishable, Gertrude questions the rigidity of Hamletâ€™s self-definition. He has, we learn again and again, an indeterminate and multifarious nature. Appropriately, it is incumbent upon two of the playâ€™s most malleable personalities â€“ Hamlet in IV.ii accuses Rosencrantz of being a â€œspongeâ€ that â€œsoaks up the Kingâ€™s countenance." â€“ to uncover the nature of that turmoil. They must go, in a figurative sense, to â€œwhere Hamlet is.â€ In going to that place, this fascinating entrance-exit sequence proves, R & G become literal tools of Claudius''s enterprise.'

text: 'Quoi? How can madness be "pure" -- a "mineral" among "metals base"? Is Hamlet''s madness just a princely madness, somehow more refined than the average bout? Is he exonerated (and thus suffering from some higher form of madness) because he "weeps for what is done"? These hypothetical answers are a little tongue-in-cheek because there doesn''t seem to be a clear way to proceed here. What is clear, though, is that Hamlet''s madness is very much in question -- its nature, its legitimacy, and even its caliber (i.e. How does it differ in quality from Ophelia''s?).'

text: 'Claudius seems to be approaching self-parody. This is the third instance of Claudius addressing someone with the dramatic "O" and the even more heightened exclamation point. It''s also a near-repetition of the "O Gertrude, come away!" that he speaks about a dozen lines earlier. Plus, this is a rhyming couplet to boot! Claudius is clearly over-acting, indulging in all kinds of hyperbole to clear himself of any suspicion as he condemns Hamlet to certain death (plot spoiler: that''s what Claudius means by "ship him hence"). Yet Shakespeare speaks on multiple levels, as usual, because Claudius''s soul is indeed full of "discord and dismay" -- why else has it been so difficult for him to do something decisive about Hamlet? One need only look at III.iii, Claudius''s "O, my offence is rank" monologue, to know that Claudius is telling the truth even as he attempts to cover his tracks.'

text:
'

Twelfth Night presents a challenge to directors and set designers, who have to tangle with the wide variety of settings and their contrasting moods.  How would Orsino''s house be different from Olivia''s?  What does the seacoast look like?  The street?  .

J.R. Brown described the problem well.  Part of the play seems to call for a bare, flat, Elizabethan stage; another for the "Italianate, free, colorful" design of the commedia dell''arte. 

In the Stratford-Upon-Avon production at the Memorial Theatre with Vivien Leigh (Blanche DuBois and Scarlett O''Hara) as Olivia, Orsino''s palace was hung with colorful curtainswhile Olivia''s was more austere.  In Sir Toby''s reveling scenes, candlelabras, fruit, and ale appeared - the "Italianate" feeling that Brown describes.

'

text:
'Viola is smart enough to keep up with the fool, and she makes a quibble here on "lie by," so that Feste''s joke about his house being near the church becomes a joke about beggars sleeping with kings.

It''s not uncommon in Shakespeare for characters to use their wit as a kind of democratic force, creating puns in which the differences between kings and beggars are made to vanish.

Hamlet has a memorable riff on beggars and kings:

Not where he eats, but where he is eaten: a certain
convocation of politic worms are e''en at him. Your
worm is your only emperor for diet: we fat all
creatures else to fat us, and we fat ourselves for
maggots: your fat king and your lean beggar is but
variable service, two dishes, but to one table:
that''s the end.

 


'

'Pythagoras, the first to figure out the numerical ratios necessary to tune string instruments (1:2 is the octave, and so on), believed that the movements of heavenly bodies generated a music that was inaudible to most people but audible to people like Pythagoras himself, who were equipped to hear it (see "Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece," Wilson - "Pythagoras").

Olivia is saying that she would rather Cesario drop Orsino''s suit than hear the music of the spheres; that is, the pleasure of Cesario''s company without the hassle of Orsino''s wooing would be the most desirable thing in the world to her.

text:
'The idea of waste comes up frequently in Twelfth Night, in a number of senses. 

Most obviously, as here, there is the sense of wasted time, which haunts characters like Olivia, who feel that their words of love are falling on deaf ears, and so are wasted.

Then there''s the Bacchic, celebratory kind of waste, exemplified by Sir Toby and Sir Andrew, in which characters waste time, wine, food, and so on, in order to have a good time.

Finally we have the waste of beauty, which is a driving force behind much of the erotic langauge in the play.  This type of waste is the subject of Sonnet 1, "From fairest creatures we desire increase," and it comes up when beautiful characters refuse the advances that are heaped upon them.
'

text:
'Beautiful, clever lines, which mean different things to Viola than to Olivia.  Olivia is saying, "I wish that you were someone who was in love with me," while Viola is saying, "You have no idea that I am a woman."

This is another instance in which Bertrand Evans''s observation, that Viola is closest to the audience in her perception of dramatic irony, is relevant.  Viola knows as much as we do in this scene, while Olivia is left completely in the dark as to why Viola might say something like, "I am not what I am."   She can only interpret it in general way, perhaps taking it to mean, "Though I am a servant I have a noble bearing," or something similar, which is the intention of Olivia''s line, "I think the same of you."
'

'Viola is getting upset in these lines, as we know from Olivia''s response, "What a deal of scorn..."

She seems to be uncomfortable with female vulnerability, displayed by Olivia in abundance, as well as with the wastefulness of Olivia''s courtship of her.  When she says, "I am your fool," she means, "You''re treating me like I''m stupid; you''re wasing my time by pursuing me when you should be responding to Orsino''s legitimate suit."

text:
'"Thee" is the objective case of the second person singular pronoun "thou," which was the informal of "you" in English since the 13th century, when "you" started to be used as the polite address (possibly after the French "vous," which was second person plural and polite singular).

Since "thou" fell out of English usage about 100 years ago (OED gives last usage in the Victorian era, with Tennyson), the small differences that Shakespeare''s characters could perceive between "thou" and "you" risk being lost on us when we read Twelfth Night - all the more reason to pay close attention.

Note that Olivia referred to Cesario as "you" in line 3.1.144: "as I would have you be."  Now, confessing her love, she switches to the objective form of the informal second person singular pronoun "thou," and so we get "I love thee."  "I love you," weirdly enough, would sound overly formal to Shakespeare''s audiences (although perhaps wasn''t totally unheard of in aristocratic circles, in which "you" was the default second person pronoun even among family).

Lower-class characters will use "thee" to each other, as Viola and Feste did before Olivia''s entrance into this scene.
'

text:
'Fabian and Toby are dying to get Andrew into a duel, purely for their own amusement.  Here, Fabian convinces Andrew that Olivia isn''t slighting him by flirting with another man in plain sight; on the contrary - she''s trying to make Andrew jealous so he''ll woo her! 

Fabian''s speech is full of little clever puns and references.  "Dormouse valour" is particularly good.  Dormice are known for their long hibernations (although the similarity to French "dormir" may be coincidental), and so "dormouse valour" means "dormant valour."  But a dormouse is also, no matter how you look at it, a little tiny mouse - not something you associate with "valour" at all.  So Andrew is the butt of some of Fabian''s "excellent jests" in these lines.


'

text:
'In Elizabethan England, exorcisms were big spectacles, commonly attracting large crowds reminiscent of theater audiences.  Shakespeare''s audiences would know what Maria meant when she told Olivia that Malvolio was "possessed," because they would have seen exorcisms performed in public, in which people acted strangely until the exorcist had gotten the evil spirit out of them.

Further, in 1603 (after Twelfth Night but before King Lear), Samuel Harsnett published his pamphet, "A declaration of egregious popish \r\nimpostures," which sought to expose as frauds people who said they were possessed by spirits.  Harsnett documented all of the bizarre behaviors that "possessed" people sometimes exhibited, and there were certainly a lot of these.  With that in mind, it''s no wonder - as Greenblatt notes in "Shakespeare and the Exorcists" - that mad characters in Shakespeare are often mistaken for possessed characters.
 '

'Sebastian, who still believes his twin sister to have drowned, now proposes a relaxing afternoon of sightseeing in Illyria. 

It''s possible that Shakespeare needed to separate Sebastian and Antonio so that Antonio can mistake Viola for Sebastian later on.  If this is so, then Sebastian''s desire to walk in the town is an effective plot device, preventing Antonio from staying with Sebastian while he wanders in Illyria.'

text:
'Having just seen Antonio present Sebastian with his purse as a display of his love, we are very sensitive to Olivia''s lines about "buying youth," especially because the youth she''s trying to buy, Cesario, is sister to the youth being wooed by Antonio!

"Bought more oft than begg''d or borrow''d" is proverbial.

If you have a strong interest in the many proverbs that Shakespeare uses in his plays, you''ll be well rewarded for consulting M.P. Tilleys "A dictionary of the proverbs in England in the sixteenth and seventeenth \r\ncenturies," which, though very long, is a useful resource.'

text:
'We''ve already discussed the four Greek humors: blood, phlegm, yellow bile, black bile.  Black bile was the melancholy humor, and yellow bile the choleric humor.  Malvolio isn''t melancholy, but his legs are choleric because the cross-gartering is cutting off his circulation.  His dogs are howling, so to speak.

It''s funny that Malvolio declares himself to be free of black bile, because he is very possibly the only character in the play who, up until this moment, has been wearing all black.  In J.R. Brown''s words, he "takes no colour from the sun" (Wells 37).
'

text:
'Midsummer madness is very inappropriate indeed to Twelfth Night, which is a January holiday.  Malvolio''s mood is summery while Olivia''s is wintry.

The critic James Simpson correlates each season with a literary mode, calling the conflation "seasons of the soul."  It''s not a rigid system, but we might say that spring is the season for comedy and autumn is elegy, leaving winter for tragedy and summer for satire or parody.  It''s clear that Malvolio is an autumnal character who has turned vernal.
'

text:
'This speech gives us the occasion to ask a question that has been on our minds throughout the play.  We know Malvolio to be a Christian, on the evidence that he''s frequently called a "Puritan" by the other characters and that he is tricked later on when Feste, in disguise as a priest, visits him in prison.  If this is true, why doesn''t Malvolio say, "Well, Christ, not I, is the doer of this," at the end of this speech?  What explains the general lack of Christian words in Twelfth Night - a play for a Christian holiday - compared with the glut of Roman gods, like Jove?

One theory has to do with a 1606 statute in England, with the purpose of "preventing and avoyding Abuse of the Holy Name of God in Stageplayes, Interludes, Maygames, Shewes, and such like."  Anyone who in performance should "jestingly or prophanely speake or use the Holy Name of God or of Christ Jesus, or of the Holy Ghoste or of the Trinitie" would be fined ten pounds.  If we are to believe that this statute explains the Roman gods in Twelfth Night, though, we have to assume that Shakespeare retouched his play after its first performance in 1601 to bring it up to code for 1606, and that the retouched version is the one that made it into the Folio in 1623.  This is a little hard to believe, though, because there''s no evidence of a rewrite of Twelfth Night, and the evidence for the Folio version having been printed from Shakespeare''s Foul Papers - that is, printed from a pre-1606 version - is very strong. 

Looking more closely at Twelfth Night, we also find God mentioned alongside Jove in a number of places.  Shakespeare uses Jove as a kind of substitute then, meant to give some of the timeless flavor of "Illyria" to the drama as well as to make Malvolio sound more grandiose.
'

'All of this is part of the traditional Elizabethan idea of possession, as discussed by Greenblatt in "Shakespeare and the Exorcists." 

If you''re interested in reading Harsnett''s "Declaration," click here to browse through the manuscript.  The chapter linked to is specifically about the behaviors of the "possessed."

There''s also a slight switch in meaning affected by Maria''s use of the word "bewitch''d," which is not quite the same as possessed, as evidenced by Fabian''s suggestion that they carry Malvolio''s urine to an expert in witchcraft - not something that you would do to a person suspected of possession by the devil.

text: 'Andrew''s cowardice is getting the better of him here, but he can''t stop the duel once he''s put it in motion.  Shakespeare''s setup, two reluctant antagonists caught in a duel of neither''s devising, gives the opportunity for many funny scenes, especially as Sir Andrew tries to casually wiggle his way out of the duel as if he simply doesn''t have the time for it ("Pox on''t), when really he is trembling with fear.  The nonchalance that Andrew must affect to save face is very funny when the terror underneath it comes up to the surface, as when "Pox on''t" becomes "Plague on''t."  '

text:
'There''s lots in here.  One notable line is the first officer''s "The time goes by," which could almost be the subtitle of the play.  We''ve already seen how often in Twelfth Night Shakespeare introduces the passage of time alongside youth, love, or beauty, so that the possibility of change or decay always colors our experience of the present.  Here, the officer''s casual dismissal of Antonio''s speech is interseting because it doesn''t accuse Antonio of lying: it simply suggests that kindnesses done in the past may not have bearing on the present.  It''s heartbreaking to see Antonio, whom we love because he loves Sebastian, treated cruelly by the officers in this scene.

Shakespeare then returns to the theme of disguise with Antony''s lines about "the beauteous evil," who are lovely to look at but in fact are merely the devil in disguise.  "The beauteous evil" recalls Viola''s lines to Olivia: "farewell, fair cruelty," in that they both evoke the misleading nature of external appearance when it masks an evil interior.  Antonio puts a spin on the metaphor here, though, by calling Viola an "empty trunk."  Evil and cruelty are emptiness, nothingness, often "o''er-flourish''d" by the devil.
'

'Sebastian''s lines remind us a little of Bottom''s, from Midsummer Night''s Dream.  When Bottom wakes in Titania''s bower, he rationalizes his fantastic turn of fortune by saying, "Reason and love keep little company together now-a-days."

'Feste accepts the role of Sir Topas, though, as he observes, he may not really fit the part.  Feste describes Sir Tobas a "tall" and "lean," which connote two qualities of good Puritan ministers: one, they are tall enough to look out over the pulpit at the congregation; and two, they are lean from many disciplined hours of study, which prohibit them from enjoying more worldly pleasures like good food and drink.

text:
'The clown is in his puffed-up, philosophizing mode, in which he makes up sources ("the hermit of Prague") and lets fly tangles of logic like, "what is ''that'' but ''that''."

It''s a little like Hamlet''s scene with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, in which each mine tries to outwit the others, except that here there is nothing competitive about it - it''s simply satire on Puritanism, Malvolio, learning, and seriousness.

substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.

quality that it is but a shadow''s shadow.
HAMLET

text:
'This is a very funny scene, but to appreciate it fully we have to understand what, exactly, Feste is making fun of. Who''s he imitating?

Feste begins by insisting, as Maria and Toby have already done, that Malvolio is possessed by a demon. Therefore, in the style of an exorcist, he addresses the demon directly: "Out, hyperbolical find!" He uses "hyperbolical" to mean "overwhelming" (Arden suggests a comparison to "vehement" - from vehe (out)+mens (mind) - as a closer analogue). Feste keeps this up until line 35, and his last reference to possession begins "Fie, thou dishonest Satan!"

All of the possession language takes us back to Harsnett, who, you''ll remember, was the English pamphleteer who produced, in 1603, "A declaration of egegious popish impostures." This pamphlet came too late for Shakespeare to have consulted it during the composition of Twelfth Night, but from it we can infer the kinds of exorcisms that were taking place around the turn of the 17th century. Harsnett documents public, arena-style exorcisms with the intention of debunking them, showing us that the Elizabethan public would have known exactly what Feste was spoofing in these lines.

Feste then moves on to insist that Malvolio is not possessed, but mad. When Malvolio says his house is dark, Feste tells him that it''s brightly lit, and so on, trying to convince Malvolio that "that" is not "that." There''s an element of metatheatricality to the bay-window line, too, if we read it metaphorically. In the metaphor, Malvolio would be the audience and Feste would be the theatrical enterprise as a whole. The nature of the theater is that the latter must forever try to convince the former that a dark room (the theater) is really a seacoast, or a castle, or a brightly lit room.

The clown then takes up the Pythagorean theory of metempsychosis, which is the doctrine of the transmigration of souls. Malvolio answers "incorrectly," saying that he condemns metempsychosis for tarnishing the sanctity of the human soul, and Feste rebukes him. Of course, had Malvolio answered any other question any other way, Feste would still have told him "fare thee well" - the point is to disorient Malvolio and frustrate him.

Sprinkled throughout these lines is a satire on Puritanism itself, which is a leitmotif of Sir Toby''s scenes throughout the play. Puritanism is a Protestant theology articulated by John Calvin and others and rising in England in the 16th and 17th centuries before spreading in New England from the pulpits of Jonathan Edwards and others. The values of Puritanism which Feste pokes fun at here are its "courtesy," its learnedness, and, generally speaking, what was perceived as its seriousness. Puritanism indeed valued study, charity, and discipline, but the charicature of Puritanism represented by Malvolio (and parodied by Feste as Sir Topas) is not accurate or comprehensive - it''s comic.

To get an idea of what Puritanism sounds like, click here to read the introduction to Calvin''s "Institutes," here to read the Wikipedia article on Puritanism, or here to read Jonathan Edwards''s sermon "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God." Marilynne Robinson''s "The Death of Adam" contains an essay called "Puritans and Prigs" which is a good introduction to Puritanism for those familiar with the stereotype of the starchy, pointy-hatted New England sourpuss (which is to say, all of us) but less familiar with the content of the theology itself.

text: 'The syntax of this speech is worth parsing. Orsino''s memory of fighting with Antonio at sea begins with a description of Antonio''s "baubling vessel," which was small ("shallow") and almost worthless ("unprizable").  Then he says that with that pathetic ship Antonio was, surprisingly, able to do quite a lot of damage to Orsino''s fleet, especially to his best ship (his "prize bottom").  Even by those who were most harmed by Antonio''s conduct in battle ("very envy" and "the tongue of loss"), seeing how effective a soldier he was, had to praise him.'

text: 'This is the second mention of witchcraft in Twelfth Night, the first being Olivia''s line 3.1.114: "After the last enchantment you did here."By Shakespeare''s time witchcraft was increasingly viewed skeptically by the elite.  In 1633, Charles himself sent his physician to exonerate a number of Lancashire women who were accused of practicing it!  So Shakespeare''s audience would not have believed in witchcraft as such, but they would have known exactly what it connoted.  Here, Sebastian probably uses witchcraft to mean "vague, possibly evil forces, things outside my understanding," not "the work of a woman who exchanged her soul for the power to do dark magic."  For more, see Dobson and Wells''s "The Oxford Companion to Shakespeare," "witchcraft."'

Lysander''s rhetoric here is reminiscent of John Donne and other metaphysical poets--he''s using wordplay to create analogies and metaphors to convince Hermia to share his bed.  If their hearts are made one by an oath, then he must lie near her so that he won''t lie to her.

text: 'The moon is THE major symbol in this play--in different places, it signifies chastity and promiscuity; constancy and change; cold sobriety and mercurial caprice.  Pay attention to the various associations of the moon.'

text: 'Theseus is comparing the old moon that hasn''t yet changed to an old woman continuing to live on money that, if she died, would be inherited by her young relative.  In these opening lines, Shakespeare calls attention to the struggle between the generations.'
quote: 'Like to a step-dame or a dowager   /  Long withering out a young man revenue.

text: 'The bow is another odd symbol in this play--sometimes it refers to Cupid''s bow, and sometimes to the bow of Diana (the virginal hunter-goddess).  This virginity/love contradiction is an interesting one, especially when we remember that this play was composed late in the reign of Elizabeth I (the Virgin Queen).  Elizabeth''s favorite method of international diplomacy was to hint at the possibility of marrying into whatever royal family she was hoping to appease--of course, had she actually done so, she would have lost a good deal of her domestic power and influence.  The political "spin" she put on her persona was that as her body was inviolable, so would the island of Britain be under her rule.  So both aspects of Elizabeth''s person--her marriageability and her lasting virginity--were crucial to the success of her reign, however contradictory they might be.'

text: 'Notice that Theseus here adds another option to the consequences as voiced by Egeus. Several of Shakespeare''s comedies (The Comedy of Errors, The Merchant of Venice, Measure for Measure) begin with some intractable legal problem that seems like it will derail the plot and lead it to tragedy. Think about what an effective plot device this is: not only does it provide a framework for the action (things have to unfold in such a way as to bring about an often lucky and unexpected conclusion), but it also sets up a contrast between the force of the law and what we might call the "moral sense" (or, in this play, the force of love).  This contrast often works best in Shakespeare''s "problem plays" or "dark comedies"--Measure for Measure, Troilus and Cressida, The Merchant of Venice, All''s Well that Ends Well--but it works well here too.'
quote: 'Either to die the death or to abjure   /  For ever the society of men.

text: 'This discussion over the comparative virtues of celibacy and marriage has a long history, and became (especially for John Milton) one of the touchstones of the later Protestant Reformation in England.  Two great sources for this discussion are Erasmus''s "Colloquium Proci et Puellae" (you can find this in English in Thomas Wilson''s Arte of Rhetorike, 1553), and Milton''s Tetrachordon (and his Doctrine and Discipline of Divorce).'

text: 'This is one of the best examples of a dramatic technique called stichomythia, which appears quite a bit in this play.  Stichomythia is when two characters, often in argument, alternate rapid lines (usually contradicting or partially repeating each other).  Here we have Hermia''s apostrophes (O cross, O spite, O hell) balanced by Lysander''s enumeration of the ways that love goes wrong.'

Puck has a life that predates Shakespeare.  Mischievous fairies were referred to as "puca" in Old English, and as "poke" or "pouke" as early as 1400.  The devil was also called The Pouk, or Robin Goodfellow, as early as 1530 by William Tyndale, the Protestant theologian. 

All the kinds of mischief alleged by the fairy are part of the Puck legend: he would do minor housework--butter churning, or "labour in the quern," for example--but if you fell out of favor with him, he would enchant the churn so the butter wouldn''t come together ("bootless make the breathless housewife churn").

Based on the proverb, "He that is born to be hanged will never be drowned." This is a partially veiled insult to the Boatswain. While Gonzalo believes that the Boatswain''s presence will prevent the ship from sinking, his belief does not express confidence in the Boatswain''s skill or ability. Instead, Gonzalo takes "great comfort" because the Boatswain seems to him a criminal, ungentlemanly man who is destined to be hung on land as punishment for breaking the law.

 Gonzalo is chiding the boatswain for his rudeness to noble Antonio, the Duke of Milan. The boatswain''s far inferior social standing normally requires his deference to Antonio, but here, in the middle of the storm, the boatswain ignores the social code entirely. When he ignores Gonzalo''s scolding in the next line as well, Gonzalo decides the boatswain is a scoundrel and destined to be hanged.

For the natural world, the Boatswain reminds Gonzalo, is indifferent to the socially constructed hierarchy that Gonzalo presses him to remember. ''King'' is just a name. It has no independent power.  ''Prospero'' means ''fortunate'' and ''prosperous.'' Keep this in mind as you read through the play. Was Shakespeare being sincere or ironic in selecting Prospero''s name? 

'
quote: 'PROSPERO

text:

In Shakespeare''s own production of the play in 1611, the role of Prospero was played by 44-year-old Richard Burbage, but from the eighteenth century until the mid-twentieth, Prospero was nearly always performed as a grey and wizened grandfather and played by a much older man. In the late twentieth century, the role began to be given to actors in their fourties who played Prospero as middle-aged. 

How does Prospero''s age affect the tone of the play? How does it affect his relationship with Miranda? Some critics have argued that the middle-aged Prospero harbors incestuous feelings for Miranda (feelings that were absent in the sexless old man of eighteenth century productions) and that this emotional current provides crucial motivation for his actions later in the play.

Prospero here employs anaphora (repetition of the same word at the beginning of successive sentences or clauses), a rhetorical device that is often used as a means of persuasion in speeches. The repeated word usually emphasizes a crucial element of the speaker''s argument. Here''s an example of anaphora in a speech by Winston Churchill. Notice that the repeated words express the support that his speech is intended to rally in the listeners (''we shall'' do A, B and C instead of ''we may'' or ''will we?''). 

"We shall go on to the end, we shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our Island, whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender."(Winston Churchill, speech to the House of Commons, June 4, 1940)

Prospero repeats ''thee'' to emphasize his whole-hearted devotion to Miranda as he prepares to reveal the secrets he has kept from her all these years.

The garment Prospero refers to is the magician''s cloak, the mantle of his art. He strips himself of his magical powers to speak to Miranda in his role as father, as ordinary man. It''s important to note that Prospero treats the two roles discreetly. His magical powers preclude him from performing his fatherly duties and vice versa, as he must shed his magic cloak in order to speak earnestly to his child. Note, too, that Prospero''s powers are not organic. They are, both literally and figuratively, a garment that he puts on that is external to his being.

[The altar] shall be visited of the Lord of hostes with thundre, and shaking, and a great noyse, a whirlwinde, and a tempest, and a flame of devouring fyre.

Jove, also known as Zeus, is the almighty Roman and Greek God who hurled lightening and thunderbolts down upon the earth to punish irreverent humans. The thunderbolt was the symbol of his supreme power. Later, in speaking of his own magical prowess, Prospero describes wielding the force of "Jove''s...own bolt". The description suggests that Prospero''s power is not only supernatural, but divine.

Ariel has thus far,appeared as wind or air, fire, and now water. His ability to fly and to become invisible associates him with the immaterial. We''ll soon meet Caliban, Prospero''s other servant, who represents the opposite extreme. Where Ariel is airy to the point of being invisible, Caliban is heavy, stooped, and bound in chains. He is associated with the earth and the flesh (his name is often thought to be an anagram of ''cannibal''). Prospero trusts him only with physical labor and menial tasks. Though Ariel and Caliban are both Prospero''s slaves, Caliban''s relationship with his master is far coarser, and while Ariel and Prospero often seem affectionate towards one another (Ariel once even speaks of ''love'' between them), Caliban and Prospero exchange nothing but verbal abuses.

quote: 'This   /  Is the third man that e''er I saw,

text:

In the marriage plot of traditional comedies, the woman''s father is often the obstacle between her and her beloved. (Think of Much Ado About Nothing, for example, in which Bianca is prevented from marrying by her father''s rules). Here, Shakespeare alters the model by making Prospero''s opposition feigned. He only pretends to prevent his daughter''s marriage. In fact, the entire romance between Miranda and Ferdinand is Prospero''s creation. There seems to be something illusory about it, something false, as if Ferdinand and Miranda were under a spell rather than actually falling in love. Unlike the love marriages that end most of Shakespeare''s comedies, the marriage of Miranda and Ferdinand is not attended by Venus, the goddess of romance. Love is conspicuously absent.

Stories about a man changing into an ass, or an ass suddenly given the power of speech, were more common in sixteenth-century England than you might think.  In the city of Chester, a play about Balaam and his talking ass was one of the most popular and long-lasting of the medieval religious plays.  The most famous story of a man being transformed into an ass was Apuleius''s "The Golden Ass," translated into English in 1566, in which a beautiful princess lavishes adoration on the ass.  Reginald Scot''s The discoverie of witchcraft (1584) relates the story of a sailor transformed into an ass by a witch.  Happening upon a church just as the consecration of the mass is about to take place, he “fell down in the churchyard upon the knees of his hinder legs and did lift his forefeet over his head as the priest doth hold the sacrament at the elevation.”  The townspeople, amazed at the sight of a praying ass, figured out what had happened, found the witch, and forced her to remove the spell.

Above all, Bottom was an ass before Puck transformed his head; an ass getting an ass''s head is not only hilarious and ironic, but reinforces Shakespeare''s mockery of theatrical literalism (the audience knows that  the Lion is not real before he says his name; they would understand that Snout is supposed to be a wall whether or not he had lime and roughcast about him).

Demetrius''s praise of Helena''s beauty is in the tradition of the blason, a poetic tradition in which a beloved''s body parts (eyes, skin, hair, lips, etc) are praised individually.  Shakespeare''s famous mock-blason is Sonnet 130: "My mistress'' eyes are nothing like the sun."

Later in this play, however, we see another parody of a blason when Thisbe laments Pyramus''s "lily lips" and "cherry nose."

Helena''s lament here has earned a fair amount of critical commentary for its use of romantic imagery to describe pre-sexual, same-sex friendship (compare her "two seeming bodies, but one heart" with Lysander''s earlier "one heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth").  Helena''s description of the pain of growing up and losing a close friend to love is, I think, extremely poignant, especially compared with the tripe that the other three lovers spout unceasingly.  Shakespeare had by this time written much exceptionally beautiful and touching love poetry, but this play gives us instead a kind of parody of it: lots of talk, but nothing that seems to have any "real" feeling behind it.  Helena''s speeches, however, and this one in particular, really convey the feeling of being young and in love, but rejected, scorned, mocked, and left behind.

It seems that Puck is speaking of the souls of suicides, who "willfully" exiled themselves from the light of heaven.  In the Elizabethan period, suicides were excluded from consecrated ground and were buried instead at crossroads--those that drown themselves in "floods" were often not recovered (Ophelia to the contrary).

text:

Oberon is distinguishing between malevolent spirits and friendly ones, a distinction that Shakespeare might have seen in Edmund Spenser''s "Shepheardes Calender" (June).

Apart from the first scene, the play thus far has been spoken in blank verse (unrhymed metered verse). Sebastian and Antonio speak in prose. Shakespeare usually reserves prose for clownish or vulgar characters, distinguishing their speech from the noble characters'' verse. But Sebastian and Antonio are not of "common" blood: Sebastian is prince and Antonio is the duke of Milan. Why do you think Shakespeare writes their speech in prose?

Perhaps it is because of what they are saying. Antonio and Sebastian''s sarcasm is so incongruous with King Alonso''s grief and so ruthlessly snide that one can understand Shakespeare''s decision to separate it from the blank verse of Gonzalo''s opening speech. John Bell was so disturbed by Antonio and Sebastian''s insensitivity that he cut these lines from his 1773 edition of the play entirely, claiming that they were "not worth either utterance or perusal."  

Bell''s approach seems a bit extreme. It''s more useful, I think, to consider why Shakespeare might have chosen to written Antonio and Sebastian''s snide lines in the first place, and why he chose to insert them at this point in the play. Intertwining incompatible emotions in dialogue is something Shakespeare does frequently. He often injects humor or bawdiness into otherwise solemn circumstances. The gravedigger''s scene in Hamlet provides a classic example.

Sebastian blames Alonso for Ferdinand''s death. Ferdinand would never have drowned had Alonso not married his daughter to an African prince, forcing everyone to sail across the sea to attend her wedding. If the wedding had been in Europe, they could have traveled by land.

Antonio and Sebastian subvert every Adrian makes to idealize the island. Here, they play on Adrian''s description of the island''s temperance, pretending Temperance is a woman who is easy to excite sexually (''delicate'') and sneaky (''subtle'').

OED: to omit, leave out of count, except. 

Sebastian is suggesting that Alonso''s daughter Claribel is only the "rarest" (most beautiful) queen of Carthage if they don''t count Dido. He is insulting Claribel by claiming that Dido was more beautiful, that Dido was in fact "the rarest that e''er came there".

Gonzalo''s speech paraphrases a passage from Montaigne''s praising description of Native American culture in Brazil in his essay, "Of the Caniballes":

It is a nation...that hath no kinde of traffike, no knowledge of Letters, no intelligence of numbers, no name of magistrate, nor of politike superioritie; no use of service, of riches, or of poverty; no contracts, no successions, no dividences, no occupation but idle; no respect of kinred, but common, no apparrell but naturall, no manuring of lands, no use of wine, corne, or mettle. The very words that import lying, falshood, treason, dissimulation, covetousness, envie, detraction, and pardon, were never heard of amongst them.

quote: 'and surely  /  It is a sleepy language and thou speak''st  /  Out of thy sleep.

text:
'

Notice how Antonio keeps on interjecting his speech with the vocative ''O'' of appeal. This is the fourth time it''s appeared in his conversation with Sebastian. Why?

Well, for one thing, it''s an easy, conspicuous way to shift the register of one''s speech. For much of the conversation, Sebastian remains stubbornly jokey and uncomprehending. Only by repeatedly asserting his seriousness does Antonio manage to convey his grave intentions.

 Why is Antonio inveigling his way into Sebastian''s affairs? Well, here''s our answer. As we''ve seen in this scene, Antonio is thoroughly capable of manipulating Sebastian. Were Sebastian on the throne, Antonio could probably manipulate Sebastian into doing anything he wanted.

 ''And how does your happiness (at understanding what I''ve said) apply to your own fortune?''

Notice Antonio''s method of persuasion. He prefers to suggest through hint and question rather than stating outright, thus allowing Sebastian to believe he has come upon the plan himself. Antonio only lays out his intentions in full once Sebastian is completely on board.

Trinculo treats Caliban as a valuable curio, a monster that one could make a fortune on. Even those who will not give a cent to a lame beggar will pay money to see a dead Indian, says Trinculo. In Europe at this time, people of other ethnicities were displayed as sideshow freaks, and words like savage (spelled ''salvage'' at the time) and monster were not fully distinguished from proper names like Indian and African. 

Though Trinculo is obviously untroubled by the prospect of turning Caliban into a carnival exhibit, his words present the problematic nature of the plan. ''Make a man'', the phrase Trinculo repeats twice, has a double meaning. Trinculo intends it to mean ''make a man''s fortune'' but it can also be understood differently. To ''make a man'' can mean to ''pass for human''. Though the question of Caliban''s humanity is easily dismissed by Trinculo and by the play''s other characters, it has provoked extensive scholarly and critical discussion among the play''s viewers.

This conversation about the cries of the hounds seems to have nothing to do with the action of the scene, but the idea of "musical confusion" or "musical discord" actually touches on an important aesthetic point.  The doctrine of Concordia discors, or harmony in discord, is the idea that numerous conflicts in the natural world (like the conflicts in nature that Titania attributes to her quarrel with Oberon) can be held together by the force of love.  Empedocles and Pythagoras are held to be the progenitors of this idea.

Caliban thinks Stephano is the man in the moon. 

Note from the Arden Shakespeare:

The man in the moon was accompanied by his dog and his thorn bush, because, according to folk legend, he had disobeyed the Sabbath regulations by gathering firewood on a Sunday; thereupon, the man, still carrying the brush he had gathered, and his dog were banished to the moon. 

The moon, thorn bush and dog trio also appear in Midsummer Night''s Dream. I''ve linked the line below.

As one kisses the Bible to show one''s devotion to God or as a sign of one''s honesty before taking an oath, so does Stephano jokingly signal Trinculo to ''pay devotion'' to the bottle of wine and, implicitly, to Stephano, that bottle''s owner. Remember Caliban has sincerely given his oath of loyalty to Stephano and his wine a few lines earlier ("I''ll swear upon that bottle to be they true subject"). Here, Stephano and Trinculo repeat that scene half-seriously. While Trinculo is not seriously swearing to be Stephano''s subject he is, whether he is aware or not, dependent upon the bottle.

Caliban''s unabashed worship of Stephano (and Stephano''s wine) quickly inflates Stephano''s ego and soon Stephano will be strutting about, proclaiming himself King of the island. 

In the last scene, we saw Antonio convince Sebastian that Sebastian was the rightful King of Naples. 

How is Caliban''s effect on Stephano like or unlike Antonio''s upon Sebastian? What does Caliban stand to gain from Stephano''s empowerment? 

'
quote: 'I''ll swear upon that bottle to be thy true subject;  /  for the liquor is not earthly.  /

text:
'

This scene and the previous scene are both played out by clownish characters who crown one of their own as king. Despite the clownishness of the characters, they become increasingly serious as their scenes proceed. Antonio and Sebastian, who were punning and joking at the beginning of the last scene were preparing to commit regicide by scene''s end. Stephano and Trinculo watch Caliban enslave himself willingly to Stephano and realize that they can manipulate Caliban as long as they possess wine. 

Why does Shakespeare choose to pair these scenes? How do the two scenes correspond? How do they compare to Prospero''s attempt to rise to power that forms the arch-narrative of the play?

quote: 'patched

text:

This is a parody of  Paul''s First Letter to the Corinthians: "Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him" (2:9).  Why does Shakespeare use this passage?  The humor comes from Bottom''s incorrigible tendency towards malapropisms, but why bring in the Bible at all?  If the world (or at least the dream-world, which seems difficult to fully separate off) is not really accessible to sense or reason, as Bottom suggests, then what''s the role of the religious text, or of faith?  Alternately, what does it mean for a Protestant country when "average" people like Bottom misinterpret the Bible?

Bottom''s excitement to tell his story and inability to really convey what happened make this funny, but also poignant, because while the dream-world is the source of love and magic and creativity in this play, it is so hard to convey in ordinary language.
