quote: 'if I tell you, I am no true Athenian. I   /  will tell you every thing,

text:
'

This speech about the imagination is worth thinking about very carefully.  He first compares the lover and the madman, who are both full of "shaping fantasies," imagining things that are not really there, things beyond reason.  The poet, according to Theseus, is able to capture these fleeting "forms of things unknown" from the imagination and give them, in a very famous phrase, "a local habitation and a name."  That is, I think, the poet takes things that reason cannot apprehend, and makes them subject to reason.

How close are love, insanity, and poetic imagination in this play?  Does this speech give us any insight into how Shakespeare might have conceived of his own craft, or is this merely a parodic statement?  Do we really, as audience, suppose a bush to be a bear (or suppose Snug to be a lion), or is there more involved in the workings of the imagination?

This speech has, understandably, garnered its fair share of critical attention.  Some of the best work includes Louis Montrose''s book The Purpose of Playing: Shakespeare and the Cultural Politics of the Elizabethan Theatre (especially Part Two, "The Shaping Fantasies of A Midsummer Night''s Dream").  For an older but still classic article, see R. W. Dent''s "Imagination in A Midsummer Night''s Dream" in Shakespeare Quarterly (15.2, Spring 1964, available through JSTOR through your university''s portal, or on the shelf in the library).

'
quote: 'More strange than true: I never may believe   /  These antique fables, nor these fairy toys.   /  Lovers and madmen have such seething brains,   /  Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend   /  More than cool reason ever comprehends.   /  The lunatic, the lover and the poet   /  Are of imagination all compact:   /  One sees more devils than vast hell can hold,   /  That is, the madman: the lover, all as frantic,   /  Sees Helen''s beauty in a brow of Egypt:   /  The poet''s eye, in fine frenzy rolling,   /  Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven;   /  And as imagination bodies forth   /  The forms of things unknown, the poet''s pen   /  Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing   /  A local habitation and a name.   /  Such tricks hath strong imagination,   /  That if it would but apprehend some joy,   /  It comprehends some bringer of that joy;   /  Or in the night, imagining some fear,   /  How easy is a bush supposed a bear!

text:
'

But the whole story of the night, especially since the minds of all four of them were "transfigured" at the same time, suggests that something more is going on than just the workings of the imagination.

'
quote: 'But all the story of the night told over,   /  And all their minds transfigured so together,   /  More witnesseth than fancy''s images   /  And grows to something of great constancy;

text:
'

Act 5 only has one scene, and an odd one at that.  All the action, all the loose ends are tied up at the end of Act 4.  Act 5 is essentially an epilogue containing the play-within-a-play that we''ve been promised.  Yet this is the most entertaining part of the play, and essentially works in the same way (with respect to the play) as "Pyramus and Thisbe" does to the wedding--as a final masque.

"This fellow doesn''t pay much attention to punctuation."  Mis-punctuation was an old joke by this point: Nicholas Udall used it in a very early play called Ralph Roister-Doister (1553), where a love letter is misread (through mischievious mispunctuation) as an insult.

If you directed this play, where on the stage would you put the noble "audience" (or the peanut gallery!), and how would you want them to deliver their comments?  Would you have the mechanicals respond to them, and how?  Would they be flattered, or annoyed?  What might these interjections say about how Shakespeare would or wouldn''t like his audience to respond to his play?

A good moral, my lord: it is not   /  enough to speak, but to speak true.   /  HIPPOLYTA Indeed he hath played on his prologue like a child   /  on a recorder; a sound, but not in government.   /  THESEUS His speech, was like a tangled chain; nothing   /  impaired, but all disordered. Who is next?

Although there is no record of how this was actually staged (and the stage direction "Wall stretches out his fingers" is a second Folio addition), Professor Gordon Teskey offers an ingenious and tempting explanation.  Since Snout is holding chunks of lime, roughcast, and stone, presumably his hands are full and can''t hold up his fingers.  Teskey suggests that Snout spreads his legs to form a chink, thus adding some dirty humor to "cursed be thy stones" (ie, thy testicles) and "I kiss the wall''s hole, not your lips at all" (ie, I kiss Wall''s anus).

Physical exercise may be difficult but it is also pleasurable. Manual labor, as base as it may be, can be conducted with a noble character and can produce worthy results.

The log will excrete resin when it burns.

Miranda''s personification of a wooden log echoes her father''s power. What appear to other characters to be natural reactions are in fact the products of Prospero''s deliberate effort and are under his control. Think of Miranda''s sudden drowsiness and sleep in 1.2 or of Ariel waking up Gonzalo and Alonso in 2.1. Prospero''s accountability for what is normally the work of unconscious and unaccountable natural forces is best exemplified in the opening scene by his creation of the storm.

Infected with love, Prospero means. ''Worm'' is a term of endearment but its appearance here also makes use of the worm''s reputation as a disease vector. The connotations of worm and infection also extend to the dynamics of the scene as a whole. Miranda is the vector for the infection of Prospero''s control, for it is through her that he accesses and manipulates Ferdinand. By falling in love with Miranda Ferdinand has fallen into Prospero''s trap.

Coriolanus has two central conflicts: that between the plebeian citizens of Rome (and those who defend them) and its patrician rulers; and the personal conflict of Caius Martius himself.  As you read this play for the first time, it will be helpful to consult a primer on Roman society, especially if this is your first exposure to writing about the classical world.  Shakespeare''s source for this play (and others) is Plutarch''s Lives of the Noble Greeks and Romans (often called "Parallel Lives"), which was was translated by Sir Thomas North in 1579.  Any basic textbook (or this page) will help you understand the progression of Roman society from the early republic through the empire and its eventual decline and fall.  Rome had an extremely hierarchical society, and questions about the functionality of this hierarchy form the basis of the discussion Menenius has with the citizens over the "fable of the belly;" some understanding of the structure of the hierarchy will help you if you continue in your studies of Rome, though Shakespeare''s exposition of it is certainly understandable enough on its own.

Menenius attributes the distress of the people to the famine, which he implies is a natural disaster and nobody''s fault.  Plutarch ascribes the famine to a neglect of agriculture in wartime, and reports that some thought it was "practiced and procured" by the nobility.  The issue of how much responsibility political leaders bear when the poor are disproportionately affected by natural disaster is, of course, one that extends to our own time.

This is the first of the play''s many (figurative!) references to cannibalism.  "Eating" here is a transitive action: the wars "eat" the plebeians because the armies draft them into bonded service and use them as fodder on the front lines; the patricians "eat" them by destroying the crops that they would eat.  The "love," then, is the love that the wolf bears the lamb, or the love that I bear chocolate ice cream--no comfort for the plebeians, the lamb, or the ice cream.  Stanley Cavell''s excellent article, "Coriolanus and the Interpretations of Politics: Who Does the Wolf Love?" in his book Disowning Knowledge, is the central critical work on this idea.

The fable of the belly has a few different origins: it appears in Plutarch, but versions of it appear in countless ancient and medieval texts, including the Bible (see Romans 12 and First Corinthians 12).  One Shakespearean critic, Leonard Barkan, claims that the the particular incarnation found in Coriolanus originates in Livy’s History of Rome, translated into English in 1600, though Shakespeare’s audiences would also have been familiar with a version purported to have been told to John of Salisbury by Pope Hadrian IV and eventually published in William Camden’s Remaines Concerning Britaine in 1605 as one “not unlike that of Menenius Agrippa in the Roman History.”

The fable of the belly belongs to a particular genre of political rhetoric: the idea of the "body politic."  The king (or ruler) is the head of the body, and other social institutions form the limbs or members, which work together to create one healthy body.  This allegory goes as far back as Livy, but was prominent in Shakespeare''s time (Edward Forset''s 1606 Comparative Discourse of the Bodies Natural and Politique is one example).

Shakespeare himself was fascinated by the allegory of the body politic, and used it to great effect in Richard II.  The intellectual historian Ernst Kantorowicz wrote a notable book on this subject: The King''s Two Bodies (1957).

The use of this word shows Menenius''s cruel humor.  The citizens to whom he is speaking are starving for want of grain; Menenius tells them to "digest" his words and feed on his knowledge, when they need the grain being hoarded by the wealthy.  Menenius is a brilliant rhetorician: he has taken their literal starvation and turned it into a figurative hunger for understanding, which he has "fed" with his speech about the belly.  With this word "digest," though, he seems to throw his rhetorical skill in their faces.  Digesting his words will not, after all, fill the bellies of the citizens, but it will fuel their anger.

The prospect of diverting civil insurrection into foreign wars was a familiar one to Shakespeare: he used it in 2 Henry IV and in 2 Henry VI.  Marcius again plays figuratively with corn imagery (must is a mold that affects corn that sits around storehouses too long, and here represents the idle plebeians).

A short civics lesson on the Roman republic, whose constitution of checks and balances of power is one of the ancestors of the American system: The consuls were the highest ranking magistrates, but their powers were constitutional in nature.  They are given advice (almost always followed) by the senate, and their powers could be checked by the plebeian tribunes.  The tribunes represent the plebeians, or the people, and as such, they were sacrosanct (it was a capital crime to harm a tribune).

Volumnia is an iron-willed battleaxe descended, literarily speaking, from the likes of Lady Macbeth and Goneril.  Unlike these two women, she''s not what we would call evil; she does, however, recast all human feelings toward her son in terms of honor.  Psychoanalytic critics argue that Marcius''s petulance and arrogance stem from Volumnia''s unwavering control of her son; I think a more productive area for study would be the relation among the three women in the play.  How should we read Virgilia? How Valeria?  What is the role of "family values" in this political play?

quote: 'if my son were my husband, I  /      should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he  /      won honour than in the embracements of his bed where  /      he would show most love.

text:

The period before this clause is a typo.  Volumnia argues here that a man without renown is but a picture.  Hamlet makes a similar argument about judgment ("judgment, without the which we are pictures...").  The vast difference between these two uses of the same image should make you extremely wary of any quotation of Shakespeare that begins, "Shakespeare said that..."  or "Shakespeare thought that..."  If Shakespeare thought that love of honor animates the soul, or that judgment does, this appears nowhere in his plays: what we have is what Volumnia thinks, and what Hamlet thinks.

While the meaning of this phrase is simply that heroism in war, and its bloody consequences, is just as beautiful as a nursing mother, the visual image of this is so close to Lady Macbeth''s vivid description of infanticide that it''s extremely unsettling: "I have given suck, and know how tender ''tis to love the babe that milks me: I would, while it was smiling in my face, have plucked my nipple from his boneless gums, and dash''d the brains out, had I so sworn as you have done to this."  The juxtaposition of the image of a nursing mother and the image of a bleeding head is monstrous enough to give us pause: should we agree with Volumnia? Or does the violence of her image itself disprove her point?

Cominius here defines what it means to be a Roman as a negation of extremes.  In his Nichomachean Ethics, Aristotle describes virtue as a temperate mean between two less desirable states: bravery, in Aristotle''s and Cominius''s example, falls between cowardice and rashness.  Does the rest of the play sustain Cominius''s stance on virtue?  Does Caius Marcius share this temperate perspective?

This is either a brilliant pun or a terrible one, depending on your taste.  In the Metamorphoses, Ovid wrote of Marsyas, a satyr who challenged Apollo to a music contest and lost.  As punishment, the god had the satyr flayed alive, and nailed his hide to a pine tree.  The tears of Marsyas''s brothers and sisters, as they wept in mourning, became the river Marsyas in Phrygia.

If any Shakespeare play were to be described as homoerotic, this would be the one.  A more interesting explanation of these lines is that domestic pleasure is worth less to Marcius than honor in battle and the companionship of his fellow soldiers.  Remember, he is Volumnia''s son: replace her discussion of child-rearing in relation to warfare with his views on the marital bed, and you see how closely the two mirror one another in their disdain for domesticity.

In Henry V, Shakespeare wrote such an inspirational piece of military rhetoric that a recording of Sir Lawrence Olivier reciting it was played on the BBC nearly every evening in 1941.  Marcius''s speech seems to have a similar inspirational effect, yet the speech itself cannot compare to Henry''s nationalist enthusiasm.  Marcius, of course, is a man of action rather than words: why, then, do his bland words have such an inspirational effect?

Often in Shakespeare, two servants, commoners, or soldiers will open a scene, providing a new perspective on the action.  (Sometimes, as in King Lear, they''ll close a scene, commenting on what just happened).

In this case, the two officers give some of the most striking speeches of realpolitik in all of Shakespeare.  Is there a connection between politics and morality?  Between governing and loving?

text:

Coriolanus is, above all, a man of action.  Action, in this play, is set both beside and against "voice," a central metonymy that appears in this scene and throughout the play.  The citizens are "voices," a characterization that refers both to their political ability to vote and their propensity towards rumor and reputation as means of judgment.  Coriolanus, on the other hand, is an awkward and reluctant speaker for whom politics and action are irrevocably separate.

This fits with what we''ve just heard from the Second Officer, who contrasts the "great men that have flattered the people" with Coriolanus, who planted "his honours in their eyes and his actions in their hearts" without the use of political rhetoric.

'
quote: 'I had rather have my wounds to heal again  /      Than hear say how I got them.  /

text:
'

That is, to have unnatural (because rhetoricized) speeches made about his deeds, which are "nothings" because they are, to him, merely the natural duties of a soldier.

'
quote: 'monster''d.  /

text:
'

The eloquent Cominius is the opposite of Coriolanus.  He participates here in one of the most common rhetorical strategies: the humility topos (a form of occupatio, or understatement).  "I couldn''t possibly tell you about X" is the formula of this: Chaucer''s epic love poem "Troilus and Criseyde" is the founding example in English literature, when the narrator tells the reader that he really knows nothing at all about love. 

I think it''s important to pause when we see Shakespeare using cliches like this one, which had long been a cliche even when he was writing.  To me, Cominius''s use of the humility topos here alerts the audience to the fact of his rhetoric (and how empty political rhetoric usually is), aligning us, however subtly, with Coriolanus.

'

His pupil age  /      Man-enter''d thus, he waxed like a sea,  /      And in the brunt of seventeen battles since  /      He lurch''d all swords of the garland. For this last,  /      Before and in Corioli, let me say,  /      I cannot speak him home: he stopp''d the fliers;  /      And by his rare example made the coward  /      Turn terror into sport: as weeds before  /      A vessel under sail, so men obey''d  /      And fell below his stem: his sword, death''s stamp,  /      Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot  /      He was a thing of blood, whose every motion  /      Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter''d  /      The mortal gate of the city, which he painted  /      With shunless destiny; aidless came off,  /      And with a sudden reinforcement struck  /      Corioli like a planet: now all''s his:  /      When, by and by, the din of war gan pierce  /      His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit  /      Re-quicken''d what in flesh was fatigate,  /      And to the battle came he; where he did  /      Run reeking o''er the lives of men, as if  /      ''Twere a perpetual spoil: and till we call''d  /      Both field and city ours, he never stood  /      To ease his breast with panting.  /

text:

The parallel between Roman and Christian asceticism would resonate with the audience of the play, who would remember Philippians 3:7: "But whatever was to my profit I now consider loss for the sake of Christ. What is more, I consider everything a loss compared to the surpassing greatness of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord, for whose sake I have lost all things. I consider them rubbish."

Be sensitive to the analogies between Coriolanus and Christ.  Both are wounded bodily for the sake of their people, and the display of these wounds is controversial.  Both are dismissive of earthly remuneration, with the redemptive deed being its own reward.  Of course, Coriolanus is a jerk: this is what makes the analogy so interesting and the play so rich.

'
quote: 'And look''d upon things precious as they were  /      The common muck of the world: he covets less  /      Than misery itself would give; rewards  /      His deeds with doing them, and is content  /      To spend the time to end it.  /

text:

Coriolanus here recognizes, as Volumnia does later, that politics is a fiction, a stage play, and he refuses to participate in it.  He argues that language, especially this sort of theatrical language, is deceptive and dishonorable.  Marjorie Garber writes that Coriolanus "has not yet made his peace with language, and as always in Shakespeare language is the index of humanity."  War is his language, and wounds are his words.

'

This striking image is one that Shakespeare particularly liked: he uses it twice in Julius Caesar ("there were an Antony would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue in every wound of Caesar that should move the stones of Rome to rise and mutiny," and also "thy wounds...which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips").  Lady Anne, in Richard III, also speaks of her dead father-in-law Henry''s wounds as "open[ing] their congealed mouths."

I love this line.  There really does seem to be a sense in which Coriolanus feels that Rome would be better off without the plebeians.  Sicinius betrays here, however, his fundmental misunderstanding of Coriolanus''s view of the nature of nobility: Coriolanus would not want to be every man.  Each social class has their own inherent responsibilities, and a noble man such as Coriolanus would never want to be the plebeians.

text:

Like Edgar in King Lear, Coriolanus strips himself of everything he once had: his title, his name, his clothes; and finds himself unrecognizable without them.  This is a slightly odd moment, though, that bears closer examination: why, when Coriolanus speaks of Aufidius as a long-lost twin brother, is Aufidius unable to recognize him?  Disguise and recognition, of course, are important in many of Shakespeare''s plays (Cymbeline and The Winter''s Tale were written around the same time as Coriolanus--the earlier disguise plays were mostly comedies, rather than romances).  What is this delayed recognition scene doing here?

text:

One of the major motifs of this play is naming: Caius Marcius quickly gains the cognomen "Coriolanus" for defeating Corioles (one of the only two gifts, along with a horse, that he accepts from Cominius).  When he first comes to Aufidius, he unveils himself in the hopes that naming will not be necessary, but remains unrecognizable.  Leaving Rome, his mother, his wife, and his children, he obliterates his proper names, and retains only the cognomen achieved in battle, Coriolanus ("Only that name remains").

Now Coriolanus is a man without a name, without an identity, rejecting even the name "Coriolanus"--he can''t in all good conscience, after all, take the side of the Volscians while using the name he gained from burning their city.  He will take a new name, he says to Cominius, when he conquers Rome--but what kind of name could be given to the Roman conqueror of Rome?

'

Remember the "musty superfluity" of Act I Scene 1 (ie, the people): now Coriolanus refuses to distinguish between that "musty chaff" and the "poor grain or two" that are his friends and supporters.

As Marjorie Garber notes, this makes Coriolanus a kind of grim reaper--just as the reaper''s scythe levels all the grain in a field, so does Death level all the living, without distinguishing between good and evil.

Menenius bases his rhetoric here on emotional ties of kinship and love, which are unlikely (as he doesn''t yet understand) to succeed with Coriolanus, who has abdicated what shred of these he once had upon his exile from Rome. 

The play is examining here the question of military identity.  The traditional Roman view, as expressed by Volumnia, is that a soldier must place his larger purpose (ie, service of the state) ahead of any personal commitments.  Yet it is precisely these commitments that Cominius and Menenius are exploiting to try to get Coriolanus to return to Rome.

Forgetfulness shall put an end to our intimacy; pity will not factor into our relationship.

'
quote: 'That we have been familiar,  /      Ingrate forgetfulness shall poison, rather  /      Than pity note how much.

text:
'

This, after all, is the Roman military fantasy: that the strongest bonds (indeed, the only bonds that should count) are those forged on the battlefield between soldiers, those that stem from shared honor, bravery, and strength.  If this were the case, then man would be, as Coriolanus longs to be, "author of himself" and bound to nothing outside his own choosing.  The bonds of nature--of filial duty, marital love, and parental responsibility--not only distract from the duties of the soldier to his state, but soften that soldier and make him less than what he ought to be.

Yet even as the play constructs this fantasy, it shows us its holes and frayed edges.  Even Coriolanus "melts" to see his family, and the pain of Menenius as he''s being mocked by Aufidius''s watchmen makes us think that Coriolanus does indeed owe him some loyalty, not as a Roman, but as a friend.

Volumnia''s parallel here is between Rome as "womb" of its citizens and her own maternal body.  This is a mutation of the body politic--rather than the individual body as a metaphor for the state, the state is a metaphorical extension of the womb.  There is nothing political about this: the state, in this conception, is entirely personal.

Volumnia is savvy enough to draw on a completely different set of rhetorical weapons to convince Coriolanus than Menenius does.  She phrases her plea in terms of honor, and she reiterates his obsession with his name.  For the name Coriolanus won in warfare to be "dogg''d with curses" and for history to remember the great warrior as a destroyer are the worst threats to his identity.

Speak to me, son:  /      Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour,  /      To imitate the graces of the gods;  /      To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o'' the air,  /      And yet to charge thy sulphur with a bolt  /      That should but rive an oak.

This is one of the most equivocal and unsettling endings in all of Shakespeare.  What is the moral of this story?  What should we take from this murder?  Is this an optimistic ending, or a pessimistic one--has Aufidius delivered Rome from tyranny, or has he inaugurated a new age of political instability?

Though in this city he  /      Hath widow''d and unchilded many a one,  /      Which to this hour bewail the injury,  /      Yet he shall have a noble memory. Assist.

Behind the young lovers'' gushing and swooning lies Prospero''s blunt pragmatism. To marry Miranda to Ferdinand is to ''breed'' her with royalty and to ensure the empowerment of her (and Prospero''s) line, the object of his blessing. He is not calling the heavens to rain grace upon his daughter and her lover, after all, but upon "that which breeds between ''em." 

Of course, we could construe "that which breeds between ''em" less literally and understand it to be love. But that reading is put into question by Venus'' strange absence during the marriage blessing. Only Ceres, the goddess of fertility, is present there.

A meloncholy glimpse of Prospero''s reality. Prospero''s power over the other characters on the island comes at an emotional cost to him. Not having heard Ariel''s reprimand, Gonzalo assumes that Alonso''s anguish is a naturally delayed expression of guilt that works on men like a slow-killing poison. He believes Alonso''s sudden exclamation and upset to be a purely internal affair, provoked and reacted to by elements of Alonso''s consciousness. The great and terrible symphony that Alonso hears pulsing through the natural world is, Gonzalo assumes, only a figment of the king''s imagination and confined to Alonso''s individual experience. How is Shakespeare playing with notions of conscience here? Is conscience an interior or an exterior force? How far does it extend beyond the self?

Alonso''s dramatization of his own guilt and anthropomorphizing of the natural world presents a breach of the boundary between an individual''s interiority and the exterior world that is corrected by Gonzalo''s failure to hear the voices Alonso claims ring out from the natural elements. Of course, while it would normally be easy to categorize those voices as the extroversion of Alonso''s emotions, in this case, the matter is complicated by Ariel. How does Ariel fit in between mind and world? How does he blur the boundary?

quote: 'Where the bee sucks. there suck I:  /  In a cowslip''s bell I lie;  /  There I couch when owls do cry.  /  On the bat''s back I do fly  /  After summer merrily.  /  Merrily, merrily shall I live now  /  Under the blossom that hangs on the bough.  /

This is one of several little plays-within-a-play that Prospero orchestrates, although we could perhaps call the whole play Prospero''s tempest within Shakespeare''s Tempest, considering the degree to which all the characters'' actions from the first scene are controlled by him. Like the Mousetrap in Hamlet, to which I''ve included a link below, this play is devised by Prospero as a means of exposing guilt, specifically the guilt of an impostor who holds a position illegitimately and by deceptive means. As Claudio usurped old King Hamlet, so has Antonio usurped Prospero. Yet in both Hamlet and the Tempest, the notion that a staged play should be the means to justice and truth proves troubling. Here, Prospero presents Ariel and his attendants as the ministers of destiny (of Destiny, as Ariel says, personifying it) and thereby shields and aggrandizes the true force behind those spirits: Prospero''s own grievances and plots, a tangle of desires just as individual (and, in many ways, as deceptive and cunning) as those he condemns in Antonio.

 A tricky passage. Here''s the gist of it: 

Ariel tells Alonso that the powers punishing Alonso (Ariel named them a few lines up: "the powers, delaying not forgetting...") have deprived him of his son and have instructed Ariel to announce Alonso''s slow-unfolding destruction on earth which will be more painful and enduring than any quick death would be. On this deserted island, Ariel says, there is no alternative to or defense against the powers'' wrath that will otherwise punish Alonso and his compatriots but for sorrow and a life free of sin. 

'
quote: 'Thee of thy son, Alonso,  /  They have bereft; and do pronounce by me:  /  Lingering perdition, worse than any death  /  Can be at once, shall step by step attend  /  You and your ways; whose wraths to guard you from--  /  Which here, in this most desolate isle, else falls  /  Upon your heads--is nothing but heart-sorrow  /  And a clear life ensuing.  /

text:
'

A ''projection'' was an alchemical experiment and the phrase ''gather to a head'' (meaning ''come to a conclusion'') likely derives from a description of water coming to a boil. The use of the phrase in conjunction with his reference to his ''project'' casts Prospero in the role of alchemist. The alchemical process is perhaps a relevant metaphor for Prospero''s plot. Historically, alchemy was practiced both as a science and a philosophy and was devoted both to changing ordinary metals into gold and to achieving immortality. The parallels between the goals of alchemy and Prospero''s own efforts exist both before and during the events of the play, both in Prospero''s control over the island and his daughter before the tempest and in the plot unfolding now.

The very structure of the play seems complicit in Prospero''s masquerade as personified Destiny. First time readers or viewers of the play will assume that the storm is natural and caused by the mindless, unsympathetic forces that determine natural weather patterns. Going into the play with this assumption makes the revelation of Prospero''s powers in scene ii all the more impressive for being unexpected. 

 

'
quote: 'On a ship at sea, a tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard.

text:
'

The boatswain intends this advice sarcastically, reiterating the cynicism expressed in his earlier line, "what cares these roarers for the name of king?" The boatswain''s position seems well-founded. Gonzalo''s futile protestations and appeals to the abstractions of royal authority and Fate do nothing to aid the situation. Their only hope lies in the boatswain and ship crew''s concrete, practical knowledge. While this kind of knowledge is ordinarily judged to be inferior in comparison to the lofty authority represented by Gonzalo, it is, in the end, the heartiest and most enduring knowledge, and the only authority that stands a chance against nature. 

The boatswain''s character seems to exist primarily to drive home this point. Yet while his feisty wit carries the play''s opening, he disappears altogether after this first scene, appearing only once much later on for an inconsequential line or two. The worldview he represents likewise dissolves. His disdain for the power of the human mind and his disregard for abstract authority seem robust and correct here, especially in comparison to Gonzalo''s helplessness, but the convictions from which they derive are blurred as soon as this scene concludes. The question of man''s authority in relation to nature and to other men is one of the play''s preoccupations and is important to keep in mind as the play proceeds. The extent of man''s authority as the boatswain knows it is drastically altered by Prospero. So, too, does the value placed on social hierarchy shift. While the boatswain ridicules royal authority and its attendant conventions, you''ll see that much of the rest of the play and even, in fact, this very scene, is driven by a desire for the very ''hollow'' authority that the boatswain here dismisses. 

'
quote: 'You are a   /  counsellor; if you can command these elements to   /  silence, and work the peace of the present, we will   /  not hand a rope more; use your authority:

text:
'

We''ll be encountering quite a lot of personification with regards to Fate and Destiny. It''s useful to think about the situation that frames the personification in each instance it appears. What causes the character to resort to personified Fate or Destiny? Is his/her appeal sincere?

Here we see Gonzalo call upon ''good Fate'' to preside over the boatswain''s supposedly predetermined hanging. Yet to insist that the boatswain will hang personally benefits Gonzalo: it vents his frustration at the boatswain''s churlishness and assures him that the ship will survive the storm (a hanging, after all, can only occur on dry land). The superhuman force of Fate becomes shorthand for Gonzalo''s (very human) agenda. 

Justifying or aggrandizing one''s own desires by filtering them through Fate or Destiny becomes one of Prospero''s go-to tactics, as we''ll see later on.

Some critics think this is a mistake and that Alonso means "ply the men." (''Play'' and ''ply'' were pronounced similarly in Shakespeare''s time, which could account for the error). 

If we intend to read this line as is, we can understand Alonso to mean ''play'' in the sense of ''to act''. He calls upon the ship''s crew to act like men (i.e. to be strong and brave) in the face of the storm.

text:

Neither here nor there, as far as practical purposes go. 

Antonio''s insistence that he and his fellow passengers are less afraid than the boatswain to die is intended to affirm their superiority and courage. In fact, his comment has the reverse effect. The boatswain had never mentioned fear or courage, and Antonio''s comment betrays his own preoccupation. I''m reminded of the famous line in another of Shakespeare''s plays, "the lady doth protest too much, methinks..." 

'
quote: 'We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.

text:

A bombard is a leather liquor jug. 

Note the differences between Caliban''s and Trinculo''s figurative lexicons. Caliban, as we saw in his opening speech, draws his figures from the natural world. The three comparisons he draws above are to fire, apes and hedgehogs. Trinculo, by contrast, compares a cloud to a dirty liquor jug. These may seem like small points but they can be of great use. The breadth and dexterity of a character''s metaphorical range provides information about his or her mental geography that is sometimes never stated outright. We are reminded by Caliban''s speech that he is not only knowledgeable about the natural world but that he has an organic claim to the island, being attached to it by his intimate understanding of "all the qualities o'' th'' isle / the fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile." Even before Stephano arrives with his supply of sack, we can guess that Trinculo spends much of his time drinking and will probably be one of the play''s less serious characters.

Miranda, perhaps unwittingly, subverts her proclamations of devotion by admitting that, even if she tried to imagine another lover, she would not be able to. Ferdinand is the only man for her both because she loves him and because she has never met any other. While this second reason seems to be only inadvertently admitted by Miranda, it is nevertheless present in the scene and should be considered. There is something insincere about Ferdinand and Miranda''s love. We are not certain to what extent it is under Prospero''s command. We don''t see him cast a love spell directly but he does express approval at his daughter''s relationship with the prince and suggests that the young lovers are influenced by Ariel. Recall Act II scene i :

PROSPERO [Aside] It goes on, I see, As my soul prompts it. Spirit, fine spirit! I''ll free thee Within two days for this.

quote: 'I would not wish  /  Any companion in the world but you,  /  Nor can imagination form a shape,  /  Besides yourself, to like of.

text:
'

''To blow'' here means ''to dirty.''

The flesh-fly here described is a fly of the order Sarcophagidae that is parasitic in its larval stage when it is commonly known as a ''maggot.''

Ironic (and almost certainly intentional on Shakespeare''s part) that Ferdinand should speak of parasites. He plays host to one even as he scorns them. Prospero has sown the seeds (or laid the maggots) of the marriage plot in Ferdinand and watches it unfold as Ferdinand slaves away. 

'

Compare this exchange to the later one between Ariel and Prospero, provoked by the same question. 

What do the two exchanges reveal about the respective relationships. What is Miranda to Ferdinand that he responds this way? What is Ariel to Prospero?

I  /  Beyond all limit of what else i'' the world  /  Do love, prize, honour you.  /

''Delicate'' means ''skillful'' or ''ingenious.'' 

This exchange is disconcerting. It appears out of nowhere and is, to different extents, trivialized by both parties. Ariel''s question comes at the conclusion of a playful, light-hearted song with which it shares nothing but an end rhyme. Prospero''s response is dismissive. Is he so untroubled by Ariel''s question that he can''t even be bothered to consider it? Or is he so confused by the question that he doesn''t know how to answer it, returning to his string of commands as a kind of defense?

quote: 'Argier.

text:

Some critics contend that the epilogue is not intended to be spoken by Prospero at all but is in fact Shakespeare''s personal allegory. The Tempest was the last play that Shakespeare wrote on his own (he did participate in several collaborations after it) and by the time it was performed, he had moved from London back to Stratford-on-Avon. This epilogue, some think, is delivered by a Prospero that has stepped out of character and is speaking as the playwright, summarizing his theatrical career, apologizing for his retirement to Stratford and asking his audience to set him free. 

'

Frank Kermode notes that, if indeed the epilogue is meant to be Shakespeare''s direct address to the audience, it is most likely the playwright''s apology to James I for using magic.

text:

Prospero distances himself from Sycorax by criticizing her and her "sorceries terrible." Yet he himself is a practitioner of magic - how does he differ from the witch? 

Sycorax''s magic lacks refinement. She is associated with the rough, with the physical, with the vulgar: she is pregnant out of wedlock, she gives birth to ''savage'' Caliban, her commands are "earthy", and she is unable to govern the evanescent Ariel, whose powers are "too delicate" for her and whom she crudely shoves into a pine tree.

Prospero employs the verb for animal birth as an insult to Sycorax, denying her human standing. 

'
quote: 'litter

text:
'

Caliban is unique among the play''s characters in being native to the island. Despite the confusion surrounding his appearance, his status as an islander, rather than as an Italian expat, remains stable. The tension between that identity and his uncertain species (at least in the eyes of the other characters) is never resolved in the play. This difficulty of resolution has extended the tension beyond the original work, inspiring an enormous body of secondary literature in the years since the play first appeared. Much of this critical work has focussed on the relevance of English colonialism to the play, taking Caliban as a kind of screen upon which is reflected the impressions that the first English explorers formed during their encounters with the Native Americans as well as the general cultural psyche of the English people and its stock of stereotypes. Indeed, as I''ll note in later annotations, there are lines of the play that are lifted directly from the reports of English explorers and colonists and some of the characterizations of Caliban draw heavily upon images from popular culture.

Endowed with exquisitely fine powers of expression or execution; finely skillful.

'
quote: 'delicate

text:
'

Remember that Prospero used this very word to describe Ariel in Act I (I''ve linked to the scene below). Prospero used it to distinguish Ariel from Sycorax and Caliban, and to designate the quality by which Ariel was elevated above and superior to the others. Now that quality is being applied to Caliban. Shakespeare could have chosen to use a different word here - why did he deliberately choose to evoke Prospero''s earlier line? 

Partially for comic effect. As the clowns of the play, Trinculo and Stephano are responsible for parroting and parodying the affairs of the more serious characters. Yet these parodies often touch upon more serious issues themselves. By shedding a new, superficially comic light upon the other characters'' actions, Trinculo and Stephano''s scenes often awaken us to complexities inherent in the play''s events and in the other characters'' ideas. Here, Stephano''s line reverses the opposition between Ariel and Caliban that Prospero set up at play''s start, thereby calling into question a duality that, for Prospero, is set in stone. 

'
quote: 'delicate

text:
'

Bermuda. 

Shakespeare doesn''t give us an exact location for Prospero''s island. The fact that Alonso and co.''s ship is intercepted while en route from Northern Africa to Italy suggests that the island is somewhere in the Mediterranean. However, critics have used this reference to Bermuda to locate the island in the Atlantic, closer to North America. In the early 1600s when Shakespeare wrote the Tempest, the English had begun colonizing what they called the New World, establishing settlements in Virginia off whose coast Bermuda lies.

Though the geographical coordinates of Prospero''s island remain elusive, their very elusiveness achieves an effect that seems intentional on Shakespeare''s part and ultimately enriches our understanding of the play''s ideological setting. By existing in both the Old and the New Worlds, in association with North Africa as well as continental Europe as well as North America and the British culture colonizing it, the island serves as a point of intersection for the philosophies and beliefs of each of those places. The resulting conflicts fuel many of the more disturbing undertones of the play. Notions of what it means to be ''savage,'' for example, or concepts of ''proper'' social hierarchy. Shakespeare''s specific references to certain strains of thought will come up in later annotations. For now, keep in mind that his reference to the Bermuda islands is not accidental. Watch out for how the ideals and problems of colonialism are implicated in the play.

A potentially menacing position, contrary to what Prospero himself here claims. Prospero''s power grasps every facet of Miranda''s experience. He determines what she knows, what she sees, and whom she loves. One could see Miranda as a mere puppet in the web of Prospero''s plot. I saw a production of the Tempest where the set designer seemed to take this view. He or she constructed Prospero''s magic books as a giant pile of volumes centered around an open book the length and width of a twin-sized bed upon which Miranda slept, physically enfolded in her father''s powers. 

'
quote: 'thy schoolmaster,

text:
'

A difficult sentence that Frank Kermode unravels as follows:

"The fact of my retirement, in which I neglected worldly affairs and dedicated myself to secret studies of a kind beyond the understanding and esteem of the people, brought out a bad side of my brother''s nature. Consequently the great, indeed boundless, trust I placed in him gave rise to a disloyalty equally great on his part, just as it sometimes happens that a father distinguished for virtue has a vicious son."

'
quote: 'I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated   /  To closeness and the bettering of my mind   /  With that which, but by being so retired,   /  O''er-prized all popular rate, in my false brother   /  Awaked an evil nature; and my trust,   /  Like a good parent, did beget of him   /  A falsehood in its contrary as great   /  As my trust was; which had indeed no limit,   /  A confidence sans bound.

text:
'

Introduces the dualist philosophy to which Prospero subscribes. Dualism maintains that mind and matter are fundamentally separate entities and opposes them to each other in a hierarchy where mind reigns supreme. Matter and body are considered distinct and inferior and any preoccupations with them (such as  lust, hunger or greed for material goods) are considered base and impure and are despised by the loftier desires of the mind for knowledge and enlightenment. Prospero puts aside ''worldly'', material ends to devote himself to what he believes is a nobler pursuit, the enriching of his mind.  

'
quote: 'I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated   /  To closeness and the bettering of my mind

text:
'

Shakespeare was personally acquainted with several members of the Virginia Company whose ship was caught in a wild storm off the coast of Bermuda in 1609, two years before the Tempest was first performed. Among these colonizers was William Strachey, whose account of the storm, "True Repertory of the Wrack", was one of the sources for Shakespeare''s play. Some critics match Ariel''s description of his blazing self to this passage from Strachey''s account of the storm:

Onely upon the thursday night Sir George Summers being upon the watch, had an apparition of a little round light, like a faint Starre, trembling, and streaming along with a sparkeling blaze, halfe the height upon the Maine Mast, and shooting sometimes from Shroud to Shroud, tempting to settle as it were upon any of the foure Shrouds: and for three or foure houres together, or rather more, halfe the night it kept with us; running sometimes along the Maine-yard to the very end, and then returning. At which, Sir George Summers called divers about him, and shewed them the same, who observed it with much wonder, and carefulnesse: but upon a sodaine, towards the morning watch, they lost the sight of it, and knew not what way it made. 

'
quote: 'I boarded the king''s ship; now on the beak,   /  Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin,   /  I flamed amazement: sometime I''ld divide,   /  And burn in many places; on the topmast,   /  The yards and bowsprit, would I flame distinctly,   /  Then meet and join.

text:
'

Gonzalo''s speech echoes many of the New World colonizers'' accounts of deliverance through trial and tribulation (often literally a tempest at sea) to unexpected safety and fortune by the hand of divine providence. Like the writers of those accounts, Gonzalo assumes a moral order in nature (be that operating under the name of God or providence or whatever else) that ensures a happy ending. In Sylvester Jourdain''s A Discovery of the Bermudas, he describes the passage from hopeless desperation to unexpected bounty and renewal in terms that, while more explicitly religious than Gonzalo''s, outline the same rebirth into a purer, truer state that Gonzalo traces here. Both Jourdain and Gonzalo present the suffering caused by the storm as a necessary hardship that is in fact beneficial for it ultimately enables them to realize Bermuda''s riches and their comrades'' true selves. 

"All our men, being utterly spent, tired, and disabled for longer labor, were even resolved, without any hope of their lives, to shut up the hatches and to have committed themselves to the mercy of the sea (which is said to be merciless) or rather to the mercy of their mighty God and redeemer...when it pleased God out of His most gracious and merciful providence, so to direct and guide our ship (being left to the mercy of the sea) for her most advantage...But our delivery was not more strange in falling so opportunely and happily upon the land...For the islands of the Bermudas, as every man knoweth that hath heard or read of them, were never inhabited by any Christian or heathen people, but ever esteemed and reputed a most prodigious and enchanted place affording nothing but gusts, storms and foul weather...Yet did we find there the air so temperate and the country so abundantly fruitful of all fit necessaries for the sustenation and preservation of man''s life...Wherefore my opinion sincerely of this island is that whereas it hath been and is fully accounted the most dangerous, unfortunate, and most forlorn place of the world, it is in truth the richest, healthfulest, and pleasing land...and merely natural, as ever man set foot upon.

'
quote: 'O, rejoice  /  Beyond a common joy, and set it down  /  With gold on lasting pillars: In one voyage  /  Did Claribel her husband find at Tunis,  /  And Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife  /  Where he himself was lost, Prospero his dukedom  /  In a poor isle and all of us ourselves  /  When no man was his own.  /

text:
'

A rhetorical question implying that Prospero (the Duke of Milan) was exiled from Milan for a reason: so that his issue (descendants) would become kings of Naples by Miranda''s marriage into royalty. 

Gonzalo assumes a moral order underlying the events of the world, a view shared by many of Shakespeare''s contemporaries (more on this in the next annotation). 

It''s interesting to note that the belief in such providential order necessarily delegitimizes all the seemingly negative experiences in the play: Prospero''s exile, the terrifying storm, Alonso''s grief, Ferdinand''s struggles, etc. The suffering those experiences inflicted was only an illusion, was in fact a necessary step in the path to joy. This is a more disturbing than it may initially seem. The characters appear happy in this last scene but, if we subscribe to Gonzalo''s view of the moral order, how are we to take Gonzalo''s assertion that they have "found themselves"? Doesn''t this discovery seem more like a surrender? If they are perfected, it is a perfection that resolves them to helplessness. Providence has robbed them of all independence and to acknowledge its power is to admit that they have not known even the most intimate facets of their own experience, have not known even how to recognize true grief.

We see a parallel figure used to describe Miranda''s virginity, which Prospero describes as a knot in scene IV (I''ve linked to the line below). What role does Miranda''s virginity play in relation to this spell and to Prospero''s plot as a whole? In some sense, she is the knot that holds his whole scheme in place. Miranda''s marriageability (which meant virginity, by the standards of the day) ensures her engagement to Ferdinand, thereby ensuring Prospero''s own redemption in the eyes of Alonso and reinstatement in Milan.

Modern critics have tended to agree, though not, of course, literally. Over the past fifty years or so, Prospero has often been considered the embodiment of patriarchical, racist and colonialist oppression. He has been described as deceitful, manipulative and heartless. All of these accusations are, as we''ve seen, fully backed up by the play itself. 

Of course, other critics weigh in on the complete opposite side of the spectrum. From their perspective, Prospero embodies a humanist ideal and/or champions the power of human art. Frank Kermode''s criticism supplies a full endorsement of Prospero''s character. Kermode wrote, "Prospero is...the representative of Art...As a mage he controls nature; as a prince he conquers the passions which had excluded him from his kingdom and overthrown law; as a scholar he reapirs his loss of Eden; as a man he learns to temper his passions, an achievement essential to success in any of the other activities" (from Kermode''s introduction to the Arden edition of the play).

Samuel Coleridge delighted in Stephano, considering him the perfect example of Shakespeare''s virtuosity. Here''s an excerpt from Coleridge''s essay on the play: 

See the good-humoured way in which he describes Stephano passing from the most licentious freedom to absolute despotism over Trinculo and Caliban. The truth is, Shak-speare''s characters are all genera intensely individualized; the results of meditation, of which observation supplied the drapery and the colours necessary to combine them with each other. He had virtually surveyed all the great component powers and impulses of human nature,—had seen that their different combinations and subordinations were in fact the individualizers of men, and showed how their harmony was produced by reciprocal disproportions of excess or deficiency. The language in which these truths are expressed was not drawn from any set fashion, but from the profoundest depths of his moral being, and is therefore for all ages.

 

'
quote: 'Monster, lay-to your fingers: help to bear this  /  away where my hogshead of wine is, or I''ll turn you  /  out of my kingdom: go to, carry this.  /

text:
'

''Flote'' means ''flood''. The Mediterranean flote is the Mediterranean sea. 

Though it''s possible to assume that Prospero''s island must also be somewhere in the Mediterranean, it''s not possible to be certain. Nor is it necessary. As Samuel Coleridge wrote in his essay on The Tempest: 

The Tempest is a specimen of the purely romantic drama, in which the interest is not historical, or depen-dent upon fidelity of portraiture, or the natural connexion of events,—but is a birth of the imagination, and rests only on the coaptation and union of the elements granted to, or assumed by, the poet. It is a species of drama which owes no allegiance to time or space, and in which, therefore, errors of chronology and geography—no mortal sins in any species—are venial faults, and count for nothing. It addresses itself entirely to the imaginative faculty; and although the illusion may be assisted by the effect on the senses of the complicated scenery and decorations of modem times, yet this sort of assistance is dangerous. For the principal and only genuine excitement ought to come from within,—from the moved and sympathetic imagination; whereas, where so much is addressed to the mere external senses of seeing and hearing, the spiritual vision is apt to languish, and the attraction from without will withdraw the mind from the proper and only legitimate interest which is intended to spring from within.

What are the responsibilities of the artist? These questions are pertinent ones to ask of Prospero whether he is construed to be a magician or whether, as some argue, he is the playwright himself.

text:

While the word ''savage'' may seem purely negative, that''s not actually the case. Prospero''s denigration of Caliban plays against the other half of the antithesis from which the English conception of savagery was formed in Shakespeare''s day. It all comes back to the conflicting attitudes towards the natural world, for the savage was, from the English perspective, representative of natural man untempered by civilization. Prospero, a believer in the superiority of human art and its ability to conquer and better nature, despises Caliban. Yet the opposing strain of thought would hold that Caliban, as the representative of natural man in the play, is in fact a far better man than Prospero, being a pure product of the natural world. (This view of course assumes that the natural world is inherently good.) Montaigne was a great proponent of this second view. We know Shakespeare had Montaigne in mind as he wrote The Tempest because of the nearly perfect transcription of Montaigne''s essay that appears in Gonzalo''s speech. (I''ve linked to the speech below).  

Here''s Montaigne on the superiority of the ''savage'' to the civilized man:

They are even savage, as we call those fruits wilde, which nature of her selfe...hath produced: whereas indeed...those which our selves have altered by our artificiall devices, and diverted from their common order, we should rather terme savage. In those are the true and most profitable vertues, and naturall properties most lively and vigorous, which in these we have bastardized, applying them to the pleasure of our courrupted taste. And if notwithstanding, in divers fruits of those countries that were never tilled, we shall finde, that in repsect of ours they are most excellent, and as delicate unto our taste; there is no reason, art should gaine the point of honour of our great and puissant mother Nature.

'

His solitary delight reinforces his superiority as the only genuinely kind-hearted member of the king''s party.

Their lust for the crown is a lust for the title, the grandeur and the pomp of royalty and cares nothing for the actual obligations of the king to his civilian subjects. They seem content to steal the name of king from Alonso without any means of returning to the actual kingdom.

quote: 'CALIBAN   /  Hast thou not dropp''d from heaven?  /    /  STEPHANO   /  Out o'' the moon, I do assure thee:

Compare this speech to Gonzalo''s speech at play''s end. Their strong similarity attests to the constancy of Gonzalo''s character throughout the play. And why is he alone constant? Perhaps it is because, of all the members of the king''s party, Gonzalo is most willing to accept the existence of the unseen and the irrational. He does not rely solely upon the evidence delivered by his senses. He alone among the king''s party refuses to accept Ferdinand''s death; he does not despair; and, in the end, it is he alone who turns out to be correct in his assumptions. 

'
quote: 'Beseech you, sir, be merry; you have cause,  /  So have we all, of joy; for our escape  /  Is much beyond our loss.

text:

Prospero claims that Caliban''s mind is incapable of learning morality, of taking the "print of goodness," because it has no natural tendency towards good but is instead "capable of all ill." 

Floating behind Prospero''s claim is the schematic understanding of moral beings that was popular in Shakespeare''s day. In it, the natural man that Caliban typifies serves as the link on a descending scale between civilized man and the wholly wild and unmoral world. 

 

'
quote: 'Which any print of goodness wilt not take,   /  Being capable of all ill!

text:

As Frank Kermode notes in his essay on Caliban, it''s worthwhile to think about Aristotle''s definition of slavery in thinking of Prospero''s own justifications for enslaving Calbian. In the list of characters at play''s start, Caliban is described as a deformed slave.  In Politics, Aristotle writes:

"Men...who are as much inferior to others as the body is to the soul...are slaves by nature, and it is advantageous for them always to be under government."

"To find our governor we should...examine into a man who is most perfectly formed in soul and body...for in the depraved and vicious the body seems to rule rather than the soul, on account of their being corrupt and contrary to nature."

text:
'

Prospero''s condemnation has roots that trace back to the Medieval orders of nobility and the strict class hierarchy that was its legacy in Shakespeare''s day. It was long thought that noble birth (that is to say, being a blood relative to an aristocratic line of descent) was integral to goodness. The possibility for learning was not completely denied but it was thought that a child of the nobility was more likely to learn morality and to put it to good use than a child of the lower classes would be, even if both children were given identical educations. In fact, it was argued that education could actually be harmful to those who were not born into a class naturally predisposed to its reception. While those of low or base birth could learn, the lessons would only foster wicked, immoral tendencies in them and would not impart the building blocks of goodness and morality as they had in the noble children. As the member of a "vile race" Caliban lacks the noble predisposition to goodness and though he could learn from Prospero, he could not alter the fundamental flaw of his character, inherited by birth, "which good natures could not abide to be with." 

'
quote: 'But thy vile race,   /  Though thou didst learn, had that in''t which   /  good natures   /  Could not abide to be with;

text:
'

Miranda epitomizes the feminine ideal whereby women are thought to lack man''s rational intelligence and to be, by virtue of this lack, naturally and simply good.

As Samuel Coleridge writes of this speech:

In the very first speech of Miranda the simplicity and tenderness of her character are at once laid open;— it would have been lost in direct contact with the agitation of the first scene...in Shakspeare all the elements of womanhood are holy, and there is the sweet, yet dignified feeling of all that continuates society, as sense of ancestry and of sex, with a purity unassailable by sophistry, because it rests not in the analytic processes, but in that same equipoise of the faculties, during which the feelings are representative of all past experience,—not of the individual only, but of all those by whom she has been educated, and their predecessors even up to the first mother that lived. Shakspeare saw that the want of prominence, which Pope notices for sarcasm, was the blessed beauty of the woman''s character, and knew that it arose not from any deficiency, but from the more exquisite harmony of all the parts of the moral being constituting one living total of head and heart. He has drawn it, indeed, in all its distinctive energies of faith, patience, constancy, fortitude,—shown in all of them as following the heart, which gives its results by a nice tact and happy intuition, without the intervention of the discursive faculty, sees all things in and by the light of the affections, and errs, if it ever err, in the exaggerations of love alone. 

 

'
quote: 'O, I have suffered   /  With those that I saw suffer:

text:
'

I saw a production of The Tempest in which Prospero not only explains the past to Miranda verbally but spells the key words out on the ground for Miranda to copy and learn. He traces ''duke,'' ''prince,'' ''heir,'' etc., and waits for her to spell them out herself before continuing his speech. Miranda''s realization of her power as the duke''s daughter is thus embedded in her realization of the written words that signify that power. The director''s choice to add a spelling lesson to this scene expresses the equation between literacy and power that is integral to the play''s understanding of education, particularly in regards to Caliban. No one in the play is more sensitive to the power of the written word than Caliban. In the scene I''ve linked to below, Caliban''s anxiety stems from that awareness. 

'
quote: 'Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since,   /  Thy father was the Duke of Milan and   /  A prince of power.

text:
'

Caliban''s insistence on the importance of destroying Prospero''s books before his body locates Prospero''s powers outside his corporeal form, a disconnect Prospero himself attests to both implicitly, by privileging mind over body, and explicitly when he surrenders his powers at play''s end by drowning the very books that Caliban here seeks to seize. 

 

 

'
quote: 'Remember  /  First to possess his books; for without them  /  He''s but a sot, as I am, nor hath not  /  One spirit to command: they all do hate him  /  As rootedly as I. Burn but his books.  /

text:
'

It''s worth reading Stephen Greenblatt''s excellent essay "Learning to Curse," which discusses the anxiety surrounding European books in the historical interactions between colonists and Native Americans. 

'
quote: 'Having first seized his books,

text:
'

As Stephen Greenblatt writes in his essay, "Learning to Curse," that takes its title from these lines:

"Caliban''s retort might be taken as self-indictment: even with the gift of language, his nature is so debased that he can only learn to curse. But the lines refuse to mean this; what we experience instead is a sense of their devestating justness. Ugly, rude, savage, Caliban nevertheless achieves for an instant an absolute if intolerably bitter moral victory" (25, "Learning to Curse," Learning to Curse: Essays in Early Modern Culture). 

'
quote: 'You taught me language; and my profit on''t   /  Is, I know how to curse.

text:
'

After Caliban''s startling and heart-wrenching accusation, we, as readers and viewers, expect a better reply than this. Prospero either does not register the grave truth of Caliban''s words or else he refuses to acknowledge them. Caliban''s words cut straight through to the dark core of the play but the gash is immediately healed by Prospero, who seems entirely unmoved. 

It''s worth keeping track of Prospero''s behavior in response to other characters'' expressions of emotion throughout the play. He often seems strangely unruffled, as in the last scene where his reply to Miranda''s famous exclamation is curiously flat. I''ve linked to the scene below. 

'
quote: 'PROSPERO   /  Hag-seed, hence!

text:
'

Well, yes, but is that all Prospero has to say? His terse reply feels out of place amidst the other characters'' ecstasies. Why so muted?

Perhaps, as his closing speech would indicate, he is already resigned to living out the rest of his life in quiet attendance of death. Perhaps he gave up his spirit with his power. Perhaps he has always been emotionally distanced, and developed his powers in part because of it, being more able to control the feelings of others than to participate in feeling himself. 

'
quote: '''Tis new to thee.  /

text:
'

Despite all the other characters'' expressions of disgust at his savagery, fishiness, strangeness, darkness, deformity, etc., Caliban''s command of language and metaphor is more beautiful than any of the lettered and learned others. Even his curses are lyrical and exercise a flexibility and range of metaphor unmatched by the speech of any other character. 

Henry James considered Caliban to be the highest expression of Shakespeare''s stylistic genius. In his introduction to the play he writes:

"Ariel and Caliban, and the island-airs and island-scents, and all the rest of the charm and magic and the ineffable delicacy (a delicacy positively at its highest in the conception and execution of Caliban) are the style handed over to its last disciplined passion of curiosity; a curiosity which flowers, at this pitch, into the freshness of each of the characters." 

Interestingly, the poet W. H. Auden chose to write Caliban''s speech in Henry James'' own style in his great poem "The Sea and the Mirror", inspired by the play. 

'
quote: 'CALIBAN   /  Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises,  /  Sounds and sweet airs, that give delight and hurt not.  /  Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments  /  Will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices  /  That, if I then had waked after long sleep,  /  Will make me sleep again: and then, in dreaming,  /  The clouds methought would open and show riches  /  Ready to drop upon me that, when I waked,  /  I cried to dream again.  /

 Freudian thinkers in the 20th century have interpreted Ariel and Caliban to be the superego and id, respectively, of Prospero''s psyche.

Michael Tippet''s 1971 opera, The Knot Garden, brings the play-within-a-play structure into the analyst''s office. Its Prospero (called Mangus) is a psychoanalyst who has his patients stage scenes from The Tempest during analysis. You can read more about the opera here:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Knot_Garden

quote: 'strangely.  /

text:
'

That''s us he means: the audience. 

What is the effect of Prospero''s turning to speak to the audience now, at play''s end? Does it alter what has preceded it? Does it alter our conception of Prospero? 

'
quote: 'you,  /

text:
'

Why does Shakespeare break from blank verse to write in rhymed couplets here?

If we believe that the "charms" Prospero speaks of here are those of the writer and artist, then the choice seems even stranger. Why would Prospero call more attention to his art (for the rhyme shatters any illusion that he is speaking naturally) at the moment that he is professing to abandon it? 

'
quote: 'Let me not,  /  Since I have my dukedom got  /

text:
'

Why is The Tempest titled as it is? Is it strange that the play should be named for an event that occupies only one scene?

quote: 'CALIBAN, STEPHANO, and TRINCULO

text:
'

It''s unclear whether this word was intended to be ''wife'' or ''wise'' in the original manuscripts, but it seems more likely that it was the latter. The change of the single letter has enormous consequences. As it appears here, the line reflects Ferdinand''s joy at having both a father(-in-law) and a wife and divides equally between Prospero and Miranda. In the other version, Miranda is excluded from Ferdinand''s vision of paradise, leaving room only for Prospero and his dazzling wisdom that blots out his daughter completely. 

'
quote: 'wife  /

text:
'

Why this sudden recourse to religion?

'
quote: 'And my ending is despair,  /  Unless I be relieved by prayer,  /

text:
'

The audience''s spell, that is, our power as viewers.
